"large" size cups, then had to grin and bear it when I actually had to pull out my debit card and write "$26.15" in the total column.* The $6 "small" size was, quite literally, the equivalent to a shot. After a brief yet controlled hyperventilation, I brought the cocoa back to my team mates.  The verdict? Perhaps we should have gone for the $6 dollar "shots", because these cocoas are rich. In fact, I would not even call them cocoas. I would call them thick chocolate syrups. The taste? Absolutely divine. There is no doubt about that. However, we all left overwhelmed and barely able to finish what I bought. We actually had to go to a store down the street to buy some water to cleanse our palates. We could feel the chocolate coursing through our veins.  A fine, rich, and pure product, worth five stars, but, in the future, I'll stick to buying a box of the cocoa to bring home and making it my way on my own time.  * - As my friend and team mate Carrissa stated, "You know you are in trouble when you are pulling out a debit card to pay for hot cocoa. That's just WRONG."

Stumbled upon this little jewel of a place, discretely tucked away on Broome St in SoHo. Imagine walking into a jeweled Faberge egg with lots of chocolate!  An adult's luxe version of Charlie and the chocolate factory! Delicious and hugely varied hot chocolate bar, served in beautiful antique tea cups! What a delicious treat for the senses.

The signature Blue and Brown Ganache are amazing. Mariebelle is on the very top of my chocolate list along with Christopher Norman and La Maison du Chocolat. Every piece is flawless with a perfect balance between the exotic flavors and cacao darkness. I love the playful and artistic design, I love the delicate truffle shell, I love everything about these delicacies.  Unfortunately the only MarieBelle store is in New York. Sucks for us who don't live there. If you want to your hands on chocolate but don't want to pay shipping on top of the already hefty price tag, try your local Neiman Marcus or Saks Fifth Avenue stores.

The spicy hot-chocolate was more like the tastiest bowl of chocolate soup than a beverage.  I seriously didn't take a single sip, but savored every last drop with a spoon.  Heaven in a little mug!  Yes, that little mug that they called a medium was $8, but really, what good dessert in the City doesn't cost at least $8?  The gentleman I was with ordered the dark chocolate - which wasn't as thick as the spicy, but was just as smooth and rich.    Indeed, his passion for chocolate is like nothing I have ever seen - yet he found his match at MarieBelle!    If the hot chocolate isn't reason enough for you to venture to MarieBelle - and believe me, it's reason enough - the atmosphere and friendly service might also persuade you.  We came in right as they were closing, but they let us order and "dine-in."  Even though they locked the doors and were cleaning up, they didn't rush us for a moment.  Plus, the decor was fun and sophisticated with chandeliers, mirrors, and art.  The one bad thing about life after MarieBelle is the realization that the Swiss-miss "hot chocolate" that I am accustomed to drinking during the cold winter months is nothing more than hot, sugar water.  And that apparently, I had never really had a cup of hot chocolate before last night!

I bought my wife a 25 piece ganache box for her birthday from the Merriebell stand in Grand Central station two weeks ago.  I have been to their Soho shop a few times and also have been in the Cocao Market in Greenpoint, where I live, multiple times. I always like to support my local small businesses. Well aware of the cost of the their chocolate, i paid about $80 for the box along with a chocolate sausage.  Sadly, the chocolate pieces tasted stale.  Only after opening the box and sampling a piece with my wife did I also realize  that the date was expired. I returned the box of chocolates to the Greenpoint store only to be told by the manager that he could not help me, implying that i  tampered with the chocolate.  I was not demanding a refund, but I wanted them to acknowledge the poor quality of their product and expecting at least to offer me a new box.  Extremely disappointed with their customer service and outright mad with the manager acquisition, I walked out the store leaving the box behind me without ever intending to  purchase or recommend their products again.

This place  is so adorable. They had french music playing and I got a cup of the best hot chocolate I've ever had. I bought the cheapest chocolate bar, which was $4 and was so tiny, but it was so worth it. They're shopping bags are really nice too. There is a small coffee bar in the back but it was totally packed, couldn't get near it. will definitely go back here!

If you love chocolate you'll love this place. I'm not going to get into the details . I heard once death is in the details so I'll keep it simple, 5 stars. Waiter's are very friendly knowledge and polite . High quality chocolate I recommend Aztec hot chocolate.

Cacao Bar.  Their hot chocolate is one of the most delicious things I've ever had to drink; by far the best hot chocolate I've ever had.  I will be making a special trip to SoHo next time I'm in town just for their Cacao Bar.

I spent my early years in Bombay, where a small Cadbury's Five Star bar was a treat to behold, until my dad got me some Godiva from Europe, at the ripe old age (by chocolate sampling standards anyway) of 12.  So I was amazed at how India has changed, when I got some MarieBelle for some friends in India, only to discover that they were actually familiar with the brand!  I have loaded up on MarieBelle's again as I visit India later this week.  I realize there might be more fancy brands of chocolate, but MarieBelle represents a quantum leap from the candy that I grew up with or even indulge in today.  The flavors are all interesting and the packaging is absolutely fitting for a gift item.

Temptations.temptation!! thank God,bikini season is over so I can indulge as much as I want and cover everything under the layers of clothing!!  Love Mariebelle-such a cute, welcoming and unique little place in Soho. Looks like and oversized doll house. Mirrors eveyrwhere, regal indigo colors and divine chocolate scattered on the shelves seducing me with their forms and smell!! I feel like Im Alice in Wonderland.  Next room has cute little tables and sparkling chandeliers. try mint chololate balls, macaroons and of course infamous hot chocolate.  Staff is amazing but the only problem is their shortstaffed so the service is very slow. everything is made from scratch so the hot choclate lets say, takes some time to get. well, good things come to those who wait but its NYC where the seconds count a minutes. Make sure you are not in a rush when you come here
OBSESSED with these chocolates! Really cute presentation. The staff were so incredibly helpful. Definitely recommend a trip to anyone. It is pricey but worth it.

Need a break from shopping? Marie Belle was a perfect place to escape the cold and grab a cup of tea and some delicious chocolately sweets.  I very much enjoyed my black lychee tea and dark chocolate florentine cookie. The tea salon is behind the chocolate shop at the front. I couldn't resist the chocolate sample on the way out but OMG $5 for one little piece of chocolate. That's crazy talk. I'm convinced they put crack in it.
Pretentious. Their workers are too good for their customers. With that attitude, I much rather walk out empty-handed. Pooper, it was such a darling little place too.

What a wonderful date spot! Situated in the back area of the Mariebelle Fine Chocolate store is a cozy cafe for intimate conversation with a friend or loved one. The staff was pleasant and helpful when my husband and I were attempting to choose what we would eat and drink. However, the waiter failed to inform us that the kitchen was closed when we were ready to order our dessert.    So, here are the pluses and wishes: Pluses: So many choices for hot chocolate! Milk, Dark, White...have your pick!  I enjoyed the dark hot chocolate, but beware...a small cup size is sufficient.  The milk hot chocolate with hazelnut was sumptuous as well! The food was also good. We had sandwiches (ham & cheese and turkey).  Both went well with the hot chocolate.  Wishes: I wish I could give a review of their desserts! However, the place closes at 8pm (on a FRIDAY!) so at 7:30pm, there was clearly a push to get us out the door.    Next time, I have to come back sooner and enjoy everything this place has to offer!

I am on a search for the best chocolates ever. Marie Belle is up there in terms of being delish but I know there are better chocolates in existence and I am determined to find them. I did finally get to go to the store on a recent NYC trip and it's very cute. As other's have said, the customer service is a bit disappointing. What's up with that?  Anyway, I do like the chocolates (despite the exorbitant cost) and the beautiful little pictures on them. YUM.

To be read entirely in a French Accent:  Ah, Mariebelle [drag of cigarette], a truly delicious French experience in ze heart of le Soho.  [drag]. It reminds me of my days back in Paris, when I would drink ze rich, French hot chocolate in ze cafes while eating mon croissants.  Ah, ze variety, ze flavours, ze...je ne sais quoi!  Mais, c'est magnifique!  [drag].  Zees will blow the lid off zat german or belgian merde zey like to pass off as chocolate.  [drag].  Plus, ze bags are so pretty and ze atmosphere so friendly, you will never want to leave!  [drag].  Oui, zees is not to be missed when you are shopping in le Soho.  Ah, mon dieu.  I need anozer cigarette.

If I was an eight year old girl, I would have died and gone to heaven.  The Mariebelle cafe is as sweet as the chocolate. The huge crystal chandelier is a nice touch to the antique-looking furniture and adorable dishes and cups.  The hot chocolate is liquid chocolate. A little too rich for my taste, but you're talking to a salty-carb girl. The lighter iced chocolate was perfect-- light, frothy, and delicious. I could see the service having an attitude, but our waitress was nice enough.  Oh, the eight year old in me was thrilled. The 22 year old, not so much. The perfect date for a pedophile.

Fine, artsy, bohemian chocolates at their best.  When in Soho, esp. during the cold months of autumn and winter, I often make a visit for the EXTRA THICK, velvety hot chocolate.  It's a bit pricey for a tiny cup of hot choco ($4.50), but it's well worth the bucks.  The cafe in the back is very cute and cozy - a great place to rest your poor feet after all that shopping!
Simply put, pretty!!  From the chocolate to the decor... but there are better chocolatiers in the city, and for less money!  One plus is that you can rent the Cacao Bar for private events.

This is one of the most poorly-run establishments I have ever encountered. The staff is crass, rude, and unresponsive to customers' needs. The chocolate might be worth the lofty price of $4/per piece if the ambiance was reflective of such exorbitant prices. The chocolate "connoisseurs" are far from that. They are unable to answer simple questions about the chocolate and proceed to treat everyone like they belong in the servants' quarters at Downton Abbey.

Where else can you find such rich drinking chocolate?  Europe, that's where.  So I'd say Mariebelle is doing a damn fine job, considering their New York location is quite clearly not in Europe.  Order it milk-based or water-based, however you like it.  The little cafe also serves light appetizers and sandwiches to enjoy along with your cocoa, as well as non-alcoholic, slightly-alcoholic, and highly-alcoholic drinks.  Before the cafe area are the chocolates.  They're wonderful, they are, and look very pretty too.  Mariebelle easily offers the most colorful and decorated ganache I've seen yet.  And they taste superb.  A bit of let-down comes with their chocolate bars, though.  I was looking forward to something good, but ended up getting something dry and...not as good.  All the same, Mariebelle is Tres Magnifique!

Stumbled upon this place as we were seeking a way to warm up over some dessert and coffee.  What better place to have hot chocolate in Soho!  Very impressed with the store's branding and decor - very adorable.  The cocoa salon was tucked away in the back of the store with limited seating.  I had a small white chocolate and vanilla in a darling cup, a tad larger than an espresso cup and the hubby had a the dark mocha in a medium cup.  Very rich and flavorful chocolate and you will need extra water.  Good thing dark chocolate is good for you and he didn't regret the amount once consumed.   Next time, a small would be adequate for a taste and experience this of fine cup of hot cocoa.  A must try in the area!

The hot and iced chocolate both get five stars, though you gotta be careful with their hot chocolate.  It's almost too good to drink.  The Cacao Bar is a very cute spot, but make sure you're at leisure.  The servers are very nice but have managed to forget something from my order every time I've been.  They do serve sandwiches and savory nibbles, but I would go somewhere else for that.  I tried the leek and goat cheese crepe once and the portion was ridiculously small for $11.  My sister's gruyere and turkey sandwich, $8, was huge in comparison.  As far as sweets go, the alfajors are curiously lemony, while the almond flavor in the macarons is a bit too heavy.  Also, they have tiny European-sized water glasses, but the staff rarely comes around to refill them.  I would recommend the Cacao Bar as a great place to get warm after shopping with ladies on a cold winter's day, or to grab a hot chocolate to go, but not for eating. The shop itself is beautiful and a great place to buy chocolate gifts.  I have a canister of their hot chocolate but sadly I've never been able to make it taste as good at home.

This is dainty debutantey chocolate. Beautiful painted pieces that you must consume in no less than 3 ladylike bites. Don't forget to dab the corners of you mouth with your kerchief between each taste.  Hmm... If only they served the Aztec hot chocolate at my Cotillion, maybe I wouldn't have dropped out...
The best hot chocolate EVER!!!! So thick and smooth. The best thing on a cold snowy day in Soho!

Quintessentially New York. Hidden in Soho this place is a treasure. Not only does it have amazing chocolate - but the cocoa bar in the back is fabulous.  I thought maybe i needed a secret password to get in..but that was not the case. The seating is limited and quite close together - so be prepared for someone to eavesdrop on your convo. Regardless, its a must go place.

Travel back in time to late 19th century Paris ... but instead of absinthe, you're drinking hot chocolate.  And instead of Paris, you are in New York City.  And its 2008.  We came across the MarieBelle Cacao Bar and Tea Salon yesterday and I'm not exaggerating about the main theme of my dreams last night: MarieBelle hot chocolate.  It is addicting ... unbelievably chocolatey and drinkable.  We might even be talking about a chocolate intervention.  And the salon itself, decor, atmosphere, is fantastic.  Silent movies play on the wall, there are chipped mirrors, quaint furniture, even drippy chandeliers.  Stop in and try one of four delicous hot chocolates (aztec, dark, mocha, spicy) to quench your new addiction.

The best part of going to MarieBelle is sitting in the cafe in the back and sampling European hot chocolate or fondue... with its Parisian feel and its simple (although expanding) menu is a must visit if you are in SoHo.  It is a little out of the ways so you might not have a long wait...  Yes the chocolate is excellent, as well as the loose tea.

With the chandeliers, gilt furniture, and versailles-inspired wallpaper the back room looks like they would serve up mini sandwiches and tea. The cup of coca I ordered was mini - but it was so full of cocoa and spice that I could barely finish my shot of world-altering goodness.

They refuse to accept a still-live gilt, without notifying anyone (including probably gilt). I walked from 34th and 5th to 14th and 8th, 39 degree weather.  She offered $20 for $20 I spent. Isn't that the same as if I just walked in?  You lure people in, using Gilt as your sales and marketing tool, and once you're done using them, you bait and switch people, as if it weren't a trek for some people to take time out of their day to come.  You're disrespectful to patrons and to Gilt.

About 5 minute walk from High Line and Chelsea's Market.  Small menu and they have speciality matcha drinks that you can't find elsewhere. Ordered an iced golden latte which is matcha with ginger and turmeric - $6. Different milk options which cost extra. Service was quick. The ginger taste really came through! It was refreshing and cleansing. However, it hindered the matcha taste and the matcha was very watered down. The drink was mostly ginger and spices with a hint of matcha. Enjoyed the matcha speciality options but the execution of the matcha could have been better.

The matcha was really good. I got coconut matcha . It was water based and not milk based, so it was like a refresher, which I liked. The ambiance is nice but it was just really hot and sticky inside with flies, kinda took away from the decadance. Mediterranean toast was kinda heavy, I got that since they were out of avocado

I hope this review spares other people the trip to MatchaBar. The iced drinks are 80% ice, second thought maybe 85%. More importantly, the matcha is extremely watered down as other reviewers have said. The 2 stars are because the staff were friendly.

As others have commented, this latest bastion of MatchaBar is in an absolutely adorable neighborhood. Just off the L, A, C, and E, picture millennials walking little dogs past bike racks and juice bars, and you get the picture. Gentrified beyond belief, but dang if it isn't endearing.  My first observation is "Ok, so we're going with the artsy wood look." You know the type - wood paneling, a lot of greenery, some coloring books - the kind of hip Starbucks could have been if it were able to keep up. My second observation: "It is PACKED in here." 7 people seated, 4 in line, and then I made 12; that should speak to the size of the place (and oddly, 10 of our number were women.) Unfortunately my 2:30 stop-in seemed to be contributing to their afternoon rush, which their solitary barista was ill-equipped to handle. She was fast, but this is an involved process and I don't blame her a bit for the wait.  In a house of health, I choose what have to be the least healthy options. Matcha hot chocolate (whole milk) - $5.25 and cheddar scallion scone - $3.50. All told, pretty much the same prices you'd find anywhere else. The pastries are provided by Balthazar, so you know you're in for something good there, but I got my matcha start at Resobox in LIC, so meeting that mark would be MatchaBar's real challenge.  The matcha hot chocolate was definitely tasty, and I appreciated that it was served at a temperature that didn't sear my tastebuds off. Matcha is a very powerful flavor though, and it tended to overwhelm the chocolate a bit. Additionally, I'd recommend to all who are able to stick to whole milk for this - its weight and creaminess would be sorely missed otherwise. As for the cheddar scallion scone, it was excellent - you can tell that it was made in the wee hours of the morning and not recently, but it didn't suffer too badly and was all-around enjoyable.  If you're thinking of coffee on this corner, I'd certainly recommend stopping in at MatchaBar. It offers a novel experience and a tasty drink for a cold day. Also, it turns your tongue green and that's always funny.

Was really excited to try this place since I'm a big fan of the matcha latte from Aroma in Toronto (which is not available in the Aroma's in NY), most definitely not disappointed.  A friend and I were looking for a place to hang out and get some work done on our computers and get a good cup of matcha, I found this place on Instagram from a friend who posted about it and was very excited to try it. Charles (the cashier) was great in helping us choose what drinks were best, he recommended the cinnamon matcha maple latte and the coconut chai iced (also got the cocoa matcha bar). Talk about delicious! I wish they had more of these locations. We sat down and chilled out for a while drinking our lattes and cocoa bar. Great wifi and the staff is amazingly friendly. Would definitely come back to hang out again and try some of the other drinks!
Not a huge fan of this place. Chalait is nicer and the drinks there are better. The service wasn't the greatest and the drink was too strong.

There matcha pastries are to die for! I'm a matcha addict and came all the way from MD to try this place! Next time I'm in NYC I'm def buying a box full or something! Also had the watermelon and basil matcha which I felt was a little too sour...and partner had the peach and cream matcha and overall both prefer the peach and cream!!
The Fall special cinnamon-maple matcha was great at this new outpost of the Williamsburg-originated cafe.

Earl grey pastry was dry. But the service was subpar. When my coworker walked in to inquire a carrot cake to order. They barely acknowledge our presence. It felt they were a bit sexist servicing some minority women. Felt really uncomfortable in the circumstances. Severely disappointing. I have been back. But this morning, the staff is confused as ever. The male staff seems to be always messing up my order. I said chocolate twist not chocolate cookie. The women staff when I am there never messes up my order.

After hearing about this little cafe down the street, I finally tried it. There is such a wonderful selection of items and I can't believe everything is $2. From what I can tell everything is of really good quality and nothing seems to be cheap as would be the assumption since everything is at this price point. The portions are obviously smaller with everything being $2 but that is just fine. I really like their lattes. They are so much better then the ones I get at Starbucks or Prete and you get it is a regular sized coffee cup. I also had one of their breakfast sandwiches, which was also very good.  The reason why I am giving Matto only 2 stars is because they need to label their ingredients. People, INCLUDING ME, have a nut allergy and a red flag for me was when I looked at their pasta salad and there was no listing for walnuts and then you look at the salad and there are walnuts. I also got their feta sandwich, which has a pesto in it, took 2 bites a knew something was wrong. I proceeded to have an allergic reaction, which luckily isn't terrible but still is enough to ruin my afternoon. There vegitable sandwich has the same pesto, which also has walnuts and is not labelled as such.  A lot of the pastries in their have the potential to have nuts and you can't tell just by looking at it and sometimes the workers are not versed on ingredients, especially something like spreads that might be bought pre-made. Sorry to gripe about this but this is important. I would continue coming to Matto for their coffee, for sure, but potentially little else.
Everything is $2.  I got the chocolate chip cookie, an avocado sandwich   and a large  bottled water.
Bitter espresso overpriced coffee no Place to sit  only a few stools so Not relaxing would not return here Would not recommend I threw my espresso Out  and it cost $3.25

The staff was nice and friendly but my iced DECAF mocha was not decaf. I'm 8 1/2 months pregnant and stressed twice to make sure my drink is decaf. Now I feel like my heart is going to jump out of my chest. Not good at all for my baby. Will not be returning.

Dangerously close to work, pleasantly Italian. While you can have it to go and in different sizes, the cappuccino at Ninth Street Espresso is the real deal, quite possibly better than the original, in that they really take their time to whip it up. Or foam it up. Also relevant that different baristas manage to keep the quality and texture consistent, which I think that's where many other coffee places struggle with. But please, take it "to stay, and small". The sweets are intriguing and well presented, although I found some to be overly, well,  sweet. The banana chocolate bread is different than the usual and it has that "baked at home" feel, which depending on your prowess with the oven might be a scary proposition. In that scenario, the coconut sandwich with chocolate filling is the perfect, unorthodox dipping candidate. It works, all the time.  Ninth Street Espresso does not like your credit cards, so don't even try to swipe one. They also don't want you to seat comfortably, as coffee should be served "by the bar", as they have it in Italy. The couple of stools do the job, but a larger group won't be happy. Overall, too good a cappuccino to get bothered by menial back ache and the inevitable coin counting routine.

Came here after my food god, Alton Brown said this is the best coffee in NY, he's always right! They don't have many choices but it's because they know how to do their coffee right! I got a simple expresso with milk to go. It truly was the best coffee I've had, very rich and flavorful! They have a few different locations though out the city. On my next visit to NY this is going to be my go to first place to revisit! Only bad thing, is its cash only. Hit up the ATM before arriving!

Found this joint while walking on 56th St. This little joint had awesome espresso. Their chocolate banana bread and granola were great too. The espresso was so good that I simply had to have another latte. Four espresso shots later I'm still longing another one. Will definitely be back soon. They only accept cash, so do drop by an ATM before you visit.

Great coffee! A second favorite to Bluestone.  Various locations throughout NY so that's convenient.  I tried a latte and my friend tried an iced coffee and didn't go wrong with either.  Worth a stop :)

I lived next to the original 9th St. on 9th and Ave C and that place is consistent and amazing! I just stopped at the 56th St. location for my usual Americano. This location can't pull an espresso shot to save their life. But wait Americano is a shot with hot water. Some how the 9th st and C location can get a beautiful crema on top. My Americano at 56th St. looked like someone microwaved a discarded chew spit cup. Go to he original. SKIP THIS LOCATION

Great coffee shop! Expertly made espresso. The sign of a good barista is, when they serve coffee at the proper temperature; they do here. Quality beans, friendly staff, delicious pastries and cash only. Be on 56th to get your Ninth Street coffee fix!

Truly deliciously made coffee. I am a Puerto Rican who must put sugar in his coffee--this one didn't need any!! (I tried it before putting anything sweet). The pastries are elegantly tasty. I had an almond croissant that tasted of almonds without having to have the overwhelmingly sweet filling that most almond croissants have. Small place but comfy. And excellent staff. Give it a try!!

Pretty great, a nice walk from, or to Central Park. It's a good simple cup of coffee. If you're looking for flavored(other than vanilla) lattes and more complex drinks this probably isn't the place for you. But they're coffee is hella good!

I don't need to tell you how bad the coffee is in this area and this place doesn't deserve 5 stars for that. You're not alone in your love of quality espresso drinks in a comfortable atmosphere and that's what you're getting here. I've been a fan of 9th street's locations in the EV and they didn't lose their touch when they opened this place on 56th. I judge quality with two drinks: americano and cappuccino. My americano came out looking buttery with a thick layer of crema across the top and the cappuccino was an Instagram waiting to happen.

This is one of my favorite coffee shops in the city. Best tasting drinks. They only take cash and I hope the owners wake up and take Square if they don't want to take Amex, etc. The last few times I went, the place was empty, while SB down the block is packed. People in midtown tend not to carry cash all the time; I'm sure they lose out on lots of business because of the cash only policy. There's lots of other options in the area- chances are I end up at them when I'm not carrying cash.

An abomination. Sure, making authentic baked items gluten-free is challenging. And for some things, maybe impossible. I was so excited to discover a real French gluten-free bakery. Finally I'd be able to have a croissant again! So it's six dollars. A small price to pay? Looks good, feels okay. Why does it taste tastes dense and cakey?! Just like no croissant you've ever had in your life?! I could not be more disappointed. It most closely resembles a hot dog bun. Let's just accept that the gluten-free croissant is impossible, and take it off the menu instead of luring people in, and then pulling the rug out from under them. Zero stars.
Truly unbelievable food.  We had the frittata and the quiche.  Delicious.  Great coffee, too!

This is the best gluten free pastry joint I have ever been to (and I have tried several). The tarts are incredible as are the chocolate eclairs. My non celiac, gluten loving friend also enjoyed the items she ordered and has gone back multiple times without me because the pastries are that good. Items change frequently but the coffee and to go items are pretty consistent. Service has always been fast and efficient. Definitely a go to every time I head to the city.

Found this place recently - I was very excited to have found it given that it's French and gluten-free.  I can say that their banana and chocolate muffin is very good and moist.  I have had their blueberry almond muffin and double chocolate muffin - good, but not as good as their banana and chocolate muffin.  I recently tried their corn muffin and I found it to bre pretty good.  It was a little dry, but frankly most regular corn muffins tend to be dry, so I didn't find it problematic - the taste was there.  I have also had their shrimp salad and a grape/cucumber/goat cheese salad that I am eating right now and it's pretty tasty.  My major complaint is their croissant.  I couldn't believe my eyes that there sitting before my eyes was a gluten-free croissant made by a French person.  I could barely wait until I got home to eat it.  It was pretty terrible and it breaks my heart to have to say that because if anyone can create an awesome tasting croissant (gluten-free or otherwise) it would be the French.  That is precisely why I am writing this.  I was expected to be blown out of the stratosphere and I was so underwhelmed.  One reviewer said, "as gluten-free eaters, we are used to mediocre" - that is exactly why I am writing this review.  We need a revolt.  There is a solution to this and no one has found it yet.  Why the heck are we settling for bad food - on any level?  One should never, ever accept mediocrity (gluten-free or otherwise).  Yes, I am suggesting a revolution.  But mostly, I am hoping the owner reads this and realizes that she needs to push herself to raise her standard of her croissant.  It is not right that it is so blah.  It tasted like a mediocre American grocery store's version of a croissant and let's just say that this is no compliment.  Back to the kitchen on that one.  I have not tried any of the other pastries - I think this place has promise. . . they need to innovate a bit more.

Ordered their butternut squash soup.  It comes in a tiny 6 ounce cup, for which they charge a whopping $6.00. To top it off, their payment interface has a 20% tip by default and -clumsy me- I hit ok the second the barista swiveled the iPad to me to e-sign my receipt. Ended up paying $7.20 for the munchkin size cup of soup in the photo, not to mention it tasted like it had been stored in an old moldy antique trunk  overnight.

Pretty pretentious spot. Payment system set to add a 20 percent tip to your purchase unless you go out of your way to turn it off. Im sure lots of people dont even realize and end up accidentally tipping. Then, for a $6.50 cold brew w cbd, there are just a few drops of cbd, a cup full of ice and a coffee not filled to the top.  In response to management: so youre admitting you add a 20 perfect tip to all purchases unless the buyer realizes it and turns it off? We are not discussing the benefits of tipping. I am complaining that you sneak it in as a default. That is completely unethical. If you're charging what you charge for coffee, pay your staff a living wage. You shouldnt be depending on sneakily added tips to survive. Also, for $6.50 give me a full cup of iced coffee, not ice and a little coffee. I wasn't complaining about the amt of cbd.

Such a quaint adorable space. Love the environment and offerings. I got a cappuccino. The coffee is very tasty and the barista said they use a small boutique roastery in Brooklyn. I also had their overnight oats. Will definitely be making this a regular spot and recommend it to anyone who needs a quick and juicy cuppa joe.

Stopped by here this morning for an iced oat milk cappy.. Absolutely delicious. Overall great vibes in this coffee shop.  The overnight oats are also a tasty healthy way to start the day.  Patent Coffee really cuts through the clutter of coffee shops in the area. No questions it's the new go to spot.
Had a very bad cappuccino (both espresso and milk were poorly done) and a stale croissant. No bathroom.

Coffee was bitter, possibly because it wasn't fresh. In addition, the woman (I believe the owner) at the counter wasn't too friendly. There was no greeting, no "thank you", or basic manner. It really seemed like she didn't care that I was a customer in the cafe. I definitely should of just went to Bluestone Lane, which is across the street.

The hours say they are open till 7.  Don't go there after 630 wanting anything but old drip coffee or tea.  They shut down the espresso machine at ??? not sure when.   I totally get it needs cleaned.  Then change your hours.
Coffee is ok. No WiFi. No restroom for customers. With so many places around, I probably won't go back.

A decent spot to do some work in. My coffee was fast and service was friendly. The tables seemed clean and the music wasn't too loud so you can still manage to have a pleasant conversation and here the other person.

Convenient coffee place on Carmine, in the heart of Greenwich Village. Excellent coffee and great service.  It has a modern, bohemian, artisan feel. Room for ~20 people max.  This was my go-to coffee spot when I was staying with a friend that lived a few doors down from Prodigy. I would run down the stairs and pick up a cup of coffee from Prodigy to start my day.  My default beverage was the house blend plus a shot of espresso. They never failed me.  The two baristas were nice and pleasantly sarcastic, especially for 7am. The environment was conducive to have a conversation or work.  I look forward to returning.
Spectacular neighborhood coffee spot with consistently solid coffee and pastries. Try the babka.  Totally friendly and unpretentious, great music, good vibes.
A great find in the West Village. No pretense, great coffee (both drip and pour over), and some of the best babka I have tried. Small quaint space to sit or take it to go.

Best lattes in the village & amazing orange bread.  Decor is clean, simple, modern. Good place to bring your laptop & get some work done mid-morn thru mid-day (though a little too busy before 10am).  A must-try if you're in the area & looking for a relaxed NON-COMMERCIAL coffee shop.

Excellent coffee, reasonably priced for the quality. There's also cinnamon and chocolate babkas, if you want to relive a Seinfeld episode in 2013.  A few tables are available for seating and I only saw one potential Wi-Fi squatter with a laptop, so you might even be able to snag a seat and stay awhile.

The folks at Prodigy offer as good a coffee shop experience as you can get. It's, in my opinion, the epitome of a what you'd call a "neighborhood gem."  The owners, and now support staff they've hired, are some of the friendliest guys around. It feels more like I'm on the west coast than in New York when I walk in.  The ambiance is bright, sleek, and clean and there's never a huge crowd so grabbing a table or a seat on the bench on the sidewalk isn't a problem.  Their latte's are really freaking phenomenal.  They'll run you $4 or $5, depending on size, but are worth every penny. Their coffee (iced or hot) is very good as well.  And, on top of being the nicest staff around and making kick-ass coffee, they offer a punch-card so that your 10th drink is free. Bonus!  They also have some tasty, though pretty heavy, pastries if you're looking for something to go along with your coffee.  Starbucks, schmarbucks...I'll take Prodigy any day, any time.

Horrible experience. No bathroom. No wifi. And above all, no simple syrup for my iced coffee. Like what? You'd think the West Village would house some of the best coffee shops in NYC and this one is pa-the-tic.

Amazing coffee in a quaint little neighborhood shop. Feels like the kind of place where you could work all day with a single cup and not get kicked out. Staff was friendly though not overly so. The small counter area made it hard to keep out of the way. Coffee was truly delicious though.

After making the stupidest decision of my life (going to the passport agency before coffee), I was a cranky kid.  I needed a bit of caffeine and some time to relax while I waited the hours it would take for my passport to be ready.  Enter: prodigy  I walked in with a muddled brain and a scowl.  The friendly staff dismissed the latter and offered to help me out.  I muttered something about needing caffeine to go alongside my book.  They produced something magical that warmed my soul.  I sheepishly apologized for being a grouch, but they would have nothing of it.  Though the place is small, I felt comfortable sitting there for an hour reading and unwinding.  I got a coffee to go when it started to get busy.  The coffee was strong without an overpowering taste.    I will definitely return when I'm in the area.

Meh. Was hoping for more either English Firestarter Prodigy or Mobb Deep Prodigy. This is more like Scarsdale meets University of Wisconsin Prodigy.  Coffee is pretty good. Espresso is good. Service with a half kinda not so much smile. Seems like the little one is holding the other employees back from being more friendly.  Very simple decor for discussing serious business in here. Also, dogs on the wall. Am I in an episode of Friends if it took place in 2013? Probz.

These lovely people shotgunned a delicious cortado right down my caffeine hole after I dragged my barely-conscious ass off the downtown stop at Houston. I felt pleasured in ways that would be inappropriate to write about here.  Hello, my new regular coffee place. You are the thing that has been missing from my life.

Love the layout, chandelier design, huge open space, huge window, and good seating space.  I got Latte which is great, my friend said their chocolate babka was good.  Wheelchair accessibility: one step up from sidewalk to store.

Great neighborhood coffee shop.  Coffee is solid, baristas are nice, place is simple, airy, and pleasant to be in.  Also a big fan of the bench outside where the regulars gather.  Downsides are no wifi and no bathroom, so it's a better grab and go place then somewhere to stick around.

I stumbled upon this place and it looked promising so I went in to get an iced coffee. Sadly I'm unimpressed. I would give them a second chance and maybe get a proper cappuccino next time but the iced coffee was weak and overpriced for $4.
Nice folks, but the iced coffee was too citrusy. I realize this is a trait of African beans, but it was especially extreme here.
The coffee here has a great flavor without an extreme bitter aftertaste. No sugar needed. I just started working in the neighborhood so I'll definitely be back.
this is quickly becoming my go-to spot for coffee every morning. take my money! take it all!  yummy americanos and coffee. will try their cappuccino soon

I came here with a friend after lunch at Buvette not too far away. The interior decor was nice and simple, a bit on the small side, but perfect for 2 friends to catch up. Their mocha was right on point. On the advice of yelpers, we also tried their chocolate babka but were unimpressed.

Stopped by just to sit down and get something cold to drink while strolling around with my wife.  The iced coffee was good and the staff was very nice and friendly.  Just a standard little coffee shop, nothing fancy.  But I did enjoy the coffee and I liked the staff.  Can't ask for any more than that.
Probably the best Iced Coffee I've had in NYC so far.  Good flavor, no bite.  Very small place, but clean and friendly.  Perfect neighborhood spot.
Hands down the best cup of coffee I've had downtown. Will be returning!

Best bang for your coffee buck in the neighborhood. Standard pricing, above standard quality. The baked goods and coffee (hot or iced both) are always delicious. Small place but they move through the line quickly, and they have a buy-10-get-1-free card.

When Grey Dog closed on Carmine Street i was very sad. Since 1995 it was the place to be on Carmine Street. It changed the block forever and it will not be forgotten. However Prodigy Coffee opened recently a few doors down from where the Grey Dog was and it rocks. Great coffee,friendly helpful baristas and a very nice vibe. Great coffee on Carmine Street lives on

I used to love this place where there were tables and seating for people to talk and work and enjoy their coffee. This past year, the owners have continuously redesigned their layout to discourage people from sitting. Despite all the space, they insist that customers grab their coffee and go. I am disgusted by that. Also, the coffee is too bitter.
Best latte!  Ramini's wife makes all the pastries and they are delicious!!  Additionally Ramini and his staff are always smiling and friendly! A wonderful experience!
The Matcha almond cookie ($2.25) was as excellent as the staffer promised. Will definitely be back for Doughnut Project minis and some other great baked goods.
Best coffee shop in Midtown! Coffee is absolutely amazing and salted brownie is good as well.
O so tasty baked good and great coffe. Found this little gem right next tot he Plat I was staying in. Really friendly and a great place to grad a coffe and a treat. Thanks so much.
This americano is ridiculously delicious and strong. But a good strong and not acidic. The macchiato that my wife got was also really good. The brownie was amazing. Done.

Ramini is downstairs from my office and is a great getaway from having Dunkin Donuts and Starbucks forced upon us!  I am there every morning (and sometimes afternoon). I usually get an Iced Latte (even in this weather!) and their espresso is very good. Nice strong flavor to it but doesn't taste burnt. Always grab an Almond Croissant as well, and thats one of my favorite croissants i've ever had.  A bit pricey (i think i paid $5.75 for a large latte) as compared to your generic franchised coffee shops but thats what you get if you want REAL coffee.  I've also taken notice to their cappuccino's and hot latte's being produced. They know what they are doing and their artistry is top notch. Great place!
Great iced espresso. A little pocket of civilization south of Times Square. Small selection of pastries and macaroons.

Found a hair inside the almond croissant, super disgusting, you can't image you spend $27 on four almond croissant and two drinks, then, one of croissants has hair, how can you eat the rest of them. The store should improve their quality of foods, customers shouldn't pay for food with hair! Plus this is not a cheap bakery!!!

I love everything about Recolte. The lo-fi music, the cold beverage drink selections, amazing tea & coffee, (the super sexy salted caramel eclairs), the beautiful furnitures, the super friendly staffs, how some croissants double as a secret pizza..  HOWEVER,  There are these parents who bring their f-cking kids almost everyday and lets them RUN AROUND for hours in the nice chic french-style cafe.  I asked the manager to tell them to control their kids. Poor guy cringes and I see battles have been lost in the reflection of his eyes because something tells me he isn't new to this. He goes up to the mothers and says one thing as if he had repeated himself a million times and immediately, my sensitive ass knows this 6'8" strong Latino man has been stripped of his power by these mothers. The mothers wave him off "ok, whatever" and if a 'sigh' can be in a human form, that's what he was for that moment.  These kids drive me insane and they're there every time I'm there, imagine how much therapy this manager needs from all of this. These children run and trip on chairs and bump into other human beings. I see adults roll their eyes, sigh frustratingly and have the madness bulging out of the veins of their foreheads.  If Recolte was a manifestation of a human mind, these mothers and their kids are definitely their demons, tormenting them everyday, sucking the good energy and  creating chaos in a place of peace. I imagine Recolte was not always  this way. The mind of Recolte is in desperate need of some ritualistic cleansing. YOUR BUSINESS DESERVES BETTER CUSTOMERS.  Recolte, PLEASE get a scarier mother to tell them off (as if the manager wasn't a big tough looking guy to begin with!) I understand mothers are SCARY but don't let these b-tches come haunting you. They may be mothers but to you, they are first and foremost bullies! This is out of control. Not all mothers are this selfish about their kids towards other people and gives mothers a bad rep.  Anyway, their golden milk latte is pretty solid. I also like that they carry elderflower soda. I always try something new when I am here. The owner is some kind of master pastry chef, you'll see an award framed. I completely agree, the desserts are better than the desserts I've had in France! The price is not the cheapest but it's not that expensive for upper west side, especially for the quality.

Recolte is a nice, spacious bakery with an eating area. I was amazed to see the variety of baked goods, and how I can pick up each pastries on a tray as I went by them. The tray system is very common in Japan so I thought this is a Japanese bakery -- but maybe not. Either way, the pastries are amazing so I'm definitely going back to get some more.

This Matcha Croissant gets its own dedicated post. I regretted not taking a picture of the green tea liquid that was completely oozing out NON STOP after cutting into it. I'm glad I asked the staff to heat it up, it was so good! Literally the most "Asian" bakery item I've ever had. Worth every single calorie.
The heart shape cake with lychee flavor is at just the right sweet level. Expensive but worth to try.

While walking around the neighborhood, I happened to find this small bakery. The wait staff were all very welcoming and was patient with me as I had a tough time choosing which baked good I wanted. I ended up with the Almond chocolate croissant. The outer layer was crunchy while the inside was soft. What surprised me was the chocolate filling. It caught me off guard yet tasted so good. I definitely recommend!

Second time coming to this spot, first time was a really pleasant visit- friendly staff great coffee. Unfortunately this time around was quite the opposite!! I approached the counter to order, mentioned one of my orders and was so rudely interrupted by the girl taking my order,She started  laughing with her other rude colleague. " I told you so" she sniggered to the blonde girl. I proceed to finish stating my order when she said " I should have bet you 50 dollars" to the other girl and once again started laughing.  I'm not sure what kind of staff you want to employ at your business, but coming from a woman that works in service- these two immature girls , you can't teach them manners. Such a bad image for the place.

See pic. WTH...seriously? Latte? I don't know what their problem is. Barista was not interested in talking to me at all. There was an attitude, which apparently is noticeable on the latte as well. It also tasted very watered down. Nice job guys.

Omg!! How did I not know about this place? This is Brooks brothers cafe. Great coffee, fresh pastries and a cozy environment. There are many searing options. You can sit on a sofa, table. And there is a bar with iPads!  Yes, iPads!!! Amazing. They also have a sofa on the other side of the floor. Seems idea for a meeting. I will definitely be back!  There are some board Games sitting on the table, books on the shelf and they serve wine and beer. Plus a clean bathroom! That is always a good thing.

Hidden jewel of a coffee house!   Stumptown coffee and great pastries / sandwiches and happy hour for wine and beer.  Decor is woody and the vibe is spot on perfect.   Staff are very professional.  Great wifi.  Can't beat it.   Wish they had longer hours but they are located in the lower floor of Brooks Brothers so can only be open when the store is open. (Occasional problems in summer with their air conditioning; call ahead to check.)
Nice hidden nook underneath the Brooks Brothers store. Free WiFi and good coffee/cafe sweets. Nice ambiance. Would definitely recommend!!
Average coffee shop. A bit disappointed in the size of the place. I expected something more elegant like the Ralph Lauren coffee shop.

Wonderful coffee shop. Turns into a bar with happy hour in the evening. Order at the counter and they will bring it to your seat. Some leather chairs and other high tops and regular small tables. I just hope this place doesn't get too popular!
Awesome coffee shop combined with retail upstairs. The vibe is great and awesome decorations. Very comfortable area to chill or hangout.

Stumbled accross this hidden gem while walking thru the city with my daughters.  We were looking for a spot to sit for an hour so they could finish their school work.  This place was a dream come true!  Comfortable seating that wasn't crammed with people.  I didn't feel like I was being rushed out.  I enjoyed a delicious mocha, the girls each had a hot chocolate and we all shared several different tea type cookies!  I will definitely be back!!!!

Wow. I just walked out before even getting a drink because the barista was so incredibly rude. He didn't acknowledge me and continued chatting with a friend or employee (not sure) he had just made a drink for. When he finally acknowledged me I asked if they had regular coffee or cold brew, he said it's all cold brew which is typical now so no big deal, I ordered a latte. He audibly sighed. More work I guess? They had skim and whole milk so I asked if he could do half skim half whole (also typical for coffee shops...) and he made a face like it was a crazy request and says "I guess." By that point I was just done and said I changed my mind and walked out. No reason to treat people that way. He was rude to the two women who came up behind me also. Clearly has a chip on his shoulder.  I've never walked out of anywhere because of rude service. I started a new job just around the corner but I will be bringing my daily coffee business elsewhere.

The blonde barista is by far the rudest person i have met in ALL customer service experiences I've encountered. I have never experienced such a nasty demeanor and bad attitude from someone in my life. I have visited this shop twice and both times she has been terrible. Never coming here again.

Ordered a cappucino. Barista added some cold milk to milk that he had already steamed for someone else's drink, re-steamed it all together and added it to my drink. $4 for burnt, reused milk. Not up to SCAA standards nor mine.

What's here: La Colombe coffee, a tempting assortment of Mast Brothers chocolate bars, surfboards, chillness, and a small back patio.  What's not: seating, crowds, extraneous syrups, or anything to distract the serious coffee drinker.  Hard to believe that this little gem is tucked around the corner from Broadway and on a Friday afternoon was as pleasantly quiet as a chapel, but miracles happen.

Love love love this place. In the warmer months I make frequent stops here with close friends to just chill out on the back patio area with their ice coffee. Always usually able to secure a spot comfortably. I can't really speak to the actual surf gear that is sold in the store b/c I've never taken a thorough enough look. Staff however is really chill and it's just a nice place in the city where you feel like you're relaxing at someone's quaint Soho pad.    I only dock a star b/c one time when I was there with a friend we saw a humongous rat scurrying in the corner of the back patio area. We decided to stay anyway the first time we saw it even though it seemed ginormous (seriously seemed twice the size of a normal rat) but after the second time it popped out we decided it was time to go. If this was a restaurant or inside I'd probably never return. It was an isolated incident though so hoping we just never see the mutant rat again.  Otherwise come for some good coffee and conversations!

The coffee is better than Starbucks or DnD  The guy behind the counter is predictably snotty.  Don't even try to make conversation unless you are something better than a normal person.  If you're into surfing I'm sure you'll do fine.
Delicious iced coffee, very reasonable prices, a fantastic garden seating area and none of the wifi/laptop crowd. Easily one of the best coffee shops in NYC.

Baristas/owners are as hot and tasty as the coffee!  Been here four or five times.  The coffee is excellent enough to qualify as a treat. The guys who work here are friendly, sexy, smart and a good way to find out about a bar to stop by later.  The customers seem to be equally out of a cool-kid blog, but without the attitude.  Finally, it's a nice little space with a highly edited selection of lovable merch and rotating art (I think).  A must-stop for window shopping and refreshment in all its lovely forms.
good coffee, good vibrations and a good garden spot to boot. Nothing spectacular here, but certainly interesting. I just dig the atmosphere. The simple syrup made with raw sugar was an added boost.

Like many other reviewers on here, I stumbled upon Saturday's Surf NYC on a random outing in SoHo. I was drawn in by the store's minimalist design and a love of lattes. What I discovered was somewhat of an oasis; throughout the store there are ornaments referring to surfing: surfboards, wetsuits, clothing, and books about the sport. In the front, is a small espresso bar that brews some truly amazing lattes. In all, I was very impressed-this place is truly a great little spot and has everything I look for in a new space, its calm, secluded and unique. Wonder how soon before the secret gets out?
Sorry really bad coffee. Can't believe I paid $5 for the almond latte, that's worse than Starbucks. It's too bitter. Im always up for organic boutique coffee shops, but just not this one.

Upon ordering two freshly squeezed orange juices, I received two cups from their fridge. I thought that was weird, since it is advertised as fresh on the sign outside- but I thought maybe it was squeezed this morning which I am personally okay with. I paid for my juices and left without trying them, having trusted that stone street coffee would know what all fresh OJ drinkers know: THE TASTE OF NOT FRESH OJ.  They charged me $7 for two cups of Tropicana. They also didn't answer the phone when I called to complain. This happened like 16 minutes ago. I will never go back.

What a cute little neighborhood coffee stand!  I stumbled upon stone street on my way back from my morning gym routine, and its one of my favorite look forward to events post workout.    Elena, the barista, is there most mornings, and she is a complete sweetie.  She knows most regular's java of choice. This joint is small so if you are thinking of lounging with cafe, croissant and wifi, this is not your place.  Theres no seating.  However, there is walkup window and indoor service.    If you swing by late, the back of the coffee shop is a speakeasy called bathtub gin.
Super friendly.  Called me by name.  No min on credit card.  Insanely good banana bread.  Great coffee.  Walk up window for when you're on your bike or with your dog.  Love.

Call it growing pains...headed over to try Stone Street on a Saturday morning around 10:15am. I like to try and support new businesses in the hood and I was excited to sample an espresso and some pastry. The service window was open but the door was locked. A moment later a man appeared, unlocked the door and went inside. I tried to follow but he locked the door behind him.  I stuck my head in though the window and saw the man mopping the floor. I asked if they were open and without looking at me he said they were. I then asked if all orders had to be made through the window. He looked at me and said, "That's why the window is open."  I was already really annoyed so I didn't bother to point out that I was also hungry but none of the pastry could be viewed from the window. As a result I did not sample any food.  Instead of espresso I ordered a small coffee for two dollars. It was ordinary and the  "barrista" (who was clad in a "wife-beater" undershirt) added way too much milk resulting in a luke-warm brew and, it should be noted, that he couldn't even be bothered to say thank you after completing the transaction.  The coffee house competition in this city (and this neighborhood) is too great for a business to get by with such slip shod customer service.  To be fair, this may be just a bad morning at Stone Street so perhaps I will give them another try if I am walking by, but it won't be an experience that I will go out of my way for.

Most annoying question when ordering a cappacino? What size. A proper cappacino is not measured in size, but rather three properly pulled shots of espresso, topped with about an ounce and a half of streamed milk and a dollop of foam. Two shots of espresso in an 8- to 12 ounce cup filled with milk does not a proper capp make. Starbucks gets this, as does Ninth Street Espresso, the latter my former personal New York favorite until my recent discovery of Stone Street.  Coffee is one of the few things in life about which I am a snob. Spoiled for years by The Conservatory for Coffee in Culver City, California, I had been consistently disappointed by the lack of quality coffee houses within reasonable distance of home and work here in New York. And while Ninth Street Espresso has been great, Stone Street has kicked it upstairs. To the C-Suite.  While not (yet?) privy to their roasting process, this is probably the first of two break-out distinctions here. Local roasting is rare in New York, and while others do it, Stone Street does it better. Every blend I've tried has exemplified an expert technique that brings out the full aroma and flavor of each.  And second, in terms of the perfect capp, is the milk, organic and sourced from a local upstate farm. A bonus... (And I probably shouldn't share this)... they sell it to me on the side with my purchase of ground beans to go, so my Capresso machine at home makes me $4 capps at home for under a buck. It is this attention to service and detail that really earned this five stars.  Starting each day with the proper cappuccino... the perfect blend of roast and milk... is like mainlining coffee and chocolate, and has greatly improved my morning mood and commute each day. A great accompaniment to, and something I hope to see soon "In the Papers." Some of you will get that and most won't. And it doesn't matter as long as I do.  Children of the Bean... Unite around Stone Street.
If you are an espresso freak as I am, stop by Stone Street Coffee. It had rich crema, intense flavor, and was light like whipped egg whites or foammed milk .

I just had a coffee here and it was weak, and tasteless.  In my opinion they need to focus less on the "Japanese Style" coffee etc and just make a decent cup of COFFEE. Learn to walk before you can run guys, good luck.

I went into get coffee and one of the baristas without looking at me said is that my babe? When he heard my voice. I responded no, I don't know you. The other barista said "stop making my customers feel uncomfortable."  Look when I walk into a cafe I just want to buy a coffee without drama and having to figure out if I know the barista.  Especially given the sensitive atmosphere in our culture can we all just be cool.  Coffees good as hell tho.

What makes the coffee inn is special is the staff. They are always super friendly and quick to offer a smile. Coffee is good and the use of steamed milk is always plus. The cappuccino muffin is yummy and I would definitely have the veggie muffins a try, just the right amount!
Overpriced, poor selection and long lines... Artisanal coffee is overrated, especially with a Starbucks and Dunkin Donuts right around the block.

This is your run of the mill coffee shop. Nothing exciting, nothing fun and definitely nothing VEGAN.  The iced coffee was blah and the help was even more blah. They were just as bored with me as I with their offerings.  I only came here because I was stuck in the area, probably won't be coming back.
This place has great coffee and even better customer service! The staff are always smiling, happy appearing, which makes my morning every time I go to the Coffee Inn!
Not the best service, but good for a quick bite, I do go offen due to its coneveniency, food is good.

i was a little disappointed because although this place says breakfast, from what i could tell it was mainly pastries and bagels (no oatmeal, eggs, soup). service was quick and efficient; it's a small place but there were a lot of people coming in, a testament to its coffee popularity. i got a hot decaf- a bit pricey (over $2), but good quality!

Been coming here for awhile (practically twice a week at least) but the service is really disappointing. The shop itself is gorgeous and a warm west coast feel. However, the staff (with the exception of one wonderful gentleman) is very rude and makes poor quality drinks. I have ordered oat milk matchas from here that were full of disgusting clumps. The one time I asked a barista to remake it she was incredibly rude. Today, I ordered an almond milk dirty chai. Upon receiving the chai I asked to confirm the barista if she put almond milk in it... to which she replied no. I then told her I asked for almond milk and if she could remake it and then she said "oh actually I THINK I put almond milk in it." Needless to say, as someone with lactose intolerance I felt anxious drinking the chai but I felt uncomfortable with the barista's way of avoiding remaking the drink.  I also find it weird that there are sooo many reviews like this but no response from the shop owner? I'm assuming they don't care. Anyways, the worst barista is a tall brunette who typically works on Saturday's so avoid the shop then or at least don't expect good service

I am so so sorry but i need to rate this place 1 start and the only reason is because the barista was so rude and so unprofessional, i can't accept that. Unfortunately if you work at a coffee shop and you deal with people daily and constantly you should love to be around and in front of people. Her name is Katelen i believe.  Besides this little accident that ruined my afternoon at the Elk, i love the spot, it's small and cozy.

The elk is one of my favorite coffee and lunch places in the west village area. The coffee is always fresh, strong and delicious. They serve a great breakfast/brunch menu with very full portion sizes. They are quick to serve and don't rush you out.  One downfall is that there is limited seating here. If you come at a busy time you might get stuck without a table. Also the food is a little pricey, but like I said above, delicious and full portions. So in my opinion, worth the money :)  They also have these great little coconut energy balls. They have about 4 different flavors in a big jar. Perfect snack to grab on the go with your coffee.
My favorite coffee shop in Manhattan. Employees are friendly and the vibe is great. Awesome spot to grab and go or get comfortable.
Beware of getting the iced matcha latte you will be very dissapointed seriously the worst cup of matcha ive ever had and i had plenty smh

I am disappointed on trying their iced matcha latte they did not rinse the matcha they just put matcha powder in cup and the milk wasnt so good so dont come here for iced matcha latte you will be desappointed.
Lucky me - I found this place. Great little coffee shop with a fresh clean vibe. Expertly made coffee drinks and fresh delicious food. Try the avocado toast - yummy!

Interior Design: 5-stars Service: 5-stars Food/Drink: 5-stars  There is free wifi and decent seating with outlets. There is a restroom. The music is great and played at just the right level. The space is bright and simple and in a lovely neighborhood. The baristas are funny and really friendly. There are a lot of great simple options for breakfast and lunch.  The whole experience here is wonderful.
There area lot of coffee shops in west village. This is my new favorite. Nice people, cute decor, not pretentious or too crowded. Such a pleasant place to chat with a friend or work.

Lots of light.  Tight space.  This place doesn't need yelp reviews. It will be ok. This area is so run over with tourists who will wander in and eventually it will be noted in their "not for tourist book" but to help them choose:  Take drink and sit in the park - walk west -just a stones throw away.  Menu: Find Matcha! and the standard coffee/tea based drinks. 2 sizes for drinks 8oz 12oz - way too small! They have baked goods and will offer food.  Bonus: Free drink (punch card) Wifi: So far the wi-fi pass is sight glass, look on the board. Smells good:  (keep bathroom door shut tho) Self serve water
Hipster crowd in a great location. Good drinks. OK service. Very small and lots of traffic, so hard to get seats.
This place was just ok... Good coffee but soft scramble was not great and sweet potatoes were hard and stale seeming

Never do I ever write reviews on yelp but I am seriously disappointed. I came here a few months ago with a friend and decided to come back today because I love the environment. Coffee is okay (alright at best) but I didn't mind because I came for the nice and cozy interior. At first, the girls at the counter were really nice but I realized after that I was deeply mistaken. I sat down to take a few pictures of the cafe but then overheard the counter staff talking smack about how much it pisses them off when instagramers take pictures. Their remarks were very rude. The Elk is also a small, tiny caf̩ and tables are about six to seven feet away from the counters so I heard everything they said. I was having a great day until this happened and I'm seriously disappointed and annoyed. There is nothing wrong with what I did and nothing wrong with taking pictures for instagram. Does that not benefit the caf̩ and the workers? Do posts not bring the caf̩ more publicity? Does that not give you more chances to get tipped by customers? Moreover, I also bought a canvas tote from the caf̩ with the shop name on it prior to hearing the bad mouthing and I was looking forward to wearing it around. I feel like I've wasted ten dollars that would have been better spent elsewhere.   FYI, if you're gonna sh1t-talk a customer, at least don't let them hear you. I will never come back again. Ever.

I live in the neighborhood and twice now I've attempted to come in during normal business hours for an espresso drink and have been turned away because the machine is "not ready." This happened once in the morning, once in the afternoon so it would appear the establishment isn't actually looking for repeat morning customers on the way to/from the subway. Should've read the reviews first - seems like their drinks are subpar anyways.

This coffee store looked so enticing I could not resist going in. The people are nice and the ambiance fine. The coffees on special at the front of the store were priced around $24 a lb. which seemed high. The aroma was that of flavorings heavy on the hazelnut light on the Java. That should have warned me off. I bought a large coffee (10 oz.) Kenya blend. Lukewarm and minimal flavor. Maybe it is a good place to buy beans but not for brewed coffee.

I went yesterday because as I was walking east on 70th street toward the lark, the aroma was just scrumptious.  I wish the coffee was a bit stronger and "deeper" but overall it was great and the store is super cute and really old NY
Amazing coffee! I come here for both my beans and for coffee to go. They have great bean flavors and awesome iced coffee!

Came to this tiny coffee shop to grab some espresso. The cappuccino tasted...different -- the espresso wasn't bad or anything but just not the taste I prefer. It was also kind of weird how their espresso machine is hiding in some backroom where you can't see what they are doing.  The coffee bean selection makes this place worth visiting again though. The beans I got made for some pretty good morning coffee.

After a brief awkward greeting with the employee, who did not ask if he could help me but just said, "Hi," I wasn't really sure if I was in the right place to order just a cup of coffee or tea.  Just walk in and you'll know what I mean-- the walls are artfully lined with rows and rows of big coffee bean and tea blend bins.  It seems like a place where they pack a bag of beans for you and you're on your way.  Once I discovered that I could, in fact, just get one serving, that's when the real expertise of this place was able to shine.  I told him the taste I was looking for (I was in the mood for iced tea), and he recommended not just one tea but a BLEND of two teas that he promptly mixed, brewed, and iced for me in back.  And it was exactly what I was looking for.  While he was making the tea, I decided to peer around at the coffee selection (which is bountiful).  I loved opening the bins and smelling the different flavors... raspberry, toffee, so many to choose from!  I'm not actually sure if I was allowed to smell them, but nobody was looking so I couldn't resist.  Looking forward to the next time I'm in the neighborhood and can go back.  One last quick note-- there is one bench outside the Sensuous Bean, but it does not provide seating otherwise.

The aroma just walking by is absolutely intoxicating. I love this little shop for their freshly ground beans in 100 delicious and unique flavors, but they have poor customer service. The woman behind the counter seemed almost upset I was there, and even though I left with a pleasant "Thanks!" it was returned with dead silence. I will definitely be back to get my favorite beans, but hope there's different sales person next time.

The service is so rude and unhelpful - which is very weird for a specialist store like this.  I could live with that for great coffee but it was anything but that - I would say average at best. Somewhat on par with Starbucks, which is not a compliment.
I enjoy the brewed coffee from sensuous bean... they always have 4-5 varieties brewing and I have always been happy with my selection.  I make it a weekend treat almost every weekend!

Pretty sure that putting dirty, full, outdoor sanitation garbage bins inside the only bathroom in the establishment is a health code violation. I only came in here because I needed to use a public bathroom. I bought a TINY 8oz coffee for $2.75 to be a paying customer to use the bathroom. The coffee looked very watery and translucent and wasn't a good cup of coffee. They have NO VEGAN MILK choices besides soy (how archaic). Starbucks has coconut AND almond milk in addition to soy. Then after buying this overpriced crappy tiny coffee with no almond milk to add to it, I walk into the bathroom. The stench of garbage almost made me vomit. It looked like someone died in there, toilet paper was everywhere. Absolutely disgusting . There was barely any room to even walk inside to wash your hands because the two outdoor garbage bins  took up almost all of the floor space in the bathroom. THIS IS THE BATHROOM THAT THE EMPLOYEES USE. there are also no paper towels in the bathroom so I doubt the employees wash their hands every time. This bathroom is disgusting and I am positive  that it's not safe and a violation of health codes.

Over 15 minutes to get my $4+ single origin coffee and it was cold when I finally got it. I actually don't think I would have ever gotten it if I didn't get back in line to ask about it.  The service at this location is amazingly bad. The girl at the register wasn't even appologetic.  She acted like it was my fault for ordering coffee there.  I've really have never seen such a bad coffee shop. It must be the constant flow of tourist at this location that keeps it busy. I don't think any customer would come back a second time.

Actually, I feel like shit about this coffee. It is the most burnt thing I have ever tasted. More burnt than when you forget about your toast in the toaster. It made me want to throw up. No, scratch that. It made me HAVE to throw up. I mean, if you like shit burnt coffee then this is your place!

I can't say enough good things about this place. Coffee is always delicious, store is always stocked and clean, and the staff is always lovely! I love their iced chai lattes and iced espresso! As for pastries, go for the almond croissant or a donut!
Bad. So bad. Gawd awful. If you want to have this kind of watered down nasty mess, drink hotel coffee with a spoonful of dirt. It'll be a bit better

This one is located right next to the northernmost entrance to the High Line. Perfect place to use the restroom. But they also have good coffee here so make sure to buy a cup if you're going to use the restroom. There is some seating but I can envision it getting very crowded.

The hot "Spanish Latte" i had was delicious, its their house special. They use steamed whole milk, sweetened condensed milk and their house proprietary espresso (a fair trade blend), coming from "Porto Rico Importing Co.   Don't just take my word for it, drop by to one of their many locations!!

PSA #1:  you have to pay for WiFi here ! That is soooooo not cool, I don't know any place in NY where you have to pay for WiFi, that is absolutely ridiculous & will make your coffee shop the last resort to go to. PSA #2: they are extremely overpriced... even Starbucks is less expensive than this place. It seems they overcharge in order to make up for their lack of foot traffic-- which is apparent by the way. It's run by some unfriendly Asian lady that seems to only care to make a buck. The space is large, and they have nice tables to work on, but I have two main issues with this business. The main one is that it is not actually a legitimate bookstore as they claim. All of the book are basically just the same book but translated in all different languages. The book relates to some kind of religion, but I found it to be a bit uninviting for customers who may not follow that religion and are interested in other books (like a regular bookstore with books from all over the world) I wouldn't think a business like this would do well because of that. I recommend they grow their selection of books and this way I guarantee they will have more customers. Because the space is quite nice, but the music is bothersome & the books.. well.. there is none lol! The coffee and pastries are nice though. But they should really keep their sugars and condiments on the outside where people can reach/ use them, not hidden away behind the register. They're stingy with the condiments.

I really wanted to like this place and was looking forward to making it my go to place to work. The atmosphere was quiet with lots of seating.  But the matcha and cookie I got was so horrible. I got a large matcha latte with almond milk for $8.50 which is more expensive than any other place I've had in the area. If it was a good matcha latte, I wouldn't mind, but I felt like I paid $8.50 for water down milk. I couldn't even taste any matcha at all. This is seriously the worst matcha I've ever had! And I should have read previous reviews  The cookie was stale and hard. I took one bite and couldn't even eat it anymore.

My favorite reading / studying cafe in Midtown. It's hard to find a quiet cafe around this area. So you'll be surprised at this very quiet place. Their spacious room will never be so packed.  Great coffee & tea at good price. Their cold brew coffee (12oz for $3.5) was very very good. Mild bitter and sweetness with deep aroma. I loved it so much that I asked them if they could give a coffee refill at discount price( !!! ) - unfortunately they don't ;) Their tea selection: Numi, mighty tea leaf, etc.  Mini matcha madeleines are rich in taste, soft and flavorful. Not-too-sweet, but just right sweetness. 3 for $4 Pistachio cheese cake is delicious, too. Again, not-too-sweet but just right sweetness! It was such a great idea of me to pair it with their mild bitter coffee. $6  I like the sounds of the water flowing. Free wifi and outlet. Classic music. The staff is super kind. Such a perfect place for reading.

The book collection is mostly related to Falun Dafa, a meditation practice so deep and profound no matter where you are in your life, it connects you with your most powerful self. Truthfulness Compassion and Tolerance are the principles and once you engage with their meaning you realize it's about much more then just being a healthy person. Falun Dafa ist the most beautiful and powerful meditation practice! I love their tea menu too

My favorite croissants are from Tianti books. The coffee is pretty good and the barista was nice enough to make a new brew for me one time. Service is a little slow, but there is usually only one or two people working. Also, why is the store so cold?! It makes it impossible to stay and do work, which I would like to do since it's so calm and quiet here.

They removed their Pu-erh tea as well as most of their cheaper non-flavored teas and replaced them with newfangled ideas. The bottom price is 5 dollars. The place is still super calming but i won't be stopping in here nearly as much.
Worst macarons I've ever had. Almost broke a tooth on it. You're better off with the frozen macarons from Trader Joe's--no seriously.

This has become my go-to place for coffee and work meetings.   The space is great to meet in.  Some of the staff could be a bit warmer and friendlier but for the most part they're good.   I like the vibe here and the coffee and snacks are good too.

I really liked the vibe of this place and not to mention their extensive well priced menu. Very spacious and the back is perfect for studying or getting some work done. I live in the area and have a huge professional exam coming up in June so I have been experimenting with a few places that I can use to get away from the distractions of my apartment and I can truly say this place will be my Saturday regular.  The staff is also very nice and prices are pretty good. My only negative would be I thought the classical music a a smidge too loud, but maybe it was because I was sitting near a speaker.
