This is one of those places where, when you're here, it's so easy to forget you're in a huge metropolitan area.  The cafe is quiet with calm music. There's free wifi and the patrons tend to be on the quiet side.  I ordered a cappuccino and it was divine.  I'll definitely come back.
GREAT spot. Spacious, outlets, friendliest staff ever. I got a muffin and cappuccino which were both delightful. Worth a stop if you're in the area.
A hidden gem! So peaceful, and large, with lots of nice seating. Great place to do work or relax.

NYC life is usually made better by coffee.  Not here.  Visited on a rainy, dreary day, for hope of a cheerful pick me up.  Nope.  First, the counter staff was flat out sullen, cold and hard of attitude.  I know this person can smile, banter and laugh as I saw this cashier and the barista doing so, loudly, the rest of the time while I was there.  Anti-humanist customer service.  Cashier: you are here to be pleasant and get orders efficiently taken and delivered.  Serving the customer is partially about being upbeat, positive and kind.  Didn't happen.  Now one could just let that go and enjoy food and beverage... but  those, also were nasty and unpleasant. I had an almond milk latte that tasted like the  milk was bad. Barely drank half of it and then, as I was there with a friend & didn't want to ask for a redo, just let the rest sit there untouched. A bad coffee at a coffee shop? How depressing.  The final insult to injury was the ricotta, strawberries, and balsamic toast. It looked (in the advertising photo) like it was on some lovely rustic white bread. Nope.  It was on the stalest piece of white bread that had been toasted so long ago that it was stone cold.  Oh, and not that I expected it to have a massive serving of strawberries, but there was barely one and a half strawberries cut up for each half slice of toast. Summarized: it was one piece of plain white bread, cut diagonally, thinly spread with the ricotta, and a total of 3 small hard strawberries cut up, sprinkled on it. The final yuck was that the accenting balsamic vinegar was poured onto the toast in such a way that it only hit the center part of the toast and none of the rest - soggy meet stale. It was truly a rip off at eight dollars and hardly edible.  TL/dr: For java and a snack, go to a well-known coffee chain or a bodega instead of here.

Worst service ever. The guy working there is so dry and unhelpful. He wouldn't make avocado toast said he "didn't feel like it." He goes "I'm gonna be honest with you. I'm not gonna make you toast right now." He also wouldn't tell another customer what time the store is open until. So rude!

Stumbled upon this place just when I thought I wouldn't find a cafe in this area filled with art galleries. The iced chai tea with almond milk is perfectly creamy and spicy and just a touch sweet. The tea with almond milk is 6 dollars, with regular milk is 5. Worth the price tag for a 16 ounce cup.  Nice environment and dope playlist. I'd definitely come back. Just note that this isn't one of those cafes with plugs at every seat. In fact, I don't see any.

Have passed by this cute little gem many times visiting high line park and today finally made it a try! While their pastry option was a bit limited, their espresso selection was definitely extensive.  The best way to enjoy would be to grab a small cup and sip inside the park! Creamy and balanced cappuccino, well done!

I just read through a bunch of (positive) reviews for the Underline Coffee shop - and I suspect they are all friends of the owners. I went into this coffee shop with my friend the other day while gallery-hopping, for a quick pick-me-up. It's a very small space, simple design - very plain, little character and not even any music playing. Quiet. That's fine. The counter people were flat out Unfriendly. Not a smile to be seen. The coffee was good but expensive (almost $9 for two cold brews). We sat in the back area near the baristas and the vibe was quiet and awkward. We asked to use the restroom and were told no, they do not have one. A coffee shop - under the Highline (no bathrooms) - in the gallery district (most galleries don't allow you to use their bathrooms) - and Underline does not offer a restroom to their paying customers. Okay well, that's Unaccommodating (and certainly not encouraging of purchasing more beverages). Overall we were Unhappy there. There are thousands of coffee shops to choose from in NYC - I see no reason to patronize this one.
Came here by accident on our walk on the high line. Really a hidden gem! Coffee superb! Extremely nice people, really helpfull too. Sad that I didn't give them a huge tip!

Underline is actually one word, and this error is killing folks' ability to find them on Yelp. Sadly the nice guy who prepared my  cinnamon 'sandwich'  couldn't make it non-open-faced, nor tasty or substantial, yet brutally charged $4.08 for it. Nice spot, too, what a shame -- they've removed one of their 4 original sandwiches, so hopefully they give this the ax next...knew I should've gone avocado smash.
Tasty, cute, cozy, quiet, and friendly. What more can you ask for! Just steps away from the High Line.

Gorgeous small coffee shop under the amazing high line. The employees and owners are simply wonderful and will accommodate you as best as they can. Espresso is just great and the ambiance won me over. Couldn't praise enough what a change from Starbucks!
So many coffee shops in the area, but definitely a superior choice. Tiny and super cozy with some of the most friendly staff. Little samples of the best cookies and well curated list of drinks.

I stopped in on Saturday at around 4pm after a long morning of gallery hopping.  This place has great curb appeal, very cozy and quiet.  Just as an intro, I own a small cafe myself so I can understand rushes and high volume times of day..... With that being sad this was the most unorganized cafe I have seen.  1.  The layout is bizarre, I highly recommend that the cashier and his IPAD register stay permanently at the front counter.  He was helping people who sat at the bar so when I walked in, along with other strangers, it was a bit confusing as to where we should order, follow the cashier around or stand with our backs against the wall near the bar?   --When customers come in coffee orders should be taken and paid for at the main counter, then customers should be left to either find a seat or wait for To-Go orders.       2.  I ordered a Cappuccino, what I got was no where near a Cappuccino.  They have an amazing Espresso machine, and the barista made a decent shot.... But he then poured it into an 6, maybe 8 ounce cup at most!  I didn't order a Cortado (equal parts steamed milk and espresso).  A single cappuccino should be served in a 10oz cup and a double should be somewhere around 12oz, ohh and it should be light creamy foam, not steamed milk, I got a Latte/ Cortado Combo pack.  I have no idea how many shots it was, they only have one size/price, but it was terrible.  I paid $3.75 for a drink I didn't order.  I want this place to do well but I walked out feeling disappointed with only half of a coffee.  I'm going back next week, so we'll see.

A few weeks ago, I stumbled into this place for the first time. I was impressed by their coffee selection, the cool vibe, and good music. The baristas are friendly and knowledgeable. And their espresso drinks are outstanding. Definitely will continue coming back to this little gem tucked under the Highline. And it's great to support a family-run, locally owned business.

Great servers.  They were sweet and super friendly.    Mediocre eats-- mostly pastries/cakes/sweets/carbs procured from outside food sources, short order cook foods (eggs, egg sandwiches, lox bagels), or uncooked (avocado and canned tuna), or microwaveable food.    There are more seats if you wrap around the place, and even more seating in the back patio area which also has lovely plants.    Bathroom requires a code to use--ask an employee for the code.    What put a damper on the experience was the horrible owner.  She scolded us for bringing a birthday cake to surprise our friend because outside food is prohibited.  We didn't know, so the only thing we could do was apologize profusely, but the owner was relentless and rude.  She also suggested we should tip more because for reservations, they typically expect each person to spend at least $15.  We put an extra $20 in the tip jar (more for the nice waitresses on her staff) despite the fact that we had already tipped 20 percent of the bill, however, we will not return and would advise others to beware.

Quality cafe. They have wifi for paying customers thats quick. A good size section of seats. They have dairy alternatives that aren't a crazy expense more. I highly recommend getting the Avocado Tomato Bagel. Also ordering a Chai Latte with Oatmilk. My only only only complaint is that they don't have proper utensils and only have plastic utensils. Also they have complimentary water which is great :)

The sign here was correct, the coffee was strong...and delicious. My friends and I were in desperate need of a little pick-me-up, and we were happily surprised when we came here. Good coffee, tasty pastries, and wonderful service. Would absolutely come back!

This place has a great calm atmosphere and has plenty of space. There is also wifi available and a cute outdoor patio area! I ordered the Masala Chai bubble tea made with oat milk. The chai itself was not super flavorful, but not bad. The boba wasn't a great texture. I would definitely come back but would probably try something else.  UPDATE: I ordered an iced coffee and a carrot cake pound cake and both were AMAZING! I also talked with the owner who was super friendly and told me about their breakfast sandwiches. I'll be back to try those soon.

This place is so cute with a hidden outdoor area. Great pastry and drink selection. I'll come back and spend some time working here. Good local spot for a coffee date or a casual hang out. I do have to agree with another comment where they say the music is a little loud. It's quite outside though. Depends what you're looking for.

Wow what a gem! So happy this has opened up in my hood. My latte was yummy as was my egg and cheese bagel. The dark chocolate donut finished it off perfectly ( they are from underwest donuts - amazing !! ) I would post a photo but I scoffed it all too quick. Looking forward to this being my regular go to spot. Staff are so friendly, polite and efficient!

Wow. This place was a gem of a find. Looking around on a Saturday for just a place to chill out and get some premium coffee/tea. The owner/cashier was such a sweet lady. Definitely a personality that makes you feel welcomed. The inside seating area was delightfully wonderful. Such a cool ambience and the decor was quite modern/hip. Definitely coming back, and I hope they get more business! They definitely deserve it. :D
Lovely cafe with delicious drinks! Definitely recommended . Plenty of space to sit and enjoy a cup of tea with friends.

Order the dark chocolate waffle. Not recommended... it is neither dark nor chocolaty, neither crispy nor fluffy. Instead it is very doughy and stiff. A $7.5 waffle cones with only one pity strawberry and does not even have whipped cream. Not to mention the fruit tea is beyond bland. Overall a complete waste of money and calories.

Cute small little spot near our house I just got to try. Everything is supper fresh and organic. Prices are average or a bit high (9$ for a really good egg salad sandwich). Coffee was really good too. Will go back!

Had the most adorable but delicious almond milk turmeric latte. Food looks light and healthy, many patrons had ordered a main brunch dish with chocolate waffles on the side. Coffee and lattes were good although there is a limitation on seating inside

Found this place by chance. It was either this or the Subway to doors down. So glad we did! Inexpensive and tasty food. We had waffles with scramble eggs and matcha tea. It was until we finished the tea we realized they had Milo. (We are Jamaican and Milo is a big deal for us.)  So now we have a reason to come back.  The place is quite small (i.e. tight) so hopefully it doesn't get too popular...:)

Rarely have any coffee place a five star unless I loved the combination of bean selection and ambience; this one is an exception, as it is the only place I've found in the city, serving fruit infusion tea, has lots of real fruit cubes inside.  Unlike what I've thought, the tea was less on the sweet side, yet carried the lovely fruity scent; I would love to finish those fruit once done with my tea!  Haven't got the chance to try any pastry goodies, yet would definitely love to. But at this point, go for the fruit infusion tea and thank me later!

Pros: None.  Cons: The barista / cashier made me very uncomfortable... she was very fidgety and kept repeating our orders over and over. We only ordered two drinks and a sandwich... but she couldn't get any words out of her mouth and was talking very slow and then very fast. Honestly, it didn't seem like a normal nervousness to me and she seemed under the influence of something...  Disgusting Food: I ordered the croissant egg sandwich and the oils had soaked through the croissant. But that's sort of expected. Halfway through eating my food, my friends chai latte [finally after 15 minutes] comes. Seems she forgot.  And that's when I find a hair in my food. I have long black hair and my friend is blonde.  Disgusting. We left ASAP.

I love this little cafe. The coffee shop is bright, clean, and airy with an awesome mural on one of the walls. The employees I've met are all very friendly and helpful. Their coffee is great and I also recommend trying the acai and granola bowls, they're delicious!
Awesome spot to stop for a great cup of coffee! I had the Flat White and it was heavenly.

I was looking for a place to sit outside on a gorgeous morning before work, where I could have my morning croissant and cappuccino. Yelp sent me here, and it was disappointing on all levels. Most importantly, the "outside area" that is advertised on Yelp is just 2 benches and NO table, literally nowhere to put your coffee. The SMALL cappuccino I asked for was a huge cup of milk, even bigger than Starbucks. The chocolate croissant tasted like plastic and there was very little chocolate. And of course this was EXTREMELY overpriced, even for Manhattan, at $9 for just that. 2 stars only because it's in the West Village and there are beautiful people walking on the street.

I was hesitant to leave this review because I would not want to hinder the business of a small, local shop. However, I felt that the product I received was sufficiently bad to warrant my notifying other potential customers. I came in with one very simple drink in mind: an iced oat latte. I had checked another shops beforehand with no luck. Oat milk is currently burgeoning, but definitely still relatively rare. When I stepped in here, I was pleased to be informed that the shop does indeed carry oat milk! Unfortunately, that moment was the extent of my excitement here. My latte came out tasting dirty, as in the machine hadn't been cleaned in who knows how long. Having worked as a barista in the past, I'm very familiar with the taste. This is inexcusable considering coffee is a central product at this place. The extra star is for the friendly dude who refunded my money

Favorite cafe by far! Great food, friendly atmosphere, and great to do work at. The chai lattes they serve here are the best I've ever had. And the staff is always amazing and accommodating. They never fail to recognize me and really make 11th Street a place to return to.
Sandwich was so good, the soup, cookies, banana bread, egg plate, everything. Locating in west village. Haven't tried the coffee yet.

Let me start off saying I usually really like this place.  It's a little hole in the wall cafe' with good coffee and a great spot to get some work done. However today I was so disappointed in them I don't know if I'll return anytime soon.  My friend and I met here for lunch and she ordered a beet, ginger, and apple juice. About ten minutes later she started to feel really nauseous and asked if she could use their restroom.  The waitress said, "we don't have one." Okay weird, but whatever.  Another few minutes go by and my friend looked like she was going to be sick so she ran outside and had to throw up on the street. It was obviously all from the juice. I ran inside and told the waitress, "I think the juice my friend had was spoiled because she just threw up on the street. Can we please use the restroom now?" The waitress rolled her eyes and walked back to the restroom to "check on it." She walks back, "sorry, someone's in there, you should probably go somewhere else; and I doubt it was the juice because its fresh squeezed." Even though something is 'fresh squeezed' doesn't mean the fruit/veggies are 'fresh.'  I just couldn't believe they wouldn't help out a customer who just got sick from one of their products.    Now I agree with the other reviews, the staff was incredibly rude.

This place is a little off the beaten path, so that's a plus right there. When you walk in, it's small and rustic. It's cute. There isn't a lot of seating, but I have always been able to grab a table when I go there. I'm sure it depends what time you go though.  They also have a couple of benches outside so if you're able to snag them, it is a really nice place to sit outside on a beautiful day and people-watch. This is a great, peaceful street too.  I am giving them four stars because I really like the place and the atmosphere. (And most of the staff is nice, in my experience.) However, I had to update my original review because the coffee has not been good lately. I don't know why, but it's just...disappointing. I have not yet tried the lattes or cappuccinos. Maybe I should because the regular brewed coffee is just not "doing it" for me lately.  EDIT: (August 28th) They have changed coffee suppliers and they are now using Brooklyn Roasting Company! I was at 11th Street yesterday and MUCH happier with the coffee.  :) :)  The muffins, croissants, and other pastries have all been very good so far, and I had a really good egg sandwich on a wrap recently.  Another plus: they keep three pitchers of ice-cold water out on the counter (and cups), so you can easily stay hydrated while you're eating there and/or drinking hot beverages.  I love coming here!

3.5 Stars.  A nice little cafe/coffee shop in the middle of a nice residential neighborhood.  I stopped here for breakfast and a quite cup of coffee.  The staff was very nice - maybe the best part about this place.   I felt very welcome here and almost like I was invited to a neighbors house for breakfast.  Its a very small location with maybe 12 total seats, and its very crammed in.    The coffee was decent, but nothing special.  I also ordered the pesto, mozzerella scrambled eggs in a whole wheat wrap.  It was also decent, but again really nothing notable.  This was pretty forgettable, but not in a bad way necessarily.  They just serve decent breakfast and lunch at a decent price with decent coffee.  So if you are walking by, sure stop in, but don't go out of your way.
Excellent neighborhood coffee shop. In particular, the biscuit sandwiches are fantastic for breakfast. Good coffee too.

I generally like these guys and root for them to do well, as so many places in the west village are going under or falling victim to another fashion venue.  I like the egg dishes and the sandwiches and they make one of the better cups of coffee in the neighborhood.  They seem responsive to customer feedback. I only wish the place were bigger so I could get a seat more often, but I guess that would destroy the charm and intimacy!  P

Lattes are verrry good, chicken noodle soup is the the best i've ever had. I buy bags of coffee so I can make it at home as well. It's that good. Roast beef with chiptole mayo is delicous except I always get it with ham. Fried egg blt is really good on bread or in a wrap. love the food and drinks here.
The food is great! The service is some of the worst service anywhere. The wait is always long and more often than not the order is wrong.  The food and menu is what keeps me going back.
The curry tofu stew dish is to die for. The menu is fantastic in general, great atmosphere, definitely one of my favorite hangouts. The only downside is that it is a bit small.

I try to hit up this favorite coffee shop/eatery every time I am in the neighborhood. The friendly faces, superior service and tasty treats keep me coming back. Whether you are in the mood for awesome people watching, baked goods, seasonal eats or some seriously well made barista drinks this is my go-to-place.  For bevs, I usually order whatever I am in the mood for: dirty chai latte (best ever!), cappuccino, iced coffee (really quality stuff, not watered down Dunkin), vino or a high grav/craft beer. The baristas here really know what they're doing and you can tell that they use the good stuff.  For eats, everything here is fresh and thoughtfully prepared. They really get my vote because they use unexpected ingredients to avoid the 'typical' sandwich and salad selection at most joints. Plus, the menu is constantly changing so I never get bored. While I am not a veggie or vegan, I definitely respect that they have plenty of those options and they look so good on the menu, that I've ordered a few. One of my favorite things about this place is that if you're in a hurry, they offer delicious oatmeal and eggs in a cup to go...Don't forget the doughnuts!  The ONLY downfall about this place is that it's pretty small. Don't be alarmed by the size or the line that is probably running out the door during peak hours. It's totally worth the wait and they really move it along while maintaining their high level of customer service. Plus, the crowd is pretty great and you can make new friends with the crew or the customers in the intimate seating area. Bonus!
Excellent place tiny and so welcoming really nice decoration and feeling definitely a place to check

This place looks like it came fresh out of Los Angeles - its hipster, cookie-cutter design (white brick walls, metal seating and wooden tables) is not creative, albeit, perhaps refreshing, and definitely instagram-worthy.  I came here on a Saturday morning with my boyfriend, the place was almost empty. The first thing you'll notice is that the portion to price ratio is extremely asymmetrical. You're getting maybe twelve ounces of food for 12 dollars. For example, they had carrots and leaves in a jar for $12 and pesto pasta (which you could easily make 10x the amount of at home for ~$10) also for $12. The prices are ridiculous, but I guess this is West Village and Ancolie caters to the white mom and/or vegan culture.  I grabbed a $4, 8oz jar of yogurt with mango and my boyfriend had a $6 jar of yogurt with granola (this wasn't even filled up all the way!!!). We also got a baguette with ham and cheese inside (another $6) and I ordered a cappuccino ($4). The total came out to around $22 with tax but luckily I had a voucher that allowed me to get $20 worth of food for only $10. That is the only reason I'd ever eat at this place.  The jar concept is fun, but I feel as though it's a misleading tactic to overprice your food and give you tiny portions. There are so many great yogurt/salad/acai places nearby, do not come here on an empty stomach - you will still leave hungry.  The baguette with ham and cheese was a joke. 1 star for this. They "warmed" it up but the cheese wasn't melty at all and the ham was average. You can get high-quality baguettes + ham/cheese like this in Europe for a single euro.  The mango yogurt I got was yummy, but tiny. The yogurt parfait my boyfriend ordered ($6) was sub-par and not worth it.  The only thing I could actually ever stomach paying $4 for is the cappuccino. It was good coffee and came well-presented. Another bonus is getting to keep the fun little jars that the food comes in afterwards to reuse. If you give it back, you get $1 discount on your next purchase. (I won't be coming back so I kept my jar).

I popped into this place to kill some time and ordered a iced chai latte and a cold mint tea for my boyfriend. We had to cancel the mint tea order because only had hot tea and said it would take a while to cool it down (??). My iced chai was terrible. No flavor, watered down (I'm not sure how it got watered down so quickly) and it also had some of those milk specks in it from the milk jug (or maybe bits of sour milk?) It was also $6, super overpriced. The menu says there is a $2 jar deposit, so I thought, fine, I'll get $2 back when I return the jar. A $4 chai is totally normal. However, when I returned the jar, I was given the choice of a token to receive $2 off on my next visit or keeping the jar. This should be disclosed on the menu or by the cashier before a purchase is made. I knew I wouldn't be going back since my drink was so bad and I didn't really need the jar. I ended up taking the jar and leaving annoyed that I paid for a really terrible drink.

Stumbled upon Ancolie on the way to a meditation class -- and I am SO glad that I did. My mom and I were visiting from out of town for the weekend and this was one of the highlights of our trip.  It is great to see a movement of simplicity: getting away from waste, avoiding plastic, and  encouraging clean, healthy eating (while STILL enjoying delicious food)!  We had the granola parfait and a scone the first day we visited. Both were delightful. The best treat was the coconut milk latte that I am still dreaming about. We also stopped here to stock up on lunch for our ride back home. The jars were the perfect travel meal!

There was an Ancolie cafe at SUPERFINE! Art Fair in the Meatpacking District and I was obsessed with their iced coffee in the giant glass jars. I'm so picky about my iced coffee, and this is so, so good. I didn't get to try the food but I kept hearing how tasty it was. The French style and quality takes me back to St. Bart's, it really reminds me of my recent trip there. I can't wait to come to the cafe in the West Village and check it out!

Nice quiet place for a bite before heading to the Vanguard a block away.  For a French customer, this is a little home away from home and the enthusiastic and welcoming chef / owner will draw you in to her secret hideout on 8th street nested between busy 6th avenue and McDougal. In stark contrast to the loud restaurants and bars on the rest of the block, Ancolie is where you take a break and enjoy a moment of peace.  The salads are currently the main draw: colorful, fresh, tastefully seasoned and originally layered like an English trifle in a glass jar. I was very pleased with my rainbow salad and will return to try the others. Looking forward to seeing this new eatery take roots in its new neighborhood.

Ancolie serves fresh, French food in glass jars. The owner (and her husband) are delightful and the food is as fresh as it gets. The butternut squash and lentil soups were to die for and the parsnip in the winter salad is amazing. I also love the rainbow salad for a healthy dose of colorful veggies. Her grandmother's brownie is also delicious. I live down the street and have been going pretty frequently. I love the concept of not having waste when I get take out. The jars are so elegant and so easy to slip into my bag to go and I just use a silver fork when I get home - it's much more enjoyable. I also brought a few jars back for a discount on my next purchase which was a great perk. Excited to bring some jars home to my parent's for the long Thanksgiving weekend!

Lovely little coffee shop and patisserie with flaky croissants but give me a break! WHERE is the chocolate in a pain au chocolate? Love sitting outside on one of the little benches sipping coffee, which was fair. No need to come back.
Only two things are good here - atmosphere and music. Coffee and patisserie are very average and expensive.

Tiny cafe nestled in the UES. I stumbled upon this during my afternoon walk and loved the iced coffee! I can always appreciate a cafe that gives me light ice without me asking!  Didn't get to try, but they had a reasonable array of dessert options (macaroons, eclairs, the fancy pancy stuff). Not a big fan of that variety, but I would like to come back and try their other caffeinated drinks!
Goat cheese and pear sandwich was really good! Cranberries in the bread, the pear was sweet and smooth, the cheese okay and the arugula fresh and peppery.

Who can walk past a patisserie without stopping in?! We were working our way through town for the holiday weekend and spotted this cozy place. We just wanted a quick sweet bite so as to not fill up on our way to where we were going. I ordered a little baguette sandwich with mozzarella and sun dried tomatoes. The taste was great, but unfortunately they had heated it up in the paper so it was all stuck to the melted cheese and it was hard to peel off. I may have eaten some of it... The canele was good, if you aren't a fan of flan flavored things though they can taste a little eggy. This had a nice, mildly sweet taste. Last but not least, we had a blueberry mousse. I was worried it would be a case of too pretty to eat, but it was actually not bad. The first couple bites tasted like blueberry Philadelphia cream cheese but it grew on me. I couldn't quite pick out the coconut or pistachio, but the dessert definitely got better towards the end. The petals tasted like lucky charm marshmallows. This place was nice for a treat, definitely not an every day thing, but a nice treat.
Delicious quiche and sandwiches,  and excellent tarts. Mediocre coffee, though.  A wonderful place to stop on the upper East side. Can get very crowded though,  so grab a table when you can.

Living down the street in the UES, I've been searching for two specific things-- an excellent place for espresso, and the perfect macaron-- clearly so that I could enjoy both together in a lovely place. Bel Ami is perfect and delightful. It is small and intimate, yet efficient and has a very calming atmosphere. The wedding almond macaron is the single most delicious macaron I've ever had. Highly recommended.

Small and cozy cafe with nice staff and great coffee! Stopped here one day to have some lunch (sweet potato, goat cheese, and cranberry salad) with a soy milk latte. There is some seating so I sat for a bit with my laptop and did some homework. (No outlets for charging though.) Will definitely come back again :)

Not sure how this place has 2 dollar signs. I got a small lemon tart, it was $7. To make matters worse, it was served on a paper plate and they only have plastic silverware. Try as I might I couldn't cut into the tart. I had to keep picking it up to eat. While the tart was good, this place put a bad taste in my mouth.

This place is the crown of Upper East Side caf̩s. From the tasteful and impeccable interior to their fresh selection of French pastries to the delicious La Colombe coffee they use this place is perfect. There are only a few tables so try not to come around lunch time this place is a very popular among locals and the employees on Madison Avenue. As for the macarons, they provide plenty of competition to La Dur̩e. If you want to go to a cafe on the UES this is only the place. Really fun service as well, try to engage them in small talk they're full of stories.

Great look coffee shop with really friendly staff. Got a dry cappuccino. The coffee was good, but it wasn't really a dry cappuccino. Pastries were great too, but a little pricey. All in all a great coffee shop, definitely someplace I'd visit again.
Fabulous service! I had a ham baguette, pumpkin macron, and cafe au lait; it was the perfect portion for breakfast. I was impressed with the location and decor.

Quaint little, and I mean little, cafe with bench seating outside. It's not your typical Starbucks and it's a cozy, classy do-up place to fill up on your caffeine fix. I personally love these places, even if they do come across a bit snobbish because their coffees are usually worth it.
Love this place! Delicious drinks and amazing desserts/lunch food. Best macarons of my life. Also, very moderately priced especially considering the location.

Was shopping at the Celine store 2 blocks away this evening and needed a bathroom stat due to a womanly emergency, and the sales associate who was assisting me told me that there are no bathrooms in the store! She immediately directed me over to Bel Ami. The owner was so kind to let me use it for the emergency, and after everything was sorted out, I decided to purchase something to thank him... Picked out 4 macaroons - nutella, salted caramel, jasmine, and vanilla. All were super delicious and their sizes were much bigger than the Laduree ones across the street. Even though Laduree is still on top of my list, I will definitely come back to this cute cafe to try their coffee, pastries, and more delicious macaroons !
Love this charming little place! Great latte and delicious pastries!

It's just ok. There is nothing redeeming about this place. Cold brew is their only defining product but for nothing else justifies their  exorbitant prices.  The oat milk they have used, consistently chunks at the bottom of the cup. The iced green tea is more like green tea flavored water. If they run out of green tea, they just pour water into your cup, I have seen this.  The shop is their best asset, the products, not so much. I would take my money to La Colombe which is just on the other side of the Deutsche Bank lobby doors on Wall.

The cup of coffee is see-through, not a good sign. It's indeed as weak as I thought it'd be based on the translucent liquid. The cold brew is slightly better with maybe two shades darker brown compared to the drip. It also was a smidgen better in flavor, definitely less acidic than some coffee shops found across the boroughs. Flat white was better than anything we ordered so that's a plus.  They had to close early due to a staff meeting, which is rather odd to do but it's their turf so fiiiiiine. Place wasn't selling good coffee anyway so it wasn't tragic that we had to leave. What is tragic is the brew. Basically I was lead down this path in search of an excellent cup of coffee, but alas, I was lead down with lies.

Great Australian style coffee shop with a great selection of really tasty pastries/food but misleadingly claim to have free WiFi on their yelp page.  To be clear, there is no WiFi here.  Happy to delete this post/re-review if they fix this misinformation.

Tldr: in my opinion, Black Fox is good for dates but NOT regular visits. Overall better than Starbucks or the numerous NYC chains but is not a standout  Pros: Very spacious with room to sit down The space looks really nice Music isn't overpoweringly loud Cons: Prices suck Servers have a hipster look tht turns me off (a straw brim hat and that long ass beard? Really bro?? Dress more professionally) Coffee is meh (I found it weak and acidic) Internet is garbage, do not come here to work

Black Fox Coffee makes a good pot of coffee, and it better be at $3.50 for a small.  The exquisite Art Deco building at 70 Pine provides a backdrop fit for a high powered film noir meeting over hushed tones with hell bent urgency, and that'll be exactly how you'll feel with all the Wall St pretension of working lap toppers.    It's a scene, and you can be apart of it at the cost of $8 for a breakfast sandwich or $4 for a muffin, think of it as a built in cover charge or the subtle wrath of fire from a voluptuous femmes fatale.  From a misty shadow - "You might be asking me why I asked you here."

Black Fox Coffee is a perfect breakfast or coffee break option for those working on Wall Street. I stopped in here for an iced Americano and a breakfast sandwich before starting my work day and was not disappointed. The seating area was surprisingly crowded for an early morning, but there were still plenty of seats open. I opted out for grabbing a window seat and watched people hurry by outside as I enjoyed my sandwich. The croissant was flaky and perfectly toasted, while the sharp cheddar and ham added just the right amount of flavor. After sneaking in a quick chapter of my book as I finished my coffee, I felt relaxed and ready to start my work day. Overall, very nice experience.

Excellent coffee and a very cool, sleek, hipster place...as most of these kinds of coffee shops are. Yes, it's expensive but the coffee quality and the service are very good. They also offer breakfast and lunch items, and there's a decent amount of seating room so it's not a grab-and-go place.

Nice coffee spot. Has more room than I expected. One thing I wasn't a huge fan of was that people with laptops could only sit at a certain part of the coffee shop. I wouldn't recommend if you're trying to use your computer to get work done.
Came for brunch with family- arrived at 2:02 and told that kitchen closed at 2. Place stays open until 3- are you people serious?? In NYC??? I discourage anyone to go until they change their hours.
Love this place. Haven't been here in awhile. Got my usual, iced espresso and some breakfast! Very high quality. Not cheap but worth it if you'd like a treat!

If you want FANTASTIC coffee, good vibes, fresh healthy foods, try this place! These folks KNOW their coffee! Baristas are so professional and I really appreciate that because they respect the art of making coffee, they're passionate, extremely knowledgeable and work so, so hard. Try out different things, they love to try new menu items and they always have the best recommendations! Really passionate and creative atmosphere. BEST place to start your day  P.S they have lots of milk alternatives and GF pastries :)))  Pro Tip: if it's crowded on a day you try it out or if you're ever in a rush, order before through the  "RITUAL" app. But I'd still recommend dining-in one day because their interior design and flowers are phenomenal. Love them!
The best of the best! They use the best machine, super beans it is worth the stop. Best coffee I've had in Manhattan by far not to mention a great atmosphere for hanging out.

Busy, cozy vibe and top notch coffee and pastry selection. Walked in on a snowy afternoon to a bustling shop full of delicious aromas and holiday songs. The staff was friendly and drinks came out surprisingly quickly given how busy they were. Seat space is limited though there is plenty of standing area.

It's not everyday I feel like a millionaire but damn did I feel fancy drinking a latte at Black Fox. This would absolutely have been a 5 star review if it wasn't for the price. Black Fox is a great place to spend a Saturday or Sunday morning. Between the atmosphere and the presentation of the drinks, I definitely recommend stopping by at least once...even if it's only for the Instagram.

Top notch coffee and teas. I would say the best that far downtown.  Start with one of their single origin espressos and then mellow out with a filter coffee or tea.  I've been there several times for lunch and have never been disappointed with the salads or sandwiches.  The staff is very attentive as well. Excellent experience.
My favorite coffee place in the city. Their homemade nut milk is amazing, staff is friendly, coffee is strong and delicious.

Very good coffee and ambiance. Right across the street from Deutsche Bank.. this cafe is hidden behind Wall Street, but those who know it, make the trip into the backstreets for their great espresso.  I love the wide selection of pastries too. Where else can you find mini bundt cakes? They also have cookies that rival Levain.

Very cool look and feel in this airy coffee shop right off of the Wall St 2/3 stop. I like trying new places and I try to keep it simple so I can find the best at what I like :)  Staff are very warm and friendly. I was scanning the the baked goods in the open case and sadly while they all look delish there were just too many flies landing for my liking :(. Not giving up, I ordered an item from the menu "70 Pine Bagel" and a large drip coffee. I'm in the food biz and open baked good cases are a tough thing to monitor in the season of the fly so I'm not counting them out on the food front yet.  Drip coffee is incredibly aromatic and when it gets to a gulping point I'm sure it won't stand a chance lol.  Fancy presentation of bagel and the pickled onion smells amazing!  UPDATE- just finished my bagel and it was AMAZING!! Still can't give 5 stars because of the fly issue, but my morning is solid thanks to this amazing weather and breakfast
Chicken burger was amazing !!! Maple donut super tasty as well.  Melted hot chocolate was just OK.

I buy coffee beans here and make my own pour over in the morning. They run more of a coffee curation service than a roaster service. The choice of beans is great and always rotating. The staff is super friendly and Jonathan makes amazing coffee. Besides bubbly baristas, a modern and clean interior with high ceilings, they have these devilishly delicious chocolate cookies (which on occasion are under baked) but so melt in your mouth irresistible. They actually make a mean flat white and cortado so come enjoy a cup though it will set you back the FiDi cost of a coffee. Oh they also have specialty drinks like a coffee tonic which is a good change up. The venue can be hard to find, look for the sign posted on the sidewalk.  Pro tip. Watch your step on your way in or your smile might meet the floor faster than you can say coffee.
What an amazing cafe! The coffee is brilliant, the staff is so kind, and the food is delicious. I don't travel his way often, but I will now because of this cafe

Lovveee Black Fox!!  Checked this coffee shop out because I found it on Yelp and was so glad I did.  When you walk in there is bar seating across the window and some seating on the left, very cute, it definitely has a rustic industrial feel to it.  The ceilings are really high which makes the room feel really spacious and airy.  I ordered an iced latte and chocolate chip cookie to go.  Latte was really good, it had a rich and bold flavor that left me wanting me.  I'm definitely more of a tea person, but the fact that I loved the latte should really say something.  The cookie was delicious!!!  It was decadent and had nuts in it to add some texture, but it was one of the best cookies i've ever had (seriously), it reminds me of the kind I make at home. Prices are what you would expect for FiDi and the staff is unbelievably friendly.  I will absolutely be back and will be bringing friends!!  A must check out if you're in FiDi NYC.

Great selection of coffee roasters. 49th, Ritual, Heart... The shots are served a little long in my opinion. I used to frequent Ritual and they pulled tighter, sweeter shots but I'm finding more and more that long shots are a New York style that need to find their way out. (But with some of the lightest roasts in the business you should be focusing on those fruits and not pulling all the acidity) Spirit by Kees Van der Westen. V-60s. Fetco. The decor is cool. Food seems nice. Staff is friendly. Clientele is hit and miss, but that area is a hot bed of a'holes, so it's kind of a weird spot for one the more sophisticated coffee ops in NY.

I had the cold brew (aces) and the granola (amazing, had edible flower petals!) and sat in the gorgeous space in a strange new building on pine.  far and away the best option for breakie and coffee in fidi.

They have great coffee and nice staff. Well, a little pricy. It's Fido. I give it 3 stars bc their scramble egg needs a lot improvement. It was just a lump of Truth is everything related to egg needs improvement.
Cool trendy coffee shop. Good pastries, chia pudding,  parfaits , bagels and coffees.  Clean modern and nice!
Really enjoyed the bean selection. Very nice ambience, coffee was great, and the croissant was great. Great example of a well done coffee shop.

Get the chocolate chip walnut cookie!!!! It reminds me of the Levain cookie, its so good. I'm so glad I live around the corner from here because their coffee, food, and overall store aesthetic is incredible. I usually get the flat white or cold brew and both super high quality. The people who work here are also very friendly!
I would give 5 stars for the goodies but 3 stars because of price.  $8 for a croissant? Really?

I am sitting here with possibly the worst cup of coffee I have ever had in my life - and that includes the one I got at the truck stop in Kansas where I saw a guy in a "Keep America White" t-shirt eat 18 White Castle sliders in under five minutes. Never before have I felt so bitter (much like the taste of this coffee) about wasting six (!!!) dollars on a "large" almond milk latte (which is only 12 ounces because everyone knows that anything generous enough to make you happy is against the Hipster Code of Self-Imposed Ironic Deprivation and Ennui). I'd ask for my money back, but I don't think the baristas can hear me, as their heads seem to be inserted very far up into a place where the sun doesn't shine. Apparently instead of asking "Do you have any cinnamon," which merited the blankest stare since Professor Lockhart got his memory wiped, I should have asked "Do you know when the aliens are coming to wipe this pit of sadness and shame from the face of the earth" - perhaps that at least may have given me a tiny sip (still probably larger than this coffee) of satisfaction.
Awesome coffee, spacious space (Manhattan standards), decent variety of internationally roasted and sourced coffee beans. Hurry up and decide to also open on weekends!

Good coffee but nothing to rave about - didn't particularly taste like gourmet or artisanal. Super expensive for regular coffee and when you add in food, it gets pretty high up there. $10-12+ for sandwich? On the other hand, good vibe and friendly staff.
Beautiful and spacious cafe area. Bien Cuit baking goods are hard to find. They carry the most delicious pastries. Great coffee! Excellent barista!

This is one of many specialty coffee shops in the area, so I was curious to see how it compared. I stopped in for an after lunch latte w/ oat milk. I noticed someone before me had their order remade remarking, "much better!" before leaving. Without considering said scenario, I put a lid on my cup and walked out the door. When I got to the stoplight and took a sip, I was surprised by the rancid taste.  I would not return given the more reliable options in the neighborhood.

Used to be very good but service has gone down a notch in Murray Hill recently with the opening of the UWS location. Because the staff rotate between the 2 locations, sometimes it feels like the UWS centric staff picked up the UWS attitude and view our neighborhood as an annoyance...  Case and point, this location used to advertise that they're dog friendly. Then, a barista who moved to the UWS location told me that it's actually "breaking the rules" to allow dogs. I've been to this place before their bathroom opened! I was in this place when they had dogs welcomed stickers on their door! I was buying coffee here even before this person was hired! But I guess the place doesn't care about the way they're turning away East Side customers anymore (and it wasn't even about what was said but how it was said...).  Guess no more midday coffee stops here for me. Bye Black Press.

I happened upon this place last week really by accident.  I'd never even heard of it.  Glad I did.  The coffee was excellent.  I had a latte that was pulled and steamed to perfection.  The barista was nice.  I didn't have a pastry, but they did have a selection. I'll be returning when in this area.

Coffee is life. Super basic coffee chick looking to find cool cafes with good lighting for photos and great tasting coffee and Black Press is definitely another one of those cafes that has both. Last time I came in I just ordered a medium drip with almond milk and the barista, who was super friendly put the almond milk out for me to pour in, which never happens and I appreciated it because my idea of a splash of almond milk is usually not the same as the baristas idea of a splash. Didn't have any food here, not even sure if they have food but if you're looking for a good cup of coffee definitely check this place out. They have punch cards like most coffee shops have in the area, buy 10 get the 11th free kind of thing.

I LOVE THIS PLACE!!! I went here every day since they opened on Friday until I left NYC.  I will be back on my next trip.  If you love coffee this is the place to go to.  The cold brew, cortado, lattes and teas are all amazing (The chai latte is the best I've had!).  The pastries and cookies are all super fresh and very tasty.  The baristas and the owner are all very friendly.  The decor is very nice -industrial chic.   I can't say enough great things about this place!

We wanted a place for a quick cup of coffee and a pastry on an early Sunday morning, and this place was perfect: no line, great coffee, nice background music and decor. My husband said, "This is maybe the best coffee I've ever had." My almond croissant was rich and buttery. The affable man behind the counter said they're just starting their second month in business. My son and daughter enjoyed the place, too. I'd go again.
Great vibe. Staff was excellent, very friendly. Would be my go-to Americano if I lived in the area

Some of the best coffee I've had in a while. And the spot itself looks great--clean design, feels open and just the right amount of warm. Prices seem a little lowered than elsewhere as well.  Nice work guys.

I was honestly really disappointed with Blue Stripes, which is a pity since I live two minutes away and was hoping it would become one of my go-to caf̩s.  I came in for lunch to work a bit and ordered the avocado tartine with manchego. Along with a small Pellegrino, the total came to be over $18 once tip was involved. I realized that optional tip they recommended must have been including the tax, which bugged me since they didn't give you an estimate, just the percentage on the machine. It wasn't the end of the world, but just more expensive than I would have liked.  The avocado toast itself was great, though only a single piece of bread.  But what really bothered me was that about 45 minutes after I sat down, I was asked to put away my computer because the caf̩ was getting "too crowded."  This really frustrated me--because though I do dislike people who camp out for hours after buying a small coffee, I do feel like paying nearly $20 should have entitled me to at least an hour to work.  I also would have been more than happy to share my table with someone, but apparently that did not matter.  So, sure this place is cute and I might venture back to grab a chocolate treat and then go. But for anyone hoping for a lunch, know that I had really just wished I had gone to the Butcher's Daughter instead. It would have cost less, and I would not have left feeling cheated.

I'm so happy I had my friend take me to this coffee spot! Hidden from the main streets surrounding the location, my friend and I met in Union Square Park and were deciding where to go to grab a coffee and catch up. He told me he had seen this cafe a few times coming and going from classes at Parsons and suggested we go there.  I'm not sure when this location opened, but it's an extremely impressive space. Clean, modern, and open they had several high top tables along the right side of the space, with one large table towards the front of the cafe perfect for working on your laptop, as well as comfortable chairs in the back for reading and/or working. It definitely seems like the ideal space for students from Parsons, the New School, or NYU to come and do work at.  The menu was also very diverse! An assortment of pastries and staple cafe foods allowed for you to satisfy your sweet tooth or to fill up on a savory snack. My friend and I just had a regular hot cup of coffee ($3.50) but I'd definitely go back to try a few different thinks on their menu.  Service was also fast and efficient. Several people behind the bar made for the quick taking of drink orders, along with the speedy turnaround of getting drinks out.  Overall a really cool place to catch up with a friend over coffee or plug in your earphones and dive straight into your work. Highly recommended!

We got the hot chocolate and the shake. They were out of clean glasses for the shake so they put it in a plastic one.  Both were delicious but the shake was pretty amazing.  Although pricey it's worth it!

Trendy, incredibly comforting, and unique cafe serving chocolate treats (owned by same people as Max Brenner's), cacao bowls and shakes (more on the healthy side), pastries, and coffee/tea/hot chocolate.  I came on a rainy day and the cafe was just something different than all the other 500+ cafes in NYC. It definitely has a focus towards the sweets, but I loved how they balanced their menu with shakes and bowls that were made from the cacao fruit.  Theres a good amount of seating and some with outlets + wifi making it a perfect place to work or catch up with friends. I definitely would like to come back to try some of their more hearty food as well!
The Nutella filled croissant covered in milk chocolate is the best croissant I have had in my life, even better than the ones that I had in Paris !
Decadent, rich and simply delish.  Get a small because you will be overwhelmingly satisfied with a lesser portion.  Great space and friendly staff as well.

I absolutely LOVE Blue Stripes!!!! Everything on their menu is amazing!! Yes I've tried everything from the tartines to the fondue to the tasty pastries to the decadent beverages. I get a lot of visitors from out of town who typically ask about Max Brenners, but I defer them to Blue Stripes because it's sooo much better!  The owner did a fantastic job re-inventing his chocolate shop and keeping that NY feel. He's super nice too!!

My friend turned me on to Blue Stripes. It's run by Max Brenner, who has the restaurant and chocolate shop near Union Square, but Blue Stripe is like a cozy cafe. It's very "hygge." In fact, my friends and I were trying to figure out what we like about it so much -- yes the desserts are delicious, the snacks are good, they use chocolate in new ways, the lighting is good, the staff is friendly. It's not perfect, but there is just something about the energy in the place that makes it very welcoming. They have good music, good light, plenty of seats, but the whole is more than the sum of its parts. This would be a good place to catch up with a friend or to read a good book. In fact, there is a giant bookshelf full of books! It also has beautiful murals, too. Go there, get a cacao milkshake/smoothy thing, and take a break from life and be nurtured for a few minutes.

Found this gem while taking a walk in this lovely NYC weather.  I absolutely loved the atmosphere, friendly & quick staff, not to mention their food/ drink selection. I've never come across CBD powder as "shots" for my favorite drinks. I highly recommend it! Not only was the hot tea delicious, it was so relaxing. Stop by whenever you're in the Union Square area and see what I mean!

I've had coffee here now three times, and I have just not been impressed.   I either drink an espresso, a cortado or a macchiato depending on the coffee shop, their ability to make said drinks, and the time of year (winter, fall, spring, summer, etc.) This place apparently does some sort of spin off of a "flat white" that they call a "magic".  When I order a cortado, I expect a cortado, a classic one, not a "play" on a flat white (per their website description).  Too much milk in it.  A cortado should have one or two shots of espresso and a small amount of steamed milk to cut the acidity. This magic drink seems to have way too much milk, so much so that it seems like I'm drinking a cappuccino.  Simply too long of a drink.  In short, if you're not going to serve classic cortados, your customers should know beforehand, not after they've paid almost $5.00 for a drink.  I also found whoever the person was straightening up this morning obnoxious.  I kept moving away from him because they had music blasting and he's humming all about right in peoples' ears.  After I got my drink and got an explanation as to what in the hell a "magic" was, then I had to wait for this same guy to clean up the coffee area.  How about you do that AFTER people finish with their coffee....  Here I am with my cortado waiting for him to finish cleaning up.  Coffee is meant to be consumed immediately, not have it sit there after it's been prepared.

Great avocado toast however I ordered my toast (and paid for) with tomatoes. Once I got back to my office I realized that my toast was lacking the one extra I added, and paid for. This location is definitely lacking listening skills.
When this location opened up across the street it instantly became my new go-to coffee place.  Emily is also a great server
Friendly staff, great cappuccinos, and a good selection of baked goods - banana bread and brownies are especially good. Very fast service in spite of being busy at certain times on weekdays
As I already wrote- best coffee in the area with positive vibe. Service is personable and friendly. Love to start my day here

Our first couple of experiences here were great. We got lucky with awesome servers and food was pretty on point. We decided to make this a go-to spot and came a few times after this but sadly each time, it kinda went downhill.  First, the restaurant gets kinda dirty, the seats aren't clean, lots of crumbs and lint. We had to ask for cutlery to be replaced as it was dirty and my latte had a small hair in it....so yuck....server replaced it but still charged me for it which was a bummer because I obviously couldn't enjoy the rest of my meal after that.  It's a small place so I get it's hard to clean while people are dining but it's a brand new place and already getting dingy. Their hours were also spotty, we called to see what time the kitchen closed and they said 530pm.....we rushed down to make it there by 510pm and they said they closed the kitchen early and we couldn't be served. When we explained that we called to make sure, they weren't apologetic or anything considering it was their mistake. Bummer. We won't be back.

Food ok, but under seasoned.  Bacon good. No salt  or pepper on eggs, which should be cooked with butter, no salt, or maybe lemon or something on avocado, which was bland and disappointing.   Hugely overpriced and over rated. And they force you to pay with a credit card, which is incredibly annoying. Might just as well go to local deli or Irving farms round the corner which is not as overpriced.

This place is very nice, and aesthetically beautiful. The service was absolutely great. The waiter was very nice. The prices were usual compared to other places in the city, but certainly more expensive compared to suburban breakfast spots. The macchiato was so small, I thought it would come with milk, in a bigger cup. They also didn't have any flavor shots. The food was okay. I had the half avocado toast and the parfait plate. And my friend had a breakfast bowl, which had a lot more greens in it than quinoa and egg. But, overall it was a nice place. And I would recommend visiting.

Id go 3.5 if poss.  Pros are all our food was satisfying and tasty.  Cons are slow service cramped space and cred cards only.  Also reg coffee is served in these absurd glass carafes that not only burn your fingers when you lift them but do not keep the coffee hot.  Seriously?

GORGEOUS place with AMAZING food! The decor is beautiful and the cocktails are delicious with a great food menu as well! This is for sure going to be my new favorite spot for lunch and brunch!  And the service was outstanding as well! Josh took great care of us and was an amazing server! The manager was very nice and he kept checking on us to make sure we were having a good experience.  Hands down best place in UWS right now!
Arguably the best cafe ever! The customer service was amazing and the food was delicious. The coffee was definitely the highlight of my experience:) Making this place my new spot!

I have been to this location multiple times, so feel it's time to write a fair review. It pains me to say this because I love some of their other locations, but AVOID, AVOID, AVOID AT ALL COSTS. I was so happy to have them in the neighborhood, as I love their avo smash and am used to traveling to the West Village for it. This location is an absolute sh**show. Honestly, one star is a generous rating. Not ONCE have I received adequate service there. The space itself is absolutely cramped- there is not one comfortable seat in the whole place; which, given the price of their items, is frankly unacceptable and reflects poorly on the greedy owners. I reluctantly went again this morning with a friend who wanted to try it and as per usual was quoted a wait time of 15 minutes that ended up being 30. The service here is always confusing (you don't have a server, you basically just have to wave down the nearest person who looks like they work there and hope they see you), but never as astonishingly bad as it was today. Our food came out an hour after ordering, and our server was nowhere to be found. Eventually, I got up and asked her to check on our food. She seemed irritated but said sure, and proceeded not to check on our food and not check in with us either. My friend ordered the rainbow bowl with salmon, and the salmon was inedibly raw. We sent it back, and asked that they not bring us out another salmon because we had already waited so long for the food. No apologies from her at all. 15 minutes later, she brought out another salmon despite our wishes. We had a good laugh but were not at all surprised when THIS salmon was raw as well- like what?! We sent it back yet again and requested it be taken off the bill- a VERY reasonable request considering it was inedible both times. Our server literally disappeared and so we finally packed up and went to the host to pay our bill. Surprise surprise, the salmon was not taken off of the bill. When I told the host who brought our bill about the "atrociously bad service" we received, he said "I know, I know." There were no discounts provided for us on our bill despite the horrible experience we had. I literally swear I will never, ever be back; and everyone I know who wants to go here will be warned.  OH, and to top it all off, my friend who consumed the salmon has FOOD POISONING. Jesus Christ.

I love love love the food at Bluestone. I first went on the day they opened and they definitely had some kinks to work out. Seemed like they didn't do a test run at all. It was really disorganized seating people, various people kept coming to our table to ask the same thing, and the music was SO loud you couldn't hear yourself talk. I asked them to turn it down, but with all the people working, someone should have really had the sense to take initiative on that. Looking around, others were disturbed by the music volume too. It was truly unbearable. Again, I love the food but the experience left something to be desired. I do want to say that my complaints were totally openly received by the manager and all the staff was really nice. And the design of the place is beautiful!

Pros: - Food seems pretty healthy. - This place seems to emphasize nutrition over taste, which is refreshing.  Cons - What I had tasted pretty bland - They employ weird tricks to you to tip more, like defaulting to 18% without an option of 10% or 15%, and calculating tip based on the sales tax, which as far as I know is against the rules.

I was so so SO excited to find this place the last time I visited New York. I studied abroad in Australia for a few months and it was so nostalgic to find an Australian brunch place. So I HAD to go!  This place, like most Australian brunch spots, is super aesthetic, colorful, modern and sleek. One thing you must note before coming here is that the space itself is tiny, like TINY. So be prepared to squeeze through the restaurant and bump into a few people. At first I didn't know this was a chain, so that's helpful to note as well. Also, due to the small size of the resto, wait times can be a bit long. So be prepared!  My friend and I both got flat whites. I ordered an avocado toast and added bacon and a poached egg to it. I forgot what my friend ordered but we really enjoyed our meal! We were sitting really close to the parties next to us so expect that as well. Also this place is pretty pricey for brunch (welcome to NY) but it was a nice meal to splurge on. This place is a hit.

Came here on a Thursday for a brunch, I was only able to finish half of the meal, the portion is quite large. I ordered the BL Big Brekkie which is $19 that I think it's a little over priced, I liked the smashed avocado and kale. Loved the latte and the atmosphere, very chill and relaxing.
Great food and cool vibe. Service a little slow but worth the wait and the servers are pleasant.
Great cafe, great food, great coffee, great service. Found this little gem whilst travelling from Sydney Australia and it reminded me of home loved this place.

Maybe I'm the only one, but what's the hype. Overpriced avacado toast is a thing I guess. Friendly servers, cozy environment and love the ambience. To be honest, loved the place more than the food. Got hot peppermint tea, which was good. And their pancakes are good. Their bread portions are huge, but still think it'd overpriced.

JVA AI Non-Salad Options - 5/5 AI Accommodation - 5/5  They have many standard non-salad AI options.  So, I was actually torn on what to get.  They also easily swap out regular bread for GF bread.  The GF bread was really yummy.  I initially wanted the avocado smash with a side of chicken, but they ran out of chicken.  Huh?!  That's a 0/5.    So, instead, I went with the Bekkie Board, which is half portion of avocado smash (I ordered it on GF bread and without tomatoes, ie nightshade veggie) and half portion of apple-soaked overnight oats.  Both were delicious.  Although, I think that the portions were much larger than half, as I could barely get through half of the oats.  They also have almond milk, which I got with the coffee.  If you are AI, this is an easy choice for brunch!

Wow the food here is delicious and healthy! I tried the brekkie board (avo smash and yogurt) and kale salad. Although everyone raves about the avo smash, the homemade yogurt with granola stole the show. Also spotted Tom Lipinski from Suits eating here!  Only downside with this place is that it's quite expensive. $15 for avocado toast??

The food is good the Coffee is good. Starting to feel like a chain! It was 8am and felt like club was pumping. When I asked the music to be changed or turned down becoi was with a friend and wanted to talk I received A millennial moron comment of "this is how the preparation wants it." I live in the west village and will now give my money to Buvette or Maison Kaiser.

Holy avocado toast this place is a Golden nugget sent straight from the heavens above.  This place makes Starbucks look like a bad joke. For a comparable price you can get coffee so delicious it'll make your knees weak. I've searched all over Nyc for a perfect iced mocha latte and this place is the winner. ( previously a little place in Bk was my #1 for the better part of 2 years). Aussies do everything better.
Bluestone is awesome! One of the best avocado toasts in the city, and generally cool vibes. The banana bread and lattes are also amazing. A go-to West Village spot for sure!

I tried to eat at Bluestone at least 3 times before, for brunch... I won't go into details, but I'd like to highlight that every time me (or someone from my party) had to deal with the host's attitude... anyway, I decided to give it one last chance last Saturday at 2pm.  Their Mocha Coffee is fantastic, I had the salmon and the prosciutto toasties. A bit too much of cream cheese, but the jam made a nice contrast with the salty slice of smoked salmon. The prosciutto was good too, the toast was crunchy and warm. For dessert I had the banana bread with whipped cream and honey, this is the reason why I would go back to Bluestone.  Our waiter basically forgot everything we ordered each time he approached to ask if we were ok, but that's ok... (I guess)  Overall, nice spot in Greenwich ave, it just need to work better regarding their staff.

Had a really nice brunch here with a few friends. We were seated across from James Franco and had the cutest server named Alden. Great ambiance and the avocado toast with prosciutto was a real win. There is a super cozy secluded back room that's great for large groups.

Stopped in for a late lunch on Saturday. The place was hopping. Got a seat after 5 minutes. Decent service, good coffee and very good food. My only complaint is that it did take an unusually long time to receive my food.

On a bitterly cold Thursday, we ventured to the Neue Museum on 5th Ave. - too early as it tuned out, so we (2 adults, 2 teen girls) looked for coffee and brekkie at 10am.  Happened on this amazing hole is wall of a church at E90th - and it was clearly sent from Aussie heaven.  We had the best coffees ever in our admittedly limited experience in NYC, and choked down on breakfast bowls of quinoa, tomatoes, avacadoes, feta.... as well as avocado smash on toast.  It was perfect.  The lovely and kooky Aussie servers were not perfect, but their attitude and exhuberance made up for it in abundance.  We will definitely return on our next trip.  Cheers!

Let's start with the fact that Bluestone Lane was crowded on a Friday morning (everyone might have been hiding from the rain).  The indoor area was very cozy, but unfortunately it was full.  There was outdoor seating that was covered and under heaters so it wasn't too bad to sit there.  Ordered the Baked Green Eggs which was only okay and a latte which was good! What got this review to 4 stars though was definitely their service.  Even though my latte was forgotten at first, the server was very apologetic and made one right away.  Definitely worth stopping by if you're in the West Village area.

Bluestone lane has become my favorite brunch spot in west village this year. Came here on weekends in the past and there was always a wait, even on rainy days! But I stopped by with my boyfriend recently for a weekday brunch and it was very different from my previous visits.  We walked inside and there wasn't a hostess greeting us and someone told us to sit wherever we like. I am so used to coming on Sunday, putting down my name and waiting for a table haha. The only thing about weekdays is the back outdoor area being closed. Nonetheless, the cafe is still big enough with multiple sections open. We found an empty quiet spot and settled down with the menu.  The avocado toast here is always a hit but I decided to get something different this time. I had a flat white and the corn fritters. My boyfriend got a cucumber soda with the portobello mushroom toast. The corn fritters was stacked, with avocado smash in between, arugula, tomatoes and smoked salmon. And props for the generous portion of smoked salmon! The price is a little expensive but the food was very filling and I left with a happy tummy. The portobello mushroom is great as well but my boyfriend mentioned that he will probably not get it again and try something else next time. The avocado smash he ordered on the side was also not worth the $3.  Will continue to return during weekdays for the quiet and delicious brunch.
Australian accent, flat-white, and brunch in west village, I am just feeling so incredibly happy :)

I absolutely adore this place -- the food, the environments, the vibe and the staff. Unfortunately, I had quite an unpleasant experience recently. I went in for brunch alone two weeks ago and had two delicious "entr̩e" dishes, which costed my around $32. A while after I left, I got notifications from my band regarding my credit card transactions, as I always do. I was charged $32 for what I had, but then, immediately after, I was charged approx. an additional $45. I returned immediately as I assumed that it was a mistake. I talked to them, and they told me that they were too busy to figure that out immediately so they will call me within a day or two. So I waited for a few days, but they never called me. I went back again the following weekend and informed them about the problem again. They were very nice and apologetic, but told me, again, that they would call me within a day or two. I waited for another few days, but the call still never came. At this point, I do not even bother to try anymore. This post would be the extent of my efforts, and I will simply avoid going to this cafe in the future.

This was a great experience!!  I emailed to see if they could reserve a spot for me in the courtyard a surprise brunch for my anniversary. The staff was not only super accommodating but also decorated special cups for us. They made amazing Flat Whites with hearts in them for us as well.  To make the already great experience even better, the food was perfect.  I ordered the Brekkie Board and my boyfriend the Quinoa Porridge. It was all so fresh and had a great flavor.  Everyone else seemed equally pleased with their food!  The service was great, the staff very fun and witty. Well worth visiting, I'd highly recommend this to anyone and am eager to return!!

I finally made it here after it being on my "places to try" list for ages and I'm so happy I did! What a wonderful little oasis. Though I had no food (a real struggle not to order as some plates passed by that made me salivate, yet, dinner was around the corner), the Sauv Blanc and Iced Latte were wonderful. My server was a bundle of smiles and just radiated feel-goods to the point where I may have developed a crush. Fellow patrons were all so calm and relaxed that it just enhanced the experience. Loved it and will absolutely be back! Tip: Bring a book!
Great place, great coffee and food but the music is way too loud. It's a caf̩ not a club.

Such a great place for brunch! It actually seats a lot of people, though you wouldn't be able to tell that from the outside. It is Australian-based, and you can see that in some of the names of the coffees. The avocado toast gave a plentiful serving - there was probably more than one avocado's worth piled onto that piece of toast. The quinoa porridge was also amazing. The portions for all the dishes were large, so you definitely get your money's worth. The vibe is also very sweet - it felt like you could walk out of the restaurant and onto the beach.

Great coffee. Had a great New Years Day brunch with my aussie friend Sophie who recommended it. I got the avacado smash with an egg and a mimosa. Clean fresh delicious. Healthy food by satisfying. Yum

Unfortunately my review is consistent with the other recent reviews on this cafe. The cafe was not at all busy however my order was misplaced and therefore I was made to wait over 30 minutes for my breakfast. The same thing happened to the table next to me. The food was actually quite good once I received it and same goes for the coffee. The waitress was apologetic and nice about it but sounds like this happens regularly.

Nice server. Great coffee. Worst Almond Croissant I ever had. No flaky, buttery goodness to be found. A gob of bread, basically. Hugely disappointed as I thought French bakeries all had flakey pastries? Not this one.
I just bought plain croissant at 8am and it felt like from yesterday, I didn't like it at all. They do not bake on the premises.

Unfortunately I cannot say how the food is at this establishment.  That's because almost nothing has the price of the item marked on it or indicated anywhere.  Whether it is their refrigerator case near the door (the chicken salad looked great but how much does it cost?) or the display case at the register the foods are unpriced.  The big menu board lists prices for beverages but they also sell a large assortment of foods.  Rather than play a guessing game or asking the employees for the price of each item I just left.  I live nearby and would likely eat there but they have to let me know what it is going to cost first.

This is becoming a usual spot for me to visit in between teaching classes nearby. Delicious coffee, quiches, and muffins, they're always super nice, and they play great music. It's not exorbitantly priced and quick even when they're busy.  Get an iced americano and an almond croissant!

Great coffee but the staff are really rude, especially the guy and the woman working on Saturday mornings in recent months. For multiple times, I saw clearly they rolled their eyes while I was ordering. It was also pretty clear they were talking about me in Spanish. I have been going to this place for morning coffee for years and the people that used to work there were really nice and welcoming. But I may stop going because the people working there now are making me really uncomfortable

Had a terrible experience here. Asked for coffee and blueberry muffin to go. They gave me a half filled cup of luke warm coffee and a cranberry muffin. Immediately told the woman it was error- I wanted blueberry. She said we don't have that so you get cranberry. I added cream to my coffee and asked for her to fill the cup properly. She refused. I asked for bag to carry out. She put the cup in a large shopping bag which, when I picked it up, it spilled. The woman would not replace.

Hypes: - cute quality new coffee shop on the UWS in an area that's close to residential apartments! - stumptown beans - they make a quality latte - good assortment of pastries, savory snacks, and food (rarity for coffee shops on uws) - nice area to sit and do work  Gripes: - great coffee and pastries but nothing exceptional  Tip: All the pastries are 50% off after 6pm!

Great menu, okay prices. I liked the seating arrangement both inside and out. Coffee tastes great. Some interesting food items like the empanadas and guava bun which make me think this must have South American influence one way or another.  I had a few issues with the service by all levels but I'd rather not get into it so no one loses a job over it. Not enough to make a mountain out of, but enough for me not to come back. I also have some issues with the layout of the accoutrements bc of the logjam that is created there and also no water available freely. It is a busy place with just the minimal staff (on a weekend morning, at least), so I shouldn't have to ask the staff for things like water.  Solid place but I won't be back bc Blue Cafe is close and I like their people on both sides of the floor better there (less tourists). Soooo much better than Starbucks though.

This place is just so great. There aren't many coffee shops in the neighborhood where you can feel comfortable working (and get a great quiche while your at it.) The coffee and pastries are delicious, the staff is really friendly, the prices are reasonable, and the atmosphere is cozy. What more can you ask for?
I think this new place is great. Perfect for a Coffee & Croissant breakfast. I would definitely go back.
Great pastries and sandwiches! It's a nice addition to the neighborhood for a quick coffee and snack.
