I came to B&C on a Sunday afternoon to get some work done. The place is brightly lit and comfortable. I mostly wanted to leave a review to note that the latte here is VERY good!

On the corner of Amsterdam and 68th of the restaurant and cafe wasteland that is midtown, there lies a small glimmer of hope that is Boule and Cherie. It's quite large and spacious for a cafe, especially when you compare it to nearby competitors such as Joe Coffee and Indie. Lots of seating, tables and even a couch with a relatively chill environment makes this a pretty good study and hang kind of place. There could stand to be a few more outlets but on a regular day it's not too bad to nab a spot that has easy access to one.  My personal preference here is stick to just the coffee, they use Stumptown (and even have their cold brew) are pretty good at their drip brew, not too shabby on their espresso based drinks, and the pricing isn't too bad either. The food could stand to have a bit of improvement; the pastries and quiche are okay but nothing to run home and celebrate about.  What you may run out and celebrate about is an actual space to relax, converse without yelling, and do some work without having to worry about prying eyes trying to steal your seat.

Noticed Breads Bakery from across the street. Usually, go to a Pret A Manger or Starbucks. So, try new place this time.  As I walked in on a Saturday around 12:30 pm there were lots of people. Searched for something to snack on like a salad or sandwich. There were more baked items in display cases as you enter and at the counter further up. Saw Babka, honey cake, croissants, etc... Found area where they had salads and prepared meals. Went for the Salmon with cream cheese on Sourdough bread.  The line was confusing. I got on the line. Some people got off cause they were looking around. I came up to counter. Staff said that all you getting. I said I also wanted a large Cappuccino. Staff directed me to go to other end. Saw another staff making coffee. I stood on that line. One customer said she did not know where line was. By the time, I went to place order, the staff making coffee said I have to pay first. I told her staff mate at counter said go where you are. At least, I gave her the order. Then, I went to another line to pay.  Couple of things 1) Once they rang up order. The computer ask if you want to add tip. You gotta be kidding. I did self servIce. No need to tip. I went on three different lines.  2) I had to ask for bag.  3) The cashier asked what kind of milk after I had placed the order.  After paying for everything, got back online for the Cappuccino. The staff made coffee for someone else. I was happy I was out of this place. What an ordeal just to get two items.  Found their baked item to be tad expensive. You can get Babka elsewhere. Cappuccino can get at any other store.

Prices for the hamantashen went up a lot. Tried the chocolate and apple flavors, they were ok. They also got rid of their best flavor, apricot. They don't post prices for the babka anymore but post them for everything else. The cashier wasn't friendly and they messed up my order, they blamed me and the receipt showed it was their mistake (wrong flavors). Also ended up getting overcharged. Not worth it for the prices. Used to be my favorite go to spot for coffee and pastries.

Disappointed as I've been wanting to try Breads Bakery for a while.  I got the Poppy Seed Danish and it was not memorable. It was dry and just a plain danish; it didn't satisfy my craving for a good pastry.  If I were to return, I'd get the mini chocolate croissants but at $2 a piece and each one smaller than my pinky finger, I don't think I'll be returning.  Service was quick and friendly.

Everything here is usually delicious and the chocolate babka is one of my favorite things in the world but really disappointed in the sufganiyot this year - spent $25 and they were inedible - dry and tasteless- after tasting a couple threw them all out. Good thing I had backup babka - because you should always buy two - one to eat now and one to freeze.

One of few places open near Central Park, thus, we had limited options. After walking in, were not greeted, merely stared at. My wife and I ordered two pastries, one tea and a mocha. The cashier repeated my mocha twice, as I emphasized non-fat milk. We sat and one by one our items showed minus the mocha. My wife went to ask for it and instantly, the three gossiping workers stated that no one ordered a mocha. We were not given a receipt, but $22 plus our tip said otherwise. In short, were we given funny stares as if we were trying to pull as fast one for a free cup of joe. Mind you, the employees stared and mumbled at us as we consumed our food. It is a shame that people treat others as such. If we could, we would give them 0 stars.

Concord cake. That's all you really need to know about this place. Everything else was good, but the concord cake is one of the best things I have every eaten. You need this cake. It is chocolatey happiness.

I live around the corner from this bakery and the smell of freshly baked chocolate babka makes it a challenge not to go in every time I walk by. Here live the greatest almond croissants in the world. Breads is known for the chocolate babka, which is great, but their quiches, brownies, cookies and baguettes are also oh so good.  Also, the egg and cheese sandwiches (only avail for breakfast) are uh-mazing.  Don't forget to get a coffee card if you come often- every 10 coffees you get one free. They also offer a 10% student discount if you show your student id. Staff is always very friendly and accommodating.

We found this place a few weeks ago and have gone every weekend to get fresh bread. It is phenomenal! Also, the rugelach are the best my husband and I have ever had. Not saying much coming from me, but he's had a lot of rugelach, so hearing him say that was quite the compliment. Definitely worth trying! (You'll definitely be back.)

Everyone kept telling me how good the bakeries here at Breads, yet I was not able to make the trip. Today I stopped by, just to grab a quick coffee before work. Line was already starting to form even at 7am when they opened, yet I was able to get my cappuccino right away. Barista was friendly and nice. Plenty of space inside too. This is a decent place for a small conversation with friends, without feeling too rushed or cramped.  I promise next time I'm gonna give a try on their pastries and stuff, they looked so tempting to me!
Muesli Roll : fresh and has an amazing hearty and nutty flavor. Mini Fruit Tart: alrighty taste, the crust was little too dry so in the world of tarts I'd say it's mediocre. Stick to the bread there!

Bread bakery union square is the original branch and it's one of the best bakeries in NYC . However since they expended and opened this location at Columbus circle , it's a complete sham !! The famous chocolate babka cake is dry and lack a filling, I bought it twice on different occasions and the quality of the cake that used to be my favorite was so bad and disappointing for 15 $  !! They expended and the level of products and the service has become embarrassing ! I was one of breads Bakery best costumers and admirer but the lack of ability to provide costumers with consistent product quality has pushed me to this review ! I truly hope that someone from breads read this and take responsibility for it and maybe try to make a change on this branch.

Just thinking about this place takes me back to the smell of fresh sweet doughy babka floating in the air, punching your senses as you walk in, begging you for a bite of the Russian baked creation. I want to jump on the train and get some right now! Walking around Lincoln center with some time to kill, I wanted to explore a good bakery with some fresh baked pastries and good cup of cappuccino. A quick look on the yelp app, and bingo!, I found Breads bakery just a few blocks up. I called my brother to see if he would like to grab a cup of coffee, and as soon as he heard where I was headed, he jumped on the bus across central park to meet me. His exact words were "Get the babka, and an extra for me to take home." Apparently he's been to one near Union Square. Breads bakery was a great experience from start to finish. I ordered a tuna sandwich as my lunch and sat outside to enjoy it while people watching. The sandwiches are fresh and delicious. I would say slightly pricey, but I am dining on the upper west side near Lincoln center, so $8 for a small tuna sandwich is pretty competitive to the area. I do believe that they use Italian tuna, which isn't that bumble bee kind you find at CVS always on sale. No offense Bumble Bee tuna, chicken of the sea is better. The staff was truly very kind and even passed around bites as a taster of their product. The parmesan cookies were nice, banana bread was good, and of course the babka was amazing. I prefer the Chocolate one, and the best part is that they give you a discount if you purchase 2. We sat outside with a warmed up babka, we asked, on a wooden board, with a steak knife, ready to devour. Sweet babka with a great brewed coffee really made my day. I even took one to my boss and he absolutely loved it. I look forward to trying some of their other pastries, specifically, the chocolate mousse puff for two, its next on my list. Spend the money and get yourself some babka from bread bakery, you wont be disappointed.

- Chocolate/Nutella Babka is all you ever need to eat again in your life.   - Challah was very good.   - Cinnamon roll is a must get.  The space gets a little crowded but make your way to the babka cart and be happy when you get a warm one!

The only of its kind that stays open till late (11pm) on the weekend near Lincoln Center, Breads Bakery satisfies the late night sweet craving of theater goers post performances. I kinda expected mediocre quality, but I was pleasantly surprised. The creme brulee croissant is rather a misnomer. I thought it is better called creme custard croissant since there was no burnt cream (caramelized sugar) on top of mine. It wasn't to sweet, and tasted fresh even at 11pm. The almond croissant was a little sad looking, being squashed down to the pancake level. I thought it could use a little more fragipagne filling and a little less sugar. But, really, what's up with the flat croissants? The workers are really chirpy, amazingly at 11pm. There's decent seating area to accommodate groups of 2 to 4.

I'm a breads bakery junkie. There is no better babka than at Breads. The quality of their food and coffee is tier one--which is apparent given the 24/7 foot-traffic at this location. I could not recommend this spot more

4 tables and one family style, a few outdoor tables as well. Has a bathroom!  Good spot for a snack/light lunch. I got a Poppyseed Danish and an Decaf Americano (props for a bakery with decaf options!), bakery was fresh, coffee was decent. Helpful and prompt staff.  Next time I will have to try the bahka bread as it looks amazing, seems to be their specialty. It's a large loaf but I was told their rugelach near the counter are similarly made. Great tip.  The space feels a bit like a chain in terms of vibes, or lack of. Looks like a Panera. But much better quality bakery! The 80s pop hits are a bit random... "Domoarigato mister roboto..." Not feeling the epic high notes and synth rhythms with my midday coffee. "Total eclipse of the heart" is next.  Nonetheless, a nice option for the Lincoln area.
Love the boreka(pasties or patties) especially the potato one. It's very flaky and you know it's full of buttery goodness. Their babka looks delicious as well.

First of all, let me say I absolutely LOVE most of my breads and desserts from Breads despite the high price.  However, when I'm paying a relative higher price for a delicious premium product, I expect the service to match to the standard. I come here at least a couple times a week, and I have to say almost every other time I come across a different staff with a surprisingly snobbish attitude...and I'm talking about an attitude before you even start talking to them...  A few weeks ago I had to wait like 15min for a chocolate because the guy was just so busy talking to another staff about random personal things. When I kindly asked where's my order he just looked confused and didn't say anything, went back to making the chocolate while talking to the other person...  This week I went in and asked a question two times before purchase but the cashier lady did not give me a straight answer and didn't care to elaborate when I asked her the second time (dah...I asked twice because I didn't get my answer the first time! I was not looking for a repeat!) Plus she just stared at me with her head tilted...and later she got into an argument with another customer at the counter for not lining up...I'm in no ways encouraging cutting lines but things like this create a very bad experience for fellow customers.  I hope this can bring some attention to the management...train your staff, monitor what happens, or, please visit some other premium bakeries in NYC and see for yourselves what kind of service is NYC standard...you probably get away with the attitudes because of the neighborhood/clientele but I believe I'm not the only one. Such a shame when I have to enjoy my breads thinking about this!

You guys! Don't plan on going at all or with friends and having a convo or anything until the place is fully done. I was there last week and the incredibly loud and jarring metal hammering noises were horrible. I had to leave after a few minutes. I hope the employees were compensated because that noise was headache inducing.  I'll wait to try it out when it's actually in shape to be open to customers.

Two words-matzah quiche! This may be the most delicious Passover-friendly thing you can pick up in the area! The combo of sunchokes and gouda (?) was stellar, and I've been eating on it for a couple days and not bored of it yet! The only reason I'm not giving 5 stars was the service.  The person working the counter didn't know what kind of quiche it was, and then pulled up an ingredient list (salt, pepper level of detail) to read me... and acted as though it was an inconvenience to do so. Just telling me sunchoke and cheese would have been fine, I didn't ask for the details or indicate any sort of food allergy, but more importantly, I didn't need to feel like I was putting him out for asking.  Either way, I'll be back! Certainly for this Passover quiche over the next few days, and then for more delicious treats in the future!
The service is bad. My 10year old son standing in the line, and he is totally ignored, the service person just serving people after him without even asking him.
If it weren't for the irresistible babka I would never come here. The service is atrocious and the clientele tend to be rude and never leave. Expect to have a long, frustrating wait on line to pay.
My favorite is the Babka bread!  Best fresh of course!  I like how they pass out sample out front!

When this moved to the neighborhood I knew it was dangerous. I knew breads from the union square location and my God everything is worth a damn try. If want to order something small, order the hamentashen (if it's the season) and the rugaluch. To go the whole 9 years get the chocolate babka. I swear there are drugs in it, it is seriously that good. I'm drooling just thinking about the glory of the experience it's so rich, moist and sinful. Imma burn in hell for enjoying its chocolate wonderland.
Great bread and croissants. Good coffee too! Love the location. Directly across from Lincoln Center. And a nice clean modern place. Will def go back!

I got a macchiato. Huge bubbles. No latte art. It was one of the worst macchiato's I've ever had. Oh, and a HAIR was in the macchiato. You can see it here in a pic I posted. Look closely. They don't take cash either. The service was ok.

Amazing coffee and the friendly baristas play great music and make it a great morning ritual for me to stop in to grab a tasty and strong coffee on the way to work. The lattes and cappuccinos are great and the New Orleans and regular cold brew are better than most and give extreme options depending on your taste. Amazing addition to what I call Healthy Row with Clean Market, Blink, Skin Laundry, SoulCycle and Equinox all within steps.
The guy at the counter was rude answering my questions. The coffee I ended up having wasn't anything special.

My friend and I got a delicious cappuccino and cold brew here after a class at the SoulCycle next door. This is a super cute, tiny place (i.e., no seating) with excellent coffee and service. But it's not the kind of place to go if you like the fancy extra touches, like foam art in your cappuccinos, or if you'd like to sit while you sip.

GOOD COFFEE, NEEDS MORE TABLES, GOOD SERVICE  The coffee at this place is really good, as well as the attendant who took our order, she was very nice, attentive and smiley. Another barista in the back with purple hair and big nose and ear earrings didn't seem too happy to see customers, she may have been having a bad day.  If you want to plugin for work, you'll need luck. The place is simple but it does the job. The thing missing is more power outlets. If you're lucky to get a table by a power outlet, you'll quick find out that some of them don't work, so you'll be limited to whatever battery you have left on your devices.  I ordered a mocha and it was surprisingly good, one can taste the properly roasted beans in there and good quality soy milk.  We sat at the bar by the window, where working becomes a challenge, not because of the power outlets or the space at the bar... But just watching everyone walk by in New York makes this an experience that makes you want to enjoy your coffee and relax for a while.  They have coffee beans to go, if you want to bring this to your office and be the hero of the day.

Wow. You can tell a lot about a business when their employees act like they hate working here.  Coffee was strong but the attitude I got from both people totally brought me down unnecessarily . And when employees are rude you gotta ask yourself what the boss did to create that environment.

The good coffee, affordable prices, classic diner atmosphere should attract everybody from jersey (myself included). Overall, this is a pretty good coffee shop and it's hard to go wrong with anything on the menu. Just be ready to wait in line during morning - lunch rush hours!

I'm in the area every week for class and thought I would give this coffee shop a try!  There was one girl working the register and bar and I couldn't be more unimpressed by her. She was so disengaged from the customer that it came off as rude. No thank you, no smile, no desire to even be there. And then I watched her roll her eyes behind a customer's back after they asked for the code for the bathroom. I ordered the iced maple shay and paid $5.50 for something that aside from being an off-white color tasted like sour milk. I took 3 sips and threw it away. I will not be back.
Coffee: Yuk. Too strong, bitter and burned. Gross. $2.50 for small coffee. Huge space with barely any seating. My first and last visit to this place.

BRC has made it to the Flatiron district, along with pastries from Dough (see: cafe au lait donut) and Colson Patisserie (see: almond croissant, chocolate financier).  The coffee tastes great, and the baristas are skilled, efficient, and the warmest. The space is huge so feel free to find the wifi password and buckle down with a coffee & pastry. I especially like the wide, semi-circle milk & sugar station with almond & soy milks.  Of the many coffee spots in Flatiron, BRC is a welcome addition and particularly spacey.  PS the bathrooms are kept super clean!

I believe we are probably speaking of the same person, Jo D. This was my third visit and I love the coffee but this morning around 9am. However, I was in shock at how rude the girl was. She was cleaning the cooler and there didn't appear to be anyone else working. She eventually turned around and asked me what I wanted. Four coffees I replied. When she came to the counter and I clarified, 2 lattes and 2 drip coffees, she rolled her eyes. She punched it in the iPad and continued cleaning the cooler, "insert" your card even though I was holding a twenty. Then, she spun the iPad around for me to sign. Clearly my presence was an inconvenience for her. Wow! Probably the worst customer service I've ever experienced.

This is one of my go to cafe. It is a big cafe and their coffee is very nice. This is a good place to sit down and relax.  The decor here is also very cool. Plenty of outlet and wifi for your digital obsessions.

Big spacious coffee shop. On Sunday afternoon it wasn't crowded, maybe because it was a hot summer day and everybody left for Hamptons? lol I got asked couple times if I needed help by couple girls working there. All of them very very attentive and nice. I had to take a moment to look at the menu. Maple Shay caught my attention and the barista also had only nice things to say about it. So I ordered it.. Omg! It was so yummy that with the first sip you hear Poof! And I felt like the princess kissing the frog! lol Fireworks, magic dust, sparkles, rainbows, unicorns and everything in between lol. Your eyes open wide and thumb goes up on its own lol. It's a latte with maple syrup, but so silky and sweet that just makes your day! I loved it and I know I'll be back for more.
5 stars for almond milk cappuccino.  Foam was super thick and firm just as I like it . Also place is big that's nice

I ordered a cold brew with no milk or sugar. I felt like the cup had too much ice and not enough coffee. The coffee was also very bitter, I did not enjoy the cup at all.  Maybe it needed some milk so I will try it with that next time.

It's been a pleasure to get the "nitro cold brew" here for the past few weeks.  Been here ten or so times & what keeps me coming back is the combination of open space, friendly staff, and perfectly blended coffee.    The types of things that typically frustrate me about coffee shops are nonexistent here.  (Long lines, cluttered small space, no air conditioning)  The vintage jukebox is a nice touch...  You'll be floored at how large & open a space this is.

I walked by here on a Sunday afternoon craving a mocha lattee... I go to the counter and order one to fufill my craving.  They call my name and I go to taste it... but it is just a regular lattee.  I turned around and went back to the counter and being the friendly person that I am said sorry maybe they didnt hear me right but i wanted a mocha lattee?  The girl gave me such attitude as if I was wrong? And then took some chocolate syup and dumped it in as I was still holding the cup.  Ok fine, but when I finally went to drink it, it hardly tasted mocha and was cold.  Maybe it was just an off day considering such good reviews but, will no tbe back here any time soon.

Saw this on the TV News!  Wanted to try the Nitro iced coffee and it was GOOOOOD! yeah I will return for another :) what a cool way to make coffee.  Try it- wow the sensation is like a Guinness. The service people were friendly and fun!

I needed a place to do some work on my laptop without loud noises or disruptions. Brooklyn Roasting Company is perfect. There are a ton of tables and people are quiet, so you can definitely get some work done. The baristas are beyond nice, and they have a special pastry deal in the late afternoon. The location is a bit far for me, but I try to come here as often as I can.
Coffee was ok. They don't have any bagels or other proper breakfast food but they claim to be good for breakfast.  Don't get the cheddar biscuits - they were cold and hard.
Great coffee! Huge space to hang out in as well with good lighting and not too noisy. Not much variety pasty/food wise. Will be going back!

I went because the website said that the Bryant Park location has a turkey wrap. I get there and it's all vegetarian, which is fine. I ordered a chickpea salad and a Moroccan iced tea that were good, but it came out to $17 which even for NYC is expensive. But I had committed and was planning on getting some work done. When I sat down I discovered the WiFi wasn't working so I used my hotspot. I stayed and got work done, and ordered a dirty chai latte that wasn't very good (I like my chai lattes spicy and this was not). After a couple of hours of drinking, I had to go to the bathroom only to discover that there aren't any. Very disappointing. Even though the food was good, not worth the price.

This place was so delightful.  The woman who took our order was friendly, patient and so helpful. She sold me on their DELICIOUS hot chocolate.  It's like drinking milk chocolate! The croissants were super good as well. This is a great stop for a nice hot beverage and light snack.  Nice, clean peaceful environment in the busy Bryant Park area. Highly recommend!

Seating: there are about 8 barstool seats that face the window, and 4 benches with small tables. However, the layout of the space is really awkward because basically there is a huge column in the middle of the cafe, so from a few of the small tables, your view of the counter/menu board is completely obstructed.  Very chill spot - they were playing 2000s alternative throwbacks which was nice.  The menu wasn't very extensive, nothing out of the ordinary.  What I'd come back for: pastries are 50% off after 4PM, which they didn't advertise in the window. It was a great surprise! The dark chocolate croissant was decent, not too sweet. The barista also recommended the apple turnover.

We stopped in here while waiting for a reservation for brunch nearby. The whole place is so itty bitty there is not really room for people to pass by each other to get to the cream and sugar.  I can't help but mention the service. The two people "working" were kind of rude. Chatting with as customer as we're trying to place our order. Not sure if they were talking to her or us. They missed one of our drink orders as a result.  My coffee was fine... the same as any other overpriced coffee in NY. Not making any plans to go back.

Best Sumatran beans in the City. And the barista who sold them to me this afternoon was so cute I got lost in his eyes and didn't hear what he was saying to me, and then stammered to ask him to repeat himself. Delicious coffee. Delicious barista. ;)

Good lawd. Rarely in all my excursions do I encounter truly fine, smoother than silk espressos/lattes. Vita easily landed in my top three with just one visit (the others being in Seattle, so of course this Seattle based caffe would be fantastic).  This is the type of coffee that I crave - not meant to be hurried, it is for sipping and savoring. Truly a delight from the moment the first sip that hits your lips to the last. The flavor tantalizes the tastebuds.  Service is casual, friendly, sincere. An all around outstanding experience, and I'm thrilled to have a new favorite/go-to in the city!

This Caffe Vita outpost is a breadbox version of their main cafes back in Seattle, but the coffee still stands out as being delicious and well made. A significant portion of their space is taken up by the roaster in the back, and the rest is mostly for working. Not a cafe meant for crowds or even for lingering in, but good for a quick latte to go.  No bathrooms, unfortunately.

Came here and tried the cortado- mine was pretty watery/milky and my partner's was slightly better, so there are obvious inconsistencies with the preparation. Definitely not the best I've had or close to anything I would consider memorable.  We also bought a bag of the decaf whole bean coffee, and it has a burnt taste. Service was nice and friendly enough though and the experience wasn't particularly egregious, so I would feel bad about bringing my rating down to a 2 (even though we are not happy with the beans at all).

First off to a couple of reviewers: Caffe Vita is SEATTLE coffee, not Portland (that's Stumptown--get yo facts straight!).  I am SO glad that CV opened an outpost in NYC. I was in NYC last weekend and made a point to visit "Little Seattle" on the LES (as CV is next to Via Tribunali, another Seattle import). Seriously some of the best coffee available ANYWHERE, I'm so glad I can get a little taste of home when in Manhattan.

This coffee is from another world. I believe some coffee lords from a galaxy far away came to earth one day and decided to drop off roasts which they have perfected over many gizzilliian generations, in the past or future. The customer service is supreme as well, it's nice to find a place in NYC where the cashiers and baristas make eye contact, and let me tell you, Caffe Vita is on top of that! Alright, self-admittedly, this is one of the goofiest Yelp posts I have ever written. Seriously though, Caffe Vita's coffee is from another planet. Try it out sometime.

Fantastic coffee shop in SoHo that is worth traveling to for a stellar cup of coffee.  It smells heavenly since they have a roaster jamming away in the back.  Seating is very limited, but if that chafes you I suggest you go to a Starbucks with your Suburba-tron mall friends and get corporate factory coffee and spread out.  If you want epic coffee, including some devine Kyoto drip, drop in and indulge.  I had a Latte that was the perfect temperature, consistency, and taste.  Amazing joint.

I usually love this place and come here whenever I'm in the neighborhood. Today, though, was weird. I decided to make the trip before work despite it not being on my way. When I got there, it was open, but a piece of paper was in front of the register that said "Back in 5mins". I waited for over 10mins and nothing. Seriously, to just leave like that and not even lock the door or something? Kind of stupid. Disappointed not to get a matcha, and after almost 15mins, I didnt have any more time and left.
I think 5.94 dollars is too much for small ordinary cappuccino with almond milk. Also stuff is very rude. What a pity!

Tiny nook off of Broadway with friendly and super fast service for customized beverages. They offer a milk alternative, their house-made almond milk "sweetened" with dates. Although, the next time, I may opt for regular milk as this almond version was quite salty, and each sip of saltiness overpowered the matcha essence. A bit pricey, $5.25 for a latte, and +$1 for the almond milk, but their presentation is beautiful and they use high-quality ingredients, and service is grand.

I've been coming to Chalait since it was in West Village.  I'm still sad they closed that location.  I usually get a matcha latte with soy milk or handmade cashew almond milk.  I really like matcha even though a lot of people think it's very bitter.  I always ask for extra matcha and simple syrup.  The service is great here - they will customize the drink the way you want it.  Also, they have a rewards card so you will get your 8th drink free.  The space is rather small but I always get it to go so I never stay here.  This is one of the better matcha places - not a big fan of the new matcha places like MatchaBar or Cha Cha Matcha.  Yeah it's a bit pricey but their drinks and service are definitely higher in quality than other places.

I'm officially obsessed with this place!  I had been coming here religiously for their matcha lattes because it's in close proximity to my favorite hair salon. Sometimes, I'm hungover, and the matcha lattes is the cure! I love watching them be made with care too.  Their food menu is what really got me hooked and sometimes I'll pop in on a Saturday morning for an avocado toast or my favorite vegetarian sandwich in the city, The Greenwich.  Everyone behind the counter is super friendly and do a great job of getting your order together. I love the little marble counters. The space is beautiful and I'm always really happy that I stopped in.  Also, a good tip would be to download the app, Ritual, where you can place your order before you get there to have it ready.

I tried my first ever avocado toast here and was blown away by how good it was. I also tried their matcha latte and was impressed by how strong the matcha was (most of the other cafes in NYC serve disappointing matcha lattes that are watered down), and also how perfect the latte art was. Things are pretty pricey here, but the quality and taste of the food and drinks justify the high prices. I love the minimalist design of the space, and service is great!
Miso butter toast is delicious. I asked them about which drinks where whisked which turns out to be the Matcha Americano and the shot.  Good to know. Their reasoning makes sense.

The place is small, only 4 seats and some standing room. I ordered the ice matcha latte ($5.25) and quinoa bowl ($12) which is definitely a bit pricey but a nice splurge. Quinoa bowl was flavorful, well cooked and warm quinoa mixed with the egg and avocado and butternut squash made for an excellent breakfast. The iced matcha latte was refreshing and not overpowering. 4/5 only because it is a bit pricey. But delicious, quality food!

Great food! Quick. Excellent service! But be warned: TINY place. Only 5 seats at a bar facing the wall. A perfect spot to grab a quick bite. Not a place to meet or plan to spend a lot of time. They were out of spinach and avocado mash and their supply delivery was late, but opted for the quinoa bowl with butternut squash, egg, avocado slices & cauliflower. Was excellent! Fresh, great flavor (although I skipped the spicy sauce). Hit the spot!And the iced Matcha with a splash of their homemade almond-cashew milk was flavorful & refreshing.
As much as i love matcha, i thought a little cup was overpriced...FIKA has better price.

Having been to the since-shuttered West Village original yelp.com/biz/chalait-new?  , dropped in to this new location with no Broadway frontage looking for something matcha-related, but only found plenty of other boring stuff.
Delicious -my first green tea latte and I'm totally hooked. And the avocado toast-----OMG

Not often do I have an experience like this with one of the rudest servers of all time.  I have done over a thousand reviews and this one takes the cake.  This server was on fire with the attitude and had an attitude the whole time we were there. He didnt even let me open my laptop to check something for work. Apparently it is not allowed here. I could understand if I was trying to camp out for hours but I wasn't. I literally opened my laptop for a second and he pounced. Laptop police!!!  This terrible service ultimately ruined the whole experience for myself and my guest. As for the food, it came out very quickly which was also troubling. I went with the quinoa bowl with smoked salmon. It wasnt bad but not the greatest. My guest had the waffle which she said was good but was a very small portion. This rating would have been a lot better if it wasnt for the server who woke up on the wrong side of the bed.  It is a shame because this place has potential. Too bad this is NYC so many other places to go instead. The only reason they didn't get 1 star is because the food was decent.

I came with a group of 4 girls and we were seated within 5 mins on a Saturday morning. We got Shakshukas and the Brekkie sandwiches. For the prices, the portions were so small (we all agreed we could eat two plates each) and it just wasn't worth it. The food was just ordinary too, we had high expectations since this place had such high reviews on yelp. Staff weren't particularly nice either and we had to wave down our waitress several times for water. Sadly we won't be back :(

love this place! it was my first time today and I got the avocado toast. since I asked for it without feta, it was a little different than what you would see in pictures. just an fyi still super good.. the pink beet sauce is so delicious with the avocado toast. love the environment of this place, lots of plants~ love the vibe I would recommend this place! my friend got the brekkie sandwich, which he loved--he specifically loved the biscuit it came in!

Super disappointed. From what I remember, the coffee here was decent when I used to be in the East Village more frequently. However, upon my most recent revisit, the cold brew was undrinkable - burnt, bitter, with a really bizarre medicinal aftertaste. I tried my best to drink it because it is quite expensive, but had to throw it out with 90% wastage.

Lovely small coffee shop in East Village!  I love the minimalistic interior and the seating that faces the windows. It's perfect for when you want to relax and people watch, or jot down some thoughts in your journal. The coffee is also soooooo delicious and well-made.  Minus one star for not having wifi though. I love working on my laptop at coffee shops. I'd come more often to do work if this place had wifi.

I am on a diet right now. Low carb/low fat or something.  So I was deprived of milk tea and my flavored lattes for a week or so. I was lost and sad.  But then I discovered something I could have. LATTES WITH ALMOND MILK AND HONEY.  And so that's what I've been getting everywhere. And this is like the best one ever.  City of Saints's espresso is sooooo fragrant, when you drink it, the smell just lives in your mouth/nose/nasal cavity (hahaha, if you try it you'll understand what I mean!). I've forgotten that I'm not drinking a vanilla latte with whole milk.  The baristas carefully measure out and press the espresso. They have manual espresso machines, so they weigh the espresso themselves on a scale as it comes out and they stop it right at the perfect weight. Then they add the honey/whatever you're adding into the espresso. I have discovered that 15g of honey is the perfect amount for my almond latte. :D  My boyfriend got the lavender agave (which I think was seasonal. Homemade agave syrup with lavender pressed into it or something?) and he let me have a tiny sip even though I'm on a diet. Tastes similar to Bibble & Sip's lavender latte.  Also, if you plan on coming back for more wonderfulness, make sure you go through all of the pay screen and after you press no receipt, you'll get stars to get $3 off your 10th purchase or whatever. :( I've literally gone there every weekday since I discovered it last Thursday. I bought 1 drink on Thurs 10/4, 2 on Fri 10/5, and 2 on Mon 10/10, but didn't think about asking until yesterday, so after today, I only have 2 stars, instead of 7 :(((((.)  TOMORROW IS MY ONE WEEK ANNIVERSARY OF DRINKING CITY OF SAINTS LATTES X3 I will celebrate by going to City of Saints and drinking a latte.

Will definitely be back! Beautiful cafe, friendly baristas, great latte! They also carry Doughnut plant - yay! And seemed to have a good amount of pastries available.  I really want to buy some of their coffee to make at home - beautiful packaging.
OK. Coffee is good but their Bushwick location is way better And they have no bathroom And they have no wifi
no wifi. I know, I know....first world problems....but come on! You're a coffee shop in the east village, in NYU territory and you don't have wifi?!

Really, really want to give this place a glowing review & agree with everyone's reviews of great coffee, great doughnuts so far, but I feel like it's worth pointing out this place is best for grabbing coffee on-the-go and isn't as great for folks wishing to stay and enjoy their coffee.  Their metal countertops - though spacious - heat up so quickly under the sun that it's practically impossible to touch. (Lots of natural light though, which is a plus.) Also, they have no wifi, public restrooms, or power outlets, so FYI - may not be a prime spot for staying and getting work done on your laptops.  Nevertheless - definitely worth stopping in if you're looking for quick caffeine/sweet tooth fix.

Stumbled upon this new joint on the way to Sundaes and Cones next door and decided to have a cup of iced coffee. City of Saints is a Brooklyn roaster that opened up shop in the East Village. Friendly baristas served up a lovely cup of cold brew (which they keep on tap!). Definitely a subtle flavor without being overly bright, which is a plus in my book. For $3.50, a very good deal.  City of Saints also serves all sorts of espresso based drinks and sells pastries and freshly roasted beans. Definitely a cafe I will return to!

Getting better and better. I think the beans they are tossing  and using have really improved. There is a little Barrista difference, but these days they are often pulling 7s and 8s rather than the 5s and 6s of 6 months ago. Very friendly staff.

Overpriced bagels and rude employees...  The upper east side has some outrageous prices on items but the fact that your charging 2.75$ a bagel PLUS charging extra for cream cheese & others... that's outrageous!  Also it doesn't help when your employees are rude and obnoxious...

Disappointed. Paid almost $7.00 for a matcha latte w nut milk... and it tasted like warm milk, lacking in matcha. Couldn't tell if too little was put in or none at all, when I opened the lid to look inside, it looked yellow rather than green latte color. I'm disappointed at paying that much for nothing. There are better matcha places. Perhaps stick to regular tea or coffee here. Good luck.  The place itself is cute, but I felt my drink was not up to par. There is a restroom available with plenty of tables/chairs for seating.

The WORST. I ordered coffee and a croissant - first they told me they were out of croissants, then said "oh, here I do have them in the oven" and took one out, poured the coffee and when I went to pay, said "you have $5 reward", BUT she couldn't get the system to give it to me. Called a manager who didn't answer. Finally got someone who said system wasn't working, they would give it to me next time. I said OK, they charged me $6.53 and handed me a coffee. Where was the croissant? Oh, they had it but threw it out. TWENTY MINUTES, NO CROISSANT OR COFFEE AND CHARGED. I had to go back in to get the $6.53 refund. And, the food and coffee is to great to begin with! Find anyplace else! I am giving it one star because no stars is not accepted.

Stopped in for a coffee while I was in town for Thanksgiving, stayed for the cake! Loved the Honey cake, I've never had anything like it before. Hope to be back in NYC soon, I'll definitely be back to try more cakes! I loved the super cute art in my coffee in the shape of a heart. Felt so welcomed when I came in!

This is one of my favorite spots in the area, their coffee is great but the pastries are extremely good! The environment is very trendy still cozy and the staff was super helpful providing details on the ingredients, origin and even recommend their favorites! Will keep coming back!
Really good coffee and very friendly service/staff.  Great atmosphere.  Reduced prices on desserts move it from 4 stars to 5 stars.

Cool place. Coffee and etc is good. Got a breakfast sandwich, VERY disappointed to find the eggs aren't fresh (powdered) and sandwich was very bland and soggy. The egg coloring was even off. If a real egg was used it would have been fine. Upsetting such a cheap route was taken. *I'll be back for a coffee if I'm not hungry, but that's it.

I'm torn on this place. I actually work in the building so it's incredibly convenient that I don't have to go outside to come here to grab a quick coffee (there's a door from my work lobby that leads directly into the coffee shop).  The upper west flatbread is delicious. Can't go wrong with mozzarella and pesto! Yummy. I typically get the cold brew.  I've had the iced matcha once and NEVER again. Even with the convenience, it's a bit overpriced. Will I be back? Probably. Am I happy to be $12+ for a cold brew and flatbread? Nope.

Made for getting some work done, or meeting up with people as they have both ample counterspace and table seating. Super chill with a lot of unique options between their various salads, sandwiches, and all day (gasp!) breakfast items. The wifi is free and it almost feels like a cool little den to work in, but lit nicely by outdoor sunlight from the glass storefront.  Love love love the sandwiches here...tried the Turkey Club ($11) which had a combination of avocados, olives, and pickles (all things i find necessary in a truly good sandwich) and was so large, I had trouble taking it down and ended up being lame and resorting to a fork and knife method.  The breakfast frittata (which is actually an egg sandwich) is also quite good and tastes like a complete meal, warm and fresh out of the square egg-steaming-mould.  Tried the Peruvian Pudding (quinoa soaked in almond milk, honey, and topped with berries) which was less of a dessert and more of a cold oatmeal replacement.  For some reason, everything here comes packaged for take-out. Convenient, and sends the WE'RE NOT HERE TO INSTAGRAM- WE'RE HERE TO WURKKK message.  All in all, very good options for eating healthy if you're not afraid of carbs.

One of the worst coffee shops I have ever been to. The people behind the counter could not be more rude or look more unhappy.  The coffee is not fresh. They literally store the old coffee on the wall and use it when they run out. They walk out into the area where the customers are sitting, take the stale coffee off the wall, and then they serve it to their customers. Both the coffee and food are extremely overpriced as well.  The tables are also SO sticky that my clothing and my skin stick to them. This establishment needs to get their act together.

This was a great little place. Dove in on a cold day to drink something warm and charge phones with my friend. We had been out all day and were happy to find plenty of outlets, great customer services and some tasty pastries. Good place, I would recommend a stop.

This poor rating is because of a really bad croissant.  It had a very nice aesthetic, the outside is what led me to try it. The atmosphere was intimate and encourage To-Go orders; there wasn't much seating. The prices a great, but after you try the items you can understand why everything is $2. They serve you quick and did not invite conversation into the transaction. The coffee does not taste great and neither does the croissant.  Overall, I would go again if it wasn't out of the way; however, this is not the shop for me.
One of the places where the attendants are on their phones until you go up and ask for help  No decaf  Cheap prices though

I was randomly walking to work when I found this cafe, where everything was $2. It helps that the iced soy latte and blueberry scone I got was actually good. The baristas were also super happy and put you in a great mood first thing in the morning. Keep it up corvo cafe!

When I saw "everything $2", I thought it was a one day promo, joke or scam. An excellent $2 12 oz. iced cappuccino later, I was a believer.  The sandwiches and pastries looked good and the barista was nice.

I work two blocks away from the Bus Terminal with Corvo being in between. Man, this place has become my go-to morning spot. They have quite a few offerings on their menu all for just $2. My favorite is their flat white.  The Employees are always polite and fast. It does get a little busy around 8:30am, but as long as you know what to order and don't waste time, you'll be in and out.
Pretty good coffee but very doughy substandard croissants. Very convenient to escape the worse coffee in the hotels on w 40th.
This little coffee shop is everything you want in a tiny New York coffee shop. First off everything is $2 and the pastries and coffee are perfect.

My husband and I discovered this place when we stayed at the Staybridge Suites nearby over the holidays.  Everything on the menu was two bucks.  The pastries here are awesome.  We bought about a dozen danishes to take back to Florida with us.  The service was very friendly.  Will definitely stop in next time we are in NYC.

Based solely on the matcha latte with almond milk - distasteful, bland, and prepared with a lack of care. The barista steamed the almond milk for 3 seconds and just dumped it with the matcha powder. The matcha flavor is VERY subtle. I can barely taste it. I don't even know what I'm drinking honestly. Not the place for a matcha latte. Highly do not recommend.
Cute coffee shop with super rude employees! No customer service skills whatsoever. They mess up but make customers feel like it's their fault. The Latte, however, was really good!

A great escape from the American concept of a coffee shop. I love their coffee. I love their chocolates. I love their croissants. I even just sent a friend to go in and get coffee! I'd highly suggest these guys to anyone in need of a caffeine fix that's above the ordinary.

I've been to another FIKA location but I love this one because it's so spacious and has tons of seating. Boyfriend and I shared the coffee, spicy hot chocolate, scrambled egg breakfast "your way", princess cake, and semla. We wanted to try a little of everything and left the place in a complete food coma, haha. The pastries are amazing and aren't super sweet so are easy to overeat! The scrambled egg breakfast was delicious and has a good portion of everything (loved the sourdough bread). The spicy hot chocolate (made with Valrhona chocolate) had a nice kick to it without the spice being overpowering. It also wasn't super heavy or thick so was easy to drink and was a nice compliment to the meal instead of being a meal in and of itself. Coffee is on point, as always. It's a nice place to either grab something to go or to chill out and have a meal.

Great addition to the neighborhood. Rex, which is just one block away is great too - but it was getting too crowded lately, and obviously the neighborhood needed another coffee place. I've been here a few times and tried and loved the Princess cake, mini brownies, oatmeal, scrambled eggs, coffee and pasion-envy green tea.  They have a great chocolate variety and nice ambient music. Not too noisy.

Stopped by after a dance class and before a matinee after trying a dozen smaller coffee shops, which were all packed. I was shocked to find FIKA so empty, but I was thrilled. The staff, coffee, and salmon croissant sandwich I ordered were all fantastic. Will make this a regular spot for sure!

Coffee and desserts are above average in quality. However, my gripe is with the wifi here. Agree with many other reviewers. Do not expect to get any meaningful work or writing done here. Not only is wifi spotty, you get kicked off every 20 minutes or so and need to go through the whole process of getting back online again and again and again. Why one must resort to to Starbucks to get a good, fast, reliable connection is beyond me. I'd rather support businesses like Fika than Starbucks but it just isn't keeping up. Fika, please listen to your customers. Our feedback is intended to help you succeed and to create a loyal customer base.

This place is a better than average place for a cup of coffee. The space is large and there are normally places to grab a seat. The cardamom buns and the chocolad balls are my favorite. The service is hit or miss. Usually the staff is very friendly, but one time I came in at 6:45pm (they closed at 7p) to grab something to go and the guy behind the counter said "sorry, I closed the register already"- even though I wasn't planning on staying and there were plenty of people left in the store!

The coffee is pretty good and the place is cute if you don't mind the dude-y, this-job-is-beneath-me attitude. They yell out to take your order while you're far back in the line and if you don't hear them, you get the silent treatment and attitude. If you like your pleases and thank-yous, you're better off at Starbucks.

What is not to love about this spot? The clean decor, great coffee, or the piece of sanity they provide upon walking through the door to get away from the bustling city of NYC. The staff is helpful, inviting, and they know their stuff when it comes to coffee.  They don't have wifi which at first I was surprised but then I thought "maybe that is a good thing". Enjoy the moment and less work? . I expect to become a regular here! Welcome to the neighborhood Gotham !

Love this place! Just opened directly across the street from my office. Got my first drink here today (a delicious iced Americano) and you can bet I'll be back soon- maybe tomorrow. Nice baristas, clean location, great drinks. So happy!
New Yorker breakfast sandwich tasted like it was covered in Salt. Late was also too hot when served, milk was over steamed. Won't be returning
Been here before with no issues. decent coffee and food. however the guy working the counter at noon on Tuesdays is incredibly rude. makes me not want to come back

I love it! Today I went i  and didnt have to say anything. The guy knew what I was going to order and I said Thanks, tipped them of course and went to wait for my drink which was not a long wait. It was fast, easy and it was morning so I didnt have to talk. I have not been there for a long time so I was surprised that he remembered me and what I usually order. It is great coffee, I love the vibe and the customer service is great!
Great coffee But terrible cashier - no smile, feel extra irritating when I asked for receipt, no thanks!
The cold brew is delicious and the espresso is strong. It's a roomy place great for working or relaxing. My only complaint is with their muffins - they are much more health food than pastry.
Fantastic place!  Fast and super helpful.  I regularly go in for a cold brew and am in and out in under 30 seconds!  Fastest place I've ever been to.  Great work!

They refuse to disclose how many Gregorys there are*  Redeemed a $2 LevelUp credit here for their s'more[s] cookie, which fell right out of the pouch they placed it in onto the floor (due to improper production, per the staff who laughed it off and handed me another with no hesitation). Would definitely go 5 stars if the cookie itself was better.  Transaction Amount $2.00 Credit Applied -- $2.00 *No apostrophe

The place can get super busy but they have a good system.  The espresso is good. And I like the group of people that work here; they are cheery and helpful even when we aren't, and that can be contagious.

Let's start with the good: they make a great cup of coffee.  The not so good: it should not be so hard to pay for something.  In a coffee shop, the customer must always do two things: ORDER and PAY.  It is astounding to me that during the morning rush they constantly have one cashier.  Perhaps they should retrain the one worker who is always behind the counter wiping the same spot with a cloth to use a cash register?

Fool me twice, shame on me...Do not go to Gregory's. The entire experience--coffee, service and food (breakfast pastries) is a disappointment. Twice.  This is an area of town where your expectations for good coffee is already low but the watery brown water and burnt coffee aroma is not just the Gregory Experience but a metaphor for the neighborhood...and I live here.  When you ask if the muffins, donuts, etc are fresh you will get a blank, hollow-eyed but reassuring "yes" (if you can get them away from their phones) but one sniff, touch or taste will tell you otherwise. They all have the characteristics of formerly wet paper that has been kept in a cool attic under a can of paint.  If all the above is your thing; have at it. Otherwise, I'd walk 30 paces in any direction and have a better coffee experience.

Nothing special in my opinion. The cold brew was decent but service was lacking. Maybe because I was there just a few hrs before closing, maybe because I didn't order a specialty drink, I don't know but the barista seemed as bitter as my coffee.

I've seen SEVERAL Gregory's around the city, especially when searching for places to study, so we decided to give Mr. Gregory himself a shot today.  Enticed by the glasses logo (YAY OD's!), this was another reason why I've been wanting to try this coffee place out. This location has quite a few tables, however they are PEA-SIZED. As in super small, good for one person's laptop. There are a few high tables in the front that have bigger surface area, but you'll mostly find these small round ones along the wall and in the back area. They are the perfect size for a laptop though if you decide to study here.  Their cold brew was just okk. I'd probably try something else if I come again. They have a big selection of baked goods, which I was very tempted to try.. but I had just come from Laduree... so maybe next time!  Overall, not a bad choice if you're in need for a coffee break.
One star is too high as the coffee is served cold and the manager refused to do anything.
a very good coffee, excellent place with excellent staff. will leave you caffeinated and happy(:

This place just made my day. It has a trendy small town vibe for a chain metropolis location. Great service bar layout and seating for customers to enjoy their coffees and treats with friends. There is also a back room with more seating available. Staff is really friendly and welcoming. I will definitely be coming back.

I ordered a matcha latte and cheddar chive biscuit here. I could not taste the matcha in the latte, and it was remade. The second one was just as disappointing as the first. Also, I asked the server to heat up the biscuit and it was returned to me cold. Extremely disappointing.

Finally- a great vibe coffee cafe in this area I want to keep returning to! Super friendly service, great music and loved the art on the wall. Chocolate croissant had a good, buttery taste- chocolate could have been more and better quality, but it was good.  Very generous pumpkin muffin samples! The best thing was the latte -- think this was the best latte I have had in the city.  Not a hint of bitterness, perfectly smooth.  Served with a heart! :)

Stopped here at on a Saturday morning. Got something basic-iced latte with almond milk. They did it right. Coffee smooth, right ratio of almond milk to make it easily drinkable, but luxurious. Bakery selection looks very good. Croissants, muffins, donuts, pastries, pockets, beckoning an undeserving stomach (too much alcohol finished with Magnolia bakery German chocolate cake the night before). Sweet, helpful, down to earth staff who know what they're doing! Old school jazzy music. Seating not plentiful, but good use of space-and I got a table as it was not crowded. Cute place with wooden floors and a slight industrial feel, but still warm in the middle of businessy midtown. Will come back!

The staff is so friendly here! Especially Alex! We are new to the hood and love coffee. When we passed this place, we stopped in and just mentioned we are checking it out as we are new to area. Alex introduced herself right away, gave us a little info on the coffee and let us try samples! It was great and so was the coffee! Mmmmmm.... We have made this our regular coffee spot before coming to work. Stop in for friendly folks, great coffee and a nice cafe vibe.
Coffee like coffee should be ! Friendly and great staff! Great sandwiches although a little pricey, but the coffee is the  best in the world !!!

Fun and cute vibes. Unbelievable poor coffee. The shots pulled in under 6 seconds. Pretty much the worst espresso shot and steamed milk I've had in years. If you want a good Instagram photo this is your spot, if you want good coffee run for the hills.

Cute coffee spot in UES. Great vibes, okay price, and average latte (my go to drink). There's something disappointing about having a classic latte that's more fluffy than creamy that makes me dock them a star. The fluffy portion of my latte took up basically 1/3 of the whole cup, and not in a good way. I'm sure there are other redeeming foods/drinks here that I haven't tried though!

this place is so lame. it's a pretend 'artisanal' coffee shop with truly terrible coffee and an employee dress code that mandates fedoras. try finding out where the coffee beans are roasted - you won't see any sort of indication or signage, because it's probably cheap bulk coffee. it certainly tastes like it. the location is right next to the subway entrance so it gets much more business than it deserves, but do yourself a favor and walk two blocks south to joe, or three blocks east to oslo, if you want decent coffee in the area.  bottom line: handcraft does a disservice to small businesses that actually try hard to put out a good product (and don't require their employees to wear fedoras), and it does a disservice to the neighborhood, which deserves better. they've taken us for fools. hard pass.

This is a general review of this cute little spot as I only got to try their soy latte. The place is small but decorated beautifully! The staff is very friendly and thy look like they have a huge variety of drip coffees in all different strengths/flavors. I also noticed their pastry case--like I said... didn't get a chance to try any of them but they looked absolutely fresh and delicious. A huge variety ranging from danishes to doughnuts. Only downside is that they don't have a bathroom!  Also, another perk is that it is located RIGHT at the subway entrance/exit so it's a perfect spot to visit f you're in transit! Will definitely be back :)

Super cute neighborhood coffee shop. I have been here a few times now and the coffee is reliably good. They also have a nice selection of pastries, including a few gluten-free options. There are about six barstools by the window to grab a seat and I have always been able to find a spot. Will definitely be coming back here!

Came here for Sunday brunch and it was PACKED. The place is tiny with only a few tables, so expect a wait if you want to sit down! I got a cold brew which was fine, but their paper straws disintegrate within five minutes. I'm all for being environmentally friendly but I've had way nicer paper straws at other places and they really need to switch brands!  For my main, I ordered the Morning Greens, which was supposed to have kale, quinoa, tomatoes, goat cheese, sunflower seeds, fried egg and lemon. It took probably 20 minutes for it to come out and when it did there was no quinoa on it. We went back up and were given a little cup of it, but it would've been better had it been mixed in to begin with. It was very average. Nothing special about the dish at all.  My main issue, though, is the price. The cold brew was $6 which is seriously ridiculous. I was also charged an extra $3 for an extra egg because the guy originally thought I asked for it - I clarified literally three times that I only wanted one egg, nothing extra, but clearly he didn't understand that. I didn't realize I was charged for it until after and didn't feel like causing a fuss. So, the total was $21 which seems insane for what I got.

Very cool place. Parlor espresso, which is fantastic. Great music and atmosphere. Servers were very nice. My cortado was outstanding.  The cold brew here is idiotic however, it is the most expensive in the city and doesn't taste good. They say they do it for 48 hours which is about three times as long as anybody else. That's fine, but longer doesn't necessarily mean better, end it isn't better, it's worse. It's kind of like kyoto style in flavor, but too much. It's also kind of like Starbucks back in the day: way too strong, and begging for milk or sugar. And that is six dollars for an average size portion. Makes no sense.

This place is the biggest gem of the Upper East Side! Was up there recently for a dentist appointment mid week and didn't have a clue where to get lunch and found it right by the Q train.  The space has cool vibes & very chilled. Staff are super friendly, definitely not something I expected to find on UES. The food was even better, I had the Mushroom toast & a 48 Hour Cold Brew (my new fave) and it's was so delish!  Update: Been back a bunch of since this and have tried out more of their menu which is equally fantastic, I even offer to trek to the UES to meet friends for brunch now on weekends!

In distant memory Yorkville residents can hear the boom of controlled explosions from the birthing of the Second Avenue Subway. Now, we experience the excellent small business boom that's followed, hoping for shops like Hutch & Waldo whose staff are Upper East Side proud. Imagine the best of the beverages from downtown and Brooklyn coffee shops without the "too cool" hipster attitude. Hutch & Waldo is slinging Parlor beans which in my opinion, are some of the best you can serve in the New York City area. In addition to bringing new beans to the area, they also have a variety of milks from hemp to coconut which is rare uptown beyond Starbucks. Even though the caf̩ is small with only 6 bar stools, the vibe is still warm and welcoming. This is the sort of spot you can grow to call your own and keep casual conversation with the baristas. Wishing only the best to these folks and very much looking forward to the spring when they'll open their front door hatch to the sounds of the neighborhood and I can loiter, sipping and indulgent iced latte.

Hutch & Waldo is a cute coffee shop that serves good coffee. The first time I went there I got their matcha latte made with almond milk and the drink had a subtle matcha flavor which was good. The second time I went I got a soy flat white and the drink was good. The seating is very limited and they also have food there. Overall, this cafe is a good place to study or grab a coffee on the go.
I think I found my favorite cortado! Great coffee at a quaint location only a block away from an exit from the Q train stop.

After my less than stellar experience, the owner reached out and invited me in for the "true experience." It was a lot better this time around - the service was friendly all around and the cold brew nice and strong. Appreciate that although it's a small space, it's kid friendly (owner mentioned the garage doors are by design to accommodate the UES stroller crowd). Look forward to going back and trying some more menu items, including the yummy-sounding food.

I have often come to idea coffee because there are BTS birthday events where fans who buy a drink and get a cup holder. I've come here three- four times already and always look forward to it. But this time they changed the policy where you have to buy either the special drink or two selected drinks from the menu in order to get the cup holder and photo card, items that aren't even provided by the shop itself but by fans. You're already profiting off of fans who come here to buy drinks but to make it limited to certain drinks that are more pricey is not fair. The special Hoseok drink is nearly $7 and consists of pineapple, apple and some sort of soda. That's ridiculous. People come here out of pure love and joy for our boys. I hope that you can continue to collaborate with BTS fans to hold these events but please do not take advantage of customers.

They do the events related to kpop star sometimes, which is totally fine. But I saw they were selling over priced drink for event to provide photo card with it. Before they provided cup holder to everyone who order drinks, but somehow now they make specific drinks to make more expensive to give people a picture. I dont understand.
Great place to do some reading or work here. Also like their lattes and great music (not too loud either)! The staff are super friendly as well. Highly recommend.

Environment It is a perfect coffee shop to work in. There's free wifi, and outlets around. It's not too spacious, but it's comfortable enough to do work in.  Food Honestly, I only came here for the lightbulb drink, which was overprice as expected. It tasted like your average peach ice tea (though really refreshing on a summer day). It even had this cute light attached which made the light for the plastic light bulb. I don't think I'd order the light bulb drink again though. I would definently come back here and try the coffee next time as the shop smelled really aromatic of coffee beans.

Happened by this spot near our hotel (OTR II!) and got a Raspberry Addict tea. I didn't expect much because it's NYC so when the guy said they were sweet, I did an internal side eye-I'm from NC so I'm not about tea games. But it did not disappoint. Sweet but not overly so, tasty fruit floating around....and jams on the radio. 112 "Now That We're Done" and 112/Mase "Hold Me?' whet? I could live here. Highly recommended.

Prolly one of the best caramel lattes I've had in a while. The muffins in here tastes fresh...most of the ones I've gotten from other coffee places taste like they've been out for days. This place put my faith back in muffins lol.

I came to the coffee shop to get an iced coffee and ended up trying the light bulb juice as well.  Large iced coffee (~$3.50 ish): Good iced coffee. It's a little bit on the stronger side.  Yellow light bulb (~$7.50 ish): Sweet peach flavor juice in a plastic light bulb container. While i was drinking it by the window side, a couple of pedestrians pointed at the unique cup and came in to try as well. If you have sweet-tooth, i can see you loving this drink. Definitely something new to try.  Seating: A big bench for a large group and a few small tables. I sat at on a bar chair by the window.  Pastry and dessert looked nice, but i didn't try any.

I stopped by this place today after a workout for a smoothie. I thought smoothies were in a bulb shaped cup, however they are in usual cups. They explained that you get a bulb cup if it's another drink (something mixed with tea). My smoothie was good, they add almond milk to it. Also chicken wrap sandwich was delicious! Highly recommend!
The atmosphere here is great! The interior is amazing. The staff is so nice and I always enjoy whatever I order. Their cheesecake is great. One of my favorite places to get a cappuccino!

Solid cup of coffee with a pretty large area with wifi. Expensive drinks but all in all similar to other coffee-centric places in town. A nice spot to chill for cup of coffee with friendly staff and good location.
Nicely decorated with great coffee, food, friendly workers, and a good amount of seating.

Tried out the red light and although the concept of the drinks and juices is amazing. I have to admit that the juice was not as tasteful as I would have liked it, perhaps it could have been a little more sweeter? But I would like to go back and try something else :)

Went because I #thought it would be a great place to get some work done, people watch and possibly mingle.  The atmosphere is cute but won't be going back unless it's with that one girl whose name I unfortunately didn't get....  She's the chick with the tattoos on the upper part of her left arm.  Can they start a Yelp: Missed connections or what?

Nifty little coffee shop located in the High Line Hotel.  Tasty iced mocha drinks, friendly service, and wonderful outside seating in the backyard and front area lit up by old school gas lamps. Free WiFi too.  It's basically also right across some guest rooms and the main lobby check in area. Just a few steps down the hall is a clean public bathroom if needed for hotel guests and coffee shop patrons.  Dropped the kids off at the pool then went outside to enjoy my drink in pleasure! I think I dropped a weight class here!

Stopped here to meet a friend before heading to the Chelsea galleries and this place was love at first sight.  The front has spacious outdoor seating that gives a comfortable airy vibe. I had the intent of going inside, but got totally distracted by the front.  Grabbed an almond latte - strong ,thick, and creamy, which tasted amazing. And the barista was nice.

I come here every morning for coffee (and sometimes a cookie). The service isn't as fast as Starbucks but it's more authentic and real Service. The coffee is good. I typically get a latte with oat milk or almond milk. I do work outside especially when it's nice. They have a cool back area and nice front area to sit and do work.
definitely had a NY cafe vibe. Quick, in and out kind of place. Too dark of an ambiance for my taste but the tea is excellent.

If you are on the High Line or by the High Line swing by this hidden gem. I had a hand crafted top notch Latte made with their Black Cat Espresso.  Delightful just as much as the ambiance. ??? just go܋

We stopped by here after our brunch in the neighborhood yesterday. I never knew there was a High Line Hotel, so the big plastic banner (not even a sign) outside saying "Intelligentsia Coffee in High Line Hotel" did help!  Intelligentsia Coffee is located inside the small lobby of the High Line Hotel. I have to say the d̩cor (of the lobby) is a bit odd and outdated -- only the smell of new paint indicates that it is a "new" place.  The baristas were very friendly. The coffee was good. I liked my Mocha ($5). My husband ordered a pour-over of its decaf blend ($4). It came with one mug of coffee and one small glass jar of refill, and the mug and the jar were served in a tray. It looked very sophisticated. I also drank some of his coffee, and it seemed to be the kind with high acidity. I noticed that they served croissants from Bien Cuit.  The seating was limited and only in the lobby area. There was also a small bar for standing. A lot of people dropped in, took a look, and left, probably due to the lack of seating. The good news is that we heard the barista telling another customer that they would open the garden (located behind the lobby) soon.  Overall, it was a pleasant experience. We will come back if we are in this area again.
Nice coffee but $4. Space basically in lobby of High Line Hotel with little space, cold wind coming through the front doors, etc. Go to Chelsea Market.
Quiet, relaxing spot in the highline hotel. enjoyed my coffee here.

I love the convenience of having a solid sit-down coffee place around my office but there are some aspects of this place that leave me a bit cold.  First, each time I step inside, I'm always hit with the desire to give everything a solid scrub-down. Floors are sticky; tables have small spills and leftover wrappers. I don't want to come off as the health inspector and I don't mind eating dumplings in a dingy Chinatown room but for a cafe where you want to catch up or read a book, ambiance matters a little to me.  Second, on the few times I've been here, the baristas tend to treat the line like herding cattle. I understand that kind of attitude in Starbucks, where you need to keep the line and the flow of orders going or you'll be swamped, but, in the late afternoon, with maybe one or two people in line, there's absolutely no need to beckon impatiently and roll your eyes.  Also, when I took a sip and realized that my latte contained regular milk rather than almond milk, the barista doubled down and absolutely insisted that I hadn't specifically requested for almond milk. Maybe I caught her on a bad day but the barista more or less flipped out and started banging things to show her displeasure at having to remake the drink. At that point, I would have preferred to just scrabble out of there with the wrong drink in hand. It was very strange.  Two points for the amazing goat cheese and honey toast - the combination initially weirded me out but I changed my mind at the first bite.
Overpriced spot for decent coffee with ABSOLUTELY NO WIFI. So much for coming here to get some work done...
Had the maple latte and it was so smooth and not overly sweet...the food looked amazing but we were only grabbing coffee so I will be back!
Great latte but I'm pretty sure they had to hand churn the butter and knead the bread.  It took them 40 minutes to toast a dang bagel.

The food is average, the space is nice, but the employees?  I think the staff needs a professional development day on customer service basics. Like greeting customers, making people feel welcomed, answering questions, and pretending like you're happy to be working here.  I might have returned to try some other menu items, but the employees ensured that I will not be coming back.

I really wanted to like this place, as it's a really cute coffee shop and it looks like they have a nice selection of coffee beans for purchase.  However, I was very disappointed with my drink and the transaction process. I paid with my credit card and as the barista moved to return my credit card, I reached out to take it from her, but instead she just slapped it on the counter. That was so weird. Is it a cultural thing?  On to the drink. She prepared my shots of espresso and once they'd finished, she went to get the milk, then came back to stream it. The shots sat for a couple minutes before she added the milk. The result was a very bitter flat white. And the dairy tasted like butter, but not in a pleasant way. I couldn't drink it and tossed it.
My neighborhood place. Great atmosphere (like you're in your mother's kitchen and den), people, coffee and pastries. Especially great if you like flavored coffee options.
Favorite neighborhood coffee/tea shop. There are tons of loose leaf tea options and some great pastries as well! It's also a nice place to sit and read a book

I know that going up past 59th street on the east side isn't for hip, cool people, but if you ever dare, then I would recommend stoping by and spending an hour or so at what I think is the best coffee/tea shop in NYC.  Well, maybe that's a old statement.  Let's just say it's very good. If it was located in some obscure downtown location then their owners would probably be opening up second and third locations.  The coffee is rich and one can choose from a variety of different types. It's self-serve, which I also prefer. A cup of coffee should be drawn from the drinker. More specialty coffee and tea drinks can be made by some trained college student/barista but if it's just coffee, then I can do it myself.  It's a little small but not as crowded as one would imagine. There are usually a few people working on their screenplays and a table for light conversation; it straddles work/study and date house.  There is also a few comfortable chairs outside for warm weather seating.  The UES is pretty stuffy and there aren't too many reasons to go up there, but this mom&pop place is worth the effort.

I absolutely love Java Girl! The selection of coffee is amazing! They are very much an international coffee shop with coffee selections from all over the world! My usual here is an oatmeal smoothie and almond croissant. I have also tried the chicken salad, lentil soup, chicken roll, and iced hot cocoa with an expresso shot! Everything here is amazing and I love how cozy it feels. I'm such a regular that when I walk in they start making my order without even asking! Love that type of customer service! Lastly, they have many little arts and crafts for sell as well.
The ginger carrot soup was good and so was the rice pudding. Quaint lil place to laze about in.

Think Central Perk from Friends; Now imagine it was tucked away on a residential part of Upper East Side, was tinier, and had a couple of sun tanning chairs resting in its front door... so what's similar? The vibe! Start with cool decor and unconventional mixed furniture occupied by neighborhood regulars, add two scoops of friendly staff familiar with most patrons, and finish with some good (but not great!) coffee. You can then sit back, and chat with friends completely relaxed without any intimidation of emptying your seats. Bonus perk: they sell their coffee in bulk and it's often on special!
The coffee addicts version of an anechoic  dive bar. Disheveled patrons abound- aghast at the idea of smiles, decaffeinated monogamy and hair combs
