Charming little place with great hot chocolate.   Their chocolates are adorned with lovely little artwork.  The Aztec hot chocolate is my favorite.  A great little place to have a date with girl friends :D

once you get past all the amazing goodies in the storefront and make it back to the lil haus o chocolat. you must try the spicy hot chocolate  the spicy hot chocolate is like sex!. i can only finish half the small because it is so rich.. but so gooood. can someone please send some west to cali!
The absolute best hot chocolate, hands down. And a great place for fondue in the back. The home version of the hot chocolatev is good also but you have to use generous portions of the mix.

This location of Matto is so beautiful. The outside is a simple white brick building and the inside has all the right paintings and wooden tables inside. Sadly, the coffee is not up to par. It's one of the cheapest cups of coffee (most drinks are $2 only), but I ended up throwing my iced latte away. It tasted burnt and not good I didn't want to waste getting full on it when NYC has better coffee!
Cute little pop up type cafe with cheap eats DVD drinks We could use more places like this - Everything is fresh and tasty

Delicious coffee, espresso, sandwiches and pastries. Cute space, free WiFi and plenty of outlets to charge your phone. I don't know how they do it, but I'm not complaining! New York's best kept coffee secret... I hope their limited time sign is just a marketing gimmick because I'd be sad to see this place go!

This location of Matto is so beautiful. The outside is a simple white brick building and the inside has all the right paintings and wooden tables inside. Sadly, the coffee is not up to par. It's one of the cheapest cups of coffee (most drinks are $2 only), but I ended up throwing my iced latte away. It tasted burnt and not good I didn't want to waste getting full on it when NYC has better coffee!
Cute little pop up type cafe with cheap eats DVD drinks We could use more places like this - Everything is fresh and tasty

Delicious coffee, espresso, sandwiches and pastries. Cute space, free WiFi and plenty of outlets to charge your phone. I don't know how they do it, but I'm not complaining! New York's best kept coffee secret... I hope their limited time sign is just a marketing gimmick because I'd be sad to see this place go!
I paid $10.75 (tip not included) for a piece of bread, a thin spread of avocado and a poached egg on top. Was a $5 dish. Cortado was good.

I went there because my friend said it was a good place.  I felt the staff was a little rude and this place was pricey.  I had a regular coffee which tasted burned.   My friend had something else and she said it was good.  Maybe they just had a bad day!

Not all coffee is created equal. I visited this cafe on the recommendation of some fellow  New Zealanders and was not disappointed.  I fortified myself with Banana, Tahini, Honey, Mint and Cinnamon Toast from the Breakfast of Champions menu and enjoyed a dam fine flat white before hitting the streets of NYC to do some serious sight seeing.  The vibe here is similar to that found in many Australian and New Zealand cafes. They are nailing the all important coffee fix that we need and providing delicious food. This is a place I recommend and will be a place I return to when next visiting NYC.

This place looks cute from the outside but it's pretty bland. When you Think coffee shop you think a place to sit down and get your work done while sipping a cup coffee. This was not one of those places. The tables were dirty, furniture is very minimal, and the workers are super loud and rowdy that no one can hear anything but them. One man came in and commented on the level of noise and one of the workers just replied, "it's a free show," which annoyed me because there's a place to hang out and there's a place to work. You're not hanging out with your friends at a zoo. Zero work etiquette but maybe that's just me.  The two stars are for decent pastry, and a strong cortado.

Solid intense coffee.  Service was what turned me off and the ambiance. It was really pretentious and cold. The service was poor and just not welcoming. There is no seating, just uncomfortable high metal bar stools. If you just quickly want good coffee then this is the place. They only have 5 drinks so dont try to get fancy with some vanilla chai latte. This place does coffee.
The place is midst in the market. The staff is vwry friendly, the caffee is good and they sell beans if you like!

Ducked in here for a cup of coffee and a pastry just to escape from the sudden downpour and was delighted to have one of the best cup of coffees I've ever had! Despite the limited selection of drinks, as someone mentioned before, it's only so as not to distract from the high quality brew. Had the "espresso with milk" and the banana chocolate bread and the combo was smooth, delicious, and just what I needed to satiate my afternoon caffeine craving! Will definitely be back here whenever I'm in the area. Highly recommend this place for a fragrant, not acidic, and balanced espresso!

Wow. Nothing I can say will add to the wonderful coffee served in this place. Perfect coffee selection and one of the best barista in NYC (the guy with the long hair). For true coffee connoisseurs. The macchiato was devine. 10 stars!!

9th street espresso is a reliable, serious, back-to-the-basics coffee shop. No fancy coffee & milk based creations: the menu can be divided quite simply into three parts, espresso, espresso w/milk & (iced) coffee.  Although this might seem spare, perhaps *too* minimalist, 9th st espresso is a safe heaven for coffee purists who want to take a break from the sometimes exhausting (and increasingly complicated) world of coffee.  What they do here, they do it well. Their espresso w/milk (a latte) might not be the absolute best of its kind. It lacks complexity perhaps - its more bitter and distinctive than the drinks they serve in East village hangouts Bluebird, Gasoline Alley & City of Saints but it doesn't shine through like Stumptown, Abra̤ao or Intelligentsia. I noticed however that it is very caffeine intensive.  For this particular expansion of 9th st, location is KEY. Midtown's coffee scene is seriously lacking and, as a result, 9th st easily takes the crown of best coffee shop around.
I ordered a latte and it had way too much milk and ice. I barely tasted the coffee. Disappointed- don't think I'll come back here.
Great place to grab a quick or long cup of coffee! Be sure to check out Cappy Hour (I've been told it's April only). Great coffee! And they have oat milk!

I ordered a flat white from here. I am very big on coffee, and this was a decent cup. The espresso was a like sour. The customer service was average, i usually try to engage with the people behind the counter but Pennylane personnel were not very friendly. The atmosphere is crowded. The coffee is hella expensive and you get like a 4-6oz cup for $4.75. I would also like to add that the owner is very serious about customer service. He explained the bean that they use--it is fruity, not nutty. He takes pride in his business and I appreciate that. He makes sure that his customers are happy.

I love the coffee here and I like the space too, so normally I would give this place 4 or 5 stars. But this morning I went there at 9am for a coffee, and they said, 'we're out of coffee'(!!!)  What kind of coffee shop doesn't have coffee at 9am?!! Were they literally out of coffee?  Or did they forget to brew it??   Who knows?!  No explanation given and no apologies offered. I had to move on.
I never would have thought to put Earl Grey and Hot Chocolate together, but I'm glad someone else did. It had a strong flavor but you could make the distinction between the two.

Pennylane is my go to coffee spot for work. Coffee beans are stumptown and very high quality. I usually get the latte or flat white and milk is perfectly steamed to the right temperature (with latte art to top it off). The food here (they have small breakfast items and cookies) is a bit pricey. Ambiance is hipster, there is some seating at a common table and some chairs near the window and as far as the crowd goes, there a lot of UN delegates that here go for coffee break so it's always interesting to people watch. I always look forward to their quotes they write outside on the chalk board!  Great place to study/do some work but space is limited, good place to grab a coffee with a colleague.
My daily spot for my coffee dosage, good brews, the cappuccino comes in a double shot

Oh boy delicious. I'm traveling from Florida and found this little gem , trying to refrain from my everyday Starbucks trip which btw I'm glad I did. I got here pretty early in the morning to sit and enjoy a cappuccino. It was beautifully poured and oh so delicious - honestly super delicious - I didn't even add sugar for my sweet tooth. Haha. They also have baked goods which I did not indulge in but they look scrumptious. As I sit here enjoying my coffee they put the music up - which is great and people start flooding in. I love the vibes in here and it makes my heart full being back in the city finding gems. I'll be back on my next trip down - or maybe all week while I'm here

The coffee is pretty good but they're often out of pastries and the place closes (as in stops serving) a good 30 mins to an hour before the time it states on Yelp, and to echo other people here, the staff are often kind of rude
This is my favorite kind of coffee shop. Great coffee, nice atmosphere, and great baristas.

I came across this little coffee shop after a stay in the hotel nearby this past Sunday and I am very satisfied with what I experienced.  I had a cortado made with Stumptown Hairbender espresso. Well-made, smooth and creamy. Then I had an espresso in which you can tell their baristas had gone through lots of training to make it happened. I was also told they serve coffee from other roasters like Hearts, which is one of my favorite as well. Decor are simplistic but very comfortable for me.  A shop created by a man who just wants to serve the area great coffees. A shop with baristas who are passionate about coffee and professionally trained. Go soon.

I had to come back to change my four stars to five stars!  I love this place. The baristas are very friendly and the last time I went they took the time to explain to me the difference among, for example, a machiatto, a latte, a cappucino, and a cortado.  We also talked about some of the trends in coffee culture.  They were very knowledgable and made me feel more than welcomed.  Also, I had a new dessert: the dulce de leche brownie? It was delicious, just like all the other desserts.  Somehow, I always feel better after coming here. :)

The customer service is excellent. Everyone was very friendly and quick. I got a salted chocolate chip cookie which was actually amazing, it was so soft on the inside and the chips were huge. I also got a hot chocolate which tasted OK. It had a bit of a weird taste to it, definitely made from scratch with actual coco powder. The after taste was good though
Found this place through Yelp and I concur with the good reviews. Excellent espresso drinks - I got vanilla added to mine and the service was impeccable. Not cheap, but worthy.
Took one sip of their coffee, and had to dump it in the street.  It was that bad.  Still, it's better than their espresso.

I was in the area because I had to attend orientation for my new gig and saw this cute, hipster-like cafe as I walked by.  I was totally mislead by their exterior. Hence, my experience below.  As soon as I walked in, I waited on the line and observed what they had available. They didn't serve bagels or created sandwiches; they had only croissants, huge donuts and sweet buns.  I was next on the line and very excited; I was in a good mood. I guess my excitement was a turn-off. I was met with such a nasty attitude from the barista. He was like "what do you want?" in such a tense manner, I was ready to pull the stick out of his behind. I requested a croissant and a decaf espresso and placed my Fiji water on the counter. The other barista was like "well, how do you want it?" in such a stank voice. My response was firm but full of attitude, "I will take just take a shot of it".  My smile was totally gone by the time I paid. I waited for the other male barista to finish making the espresso, got my stuff and walked out in a hurry.  You would've thought the cafe was filled with a happy aura because of the cool music and the edible-looking pastries but nah. I wasn't impressed with the customer service. They were so rude.  Even the shot of the espresso tasted like unpleasant 'ish. The croissant was actually okay. But I will never come here again.
So far I've only had a cappuccino, but it was very good.

Quick service and great doughnuts and coffee. Their honey and almond ice coffee is especially good! Not a ton of space to sit and work but customers usually don't stay too long so you can grab a spot. Employees were also friendly and prices are more affordable than some coffee shops.

This is such a nice place, the coffee is excellent (always a double shot which I LOVE) and their pastries are to die for. It's a very nice place to sit down and do some work. After noon it's not so crowded.

This place is amazing. It is a mini oasis from the hustle and bustle of NYC. I'm glad I decided to spend my lunch break here as I needed a break from work. I throughly enjoyed my chai tea and my coconut donut. It was simply divine. I recommend anyone who is looking for a great cup of joe and a relaxing place to unwind or get some work done.

Well, after reading reviews I really wanted to try this place that is pretty close to my home. The truth is the food is indeed very good, so the stars are for the food. Kale Berry salad was amazing and main course was very good. I enjoyed the house white wine but portion was not a standard, it was tasting portion. It was literally two sips. My husband had Bordo red and the portion was tiny again. So weird. Usually it is pretty standard. They brought salad for appetizer, then immediately they brought entry for my husband and like 20 minutes later my entry. You cannot bring entry 30 minutes apart, my husband ate because he did not want to get food cold. I ordered turkey and waitress clearly said that it has veggies and rice or potatoes. I said it is fine. When I got food, rice had beef or pork or lamb... basically red meat that I do not eat. You MUST tell a person that food has beef inside. I am ok with any veggies but having red meat is not acceptable. I was very disappointed because it is not what I eat, so my husband ate it. Then they removed plates and brought check. Seriously? They never asked if we want another wine, or dessert, coffee, etc. It was more than 1 hour before closing, so clearly that was not an issue. We decided not to ask for another wine/coffee or dessert, we just left. So food was good but they way they served it and the whole experience was pretty disappointing. Not sure how was coffee, maybe it is great but it is not a dinner place for sure. Their chef should go work somewhere else. Place was empty on Friday night, not a great experience.

I rarely write reviews, but this spot is worth me taking the time... Pink Moose is incredible. It has a charming, cool atmosphere, great service, and an INCREDIBLE menu. It has all the trappings of a charming 90s sitcom-coffee shop/hang out - all that missing is a vintage couch:) I've always wanted to have a go-to spot in my neighborhood and I finally got it when Pink Moose opened. Now I  eat here all the time but also stop in for coffee and am never disappointed. The gluten free spaghetti is AMAZING, but so are their salads and roast chicken. Each dish is prepared from scratch, so it takes a little bit longer to prepare, but it's sooo worth the wait. It's like eating the most delicious home-cooking ever.  This is a fantastic spot  to meet a friend for coffee or brunch/lunch, wine or dinner and also a great spot to study or read by yourself with the tastiest coffee in the city (they actually roast the coffee themselves which is rare to find). They also make their own almond milk and make delicious matcha lattes.  Honestly I can't give them enough praise and love having them in my neighborhood as there is nothing else like it up here.  This local spot is a treasure but I'm not sure many people realize how amazing it is as it's fairly new. If you live  nearby you HAVE to check them out - you'll be glad you did and it will become one of your local favorites too:)

Stopped in for coffee and appetizers. Left extremely happy and satisfied. Coffee was amazing, food was great and tasty.  Decor & atmosphere are welcoming and cozy. Very INTIMATE.  Great customer service. They roast coffee beans in house, all pizza's and breads are made fresh in house. Ordered the sliders, meatballs, meat & cheese platter and pizza with meatballs. We ended with cappuccino, coffee and cookies. EVERYTHING was great. Will def be going back regularly.

First time here but stopped in twice in one day! The cookies are out of this world, the service is so friendly it makes you want to come here and give them your business! The food was delicious but I'm not sure if I accidentally got someone else's or they took creative liberties (which is ok for me, but not for someone who may expect a vegetarian and find meat) because the description on the menu was different from what I got, but again, it was amazing! Will definitely come back to try more things and support this delightful spot!

Went on a Saturday afternoon for coffee and ended up staying for lunch. The pumpkin pie latte was one of the best I've ever had. Also got the kale quinoa salad which was fresh and full of flavor. The service was unlike anything I've ever experienced in NYC. The wait staff was friendly, attentive, and customer focused. Definitely one of my new favorite spots. I highly recommend checking it out, you won't be disappointed! Also get the chocolate chip cookie, out of this world!

I stumbled upon this place and I am so glad I did! I received excellent customer service by Luis and Mary and had the most delicious and affordable iced coffee in all of NYC! Well priced and amazing. I will be back here for sure-- my new regular coffee shop!

We chose Prodigy over Bluestone Lane, which turned out to be a mistake. While the decor and vibe are reminiscent of your run of the mill nice coffee shop, the drinks left MUCH more to be desired.  I ordered an iced mocha, which was decent, save a few sugary chunks. My girlfriend ordered an iced dirty chai, which is what prompted me to write this review. The drink had a sour taste akin to curdled milk, unlike any other dirty chai I've tasted before. To quote my girlfriend, "I have no idea how they could serve this."    But despite the grimy chai, the ambiance of the shop gives me the impression that we may have ordered incorrectly, and we'd be willing (albeit reluctant) to try Prodigy again.

Prodigy Coffee NY Manhattan West Village 1:30pm Thursday 6th August 2015 Five Stars  It's a pretty quiet shop with four different people having setup shop here: laptops, plugins, bags, four cups of coffee. The music is barely audible. There are 6 two-tables and a little bench counter for two. The big front window, glass door, white brick walls and the two vintage chandeliers give place a lot of light.  What caught my eye was their signature drink "Frost Bite" which their cold brew poured over Shaved Ice $6. I am not sure why someone would pay an extra $2 for shaved ice other than for its novelty but hey why not. (Update: it lasts forever)  Coffee: Strong, Tangy, and Tannic Cold Brew Caffeine: Very High (update: I am super wired) Ice: Shaved Cup: Classic Clear Plastic  They do sell branded mugs, Harney and Son Tea,  a small selection of pastries and bread loaves which look pretty delicious.  They have two other interesting drinks ($4 Each)  1. Undertow: Shooter of simple syrup, cold milk, and espresso (available only in the store)  2. SnakeBite: melted dark chocolate with espresso shot.

I stumbled on this shop while wandering around the village on an impromptu, self-guided tour motivated almost completely by my deep and unyielding love for Bob Dylan. I digress. There are half a dozen tables, a standing bar, and a wonderful coffee shop vibe. The street view allows for people watching, and the place, albeit small, isn't so cramped that one can't sit and and stay awhile. I ordered a cortado and it was perfect. The foam was creamy, the coffee superb. The barista was friendly enough, and service was quick. The only thing I noted was that while they use a similar payment setup akin to Square, I wasn't able to leave a tip on my card, which I hate. I'll be back though, and next time with cash.

Stopped in at Prodigy after an exceptionally terrible dining experience at Blossom down the street. A solid soy latte always improve my mood so I figured I would give it a shot.  Ordered a soy cappuccino - thank goodness for Pacific barista soymilk. I have had more than one latte in the last few weeks where they use cheap soymilk and I end up with a gross, chunky latte. I was THRILLED with my cappuccino. SO GOOD! Extremely smooth, happy baristas and a very hipster environment (this is how a coffee shop should be!).  Another place to add to my list of must-visits in NYC!
Great smooth, strong coffee.
I ordered a decaf iced coffee - it was terribly watered down and weirdly acidic even though it was freshly made. My friend's latte was okay. Maybe I should have ordered something fancier.

To all coffee lovers out there, Prodigy Coffee is the place to go if you're in West Village and craving some caffeine (or in my case, something to warm me up on a chilly afternoon).  Wow, this coffee is good.  Such bold, rich flavors - I will definitely have to make my way back.    I tried the Americano, which was simply amazing.  I may have to try the cappuccino next time - a few people in there were sipping on those, and they looked amazing.
Solidly made espresso drinks. In this part of west village, Prodigy serves the best coffee I've tried.
It's a cute little coffee shop. No special decorations, white walls, few paintings. It gives me a feeling that the place is very clean. I enjoy sitting by the window and sipping my coffee.

artisan, quaint, delicious coffee, extremely knowledgeable barista (more so than most).  Up there with the best of them, though as one reviewer stated I'm starting to lose track given the amount of boutique coffee joints that have sprung up in the past year.

Not great... I ordered an oat cap and it was so sour that I had to throw it out after a couple sips. I suspect the oat milk went bad (not sure if it was oatly or another brand). The pastry selection is great though: Balthazar viennoiserie, Blue Sky muffins/banana bread, and Dough donuts. But considering how bad my coffee was I really think there are so many better options nearby: Culture, City of Saints, Blue Bottle, Stumptown, Joe etc. Unless you work in the building and are in a time crunch I see no reason of going here unfortunately.

I am reviewing only to the 38th St location, which space had formerly been occupied by Hole-in-the-Wall Coffee, and therefore I can't help comparing the two since nothing appears to have changed except their coffee roaster/supplier, and the staff.  Oh yes, and the taste.  I have to say, the pleasant, matter of fact staff at PROOF was nice improvement over the Hole-in-the-Wall staff, who always seemed to immersed in their private party which I was sad to interrupt.  However the espresso in the previous establishment was delicious:  smooth, deep, spicy, fragrant.  In contrast, the espresso I drank in PROOF tasted burnt, bitter and generally difficult to swallow.   So sadly, I will probably have to find a new place around the block or go without.

I went in and got a matcha latte. There was way too much milk in it and that made me nauseous. The barista also seemed like he hated his life and was hoping no one ever came in again so he wouldn't have to either.

Quality lattes. So-so experience. Came here around 3pm on the Thursday before Christmas. It was a strange find since it was inside the lobby of an office building, but I spotted the sign directing people on 5th avenue to caffeine and I was in need of a jolt.  They were, I think, tidying up to prep for closing...not that it was approaching that time...but because of that, when one of the baristas went to make our lattes, the other instructed him to make the lattes one after the other instead of "dirtying" the other espresso machine that had obviously been cleaned for the last time. It was awkward because we just stood around waiting for him to make them 1 by 1. I guess it could be worse. Then, one barista was looking to throw out their huge garbage bags from the day, so she instructed us to move our bag off the coffee bar that lifts so that they can leave, and we had to awkwardly squish to the front of the coffee bar so she, and 2 huge garbage bags (gross) could push past us and get out of the shop.  Again, the product was good, and the cheerful barista was refreshing. But I don't expect to be back.

It's a bit bigger than just a hole in the wall, but not by much. Maybe more like a closet. Regardless of the size, this coffee joint serves a nice brew and good pastries. The service is very friendly, you get the feeling most patrons are daily visitors who work in the building. The coffee is flavorful and creamy. The pastries are very tasty, especially the fairly odd sounding gluten-free mango muffin was awesome. It's a perfect place for getting your daily pick-me-up.

love this place! This is the only go to spot I have for coffee breaks in midtown. The workers are incredibly friendly and fun to talk to. I'm happy they started selling the matcha green tea latte. I also appreciate all the email announcements they send me. Happy to see them expanding to other locations too

Yeah, so Dough Donuts, Australian-style flat whites served by an actual Australian dude, ridiculously awesome staff, and a sharp, peppery tasting espresso all make this spot a stone cold 5 star coffee shop.  What boggles my mind is that people actually work in the office building that this coffee shop is hidden inside and that they can just wander downstairs and drink this stuff any time they like.  As for finding the spot just go into 420 5th Ave. Don't make the mistake (like I did) of even attempting to look for it on the street or side street or whatever, just walk into the 420 5th ave office building and you will find it in the lobby off to the side.  Today I got glazed and passionfruit cocoa nib dough donuts (which were both awesome) and a quad. The espresso here is strong and it is of a much darker roast than you might find at a Stumptown or Blue Bottle. In this way the espresso itself may have a more wide appeal because it inches more toward the tannic Starbucks style. However, make no mistake, the stuff pulled here is of an extremely high quality.  This place is hands down one of the best spots for coffee in the area, for something at all comparable you have to go 20 blocks uptown and 2 avenues over to Little Collins (which is wayyyyyy more crowded because no one knows about Hole in the Wall). Also, Dough donuts.  So yeah, a pretty sweet place. I am sure someday someone will come along and try to drag this place down from 5 stars but in my heart Hole in the Wall will always be perfect.

Thank you yelpers for the directions. Never would have found it without your help.  Grabbed a latte. It was consistent with a lot of the reviews in that the flavor was slightly sour.  But staff was super nice. Two ladies running it were friendly. And they knew their regulars. Very small town, quaint feel to the place.
This is one of my go-to coffee place. Also this place have very good pantries and I love the chocolate walnut almond cookie.

Got a chocolate chip banana bread as I had something caffeinated earlier. Nice flavors, not sure if they make it there (I doubt it since it is such a small place) but brand is really good. Really nice people here. Will go back for a Flat White or a cappuccino.

Love this place - totally unexpected in the lobby of an office building. Great coffee and they have Dough doughnuts from Brooklyn! I had a strawberry thyme scone, which was phenom!  Super simple and limited menu of coffee, so if you're looking for fancy sugar drinks with a splash of coffee, go somewhere else!

Really cute coffee shop in the heart of midtown chain coffee fronts. I was in the neighborhood for meeting and needed caffeine. I checked Yelp and it pointed me in the direction if Hole In The Wall. Like others I was a little confused as to where it was exactly. I finally walked into the building marked 420 5th Av, walked around the corner to the right and stumbled right into it. I ordered my usual, a drip coffee, and chit chatted with the baristas. Everyone who works there are sweethearts and seem to be genuinely friendly people.  Four stars only because the coffee was a tad weak for me.  Otherwise, great option for the area. The donuts (from Dough in Brooklyn) looked phenomenal.
Special honors given to this quaint spot- knighted amidst a coffee dead zone.

Perth coffee culture headquarters. Some of the staff have accents so thick they are hard to comprehend. However they will be your new best friend. The ice coffee is the real deal. Loyalty cards available. Once you taste the coffee you will come back every day

One of the best coffees I've had in NYC. Great staff and delicious snacks!  Very similar to the amazing quality of coffee in australia which is great from the Aussie owner. Will be my new regular. Well worth the extra price for the friendly staff and guaranteed good cup of coffee!

This is little tiny coffee shop..(?) It's near bryant park on the 5th ave. coffee tasted okay. It's like stop and go=) They are nice to serve. Everything is good=) especially for me. BUT, I know it is little hard to find it if you are first time to be around here. You need to go into the building. Don't give up! =] You are right on the way. And you can can it nice brew coffee=]

I love my cappuccinos and I want them the way I want them without anybody telling me how I am supposed to like them. I have been in this coffee shop twice and each time do I get attitude. Now if the cappuccinos I git from them would at least be great I may put up with it, but it is not. It is weak and can't even outdo Starbucks, which is a shame.
Iced matcha latte tasted like... very expensive milk and ice. Barely tasted the green tea. Same for the beets latte :/

the cafe is hidden at the corner, a little difficult to find it. do remember turn around the corner, and look for a white big shop sign. I ordered a small soy latte as usual. Definitely the best latte art by using soy milk that I've ever seen. Coffee is too strong to my taste as they added two shots of espresso in the small latte. The aroma is not as perfect as seven grams coffee. but I guess it's a personal taste, some people may prefer Ramini's boldness and intensity. The overall store decoration is chic and cute. Will try work/read over there on a weekend afternoon :)

Unexpected little cafe in Midtown. There's very little seating (2 high tables for 4 people each and two benches inside) and it does get busy.  I got the iced chai latte - just your normal chai but they don't charge extra for soy milk, which was nice.  My friend got the Kyoto - after drinking Starbucks for a couple days straight it's definitely something different. He could even feel the caffeine halfway in since this has double the normal amount.

I work in NYC I get coffee twice a day. It's a shame that this local coffee place have a lousy coffee and lousy service. No branding, lousy cheap coffee cups and poor cover.  It's really a shame because I rather buy from a small coffee shop then a large brand name chain. At this point I rather go to a branded coffee chain where I feel more comfortable. sorry about this

The coffee was actually not very good - perhaps their espresso is better. It is cute inside with a couple of tables. I got a blueberry muffin which was good, but to be honest, I would have been happier at Starbucks. Which kind of kills me to say because I really like to support local coffee shops. I would give it another try for the espresso.
Great coffee. I'm thrilled I stumbled into this place after a long commute. I had a delicious Flat White. Really yummy. Friendly and educated staff. They really know their coffee!

Love love love this place!! The baristas know how to do a great flat white which is a rarity in NYC. I can also highly recommend the muffins at 2.75 they are a steal. How folks can still roll up to Starbucks when this place is around is beyond me. But I do hope the crowds stay away! 5 stars!

Not great, not bad. The place is busy and the baristas are friendly, so they're doing something right, but it's very small so not much in the way of seating, and the temperature control is bad.  If you're in the area and looking for a good place I'd recommend checking out Ramini, but I wouldn't go out of my way to get here.
THIS IS NOT A REVIEW BASED ON THE COFFEE. No bathroom and rude staff. If it were just a counter for people to grab a quick coffee to go I wouldn't care, but they have tables for people to do work at.

A very no-frills coffee shop, the one upside is that Stumptown is used for the drip coffee here.  That said, no pour overs are available, the space is tiny and the staff is hardly friendly.  Look elsewhere if you want a quality cup, especially in a good atmosphere.

I am on a crusade to try a new coffee shop every day on my way to work until I find one I can't live without. This is not the one.  There was one person, completed drink in hand, on line when I walked in. She and the barista were chatting. No biggie, I wanted to peruse the menu anyway to find the most tempting item on a day that was heating up. They continued to chat as I scanned the menu finding no iced options, panic beginning to itch at me. Decided that when I was acknowledged I'd ask if it were possible to get something black and iced. Waited a good 3-4min to be acknowledged at 820am on a weekday. When I was the only un-served guest in the place. ::upside down smiley face emoji::  Finally I asked about an iced coffee...perhaps a cold brew? Question was met with hesitation...turned my panic itch to an all over uneasy feeling. Apparently they "can make" iced coffee...and when I asked about a cold brew, they had stumptown bottles in the mini fridge behind the counter. I was warned it'll cost $1.50 more. I'll take it...over your hesitant to respond about iced coffee.  Anyway, stumptown was good, but I already knew that. Aside from the lackadaisical service and the limited iced options, ambiance was cute and the location is nice for a sunny morning walk. But, nevertheless...moving on to the next coffee shop tomorrow...

Walked in to this place with high hopes based on the rating. First impression was good - very chic ambience with a bunch of people working on their Macbooks and sipping on coffee. It was extremely quiet and no place to sit - that was the first negative, but you can't judge a place because it's popular.  What really disappointed was the actual product they served. We had a coffee and a hot chocolate and both of them were extremely bland and watered down. The hot chocolate tasted like warm milk with a hint of chocolate buried somewhere. The coffee was pretty much the same. I hope this was an abberation and not the norm! So unfortunate.

The place is a bit small so if you are planning on doing work there you may not be able to find a seat. The interior is trendy and they played chill music, which gave a good vibe. My huge issue was with the person behind the counter, he was dismal. Didn't say hello, how are you, what can I get you, do you know what you want, any questions.....literally nothing! He just stood at the register looking at me. Not only that, but after he made my espresso I said "have a good day," and he just looked at me not responding.  The espresso was good, but after not feeling welcome, I don't think it's worth it one bit. There's plenty of other places out there that are better and have a nicer staff.  Also....no Apple Pay, only Samsung pay.....definitely a little odd.

Went on a Sunday afternoon to get coffee with friends. Coffee was good but couldn't sit to enjoy it because all seats and tables were taken by people with their laptops. It was so quiet that I felt I was in a library or a classroom.  Note to the management: Please limit the use of laptops to weekdays.

Pretty cute place in the West Village. The woman at the counter was bubbly and humorous as she recommended donuts to try. She joked it's the best and worst thing since we might get addicted. My friend got the honey lavender and I took a bite, interesting herby flavor.  It was about 1 PM and I hadn't had coffee yet, so got a 16 oz drip which did the job and gave me a second wind. They brew Stumptown beans, it was pretty standard, mild tasting good coffee. Brew strength was a little watery and not as strong concentration as I like, but then again I'm used to Philz which is about 2x your regular coffee strength.
To be honest, place was very nice, comfy and quite, looks like ain't one of those crowded places, but the espresso tasted over extracted from my opinion. Good service

Came in early on a Monday morning. It was very quiet and every seat was free. Even though I was just stopping by I thought it would be a great place to sit and get some work done. The coffee was delicious and strong. Great, peaceful place to get coffee. I'll be back again when I'm in the neighborhood.

A combination of Underwest donut and stumptown coffee? I'm in for sure. Dropped by after a short run in the morning and all I wanted was some decent iced latte. Rebel definitely nailed it. Well balanced flavor, refreshing feeling, cool ambience, guess it just worked perfectly!  Rule of thumb - can never go wrong in west village for coffee!

I've been here a couple of times. Their regular coffee is great, and their cappuccino is consistently excellent!  The service is impressive -- the staff is friendly and yet promptly when helping their guests.

Wow what a terrible iced latte. Person who took the order could not have anymore disinterested and the barista was too busy talking about real estate to ( I guess) focus on making a decent drink. I wish this could have been good because the spot is pretty cool. But it's a big waste of $5

This is a quintessential West Village cafe that really makes you feel like you're in the heart of the neighborhood. It's been a bit overrun by the Macbook-wielding mobile workforce, but they use Stumptown beans and the baristas are super cool, making it a nice pit stop along 8th Ave.
Great coffee, fast wifi, and friendly service! But it's a small place so it's a toss up whether there's a seat.
Had a shot of espresso and a cappuccino. Both are delicious. Nice, cozy place, plenty of light during the day.
Best cappuccino in NY so far. The guy behind the bar was extremely polite and helpful. I will stay for another week in NY and I will defenitely return to this spot
Thank you for tasty coffee, beautiful decor and pleasant service. Good music and positive vibes!!!
Delicious coffee!! As well as kind and friendly service. Day 1 had me coming in day 2 without a question. Thanks Rebel!
Relaxing, laid back environment to people-watch and catch up with friends. I could also see this being a great date spot. Tasty americanos!!

The cappuccino was fantastic in both taste and the art on top.  The barista was very helpful with helping decide on drinks and a light snack.  It was a little on the smaller side, but a very cozy place to grab a cup of coffee with a friend.

everything just plays out almost perfectly here --- starting from the simple, yet endearing cafe name...to the pleasant ambiance... and of course, the endless variety of freshly roasted coffee and treats.  If you're a sucker for coffee artwork, go check it out & while you're waiting, don't be afraid to try one of rebel's delicious donuts :)
Cool little coffee place that serves the wonderful stumptown coffee. Almond milk available, as well as sense of humor and a bench.

Cute, quant and exactly what'd I'd want in a little coffee shop in the West Village. The staff are friendly and the coffee is good, I like going with friends and sitting at the big table with the newspaper on the weekends. My only knock is they don't have a bathroom....so it limits your hangout time but other then that it's great. I'd def recommend for a cozy neighborhood spot.
Coffee and tea were fine but what coffee shop doesn't have a bathroom?We had to go to the tavern across the street to use the lavatory.

I visited my best friend in NY during Veterans day. Since she had a meeting to go to, I wandered around and came across this cafe shop. I decided to go in to get some work done since I was behind on reading and had time to kill. They have free wifi which was really convenient. I only ordered my mocha once, but they never rushed me. I really like the vibe of the store and will definitely recommend anyone who wants to get some work done to come check it out.

A smaller spot in West Village, my beau and I stumbled upon after getting off at the wrong stop on the subway. Walked in to this modest 10 seater coffee shop- the barista was super friendly and helpful with options which were pretty limited. The coffee was mediocre, and the croissants were good but not great. If you want to go to a coffee shop with actual seating, go someplace else! Otherwise if you have time and want to relax in west village this is the place to be!

Sometimes I like to get away from the lul of my apartment to really sit down and focus on my writing. Starbucks is too noisy and I can't even hear myself think. However as soon as I entered Rebel Coffee, I felt at peace. The aroma? Heavenly. The ambience? Superb. The decor? One of a kind. I'm able to do the work I need while fueling myself with the coffee I desire.  The customers always seem satisfied with the service and you get a general feel good buzz from the room. Love this place

super cute chill coffee shop in the middle of west village. really good lattes (coffee from stumptown) and donuts (from underwest)! space is small but cozy with limited seating and free wifi. staff helpful and sweet.  such a hip spot! will come again.

Love the vibe here. It's the perfect mix of cozy and hip and is now my favorite coffee shop in the entire neighborhood. Tbere are only a few seats, so be prepared. Also, I'm not sure what the fuss is about Underwest Donuts. Had one here today and as a doughnut aficionado, I was disappointed. Even Dunkin Donuts does a better cake donut. The one I had here was dry. Anyway, not really Rebel's fault. Will come again for sure.

Cute coffee shop.  Good Coffee.  But no Wifi or bathroom?  They told me they are "deciding if they want to get wifi".   Good news is that with No wifi or bathroom, there's never anyone in here.  Bad news is that's a recipe for a short business lifespan.
Great cappuccino this morning.  The have a reward card too!  I will be back.  We will walk the extra blocks for this.
I've been to this place so many times and I have never been disappointed. They have the best donuts and their coffee is excellent. In addition to that, the people who work there are very friendly.

I went to NYC with my sister Alice (wow she beat me to it for reviewing), last week for a day trip and I was in desperate need for caffeine. But hey, I'm not in NYC often, so why would I settle for basic coffee from Starbucks. So I ask some of my friends who are familiar with NYC for recommendations and my friend Lucy suggested going to this place called Rebel Coffee. And come on. Who doesn't like a little rebel in them?

cannot say enough good things about Rebel Coffee. It's small, quiet, has exposed brick, plays consistently good music, and serves consistently good coffee. come one come all. the location at the northern tip of the west village is nice and convenient, too.
If you know your coffee and want to experience the best in the city, this is probably it.

Whenever I'm in New York I always try to stop by Rebel Coffee. I feel some sort of calmness from the ambience and the coffee is delicious. The latte art is on point and the donuts all looked great even though I didn't order one myself. The staff was also very accommodating which I always appreciate when I stop by a coffee shop.
I enjoyed the ambience and decor of the place! The latte was good and staff was nice. This is one of the cafes I will be revisiting soon
Superb coffee shop. Stumptown beans are excellent and the barista (Vivian) is both exceptionally talented and incredibly personable. I love stopping in here.
Cool spot with some character.  Coffee is great and staff is always friendly.  Highly recommended if in the area.

I walked past the sign for Red Fleece Cafe (in the basement of Flatiron's Brooks Brothers) almost everyday on my way to work last summer and always wanted to go in but just never did. I did today and it was a disappointment!  First off: service was good. Friendly and patient as I was indecisive over what to order.  Aesthetic: honestly loved the interior design of Red Fleece. Very rustic lodge-y. There's a few big comfy sofas, lots of outlets and tables, lots of books...I could see myself camping out there for the day.  Drink: I tried the horchata cold brew and I enjoyed it for the first five minutes and then all of a sudden couldn't drink another sip. $5.50 ($6ish with tip). I just didn't like the mix of cinnamon with vanilla flavoring and coffee. It was also very small :(  My friend enjoyed his drink and I'm pretty sure I just didn't order the right drink. I wish I'd been able to sample it first!  Overall: I'd still be back just for the free WiFi, interior design, and rustic warm vibe. I just would not order the horchata cold brew at all #ragrets

Ive walked past Brooks Brothers many times and never knew there was a hidden cafe here! I recently went there to study and I really liked it. The baristas are friendly, the drinks are good (they also serve wine!), it's spacious and has WiFi/outlets, and the bathrooms are clean. I will def be coming back to study here again!

Hallelujah, there's a place serving Stumptown near my office, and it's only a block away!  This little cafe is tucked away in the basement of Brooks Brothers. I'd normally never step inside the store, but the need for caffeine has changed that. The atmosphere was very cozy. It's a relatively new spot, and whenever I go there are barely any people, so I get to order right away. That's a rare find for any coffee shop on a weekday morning.  They serve a variety of hot and iced drinks, namely coffee and teas. I got a soy latte and it was excellent. The menu didn't list iced lattes, so I was worried they wouldn't be able to fulfill my summertime needs (planning ahead never hurts). Luckily, it's an option. The downside is... it cost me $7 for a medium soy iced latte. I think it's $1 for a milk substitution and $1 to make it iced, which is kind of ludicrous. I'll just stick with their regular soy lattes from now on. They also have Balthazar pastries on display. The sticky buns, scones and monkey bread looked mighty good.  Also, the coffee cups have an "in style" design! The promo images were decorated in houndstooth, but when I went it was plaid. Either way, you get a little fashion statement on your cup, which is a cute little touch tying it in with the store.

Red Fleece is a real gem of a caf̩. Fast wifi, strong coffee, chess board, passable pastries all rolled up in a beautiful old-school preppy interior makes this my new favourite place in Flatiron.  The prices aren't bad at all and the staff is genial and upbeat - perhaps not something one would expect from a tartan & tweed tainted clothier that loves to remind everyone that its been around since 1818.  If you are in the area looking for a place to study or just loosen up over a cup of coffee - this is it.

Ridiculously expensive! I ordered the Berry Matcha Latte with Oat Milk and it came out to be $7! That's the same price as one of the flowers in a vase. The latte art wasn't even pretty. I would expect every cup they make for customers to be consistent. Not to mention, the cup wasn't even full. I also ordered to stay, which evidently wasn't taken into consideration. I wouldn't recommend coming here. There are more inexpensive options throughout the city that are better. Nothing special here, other than the fact there is a flower shop inside.
Barista is awesome. Great latte art. The flower latte is great! I love this place Place also sells flowers
Nice place to meet some friends for coffee. It has a nice escape that's very relaxing in the eyes.

Such a cute space!! Picture worthy? Very much so. They use La Colombe coffee (one of my top faves!). My cappuccino was just right with that strong espresso taste I like rather than something that tastes milked down. They also have a selection of pastries to choose from. They have one larger communal table (maybe could fit 4-6 if you really squeeze) and two smaller tables for maybe 2-3 people catching up with conversation. They have free WiFi as well so it made it a nice place to study. Their plants add a lot of life to the shop. Several people came in not for the coffee but to purchase some flowers and plants. They seem a bit pricey for me, but then again, I haven't really shopped around for plants in NYC so maybe the prices are normal?? I'm not often on the east side but I would definitely come back!

Super adorable coffee shop filled with flowers. The sitting area is awesome and flowers smell amazing. They also have adorable orange trees. My matcha was delicious and served with nice foam in a cute blue cup. We sat in a comfy area by the window surrounded by orchids. I loved everything about this place.
Cozy flower&coffee shop. Love the rose latte!

Overall bad experience. Went in one morning for a coffee and it took two bored baristas a whole five minutes to get me a simple coffee which was overpriced, I mean it was le Colombe coffee, it shouldn't be over $3 for a small.  The barista (who was quite rude, not smart as I was the only customer) filled my cup a little over 2/3 even after I said "no room for milk" and she nodded, clearly hearing me.  The concept is an ok idea, but it's too bright inside and not a typical warm, inviting cafe. It feels more like a convenience store with the bright lights and smell - not of coffee or food, but of musty plants. Also, the seating was strange, an ill conceived plan that is again, not inviting at all. I only went in because I liked the idea of flowers and coffee and wanted to support a new business, but nothing about the place made me want to return. I'm sure it will survive, however, people like paying too much for middling food and bad service.

Easily the best coffee we've enjoyed since moving to New York in January, 17.  We've been hanging for a real coffee as our coffee culture in Australia is the best.  Remi meets the mark easily.  Staff are friendly and the atmosphere is great surrounded by such beautiful flower arrangements.  It's becoming my daily go to place (mainly because my fianc̩ is a coffee nut and without great coffee she's just not the same )

"Am I on Mars?"  Cue the David Bowie song...I must have gone on the wrong day or something but this place wasn't anywhere near  You might like this place if.... - you like employees arguing in front of -  a disorganized hot mess - pretentious customers who have to understand if the beans were grown in a humane way and who take 10 mins to order a cup of coffee - way too many choices on a coffee shop drink menu  If not.... I'd suggest walking a block more to Boris and Horton where the dogs are much better

I wasn't very impressed with saltwater cafe. With the great reviews and heavy following I was expecting more. I ordered the matcha latte and looked at the very few, sad looking pastries in the case but decided against one. Maybe it's just the timing but there were only one muffin, two pastries and one oat bar available and none of them looked appetizing.  My matcha was sub-par. Upon first sip I couldn't place it, but as I kept drinking, I realized it was almost half water when I ordered mine with oat milk (up charge - which I'm fine with paying if I get the oat milk... not water). The aesthetics and instagram prescience are there but not the taste or the variety of food options.

I found this cafe through Instagram. If you haven't, I suggest following them because their photos are on point. Even yelp have 5/5 star so that's what drawn me to this cafe. I still don't clearly understand why its a 5/5 but I decided to try it and truth is, I love the decoration and spot but the drinks have a lack of flavoring. The drinks are great for pictures but there's not a lot of taste to it. The ube latte drink literally taste like soy milk, I didn't taste ube at all. The charcoal was interesting but still taste like milk and ending up with black teeth. It could just be me because I love strong flavors. Overall, it's a nice place to sit, read, and enjoy a drink.
A very cute cafe in the area with delicious drinks.  Brownie points for impeccable service!  I love how aesthetically pleasing the store is.  I wish there was a bathroom.

Bright space with friendly faces - maybe it's an Aussie thing?  Plentiful drinks ranging from health conscious favorites like tumeric & charcoal to your basics. Love that they offer to warm up your pastries and have a love hate relationship with the tiny space which can be great for cozying up or doing work when you're able to grab a seat. Wifi works great and it can get a bit loud depending on who is sitting in the cafe that day since the cafe is so small after all. Unfortunately, there are no bathrooms, which means stay as long as you can hold your pee! My only other complaint is that prices are a little on the expensive side, but I loved my charcoal latte which was smooth, slightly sweet, and made me feel good. It reminded me of black sesame, but I'm sure it's the visual effect of the black drink 8)  Would definitely come back!

It was my first time in New York with a couple of friends. We love our coffee fix and decided to go to Saltwater Coffee because we saw that they had charcoal lattes and we wanted to check it out. I'd have to say this is my favorite coffee spot I've ever been too. My friends and I tried the black charcoal latte and the purple Ube latte. Prettiest latte art and best tasting coffee I've ever had and for a reasonable price too. I would definitely recommend to everyone. And on top of tasting great, the workers were super nice and the shop was super cute. I can't wait to go back on my next trip! I even have a stamp card!
Best coffee I had the entire week I was in NYC! These people know what they are doing and are passionate about their work. I will find an Airbnb near this coffee shop next time we visit the city!

I came in here today on a whim as I was in the area and had wanted to check this place out. It's really cute with exposed brick, cool lighting and a big window perfect for people watching. It's quite small though with only a few bar stools and two tables. The menu is also pretty limited, but they have some great coffee drinks and pastries. I would definitely recommend coming here if in the area, and looking for a solid coffee place.
Cute shop and delicious drinks! I had the charcoal vanilla chai with Oatly oat milk and it was PHENOMENAL. It tasted like a marshmallow. Highly recommend. (They also have almond milk!)

New Aussie cafe in the neighborhood!! The owners are bringing their coffee expertise all to way from Sydney to NYC. My favorite is the milo mocha with almond milk (yup tastes as good as it sounds). The interior is well-lit with natural sunlight, minimal but limited seating. Perfect for a lazy weekend catch-up.
Great clean place in the East Village area. I loved the tumeric coffee. Felt cleansed and ready for my day. The people at the shop where very nice.  Will come back if I am ever in the area.

While it's upsetting that we live in an East Village where a good local coffee shop is a novelty, Saltwater Coffee gives one hope like a flower sprouting up between cracks in the sidewalk.  They offer super high-quality beans and friendly but not chatty baristas who speedily knock out everything from basic drips to matcha lattes.  If you need, there are Balthazar baked goods too.  And refreshingly, that's it.  The most wonderful thing about Saltwater Coffee may be what it isn't.  There are no frills, no groups of moms with strollers, or tables claimed by territorial freelancers.  It's not trying to be anything beyond a solid little neighborhood coffee shop.  The shop itself is small but bright with a light Danish design touch and an Australian influence.  For East Villagers with discerning taste, it has quickly become the go-to.  If there's a down note, it's the menu pricing, which may be the only thing Saltwater doesn't nail. Currently, nearly all menu items leave customers with totals of a few cents over the dollar--and no one likes getting .95, .89 or even .60 cents in change. It's a close call whether this pricing scheme is more annoying for customers who get a fistful of coins or the poor baristas who have to count it all out a hundred times each morning.  It's hard to imagine that store runners won't soon round down prices to make everyone's life easier, but until they do, just pay with plastic.  On the whole, though, Saltwater is an excellent neighborhood addition to the top of the East Village.    May the roots of this little coffee shop grow deep and strong!

Easily the best coffee in New York City, having lived in Sydney all of 2016 and part of 2017. Australian coffee culture taught me how bad coffee/coffee culture is in the states wSaltwater imports its beans from the little marionette coffee roaster from Sydney one of the best I had in Australia and actually worked for for a brief period. The coffee here tastes like it's straight from an Australian caf̩! Silky smooth milk and a nice strong espresso flavor blast. The staff are friendly and know what they're doing with the coffee, my only complaint is it's quite small but then again it's NYC not Sydney.
Super aesthetically pleasing place! Coffee was pretty good, definitely get the oat milk and milo! Friendly servers and latte art was pretty!

I walked by Saltwater Coffee at least 30 times before I actually walked in last Friday. When I walked in the barista asked what do I normally drink, and I replied with a flat white; however, before I decided on that I asked what did they have that was unique to their shop ... The barista mentioned a Tumeric Latte, but also mentioned they had a Charcoal Latte (which was a Vanilla Chai with Charcoal I believe). She then asked if I like sweet drinks, and I said I do, so she recommended the Charcoal Latte. I went with her recommendation and what a pleasant surprise it was. Not only was it delicious, but it was Instagram gold! Since then, I stopped by and had a Flat White and must say, it was one of the best ones I've had in the city ... This will definitely be one of my new go-to-spots!

Such a great gem in east village! Their chai latte was one of the best I have had. I had it with oat milk and was simply amazing. Will be back to try the one with charcoal vanilla. Looked interesting. I had a dark chocolate donut too which was not too sweet and I liked it that way.
Consistently excellent coffee. They introduced me to delicious macadamia and oat milk. Staff are great. Highly recommended!
some of the best coffee and super friendly staff!! the place is small but there's enough room to study for some time :)

cafe_name: Sant Ambroeus Coffee Bar at Loews Regency Hotel
review: After years that I come here, now I decided to write a review. I am italian from Milan and I obviously stop by here because of italian coffee and good croissants. I really love this place, but it seriously annoyed me. It's not possible waiting so much time to be served: the girls at the bar are always too slow. Today I entered at 11.58, with only 3 people before me at the cashier; I received my cappuccino and croissant at 12.18: 20 MINUTES for a cappuccino and croissant, on Sunday, with 13 people in total inside the bar. It's always like that, but today it was really too much, and for the price I pay all the time, I expect a different service (for example available napkins too!). I will change place for my coffee.

cafe_name: Sant Ambroeus Coffee Bar at Loews Regency Hotel
review: Standard croissant and not great coffee.  Yelp just alerted me that my review is too short but this is literally the most I can come up with. Not much to say.

cafe_name: Sant Ambroeus Coffee Bar at Loews Regency Hotel
review: Again - coffee as good as Italy , Pastries and cookies that are what Pastry chefs would appreciate ,  Mostly international crowd in this upscale coffee bar where quality and flavor determine every espresso drink , pastries and food    Wow - what quality

cafe_name: Sant Ambroeus Coffee Bar at Loews Regency Hotel
review: Coffee was good as was the chocolate croissant.  The regular croissant was neither buttery nor did it taste good.  Completely different texture than the chocolate one.  I am only writing this review because of the dichotomy when they should be the same.  So look out for that one.

cafe_name: Sant Ambroeus Coffee Bar at Loews Regency Hotel
review: Service has improved and the consistent staff is amazing at proving you custom service. Great for a light snack.

Lacking in customer service.  I visited the store yesterday to buy beans.  the guy behind the counter was unable to explain the difference in the variety of beans they offer.  He seemed frazzled and hyped up on something (maybe too much coffee).  There are other coffee shops nearby that employ professional, knowledgeable baristas.

Cortado fans, assemble!  You can get an iced coffee or a doppio macchiato anywhere. The places that serve delicious, silky and rich cortados are few and far between. If you're a fan, do yourself a favor and check out Stone Street.  Don't come here with your laptop or a book hoping to crash for an hour. The seating is very minimal (wouldn't even consider it "seating"), but the coffee is good, the vibe is welcoming, and the cortados are enough to keep me coming back.
The cortado was pretty tasty. I need to go back and try other items.  Love the walk up window, great concept!

Confusing split between upstairs and down. Unclear who is seating you. $5 for bacon, $4 for avocado (mashed and flavorless and comes in a tiny side plastic condiment cup), $8 two eggs on toast. Pricy for a basic breakfast and unremarkable otherwise. Toast was burnt and did not taste good. No seasoning. Absolute garbage for the money. SKIP IT

I ordered a drip coffee in advance through an app. The message from the vendor told me to go and pick up my drink, which I assumed would be ready to go. After waiting for over ten minutes I asked the staff and she threw me a cup and told me to pour it myself. Sure, that might have been the protocol to have customers pour the drip themselves, but it was my first time visiting the cafe and I thought my order had been forgotten, plus the employees were inattentive and rude. Probably not coming back.

All I have to say is - $5 for a blueberry muffin? Are you kidding me? Price wasn't listed and I admit it was my mistake for not asking first (I paid with the app so didn't see the total) but it was smaller than the size of my fist and I didn't think it would be so out of the realm of the other baked goods' prices. When I went back in and asked how much it had cost, the answer I received was: "We bake them in-house." That's perfectly reasonable -- it really is -- but at that price, you'd think it'd be a large enough muffin, and one of the best ones in town. In fact, the flavor was mediocre, and it was soggy in the middle. I'd asked for it to be heated up, but figured it would just be popped in the toaster or whatever. So I'm not sure how the sogginess occurred, but anyway.  Pic attached with a bottle of nail polish for scale. Size aside, it was a pretty average muffin. This was not worth it at all.  Never again.

Have passed this place several times on my way to work.  Decided to stop in today for an iced coffee, my typical go-to and readily available from over a dozen nearby coffee spots.    Coffee was good, but this place does not have it together.  The process of ordering and getting your food/drink definitely needs to be improved.  I ordered a simple cold brew with nothing in it and my order was forgotten, notwithstanding this it would have taken 10 min to get if not forgotten anyway.  The two workers repeatedly crossed each other up and it was confusing who was doing what.    With so many other comparable options in the area it's hard to see myself coming back.
Came for coffee, left with that and great customer experience.  Devin is the man!  What a nice guy!

I honestly wish i could give this place a higher review, the place was chic with great interior designs, had lots of space, and an overall modern vibe. The food was not amazing and slightly overpriced, but hey, it's NYC so i'll accept it.  The reason for the two stars is for the lack of communication we received from our server regarding "changes in the avocado market".  Yeah, are you just as confused as I was?  I ordered avocado toast with salmon and an egg from this place, and the price listed on BOTH the cafe's blackboard and the menu was $15.50 (or something close to that number, I don't quite remember the exacts); the toast was pricey enough as it was, but when I received the check, the toast was somehow $3 more than the listed price. When I approached our waitress regarding the price of my toast, she nonchalantly told me that because there had been a "change in the avocado market", and overall the price of avocados have gone up, so they're charging customers more.  ......excuse me? if you're going to charge your customers more on something, shouldn't it be appropriate to at least inform them before they place their orders?  I was not hesitant on showing my dismay, and as a result, our waitress reluctantly took off the additional $3 on our check. Bottom line - the place itself is not bad, but the service can be a little questionable.

New level for NY, $6 coffee and not good. Coffee has strange funk to it, didn't get an alternate milk because it would have made the 16oz $7. Not a friendly working space, only table service upstairs but can sit "if not busy".
Everything was fine except that the coffees aren't similar to the picture. We expected to have our coffee made by a barista but sadly was not the case.
Very nice crew and had a great cappuccino. There was lots of seating and highly recommend checking it out!

Unfortunately this place did not meet minimal expectations at all. The place was not busy yet it took 30 minutes to get our breakfast. The yolk was not well cooked and so we waited another 15 minutes for a yolk until we finally had it with the service and asked for the check. The one star was for the good coffee.

Hi, Taylor. Nice to finally meet you. You are so hard to look for ya know.  Location: if you come from 5th ave, this place is on 40th street, your left hand side. So, if you come from the park ave, this place is on your right hand side. Okay, Thanks to Cynthia, I finally found this place.  It's a great place to visit.  I have countlessly said that I hate counter culture coffee.. But this place offers three different kinds of counter culture coffee tastes. I still love the wild one  But I somehow felt like that they made the coffee differently that I can finish my counter culture americano  GREAT  Service: people are so nice. I was making fun of the girl saying that my order should've be a free coffee... she took it seriously... lol  Anyway,  GOOD N I think they all from The Great Britain.  4 stars

Cute and quaint ambiance, so a relaxing place for breakfast, lunch, and brunch. Great tasting foods and drinks. Pleasant atmosphere and staff. I highly recommend the banana bread. Definitely would go again.

I love everything about Taylor St: the staff, the store, and the coffee. I'm also a sucker for the foreign accents that some of the staff have.  Whatever drink you order, give the Wild a try. It has a a slight fruity-sweet aftertaste that I can not get enough of. Although I haven't tried much of their food, I have had the lavender vanilla donut and it's pretty good.  They have a buy-4-get-1-free card, so don't forget to pick that up!

This is a new and hidden gem around midtown area! Came here during lunch break and discovered their classic filtered coffee was surprisingly good. I said surprisingly because this is a small shop but their coffee has a strong taste without being too bitter. If you like rich coffee and balanced coffee, go for their Classic. It seems like they also have a good variety of quick lunch options. Will definitely come for lunch and a cup of coffee to go next time!

Great new coffee shop in a great location, plenty of seating upstairs, suuuuper nice staff.  Most importantly, top notch coffee!  I had a malty, smooth Americano and was delighted by the quality. They have a coffee tasting area, so you can get a sample of it before you even order.

HUGE fan. I'm here everyday for a pick-me-up because: 1. they always have amazing music on 2. everyone is extremely friendly and is genuinely passionate about coffee 3. the decor is on point 4. the juices, teas and coffee are always delicious 5. good vibes only  All-time favorite: tumeric ginger tea!!

I love Taylor St! The staff is so friendly and actually remembers your name (maybe this is because I come here quite often) and has a conversation with you. The coffee is great! I love getting a latte with the Wild coffee or a cafe au lait. They also sell some pastries and lunch items. I have only tried their banana bread and absolutely love it! It's quite pricey at $4 a slice, but worth it.

Stopped in for coffee and cake after a sushi lunch elsewhere.  We were sent upstairs for table service, and it was a good steer. The large flat whites were better than Bluestone Lane's, albeit pricier at $6.50. The slice of coffee cake was also pricey, but size justified the charge. I can't remember better service at a coffee house in Manhattan. Loved it.
Real baristas who make great coffee. Simple and good food. Friendly staff. My go-to cafe.

I was catching up with a friend over coffee at Taylor St Baristas and I was immediately impressed by how cute the cafe was and how much room there was upstairs! My friend ordered a Flat White and I ordered their Homemade Chai Latte. Both were delicious. My friend said that she always does work there because there is a plethora of outlets and it has a really nice vibe. Although we didn't get food, the people around me ordered delicious-looking food. This place is highly instagram worthy and is a great place to study.  After I got back to my office, I realized that I left my scarf at the cafe. I immediately went into panic mode since it was a cashmere scarf and it was the first time I had worn it. I called the number on the Yelp page and I'm 99% sure I ended up leaving a voicemail on someone's personal cell phone. I sent them a message over Yelp, emailed them, and tweeted them. Luckily, after a few tweets back and forth, they told me that they had my scarf and that it was stored away. I realize how lucky I am and am so thankful for Taylor St Baristas' friendly service. My only suggestion for improvement is to correct the phone number (haha). I will most certainly be back again (and will try to remember all of my belongings)!

I moved to NYC in January not knowing much about coffee. However, since moving here I have learned a little (still have a long way to go) and can now decipher between a good cup of coffee and a bad one at the very least.  Taylor St Baristas is among my favorite coffee shops. Both of my jobs are in Midtown and this place is snug between them, which makes my life, a heck of a lot better. My friend and I did tai chi one morning before work in Bryant Park and set off to Taylor St since we had about 40 minutes to spare before we both needed to be at work.  As soon as we walked in, we were greeted like friends. The barista (wish I caught her name, shes originally from south Africa if employers are reading;) ) was super friendly and helpful as we asked questions about what their cafe is known for. Immediately gave us the history and culture behind the cafe, and explained to us about their popular flat white. She also explained to two different types. The classic (which is what I got) which gave it a smooth, chocolate taste, and the other one (my friend got) which had a more fruitful flavor. We also ordered a slice of banana bread to split. The barista also suggested that she put butter on it and warm it up for us (score!).  We went upstairs to sit, and when our items were ready the server brought them to us, Everything from the decorations, to the coffee, to the bread was amazing. It was one of the best flat whites I have ever had, and I can't wait to go back to try the more fruity one just to try!  Also, their royalty program is great. For every 4 coffees you buy, you get a fifth free!! Can't beat it!

It's easy to find good coffee in Midtown Manhattan but it ain't easy finding a staff that is so helpful and always serves your coffee with a smile. That makes Taylor St. different from every other coffee place around. Can't start my mornings now without my Flat white. They do have a variety of food offerings as well and some Aussie pastries that are hard to find around here.
best banana bread in the world and really good coffee, lots of high quality drink and food options

I'm rarely super excited to delay my Lunch to write a review but this is hands down the best flat white on NYC staffed by super friendly Aussies it's really no wonder.  Large space but you may have a problem figuring where the line is but worth it, stick it out for the avocado toast. Upstairs seating looked great  although  I did get mine to go. Check this out , you may see me in my inevitable next visit. Cheers!
great for a morning chat with someone before work. Friendly service & recommend their ricotta toast. Have some great coffee too.

I am a tourist, and I was looking for a little coffee and breakfast spot. It is cozy, and the service is great. I had a mocha and a buttermilk scone, they were delicious. I highly recommend this place

LOVE taylor st baristas! it is a little pricey, but this is not starbucks. it is great coffee and quality food and ingredients. plus a lovely and helpful staff that really values their customers. highly recommend

This is such a lovely little place tucked away just where you'd least expect it! If you're an avocado fan I really must urge you to get their avo toast. It is not the lazy version, they really know what they're doing-- it's nicely seasoned and has little slices of spicy pepper. They have some fantastic donuts as well, and I am a big fan of their matcha latte. Everyone who works there is also really friendly and warm, and seems to be happy to be there. It's such a nice place to start the day.

This is my first Yelp review in probably over 5 years, but I had to rave about Taylor St., which has been a wonderful addition to the neighborhood.  The staff are exceptional not just at all things coffee, but also in overall friendliness and professionalism.  I am one of those people who enjoy going to work each morning and occasionally stopping in here for coffee makes it all the more enjoyable. I should also note that their tea selection is also superb - I recommend the turmeric ginger.

Good espresso and great banana bread, though a bit overpriced.  Be aware that the ground floor is a small cafe meant for takeout while the upstairs portion is a sit-down restaurant with table service.  They don't really make this clear when you walk in.  So I ordered my coffee downstairs, then went upstairs, thinking it was a just a seating area to look for a seat, only to realize I now had to be waited on and order all over again.  They should make this a little more clear to the customers.
Great neighborhood spot for coffee. Downstairs is usual counter service and to-go; upstairs are tables and ability to linger. Great for a midday pick me up or work meeting. Service is super friendly.
Cool vibe and great people but the coffee and drinks are really expensive.  Nice seating area upstairs too.  I would recommend going there to avoid the masses at Starbucks.

Went here twice in one week. They burnt/overextracted the espresso shots for my Americano both times. Couldn't drink it black. Not sure if they had a bad barista that week, but they need to start testing their espresso pulls.  Maybe their cold drinks or drip coffee is fine, but in my experience, barista can't pull a decent shot.  Small but cozy space however.
Been coming here for years and love everything about this place. Delicious drink, great pastries and finger foods!
Best neighborhood coffee shop. Cute interior with amazing pastries and coffee. The staff is super friendly and always very nice and welcoming. It's my go to spot for coffee in the neighborhood.

This is a lovely cafe right by my office. I pop in almost every day to get an iced chai. It is so good - I would love to know what chai brand that they use. It is amazing. Their pastries are great too. I've had the coconut pineapple stick and a danish. The staff is friendly and recognizes most the regulars.

The staff is very friendly and their spice iced chai is delicious. This is a rather small coffee shop, so it's not ideal for large groups. However, if you are looking for a place to hang out solo The Coffee Inn is a great place to do so.

Coming from a coffee snob, this place has the best coffee in the area. Hot or iced, you cannot go wrong. I haven't personally tried their pastries, but my colleagues have only had great things to say about them.

Awesome coffee bar!  They are a very courteous and friendly. They serve you quickly and the coffee is hot and pastries delicious. They even remember you and will have your usual order ready and waiting when you get to the counter.  Much better than those other large coffee chains!
Ice coffee was bitter, kinda small serving for $4.  Very small location with limited seating.

Not being a native New Yorker, but I might naive to think the coffee shops will have free WiFi. The service was fair but rushed during their busier hours, which is fine.  There is not a lot of space to sit nor do work. The coffee shop was fairly loud when I went. Next time I'll just find a nearby Starbucks.

Updating:  wow, I recently visited think and I was blown away with how dirty this location is. I need to retract a couple stars because cleanliness is above a lot of things.   Next time you're there look in the ceiling it is awful.  Taking a break from this location until they can properly do a thorough cleaning.    One my favorite places to go.  Great service & great coffee. Worth checking out before you hit the Highline.  I will say they have a manager who's a little snippy and rude.
