The only thing that I forgot to tell them was not to add the ricotta because I wouldn't like the taste of it. The avocado smash was on balthazar toast. (healthy bread)  Coffee - I got a macchiato and it was a good morning pick me up.  Overall this is a cute place for brunch but for the prices and taste wise, I feel like I could've gone somewhere else.

Australian brekkies are starting to become more prevalent and that's not a bad thing. Like most popular brunch spots, fills up fast, but was able to get a table of four with only a small wait.  Lots of options including old standbys like avocado smash. Wanted to try the Bacon Melt, but they were sold out (as well as all ice creams). Settled on the Balthazar toast with avocado and Vegemite ($8). Always wanted to try Vegemite - a thick paste with an intense tart-like flavor. Wasn't really my thing, so stuck mostly with the avocado on the thick toast. Also got to try the Pumpkin pancakes - served with a delicious maple syrup and topped with pecans/pumpkin seeds. The pancakes themselves were a little on the tough side, yet I really liked the syrup.  Service here is friendly despite being busy. I also liked the Australian beer offerings. Wish I could have tried some of their other stuff since my choices seemed to have fell flat. Another time.

Absolutely amazing. I got the wellness flight because I had been dying to try a golden latte and it was perfect being able to try a little of all three lattes! Our waitress was so nice, and our food was incredible. Recommend the avocado toast and banana bread - incredible!  I will say we got there relatively early and decided we really lucked out because it filled up quick and people had to wait - we were glad we could just hang and enjoy ourselves. Want to go back and try everything!

Came here for breakfast this morning, and it was the perfect spot to start the day.  The staff is friendly, the space light and refreshing (make sure to check out the back room!) and the food will leave you feeling great.  Between my friend and I we ordered the...  Coconut porridge: Pretty good, nothing you can't make at home though.  Avocado mash: The star of the meal, it looks like they put an entire avocado on it! The tomatoes were absolutely fresh, and it could easily be shared by two people.  Flat white: Perfect. The barista is a latte art sensation on Instagram!  Great for some pre-work calm before the storm, as I imagine it gets crowded on weekends.

The Quick: Delicious coffee, flavorful different brunch options, and friendly staff. Great place to bring a book and spend a few hours, just note the food is pricey.  The Details: You walk in to this cozy little coffee spot which seems to be crowded at all times of the day. Many of the staff members have an Australian accent (which I love!)  and everyone is very attractive. If possible, try to get a seat in the front which is perfect for people watching. The back room is cozy as well but has less lighting and less seats available by a window.  The coffee was fantastic and extremely reasonably priced ($1.50). Per staff recommendation, I got the flat white which is similar to a cappuccino but stronger.    Best Dish: Now the food is where it gets interesting. I ordered the pumpkin and feta fritter which was extremely different, flavorful, and mouthwatering. It's basically pumpkin and feta baked together until crispy, than covered in avocado/ guacamole goodness. From here, they top it with greens, pickled beets, and a side of smoked salmon.  If you logically think about all of these flavor combinations, it's mind-boggling. It was honestly one of the most delicious and exotic brunch dish I've ever eaten. I added a poached egg which was overcooked so it didn't add much flavor, however it did help fill me up.  This dish was outstanding and I'd recommend it to anyone, however it isn't heavy and could leave you a bit hungry. If your looking for a light and healthy brunch/breakfast this is perfect. If you're starved, I wouldn't recommend.  The Damage: My delicious entree + coffee came to $23 + tip. I felt it was pricey as I am still hungry, but with quality ingredients I think it's worth the splurge.  Cannot wait to return!

Let me start with the positive: the restaurant is really quaint with lots of light in a charming area of the west village. Very cute interior.  Ok, now the Cons:  The food is expensive but not very good. I got the brekkie board and my friend got the avocado smash. In both dishes the bread was so tough we could barely bite into it. I cut the roof of my mouth. I asked for a steak knife. The avocado was off, and no amount of spices added could fool you into thinking it wasn't. The yogurt was tasty but with only one sad little hazelnut sitting on the granola. Stingy for how much it cost ($16).  They tried to fit too many tables into this space. It's not "cosy" but cramped and uncomfortable. Our table was uneven. I held it straight with my knee the whole meal.  The server came over a total of once and rushed us through the order. I tipped high but wondered why. If the food was relatively cheap I'd be less critical, but it really wasn't. It's frustrating when you spend a NYC brunch budget on a very underwhelming (with rotten produce) meal and tip a server that you can't spot in a tiny space.  The coffee wasn't bad but we didn't get it for 15 minutes.  Worst part? My friend is from Australia and is incredibly homesick so I took her here to experience a taste of home. She left without saying much. She is very polite.

This is probably my favorite place to bring my friends that come into the city other than the fact that the food is amazing the vibes are just insane . We come in here feeling like we literally stepped off a plane to a cute Australian spot! I usually get the avocado toast and add an egg it's classic and filling AF! Today I tried the kale salad off the new menu 10/10 would recommend !!! Yummm

I was walking around, trying to avoid the drizzle. I discovered Bluestone Lane. I ended up sitting outside enjoying a cappachino and a cheese platter.  The waitress and staff were incredibly friendly! Has a nice feel to the place.

Perfect place for brunch or an afternoon pick me up when you need to get out of the office. It's a cutesy place with indoor and outdoor seating.  I got the avocado smash toast (I swear there's a whole avocado on this, I love it). There was feta cheese, and halved cherry tomatoes. I suggest adding on a poached egg (+ $3) so worth it. Along with it, I got the magic. I had asked my server what it was, with a name like magic you just have to ask. I thought it was spiked or something. She actually didn't know and had to ask someone inside.. :/ But maybe she was new, who knows? So what it turns out to be is that it's similar to a latte, but smaller. And more espresso, less milk.  Service is quick and friendly. Kinda reminds me of the cute trendy cafes in Amsterdam. Would come again, I hear the breakfast foods are great. Brunch is served till 4! Perfect for late risers like myself! :)

Have been dying to try this cute brunch spot after seeing it on insta time and again. Amazing for avocado toast (their mushroom toast with pesto looked so good, but i came On a mission). Party of two, we were seated quickly at noon on a saturday. The prices are a little steep, $15 for avo toast and an egg but it is very filling and massive. The bread is so crunchy and fresh, and the avocado is perfectly ripe, really nailed my Craving. And the place is adorable.

I've been to Bluestone more than a few times because it's close to my house and every time I decide it's my last time. Today was the final straw, however.  They always seems to come up with new and innovative ways to disappoint. I went for breakfast with my wife and we had 30min to have breakfast, surely enough time. Of course not at Bluestone, even though the place was near empty. After we order our drinks and they arrive the waitress tells me that they have no food yet because their kitchen is late in opening. This happened at 8:15am. They open at 8am. No offer to comp the teas we had to just leave them simmering on the table because we had to go eat something something somewhere with actual food before we had to go to work. They could have told us this when we arrived and we would have had time to go somewhere else, but they just don't care here I suppose.  This place always has this weird vibe. Not great. Also, food is way too expensive for what it is. A piece of dry bread with some fruits in it was my order the previous time. That was $11 with tax and tip...  Overprices, bad service and very uncomfortable seats. The outside space is a joke and the street seating is very noisy due to all the trucks that go by all the time.

High quality ingredients, delicious Australian coffee, and corner outdoor/indoor seating on an absolutely gorgeous West Village street. We enjoyed Avocado Smash, Balthazar toast, and Granola with our flat whites. The toast was impressively thick, jams fresh, and avocado delicious.  The place was busy on a Tuesday at 10am and seemed half populated by Australians - customers and servers, both. Service was a tad slow for what we ordered. Don't come here in a rush and you'll have a delicious meal at a gorgeous cafe in the W Village.
Sunday brunch BUSY BUSY and the service and food was amazing. Avocado mash was out of this world

The restaurant is very twee, with windowsill seats, picnic tables, exposed blue brick, and stools with small tables. But the food (pumpkin ricotta pancakes) and coffee (mocha) is solid. Service is not the most friendly though.

Walked into this place and thought I teleported to Australia because the whole staff seemed to be from there. Well..I'm under the assumption they are. If not, they sure as heck fooled this girl. I was crushing on the whole staff!  Ok, enough of the staff, let's get down to the main thing: coffee (Although, if you don't believe me, check for yourself). I had a flat white and it was made just right. You can always steal my heart if you can make me a good cup of coffee. So to that barista who made it, will you marry me? =)  The food: I had the Green Baked Eggs. All and all enjoyed except the eggs were a little overcooked for my taste. I guess I should have mentioned that in the beginning. So my advice, tell them beforehand how you like the eggs. My friend had the avocado smash, and it was delicious. It was so yummy that I stole some of it. Sorry Susan.  Overall, it was a nice and cozy place to spend lunchtime with a friend. I approve.

A beautiful find! Australian cafe! Love their toasties and gorgeous selection of coffee! The flat white and latte were our favorite so much that we ordered another round! We 4 ladies went for a weekday lunch and ordered portobello mushroom toastie $9, Smoked salmon toastie $12, Morning bowl $15, Spicy chicken toastie $12. The toasties were lovely because the baguette bread was perfectly crusted filled with warm filling on a perfectly slightly melted cheese Accompanied with the perfect flat white coffee, hit the spot for me Service was very sincere and helpful Thankful to bump into the boss/owner who seems to be a humorous yet charming guy  They serve wines and beer but sadly no corkage. Nonetheless a good spot for small group hangouts I feel. We will be back! Thankyou
Disappointing. Rude, full of out-of-towners trying to be hip. Mediocre.

I went for brunch with my boyfriend, its busy but so worth it, we took a latte on the sidewalk and took in some sun while waiting on the sidewalk for a table. We were seated and our server was on top of us right away with tap water and took our drink orders. We opted for some fresh pressed juices. The green, and the beet, both were very good. For the apps we had waffle and the quinoa porridge. The waffle was caramalized and the quinoa porridge was something very different. A healthy and satisfying alternative to something sweet. Came in a fresh papaya boat with sunflower seeds. Different. Then I went for the half portion of avocado smash combo with poached egg with the half homemade granola parfait because I couldnt choose! And they had that option. Yay! Boyfriend went for the avocado smash. Overall it was great. Loved their coffee, service was great, Marcelo the manager got us seated he was really nice then the server was very efficient despite the rush. I will be back!

I came here for brunch with my cousin on a Sunday afternoon. Wait time was approximately 30 minutes, as estimated by the seating hostess. Very fun vibe here - the quintessential brunch spot if you're looking for a good Avo toast. I didn't want a full Avo toast sandwich, so I opted for a Brekkie board (half Avo toast, half granola/yogurt cup). The granola was delicious! My cousin and I also got the almond milk latte that was super tasty. Definitely a spot to come back to ASAP!

I really enjoyed my experience here. Don't let the line outside scare you - they are really good at turning tables and getting people in as fast as possible. Our server was extremely friendly and offered to answer questions immediately. We ordered two Brekkie Boards and some great coffees. The prices are good for the quality of food. I look forward to going back and trying the rest of the menu!
Despite the long lines on the weekends, this Australian cafe will always make room for a solo-diner.  The food is consistently fresh, delicious and quick.
Fresh ingredients, friendly Aussie service, and very flavorful.  The coffee is also very good.  You won't be disappointed.  Get the avo smash and some fritters for a real Oz brunch experience.

Worst coffee experience in NY - spoon was filthy with food remnants on it and when I asked for a new one, it was apparently a really big deal for the waitress to go and get another 50cm away from our table. - coffee was burnt and cold and when I took it back it came back the same way, only with an increased air of "I dgaf" attitude. Waitress and barista seemed to have a snigger as if I didn't know how to drink/appreciate my coffee and it was meant to be that way. - when I asked for a lid for my takeaway coffee, the barista gave me a filthy look and told me they were "over there on your way out" - the check came back and when I asked for the second coffee to be taken off my check (which I hadn't had more of a sip of, again this was a big deal and made me feel like I was trying to scam a free coffee)!  Sorry guys, this kind of sloppiness and attitude might be acceptable in Australia where your hourly rate is paid no matter what, but in NY you won't survive another six months like this.  For context, this is my second review ever onYelp - I felt compelled to write a review based on this being the worst coffee experience I have ever had in this city.

Ahh conflicting feelings! I wanted to like this place so badly. I miss home with a passion and I'd been hearing about Bluestone for quite a bit now, so when some friends from Brissy were visiting we finally trekked over for a post Halloween brunch.    The Good -Chai Latte: this is the closest I've found to aussie chai in ages! So good, so cinnaminny, possibly changed my life, a little too sweet to get regularly but as a treat it was delicious -Avo Smash- my friend who got this was the only one who actually finished her dish, was amazing! -Egg Cup things- Sorry can't remember exactly what they were called, the server told me only one came with an order  but it came out with two! And I was still only charged for one so that was cool, I don't know if they changed their portion size but that was a nice surprise -Atmosphere- I headed to the back to check it out and almost started crying, it really felt so much like I could grab that chai latte and walk down to the beach, I think I need to book a plane ticket  The Ehhhhh (I don't want to say bad, nothing was truly awful) -Our Table- They were busy, it was raining so they couldn't use the outside, and their place is small, none of which of course, is their fault at all. The issue became when we were kind of forced into taking a seat at the window bar and be served there. The (i'm guessing) manager pointed to the seats and was like "That's all I have, sorry we're busy this morning" which normally we would've been okay with but I currently have a broken ankle and I couldn't freaking fit my foot between the chair and the wall and spent the entire meal in crazy amounts of pain. We weren't really in a hurry to sit, if he had asked us we would've told him that we would wait for a better table for me. But we felt rushed into taking it and I guess hoped against hope that he would take my obviously broken ankle into account before we were sat. It just would've been nice if I hadn't been sat at such an obviously non handicapped friendly seat (I realize this is NYC and that doesn't happen, it just would've been nice) -Service- Waited quite a bit for menus, waited quite a bit for water. They were busy, I get it. The barista was really combative towards my guy friends for some reason  Bottom Line: I don't know, it was truly a strange experience.

This cozy Aussie caf̩ is smaller than I expected, but at 11 AM on a weekday I was easily able to get a table right away. Service is a bit slow, and not particularly friendly, but it was more impersonal than unpleasant. Unfortunately, they were out of mushrooms, so I couldn't get the portobello mushroom toast I was hoping for. I ordered the coconut quinoa porridge instead, which was tasty, but I was surprised to find that it was served cold. It had lots of fresh berries in it, which made it naturally sweet. I also asked for a side order of buttered toast (off-menu), and was shocked that it cost $6, but at least it was two thick slices of their prized whole grain bread. The iced latte was good, but they didn't make simple syrup available as they do at their Bryant Park location, so I couldn't sweeten it. I was able to charge my phone while sitting at the bar area, with a great view out the floor-to-ceiling windows, which was very handy. I definitely intend to go back again, to try the portobello mushroom toast.

I would not come back here for the food. The pancakes tasted like rubber. And the service is really slow even though it wasn't that busy (about 40+ minutes for the simplest food). We didn't get waters until we were done with food. It's just not good.
Cutest place ever with the friendliest staff!!!! I have now been here 4 times and every time the staff is just the best.  Food and coffee is always perfect!  I will continue to go here more often.
Stellar coffee served alongside simple & healthy fare with caring and attentive service - fantastic addition to the neighborhood.
Delicious coffee. Proper flat whites served but the service is terrible. Its amazing what bad service does. You go from loving a place to never going back in in no time.
I would have given 5 stars, I think they're coffee is probably great but they don't have decaf but they do have oat milk.

Tiny little coffee shop that has a counter where you order and three or four bar stools to sit at. We were visiting NYC for a few days this past week, and after visiting a couple of museums, we wanted to take a break and enjoy a coffee/tea while it rained. This is really a grab and go place, but since no one was else was there, we sat on a couple of the bar stools for a few minutes. Decent tea/coffee. Decent service. Nothing bad/nothing particularly special about it. Good place to grab a coffee/tea to go if you're in the area.
Service - 2 stars  Batch brew 1 ($2.50) - 3 stars Pretty dilute but smooth and not tannic.  Pastry selection was dismal.

I have not had coffee at more than half a dozen places in NYC but the coffee here was really pretty good.  The space is a little small but was not crowded when I was there.  One of the best features of this place however was the 16 USB power outlets on the wall.  So many of my trips across NYC have been plagued by low phone battery.  So if you want a good cup of coffee and a place to charge your phone while you trek across NYC, give this place a shot!

I live for coffee shops. Box Kite is one of those hidden gems that you stumble upon, nearly missing it, as you stroll through your neighborhood.  I usually get a cortado (sometimes with a pastry), sit on one of the few stools available, and read while I enjoy my drink. Their espresso tonic is also one of my favorites!  There's usually only one barista working, so if there's a line it might just take a bit longer than you'd expect, but hey, all good things come to those who wait!

Well brewed coffee, though the bean for the drip wasn't anything amazing. My wife's latte was pretty good.  For those complaining that this isn't "strong" Italian espresso... it's not supposed to be. The Italians over-roast their beans, and that's not what third-wave coffee is about.
Great coffee and friendly staff. Tucked away on 72nd this tiny shop is a favorite among the locals.

Upper West Side is a wasteland, when it comes to quality coffee and espresso.  Lots of low to medium level places like La Pain, Joe, Aroma, and Darth Starbucks.  On the higher end there's Rex down on 56th and Irving Farms up on 79th.  Both are very good, but not "special."  So was awesome to find Boxkite Coffee on 72nd this morning. Great tiny hole in the wall spot.  Lots of care given here to quality brew.  Definitely the go-to spot on the UWS.

My friends and I love this shop. Never have I seen more care taken in the making of an espresso drink. Really delicious cold brew as well.  The only reason it's not 5 stars is that there's this one guy who's consistently rude. One of the baristas, he might even be the owner, big dark beard and just no sense of how to deal with clientele.  Everything else is great.
Awesome little spot, with excellent service and coffee. It's a great place to just sit and catch your breath for a minute, or grab your coffee on the go. Cool vibe, and highly recommend.

Best on the UWS. As a craft coffee trained barista I get a bit snobby. Box Kite is a hidden gem in the hood. I walk past 3 other basic-needs joints to come here. Prices are what's expected of a high end coffee spot. Matcha latte is solid, cold brew is on point, still haven't had an espresso but I will be coming here enough to eventually.

While I'm generally please with the baked goods at Breads bakery , their Union Square location is a lot better . Not only is this uptown location smaller ,but if you're getting to this uptown location nearing closing hours and expecting to get your goods discounted a la the union square location you will be in for some disappointment. Merely 30 mins before closing I was told by I think her name was Sofee that," We don't do that at this location" . Got afew things here and they were good but not as super fresh as I normally get downtown.  I'd probably try to stick to the union square location as their goods do tend to be fresher with higher turnover ,more familiar faces and yes occasional discounted goods around closing hours.

Don't get me wrong. I LOVE their breads and pastries. I only gave this location 3 stars because I felt their staff don't have a good understanding of their own product.  I got a muesli here a few days ago. Before buying, I had no idea what it is. I saw there are grains and poppyseeds on it, so I asked the guy working there if it's sweet or savory. He told me it's savory. But later I realized that it's actually sweet, because there are dried fruits in it (cranberries) and not even close to being savory.  The muesli still tastes good and healthy, but I was very disappointed at their lack of knowledge about their own breads and passing wrong information to customers.
Tasty baked goods!  Reverse chocolate cookie: very good (and huge).  Fruit tart: delicious.  Marzapane cookie with raspberry jam: also good.  Rugelach: the star of the place...

Almond Croissant was flat (as was the other 1 left) and the center was really a bit undercooked. Review got max 3 stars for the beautifully light and delicate chocolate croissant/pastry.  Just very disappointed in Almond Croissant however do definitely recommend the chocolate. Service wasn't anything memorable.

This bakery was so cute! And yummy! The staff was extremely friendly and offered us 10% off (maybe because it was Valentine's Day!). My husband got an interesting sandwich with tuna, hard boiled egg, and olives that was good! I ended up getting a cheese danish that was so yummy! There were so many items I wanted to try. I will definitely be back. Oh yea, they gave us a sample of chocolate challah bread! Yummmm!
They had me at the wafting aroma of chocolate... amazing bread and baked goods! Grab cookies, croissants, sandwiches, just myriad of yummy goodness!

Their babka is the best I've ever had.  I don't like this location, the coffee is terrible and expensive for the quality, the chocolate croissant is average and the chocolate bar inside was still hard and not melted, the service is ok but very slow.
So far I have tried poppy seed danish, smoked cheese croissant and almond croissant. They are all really pricey but taste really really delicious!

I've been passing here for some time now. Each time I ride by on my bike, or walk by, there's this wonderful baked goods scent just dancing up into my nostrils doing its best to pull me in.  After having this encounter a few times, I finally gave in on a decent Friday evening and sat outside, thanks to the construction above which provided the much needed shade.    1 Reverse cookie + 1 Triple choc-chip = A GOOD TIME.  Paired with complimentary water.  Prices were decent for these 2, @$3 + a piece.  They've also got coffee, and A LOT MORE baked goods which seem super delicious.  However, this was just a stop for dessert after dinner.    I'll be back for something more complex.

The bakery itself is very commercial...however, they have the Nutella babka, which is why I give them 4 stars. The babka is absolutely delicious--it consists of warm and gooey dough slathered with Nutella. Definitely a good place to pick up some bread and pastry.

First time eating something other than dessert. Had the soup of the day (white bean soup), potato bureka, and the Brie and olive sandwich. It took 15 minutes to get a seat as people were just sitting there reading and not eating during the lunch rush. The staff is super friendly and everything was delicious.

Outstanding service and yummy sweets.   I love the chocolate babka cake...a must if living on upper west side and looking for a great bakery. A definite must!!!!!  Great for an after movie treat or Lincoln center treat!!!!!i I Go every morning !!!!!!  Great staff as well. !!!!
You had me at "Chocolate Nutella babka" and of course daily pastry with tomato jam and goat cheese. Just stop! Easy access, great to go, sweet location.
One of my favorite places in the city ! Great food , excellent service and love your Tunisian sandwich guys. Thx Adam,, spot of kindness in NYC.

Usually I really like this place. Their bread is really good. I was in there 20 minutes before 9 tonight. They close at 9. I bought a loaf of bread but they couldn't slice  it because they had already cleaned the machine. (Yet they had a ton of bread left) The girl who was the manager really wanted everyone out of the shop because she wanted to close 20 minutes early. I wish they could put a sign on their door that they were closing early instead of being rude and unhelpful. They were open but I felt very unwelcome.  I wanted to have a quick coffee and pastry but changed my mind and went to Starbucks instead. Usually everyone is so nice in here but after tonight I will not rush back. I go to this place a lot.  I think the manager this evening could care less about all her customers. I usually buy a lot in here but tonight was  just really bad service.

I am not a chocolate lover.  However, I took one bite of the chocolate babka and feel in love immediately.  It was definitely love at first bite.  All praises to the chef and their hands.  Thank you Breads Bakery, you proved anything is possible.  I am now a chocolate lover, but my love belongs to your babka.

The baked goods are good however service at this location not so good. Came back from Paris recently and was craving for patisseries like those from friendly Parisian bakeries. Ended up visiting this upper west side location.  Got 3 Babkas, Pain au Raisin and croissants. The cashier did not automatically give me a bag to carry all of this I had to ask for a bag. Then the items were placed into the bag messily I had to reorganize them so they did not get damaged on my way home. The cashier also did not say think you.  Cafes and bakeries in Paris are so much more polite. Aw well I am back in NYC after all.
I was less than blown away by the babka, which surprised me after reading the other Yelp reviews.  But the cheese sticks (especially the ones with jalape̱os) were terrific.

I live for Lola Colombe coffee, and this place has tons of it. The service is also friendly and quick (thanks to no cash) so five stars for that. I love the punch card idea, but I would love an app even better since I never remember my card.  I only have two complaints:  1. The shop is a little small, with little being an understatement. Two customers can fit in here at one time before a line forms outside the door. Be mindful of that if you're coming on a rainy or particularly frigid day.  2. Management,  if you are reading this, you absolutely must start sourcing your coffee cups and lids from another vendor. I've been here five times and each time the coffee drops from the lid while the lid is secured on the cup; it's annoying and it hurts.  I probably won't buy more coffee made here because of the cup issue but I'll buy your La Colombe coffee beans/ grounds to make at home.

I went here a few days ago and got a cold brew and an espresso on the side. The cold brew was good and the espresso cup was full to the brim...not good. The staff wasn't friendly at all. I ordered the drinks and then pulled out a $20 to pay however, I was told so rudely by the barista that they don't take cash here. OOPS. Maybe they had a sign that I missed that said no cash is accepted but man...I walked away from that store feeling like I committed a crime by trying to pay with cash.... Nope not gonna come back here

Customer Service! Customer Service! Customer Sevice! Guys, you should never ever give your customer an attentude, especially if you coffee is just O.K. there's Little Collins right around the corner and Starbucks, if you must. There's no excuse for being dicks to your customers.

I used to go to this place on DUMBO. This looks like a much larger spot and lots more space to sit. Looks like it used to be a bar and they converted it. Seems to work! The first time I came in here, I had a flat white. That was just fantastic. I cam in again and ordered a Latte the next time, and it was just lackluster. I barely tasted the coffee itself. I'm not sure why, but it just wasn't the same for me, as it used to be. I will stick with the flat whites! If only I could get the same flavor of the coffee in the flat white, with the latte, then that would be awesome.
I loathe sour coffee, other than that I have not much to say about this place.  The plus side is its a luxury that the coffee shop is so spacious and they didn't attempt to jam it with tables/chairs.

We wanted to try a coffee place near our hotel with high reviews so we stopped here. We had just eaten so no plans to get any snacks, but a lone tres leches donut sat in the display... and I had to split it with my husband.  My maple shay was a little too sweet for what I'd like, but hey I did get something with maple. The tres leches had a tasty creme filling inside, but lacked the moisture I'd been hoping for.  The decor inside is really cool,  like a casino table. Service was very lacking though. The cashier did not share my enthusiasm for the donut, and seemed annoyed when I tacked it onto our order.

The people that work here are really nice! It was definitely one of the better interactions I've had at a local coffee shop. Some places are pretty indifferent to their customers but they seemed like they cared a lot.  I got a decaf mocha and it was pretty good. Very strong aftertaste for the espresso (but not in a bad way). I didn't even ask for less syrup and I thought the mocha was at a good sweetness level.  The environment is okay for working - the music is rather loud so if you want quiet this is not the place. They have free wifi!

It was my first time visiting and I loved their retro-feel interior with wide space to do your work/casually hangout,especially at the back. I've only tried their regular latte which was decent,can't really describe the taste but,that it was bit different compared to other stores' lattes.Overall it was worth the visit.
Lots of work space. One of the best almond lattes in the city
good coffee, several small tables, 1 big one towards the back by 2 bathroom stalls. the vibe feels a bit sterile.

Shocked that I'm saying this because I love good gooey melty cheese, but I found the innards PDQs to be meh until they cooled down and I tried them at room temperature. The inner cheese contrasts much more starkly with the chewy outer bread at that point! I think I was expecting a more hefty, creamy cheese filling rather than the almost light snack that the PDQ turned out to be! At 11am the popular flavors were all sold out so come early if you want to try something unusual like fig !  The brigadeiro croissant was huge and MESSY! I took mine to the seaport to eat and was hands deep in chocolate icing with no napkins. It was a wonderful time but not my best show as a functional adult. I wasn't sure about how the very cake-like chocolate melded with the big croissant and felt like it was a mismatch of flavors and textures. Nevertheless a big ball of chocolate ooze is always fun to eat and the croissant becomes burrito-size in heft by the time you get to the middle.

Delicious but absolutely tiny as can be for the price.  $7 empanada that is VERY lightly filled? The PDQs are good but it would be nice to be able to just get 1 or 2 of the sandwiches and not 4. Someone posted a menu pic on here that is also not accurate and they have increased the prices since then.  Let's put it this way, I left after $12 and went to go get lunch...delicious treat but light if you're looking for a real lunch.

Stopped by for a quick coffee while strolling through South Street Seaport. I'm always in the mood for a sweet treat but unfortunately it was about an our before their closing time so there wasn't much left to choose from so I took a pass and we just got two small coffees $5 total. The coffee was good and the employees were nice and they had a small seating area but no available outlets to recharge my phone unfortunately. I think it would be better earlier in the day when there's a better selection to choose from.

Adorable Brazilian cafe in the South Street Seaport District.  The decor is cozy and classy,  but the space is tight. We were fortunate that it was a chilly afternoon and there was space, but consider the cafe seats about 10 and stands about 5. I tried the Dulce De Leche cake, a hearty slice that can be shared. It's definitely good enough to get again, yet maybe not the top choice. The coffee was served warm, not hot.  The prices were exactly as expected, 'reasonable for NYC' pricing. For a first experience, I'd say 3/ 3.5, I'd like my coffee hotter next time and I look forward to trying some of the other goodies. especially the cheese breads they are noted for.

Overall, Cafe Patoro is average. I thought that the pao de queijo (PDQ) bread was a bit too crunchy and dry rather than doughy and cheesy inside. The black olive and pepperoni PDQs had a nice saltiness to the bread, but still suffered from being a bit stale. The PDQ sandwiches are bite-size so they make a good snack. However, I did not think that any of them were really memorable. What I do appreciate though is that Cafe Patoro took a traditional Brazilian snack and turned it into a more accessible food for the American market.

Cute little cafe selling authentic p̣o de queijo (Brazilian cheese bread balls) that's fresh, warm, and cheesy. Plus friendly staff and free chips if you check in on Yelp! (at least they had that deal when I went) The chips are dried, crunchy slices of p̣o de queijo of different varieties, like pesto.

This is an adorable cafe. For the longest time, I was searching for a Brazilian cafe that offered the infamous pao de quiejo, my favorite cheesy bread. It's a small shop but with plenty of choices. The woman who assisted me was very friendly and helpful. The pao de queijos were popular because when I ordered, it was nearly gone (and there were a lot of flavor options!). For $6, you get 5 slightly bigger than average pao de quiejos and had to get a slice of brigadeiro cake for $6.25, which looked amazing.  There were a few tables available so we decided to sit down: three adults and one stroller. The woman graciously offered to heat up my pao de quiejos which I immediately nodded with force. Nothing like warmed up bread to make my afternoon snack even better.  Thoughts on the five pao de quiejos:  Original - you can't go wrong with the classic. Got two of these and glad I did since we all shared it. It's just unbelievably fantastic, brings back memories when I first had this deliciousness 10 years ago at a Brazilian restaurant and still taste as fantastic as ever.  Pesto - hint of pesto flavor without being overwhelming.  Pepperoni - i love pepperoni so thought this would be cool to try. Little bits of pepperoni are embedded in the pao de quiejo. Light aroma, good taste.  Roasted garlic - for those who love garlic, this would be a great treat. Very fragrant and a subtle smell yet strong taste when you bite into it.  All of the pao de queijos had great consistency and pulled apart nicely. Of course, as I received my items, a fresh batch of originals come out of the oven...melt*.  Brigadeiro - never had this cake but saw lots of reviews and photos on this and of course had to try! It looked like a piece of yummy chocolate cake. The description for it is a dark chocolate cake with Brazilian chocolate truffle filling. Fairly small sized slice of cake for $6.25. But the richness, consistency, texture, freshness and taste make up for it. Not sugarly or too sweet, right amount of dark chocolate without being bitter, perfect amount of filling and frosting/sprinkles. Good pick and so glad I tried it. It felt like a guiltless dessert.  My mom tried the coffee there and loved it. She went with the Colombian blend and it was so aromatic! No need for sugar...that's how delicious it was. Adorable spot. My husband wanted to try the cold brew but already had his max for the day. Would definitely come back to satisfy a weekend afternoon craving.

This cafe's high rating is well deserved. As a Brazilian American, I can say their p̣o de quiejos are legit and delicious. We had original PDQ's, roasted garlic, and maple bacon because we just had to try one of their adventurous flavors. Let's just say none of them disappointed. The espresso was also VERY good. My only regret is that I didn't get to try any of their brigadeiros (Brazilian chocolate truffles, basically). Can't wait to come back next time I'm in the city! 10/10

Tried all the pao de quejo's. The original one was the best by a landslide but it was the best of an incredibly poor to mediocre bunch. The ingredients didn't taste fresh or interesting and everything was overpriced. Very unimpressive and expensive bakery.

If you are unfamiliar with pao de queijo, I am urging you to head here and indulge in the cheesy goodness that is.  If you are familiar with pao de queijo, then I'm pretty sure you can agree that it is a delicacy, to say the least!  Cafe Patoro...as soon as you walk in you are greeted with smiles that are just as warm as pao de queijo. The aroma is a mix of sweet and savory as not only do they specialize in serving the cheesy Brazilian bread, they have a small collection of desserts, headlined by brigadeiros. Now...if that doesn't ring a bell either, I suggest you drop what you're doing and treat yourself! I promise you won't regret it!  Their pao de queijo is unique because it doesn't have the same texture as others I've had. It is a bit more crunchy on the outside and has a bit less cheese. I know what you're thinking...less cheese?! Who does that? But let me tell you that Cafe Patoro knows how to capture you because each piece is LOADED with flavor. Not only that, but they even have pao de queijo with toppings such as maple bacon. Now that's something I never thought I'd see. Unfortunately I don't eat pork so I can't review it, but the aroma will please your senses.  Their brigadeiros are very delicious as well. Not TOO sweet and just the right amount of everything. They have numerous flavors, but the regular chocolate truffle is enough to have you going loco!  I would put Cafe Patoro right up there with Pao De Queijo in Astoria. You will be happy with either, but if you ask me, why not go to both?!
My friend picked up some goodies and my my~~ I ate every single flavor of them!  My fave was the Jalapeno & Pesto!! Plus! its best that you buy the 15 for $18... Can't stop grubbin on them!

Everything here is absolutely amazing. The brigadeiro is so good, and if you want to order a full size cake they can have it ready for you within a day. I recently ordered a carrot cake, and instead of the dark chocolate glaze that it typically has they offered to put brigadeiro and chocolate sprinkles in the layers and the top of the cake. It was unbelievably moist and I'm stilk craving it. I've also tasted all of their pao de queijo and mini sandwiches. I'm not Brazilian, but I'm pretty sure they're spot on and the breads are the perfect texture, nice and chewy! Oh and I'm addicted to the cornbread too ...
Always happy to step by and grab fresh cup of iced coffee and petite sandwiches! Never been disappointed!
Love the chai latte here!! My husband gets the regular coffee which is just as great!! Cute little cafe and great staff!!

This little, hidden coffee shop is a real gem in the financial district. I stopped in here to escape the heat and grab a quick refreshment. They have hot and cold coffee drinks, along with an array of sweet and savory treats. I ordered a cold latte mocha (which uses semi-sweet cocoa, so it doesn't taste too sugary!) and a corn empanada. My friends ordered mini quiches and really enjoyed them as well.  The staff is very friendly. It was admittedly slow service due to the fact that there was only 2 or 3 people working. Ambiance is cute and modern. There is a place for about 12 people to sit.  If you have time and are willing to spend a little more on specialty coffee and eats, this place is worth a shot. If you plan on coming a lot, make sure to ask for a coffee card as well!

This is my favorite bakery/cafe in Manhattan. Everything in here is made to perfection. From the food, drinks, atmosphere, employees and owners.  When you walk in you're greeted by warm staff, everything smells/tastes amazing and is affordable. Also their coffee comes from La Colombe which I am a huge fan of since it is so delicious. All the espressos come with double shots so they're nice and strong but not bitter at all. It's sooo delicious when I get iced latte with cream/milk and then put sugar in it. I always get the large size and they even have this amazing coffee card. Who doesn't love earning free drinks for delicious coffee?  Personally I have tried everything in here so far and my favorites are the iced lattes, corn bread (with coconut shavings and corn kernels), brigadero cake, brigadero truffles, spinach/heart of palm turnovers, mango juice, garlic pdq sandwiches, sohno de valso and bis candies. Literally the list could go on and on but if I could I would eat all of those every single day and not get tired of it.  The atmosphere is a nice place to sit down, listen to music, enjoy the food and wifi while exploring the Seaport area. If I could give this place more stars I would. Everyone that works there is so nice. I always feel welcomed whenever I go there and would highly recommend everyone to visit and try the food/coffee there
Excellent!  The coffee is really really good, and the fancy p̣o de queijos are delicious.  Good service and very cozy place

If you crave Brazilian cheese bread this is the place to come . Multi flavored P̣o de queijo and a great selection of sweets and coffee all in a warm and cozy environment with a great looking and very professional manager who cares about his patrons and wants to please . I'll definitely turn this place into my regular neighborhood spot to chill .
Beautiful little cafe. Delicious coffee and bruschetta like pastries. Excellent customer service!
Best chocolate cake in NYC! Take some home and heat it up and it's even better....  The mini sandwiches are so good too :)

I have to update my review to 5 stars because I've just come to love this place so much I stop in EVERY TIME I'm at the Seaport. Even if I just stop by to pick up a cappuccino and some snacks on the run or if I have some time to kill and I can chill and enjoy my coffee and snacks with leisure. As I said in my last review, this place serves the BEST QUICHES EVER!! Additionally, every day they have the most amazing assortment of mini cheesecakes, mini red velvet cakes, cakes....I love this place!!  Service is always rendered with a pleasant smile. If you aren't sure about anything they are ridiculously helpful and friendly.  Restrooms: They have a large one stall restroom. It is clean and well maintained. However, you do need to ask for it to be unlocked for you. Lol. That's probably why it's so well maintained.

Okay so they close at 7PM but stop baking  cheese balls and all at 6PM.  For the last hour of business, there were just a few of their famous cheese balls left to purchase. The nice guy at the sales counter reheated the remaining cheese balls for me. But, they aren't so good reheated.  I wanted to like this place (lots of great reviews) but these cheese balls were too salty, not cheesy or  "gummy" in that unbelievably good chewy way. And, they shouldn't sell mediocre goods at the end of the day. Or, sell them, but at a discount. The Coffee Shop Bar (Union Square West and 16 Street ) does these Brazilian Cheese Breads better than anyone else in NYC. I'm heading back there...

A good surprise to find in Southstreet Seaport this new place. Home made Brazilian pao de qeijo ( bread made with cheese) and great desert.  My pick try the jalape̱o bread and for the corn bread desert.

As a catering customer, I ordered 50 PDQ from them for an event. The owner, Ah La, took my order down and was so sweet. She suggested that I come by the shop sometime to see how it's all done. Given how the PDQ was such a hit at my event, I might have to take her up on her offer.  By the way, they do offer delivery via UberRush. I think I paid at most $5 as a delivery charge for my order and the PDQ still arrived mostly warm, soft, and fresh!

Small PDQ's are absolutely delicious. Try four different kinds and you will not be disappointed. Hope to be back to try this again and try the delicious looking chocolate cake for the first time! Ambience is very nice and the decor is impressive.

Very good pao de queijo. OK brigadeiro cake. Also got the grilled cheese but...too much bread (thick slices) and not very melted cheese, it was more like a cold sandwich. Plus the side salad (3$) was honestly inedible, the corn and tomatoes were basically out of the fridge-freezer, they were so cold it hurt my teeth and had to throw it away. Service was friendly and nice but prob won't make it there again.

Everything here is amazing - the coffee drinks (whether its "regular" coffee, cold brew, lattes or something more exotic) are great, the cheesy bread is always warm and delicious and my kids love love love the mini sandwiches.  We are all huge fans of Cafe Patoro - it's a must try.

Super coffee, super staff, super sweets!  Try the brigidero chocolate cake.  The cafe is small but quaint and the setting in Seaport adds to the ambiance.  They even gave us a free PDQ to try, you should have one too!

Omg!!!!! Amazing! Staffs are super nice and friendly! And take that from someone coming from Virginia where everybody talks to everybody on the street  Their PDQs along with mouthwatering cakes are just bang on  reasonable price especially for New York. The vibe here puts a massive smile on my face. Defo coming back soon
I have been here twice and I love my experience here. The music and the atmosphere is quiet and relaxing. The service is amazing. And the food is a little pricey but totally worth every penny!

I'm only reviewing the iced coffee I had.  This is really espresso poured over ice rather than traditional iced coffee.  As a result, it's cloudy and weak.  Also, it had a heavy coriander flavor that I didn't love.  Finally, I wish I didn't have to wait quite so long for it.  If the coffee had been good, I wouldn't have minded waiting.  But this wasn't worth the wait. The pastries did look quite good.

I love the PDQ's, they can be addicting. It is a cute and comfy spot to just hangout and have a coffee with a variety of desserts! They even have empanadas but in a brazilian style which are really tasty. Recommend this place for anyone, you wont regret it!
Delicious cappuccino, great service and inviting space! Oh and, Brazilian cheese breads!

Lovely, warm customer service. They offer to warm/toast the PDQs for you, too. The regular cheese PDQ was my favorite but to be honest I'm a bigger fan of the "sweet" cornbread they have! Full disclosure though, I love corn, and I love sweets (I also love cheese and tapioca flour but still..this cornbread impressed me more than the PDQs!). I had tried Cafe Patoro a couple years back when they had a stall in the outdoor market by Times Square and offered PDQ "sandwiches." They had a guava and cheese "sandwich" made out of PDQs (among other offerings/varieties) that was just absolutely incredible and I was sorely disappointed to see they weren't offering this at their new shop. I'm hoping once business picks up they will expand the menu to begin offering these "sandwiches" again -- they were really standout and wonderfully unique.

Such a sweet cafe.  I stopped by for breakfast the other day and had a cappuccino and 2 pdqs.  It was my first time eating pdq and i really liked it. The employees are so friendly and I plan to come again for breakfast soon!
amazing location with amazing beverages and breads. this is my new favorite spot for sure.

Wasn't too impressed. The prepared foods made for a decent lunch but it was pretty expensive. The ham "panini" was literally a slice of meat between bread - no other fillings or condiments. Tasty, but it felt a bit bare. The ribollita soup was great.  Baked goods were hit or miss - the chocolate hazelnut and sour cherry tarts were amazing, but the rest of the things we tried were kind of average.  Friendly service and there is some high top/bar seating. Overall, nothing too special.  3.5 stars.

The Danny Meyer hype machine rolls on with his classic Italian complex of Marta, Vini e Fritti, and Caffe Marchio in the Redbury Hotel. I was going to the dentist in the area and decided to treat myself to pastries at the latter beforehand.  It was easy to spot, despite the construction. Inside wasn't as airy and bright as all of the press pictures suggest, probably because of the gloomy day and sunlight-blocking construction. It looks authentically European, and it was cute, but not that cute.  They have quite a few pastries on offer, and at reasonable prices ($1-4). I went with a hazelnut ball and a sour cherry pastry. My boyfriend had an egg sandwich.  His sandwich was pretty good. My cherry pastry didn't taste all that fresh (and we were there around 9 or so). The hazelnut one was slightly better, but still didn't blow my mind.  One annoyance is that we were standing around for a bit waiting for my pastries, even though there were 3 people working and no other customers. Eventually they noticed and then quickly bagged them up. Hospitality is otherwise good here.  Overall, this is not a bad choice if you find yourself in Murray Hill / Midtown East. Don't think it deserves a trip out of your way, nor all of the glowing press I've seen lavished on it. The pastries were just fine, but this is nothing out of the ordinary from what you could get at any other bakery.
Hard to find in Rome itself, but finally a place that offers maritozzi con la panna "come Cristo comanda" in New York too. Awesome!  Update: unfortunately, they don't serve them anymore.
Had the German chocolate doughnut and regular coffee. Regular coffee very good would definitely become a repeat customer. Doughnut was ok.

Really good cold-brew and reasonably priced. Small, more of a grab and go place. I'm not sure if they have wifi as I'm usually there for less than 10 minutes.  With that said, I've walked to Tiny's Giant and Starbucks sometimes just because the vibe is hit or miss with the staff here. One woman in particular tends to make you really feel like you're interrupting her day. It's hit or miss, so hopefully she's just not there when you are-orrr hope she's having a great morning. I think coffee shops being reviewed need to be weighed heavily on hospitality.
Coffee is great, but the woman with long brunette hair who was workin at this time 16:14 kept rolling her eyes at my friend who is ESL because he took time to state his order. She should relax
The coffee here was fine but I hated how cramped this shop is. This place would be better off as a walk-up window or reconfiguring their setup.

Awe! Caffe Vita a little taste of home. I went to Caffe Vita this morning since, even though I love NY, there's always a little piece if my heart that will always belong to Seattle. Caffe Vita is definitely one of the best coffee spots. They roast their own beans. And their LES location is no different. I walk in and this rocker, all black clothes with patches was roasting up a batch of coffee beans. The aromas of the beans being roasted was making me salivate. It was early in the morning. I ordered an americano and found a little spot by the window to work on my little ipad with the attached keyboard. They let me know how to set up the wifi and I had a beautiful writing moment before I had to head to work. I would love if there was more space to sit at a larger table but it being LES and knowing how much rent is, I see this is the NY version of a Seattle favorite.  I heart Seattle! And I love wearing my Caffe Vita baseball tee!! And I use my pour over funnel all the time. Keep up the good work!
Awesome little coffee shop with a huge grinder! Looks like an antique and it's super shiny.

There are many cafes with excellent coffee and espresso based drinks these days and Vita is on par with the best.  Capp/latte cannot be improved upon. The standout for me is their iced coffee which I have to say is the best I've ever had. Uncommon depth of flavor, strong but not acidic at all. Similar to Kyoto style; hard to believe they get this kind of flavor from just extended steeping. Delicious and worth going out of the way for.

Stumbled upon Cafe Vita one day when my usual place Irving Farm was closed. This place has great staff that are super friendly and their cold brew is top notch.    It is a very small space with one small table but I usually grab and go.  The best part of the place maybe the fresh beans being roasted all of the time giving off an amazing aroma.    The price of drinks is pretty standard for other similar establishments.  It's not an every day place (unless you can afford it) but if you need a pick me up and want something tasty check out Cafe Vita.

Call me a snob, but finding great coffee in NYC isn't the easiest task. Sure you can sip your comforts at Dunkin Donuts, but it's more of a nostalgic caffeinated taste than a quality cup of Joe. But this here Caff̩ Vita does it up right. They fresh roast their beans right in the store (which happens to be like, 120 square feet total), so you know what you're drinking is darn near as fresh as you can possibly get. Their espresso drinks are top notch, and the staff is super friendly as well.  If you're in LES, be sure to bookmark this ish.

I've been getting my coffee from Tiny's Giant and Spreadhouse and haven't been impressed. Wanted to try something new close by. Vita is outstanding. Hands down the best latte I've ever had. Barista was so quick and a multi-tasker! The latte is smooth and full of flavor. I'm honestly trying not to finish it in one sip! I'm certain I've found my new go-to coffee shop.

I don't go here super frequently, but every time I'm in the area, this is the coffee shop I head to. The servers aren't super friendly if you aren't a regular, but they are nice enough. The real thing is that they just don't fuck up the coffee. Its ALWAYS good, no matter what style/drink I choose. It's small, so I never chill in here. They are more expensive but sometimes when you need a good coffee, its worth it.

Chai lattes are fine, but not great, even if they do come in a cute lil to-go cup with a panda bear.  Additionally, the space is small with about 3-4 bar stools to the side. The cafe is basically the entryway into a work building / coworking space.  Overall it's an okay spot and super convenient if you're in the coworking space, but there are so many places in the area worth trying more if you're into chai lattes.

I thought that maybe the houjicha hot chocolate would be really interesting.  It was just okay. I would prefer an option on the menu for just straight houjicha, but I do not think the chocolate works that well inside this drink unfortunately.  Its also a very small shop and a bit difficult to move around. But the customer service was pleasant!

Teeny tiny matcha shop in Midtown, serving high quality Japanese tea, coffee, pastries, and a small selection of light fare. They refer to themselves as purveyors of fine matcha, with a mission to make the tea more palatable to the western world. Due to construction, there was no seating on the day I visited, but it looks like there is typically room for about 5 people. The concise menu includes hot and cold specialty matcha beverages, ranging from matcha hot chocolate to their matcha Americano.  I got an Iced Matcha Latte with oat milk, which was just okay. For $5.25, I was expecting the matcha flavor to be more intense, but it was barely distinguishable. While I enjoyed the subtle sweetness of the drink, it may as well have been a cup of iced hemp milk. When I asked if any of the baked goods were vegan, the barista rolled her eyes at me and pointed to a sliced Orange Poppyseed Loaf. The cake had a nice moist, delicate texture, but lacked flavor. I noticed a few vegan options on the food menu (PB&J Tartine, Matcha Smoothie Bowl), which are perhaps better.  $11 for an underwhelming latte and pastry felt overpriced, even in NYC. As a matcha enthusiast, I salute CHALAIT for their efforts and availability of vegan options. However, I am not in a rush to return.

I wanted to try Chalait after work on a Thursday around 4pm and was glad that it wasn't super crowded. There was one other customer in, what seemed more like a counter than an actual cafe, however, I still waited about 10 minutes to be served ! The only barista was chatting with the other customer and a random person who didn't order anything for so long with me standing right in front of her waiting for her to take my order. While I understand it is nice to meet friendly people in New York, especially around midtown, waiting ten minutes in an almost empty cafe is crazy, and makes me think my personal time is not respected.  The shop itself seemed like it was still under construction and smelled strongly of saw dust.  My matcha latte was good, however, I was not impressed with any other aspect of Chalait.

After walking around in the cold for a while, I needed a place to warm up and grab a drink. I saw that this place specialized in matcha drinks so I decided to give it a try.  The place is small, VERY SMALL. It's mainly a to-go coffee shop rather than a dine in one. There are about 5 seats located in a hallway that leads to an elevator. I felt like I was awkwardly in people's way since several people kept passing by. The decor is very pretty and minimalistic. The food and drinks were expensive so we kept to ordering drinks only.  I ordered a hojicha hot chocolate. If you're not familiar, hojicha is toasted green tea. It has a unique flavor, very different from matcha. As much as I wanted to love my drink, I wasn't a big fan. I can taste the chocolate and hojicha but it was really drowned out by the milk. I do like that their hot chocolate is milk-based rather than water. I completely forgot what my boyfriend has ordered, but it was just alright. The service was quick and very friendly.  It's a good little spot if you're nearby and would like to grab a drink on the go. Overall, I wasn't really impressed with the drinks that we got.

Ok ok... So I should preface this with the fact that I'm slowly turning into a matcha snob... And call me basic- but I've seen the CHALAIT name all over my fav food bloggers pages, so I had to check it out.  Really cute shop, nice people working, but wasn't a fan of the product. I got a matcha latte with cashew milk (they didn't have skim), and I swear it just tasted like milk. In fact, if they had given it to me with a lid- I would've probably thought it was just milk.  Did I just pay $6 for a small cup of warm cashew milk?

Let me start by saying that the Smoked Salmon & Matcha Cream Cheese changed my entire perspective on smoked salmonWhatever they created here is so unique, and that cream cheese is difficult to describe but absolutely scrumdiddlyumptious. 10/10. The latte was amazing and I also had an orange juice which it was amazing. Unfortunately, I have to knock off a star because the dude serving me was so rude and nonchalant. I'm from California, and this is the new Toria's way of New York, but he was just so unenthusiastic that it was a daunting task to just ordera couple menu items. he made me feel like I was ruining his day (maybe I was?) Regardless, the food was amazing and I will definitely be back, but just prepared for that warm welcoming New York City service. Gang gang.

Yummy but expensive! Tried the iced matcha latte ($5.25), avocado toast ($10), and salmon sandwich ($11). The chimichurri sauce is really what makes the avocado toast, but that doesn't really justify the price for me. Matcha latte was also good. My sister tried the version with cashew almond milk which was so good but it was an extra DOLLAR. Yikes!  Plus there was about 4 seats in the entire cafe. We had to stand at the serving counter to eat, with barely enough room. Glad I checked this place out but would I come back? Likely not :/
Stopped here for a quick cup of coffee and it was pretty good. The latte art was a nice addition. This is a good place if you're in need of a quick pick me up.

Good matcha drinks and snacks. Not a great space.  The barista was super helpful and friendly. I enjoyed my matcha capp - the matcha taste was there, the milk was just lightly sweetened and well-foamed. However, definitely not a fan of the space. They just have about 4-5 barstools up against a bar table facing the wall...right in the middle of a hallway that leads from the door to an elevator that I guess leads to other office spaces/apartments? It was weird place to sit with so many people coming in and out, so I wouldn't recommend this place if you're looking for a place to lounge for a bit/read/work. More of a grab-and-go.  Also, agree with the prices - a little overpriced for sure.

Don't kill me but I'm not a fan of matcha lattes. I'm not sure if the creaminess of milk syncs well with the bitterness of matcha and, despite ordering it every now and then in the hopes of finally falling in love with the taste, I have yet to really think of it as a first-choice drink. The matcha latte at Chalait may satisfy purists in that it hews more closely to matcha's original flavor but it's really quite bitter. Towards the middle, all I could taste was burnt tea. I much prefer Cha Cha Matcha's version.  The one thing I will say about Chalait is that its prices are emblematic of a bigger problem in NYC: extravagant prices for trendy, healthful, superfoods. On my first visit, I was desperate for a breakfast item and ended up lunging for one of the last tiny cups of bircher muesli. Which was $6. A box of regular old Swiss muesli and some almond milk is maybe $5 at my bodega. I really did like that muesli and it actually filled me up but it was definitely not worth $6.  Since then, I've also tried the super smoothie bowl and the butternut squash and cauliflower quinoa bowl. Just warning you that you may need a second meal after consuming both of these. The smoothie bowl, which sounded excellent on paper (so many ingredients AND PB), ended up being really watery. Unfortunately, without any particularly forceful ingredients (cacao nibs don't count) to really stand out, all I could taste was diluted banana. The butternut squash bowl was much better but with very few chunks of squash or cauliflower. If it weren't for the $12 price tag, I would want to get it again just for the Sriracha tahini dressing.  The times I swung by, I came well after the lunch rush; by then, most of the popular items had already sold out, including the matcha yogurt parfait.  My main complaint is with the space. Obviously a store must work with what it has architecturally speaking but this is definitely a grab and go joint. There are only about 4-5 stools, all pushed within inches apart, and you're facing a white wall. There's a giant GRIND sign pointing to the next floor, which I thought indicated a separate seating area, but thankfully the barista quickly informed me it was another office before I actually wandered up there. Next to the seating area is an elevator with more than a fair share of foot traffic. It must be nice for those employees to have a coffee place so close by but I gobbled down my muesli and dashed out of there. Overall, I wouldn't recommend this as a spot to work or read or while the afternoon away.

Probably my mistake but when I think of matcha latte, I think of something sweet. I should have asked the cashier if it was sweetened before I placed my order. MATCHA LATTE IS UNSWEETENED.  This small cafe has about 6 bar stools lined below a bar-type table attached to the wall, right next to the door. There's barely elbow room when all the seats are taken.  Latte art here is dependent on I guess the barista's mood. The customer before me received pretty latte art and well, I got an average looking heart. Pretty unimpressive.  The plain croissant was at least flaky and soft, clearly didn't taste stale.  Would not come back based on latte art and bitter matcha latte. I really hope in the future they create an option to have it sweetened.

I got the breakfast sandwich from the Chelsea market location and it was pretty good, nothing super fancy but exactly what I wanted.  My friend got the matcha hot chocolate and it was very good.  Since they specialize in matcha, I would suggest getting something with matcha in it! I regret not getting an item myself. The service is quick and you can see them making your food. The seating area is great for a quick bite.

New location near my job? Yay!  I preferred the old location, because it is closer to my house and school. There were more tables than this location.  From this location, there are about 7-9 stools. This place is instagram worthy. It may seem like there prices are pretty high, but their drinks are worth it. Came in on a Wednesday afternoon and the store was mostly packed. There was one stool that was available. The service was pretty attentive & they did greet me when I went in. They had a pretty wide amount of matcha drinks and that was perfect. I love matcha and I decided to get the Matcha Chocolate Latte and the Match granola yogurt. I didn't wait along time for my drink and it came out really pretty. Their latte art is on point!  Match Chocolate Latte: 5/5 stars. Matcha was throughly blended and there is a hint of chocolate in it. Not overly sweet and they do use whole milk. You may ask the barista to change the milk. Matcha granola yogurt: 4/5: Never tried Matcha granola yogurt and it was pretty good. The yogurt and granola was fresh and tasty.  I would come here again to try their other matcha drinks out!  They do sell other drinks in a mini refrigerator in the bottom of the cashier stand.  Wished they had WIFI in this cafe, that would've made it 5 stars.

For some reason, the almond-cashew milk is not as rich as before and the matcha latte was not as strong and flavorful. I guess is that this place got popular and started opening more chains and lost track of their quality. :(
Cute little spot with great options and kind staff. I ordered an iced matcha latte.  They have a rewards program.

I'm so glad Chalait has a location now in midtown! I like to swing by before work and grab a matcha latte; it's usually not too crowded when I get there (around 9 AM), but I'm not sure if it's because the location is still relatively new. It's also a bit more tucked away, so it can be easy to miss.  For drinks, I've only tried the matcha latte and the hojicha hot chocolate so I can only speak to those. Love the matcha latte and how strong the matcha flavor is; I really wish I liked the hojicha hot chocolate more, but I think the chocolate drowned out the hojicha flavor a bit. I hope they come out with a hojicha latte, though! (For those who have never had hojicha, it's a toasted green tea.)  There is also pretty much no seating here, so don't expect this to be a place to hang out with friends. I also find their food to be pretty overpriced, so I only come here for the matcha.

I got a matcha latte here with almond milk. It was pretty good! I'm not sure if maybe just not enough matcha was used or this matcha just doesn't have a ton of flavor but the latte just wasn't as flavorful as I would have liked. It wasn't bad, just could had a bit more flavor. The latte was made really well: it was very smooth and mixed well. I would really love to try one of their matcha bowls next time I'm there.

My oh my, I've had my fair share of avocado toast and they all taste the same everywhere except here. The toast they used had lots of grains in it, they were generous with the avocado serving and it was seasoned perfectly.  I cannot get over how great the avocado toast was. I also ordered their Muesli Toast which consisted of yogurt, a variety of berries, almonds, and honey. It was a bit too sweet for my liking and I probably wouldn't order it again. The avocado one on the other hand though...

When ever I work in the area I always stop by in the morning for their matcha latte with house made almond and cashew milk. If you are a nondairy drinker like myself want more of the matcha flavor. Try the matcha latte with soy milk instead.  Oh and I started to order through the Ritual app. In the mornings it gets busy. Plus you get 5 bucks off for new users !

Officially open! The place is literally in an office building and only has seating for 4-5 people (next to the side entrance). They do offer breakfast-type food (think avocado toast and baked goods like croissant, muffins, & etc.).  Bought the Iced Matcha Latte with Almond Milk. Total came out to an estimate of $6 (almond milk was $.75 extra) [insert shock face for the price]. Don't get me wrong, I do love matcha, but it is expensive. Matcha powder usually costs around $10+ in a small can (30g), and if you're like me and too lazy to make matcha tea at home when you have the ingredients, you come to stores like these to have someone make the drinks for you.  Anyway, I do love Chalait for their minimalistic interior, and the products they offer.  The star knockoff was for the limited seating.

I order a mocha and they gave me a hot chocolat. I don't like to waste food so I was fine with taking it. Well, it was an amazing hot chocolat! In fact It was exactly what I needed it. It wasn't too sweet as I hate sweet chocolate and it didn't make me nauseous as I also am a little bit lactose intolerant. Best beverage for winter. Recommend it

From the pictures online, you could not tell that the coffee shop is so small in size! I got the classic avocado toast and the alchemist. There was a side bar with stools, at which I sat and ate. It's a quaint little shop with good to go coffee.

Love the matcha latte here and their food. They make my type of breakfasts such as crossiant with eggs, smoked salmon sandwiches, or avocado smash toast, and such that are all generally healthy and delicious. Chalait's coffee with their food definitely fuels my energy to boost the start of my day. The only thing I don't like about this location compared to their original location that got shut down is that there's so little seatings here. They have an extremely small bar counter against the wall with stool chairs that sits about 5 leaving a tight elbow to elbow space while the skinny bar table makes it really hard to even fit one plate of your food with your coffee cup to comfortably eat. It's also tucked inside a random office/commercial building where random people are constantly leaving the door open while wheeling big stuff going in and out. They should at least think of making coat hooked under the bar tables so they're space we hang our jackets & bags while we sit down to eat and enjoy our coffee. Other than that, I really do enjoy their food and coffee a lot I heard they opened a nicer one in Chelsea Market now and I'll definitely check it out!

This little store is located in the hall of a building. It's not the ideal spot to get a matcha and chill but it works perfectly to get a drink to go. The staff is friendly and the lady there told me that they happen to make HOMEMADE ALMOND MILK. Next time I shall try that! The matcha is tasty, not sweetened like most places. Cute stop

Underwhelming would be the word I would use to describe Chalait. I like matcha lattes, and Chalait had been on my list to try for awhile. But honestly, I couldn't tell the difference between theirs and instant matcha lattes. Pass.

I ordered the matcha latte. It was everything I hoped it would be and more. Small and cute little shop. I got a spot on the small counter on the side where several bar stools were lined up and enjoyed my drink. Gave me a good boost of energy for the rest of my day! :)

Small version of the original CHALAIT. Friendly staff. In the process of being converted into a grab and go place. So no menu, but basically a place to pick up already prepared salads, pastries (which looked yummy), and drinks. They also sell health-aid kombucha for under $5 which is one of the cheapest prices I've seen it at. However, I wasn't thrilled about my matcha latte. It took a while to be made and just tasted like milk rather than matcha. I got almond milk and my friend got whole milk but it felt the same for both.

Great drinks, great food, great service, great atmosphere. My favorite drinks are their Matcha Hot Chocolate, Oolong Tea, and Matcha Latte. Their Smoked Salmon Rilette is delicious! So glad Chalait is back, I was sad their West Village store closed.
The best matcha ever. They use really good quality matcha and whisk it (the way it's supposed to be prepared).
Cute coffee spot in Nomad! You can be in and out, within seconds. Their egg scramble is delicious!

Very small space to grab a drink and bite to eat. The matcha latte was nice, but the croissant with miso was a bad idea. I really like miso, but it shouldn't be slathered on a plain croissant. I ordered it because I was staring at the menu in line too long and panicked.
Great matcha ice tea! The people are so friendly and they're fast--orders are usually ready in five mins or less. The Bircher muesli is also delicious and perfectly portioned for breakfast!

Everything from the atmosphere, worker, and product was on point! They put care in the product which makes it worth the price. The avocado toast had a generous portion of avocado and the chimichurri sauce was the perfect add on to the dish. Will definitely be returning!

The brunch menu was much more robust than expected, and the avocado smash was great! I was not a huge fan of the iced matcha latte, but only because it wasn't as sweet as expected. They seemed to have a full variety of drinks for any preference on that
The coffee is good but the matcha is amazing, they have it in so many different presentations, I tried the matcha energy bowl and it filled me until dinner. Plus they so coffee art in the lates.

My score is based on the fact that the coffee is extremely overpriced and that they won't let you use their restroom  The shop itself is tiny, clean, and cute in a generic sort of way. I'm a coffee fiend and theirs didn't strike me as worthy of the cost.  The person behind the counter was fast and courteous with a splash of fake cheer.  In summary not a bad place but if you need a restroom and think that by buying one of their overpriced items they'll allow it, then this is not recommended.

Food was excellent Table service was terrible -- they seemed very overwhelmed and hectic/disorganized at lunch time today. There were 6 of us, gratuity was included automatically and I felt like the servers took advantage of that We had 3 different people serving The first did not write anything down for the 6 of us when we ordered and made 2 mistakes. When we commented on them, we received very negative attitudes from him and another server who stated "well I'm not the one that took your order". The original server came to our table and he said "I got everything right with the exception of 1 thing" and aggressively handed member of our party a card for 1 free drink and stormed away I had to ask 3 different people for my drink order And ask several times for water I would take food/drink to go but will never sit for table service again

Stopped by on Sunday for brunch and luckily the place wasn't too packed yet. Been to Citizens of Chelsea before so I had high expectations of this place. The interior is modern and it is nicely decorated. There is an instagramable neon sign in the back which was nice for the pictures but I wouldn't recommend sitting back there because lighting gives off a dim cast. I ordered the salmon eggs ($15) which were delicious and left me feeling satisfied. My boyfriend ordered the Pulled Benny ($12) which was delicious but felt that the portion size wasn't big enough. The presentation was also a little odd because the Pulled Benny was placed on a plate that was too big so it so there was was so much empty space on the plate.  Overall I was satisfied with my meal but I prefer their other location to this one.

I thought I was going to pushcart cafe, but instead found that they had closed and replaced by citizens of gramercy. Sorry, pushcart  but I had no time to sit and wallow when I was greeted with this fresh new establishment. There's light, there's greenery, there's wifi and there's FOOD!!!  Delicious food.
