I think In̬s has some promise.  I was attracted by the variety of healthy breakfast options.  I chose the Healthy Start bowl.  I liked it but I did not love it.  The bowl contained couscous, arugula, cucumber, radish, carrot, cabbages, avocado, and scrambled eggs.  The eggs were the best part: soft, well-seasoned, and luscious.  The half avocado was ripe, soft, and a generous size.  I was surprised that the couscous was cold.  I was expecting more warmth to the bowl.  The eggs were the knot warm component.  The bowl started out tasty but once the eggs ran out it moved into make-me-feel-like-a-cow-territory with too much chewing of raw veg too early in the morning.  I did not finish my bowl. The cashier was very friendly and the WiFi worked.  At 7:30am on a weekday, it was calm and quiet inside with only a few other customers.
Avocado tartin was very tasty. Croissant not bad too. Beautiful girl at the cashier. But very bad ventilation, all smells on my hair :(

Come for the coffee, avoid the food and matcha. The service is really what shines at In̬s. I ordered the americano, matcha latte, bacon egg and cheese, and the avocado toast. The americano was really good; I'd order it again. They use a good Colombian bean. The matcha latte needed some honey/sweetener.  Onto the food. Other people's reviews mention the star of the bacon egg and cheese was the bread, but I didn't think so. The egg was too salty; the cook should taste it first. The egg shouldn't require much salt since the salty bacon is piled right on top. For $9, avocado toast was minuscule. The taste was good, but I'd recommend a tad more acid and maybe some chili flakes to really spice up the dish and take it to a new level.  Overall, I'd say this is a decent place if you're in the area, but lately there have been a lot more places popping up around the UES that I would recommend over In̬s. The price at In̬s does not justify the quality of the food you receive. Stick to the coffee.

It wasnt yucky here but it wasn't spectacular either. The food here speaks for itself. You taste what you order. I got the healthy start bowl and it literally was a bunch of veggies nicely plated into a bowl. It's not like the flavors blended well together. I just had a bowl of raw veggies and that what made it healthy but not flavorful. My husband got the croque madame. He thought that they went heavy duty on the cheese which made the dish really greasy. It's mostly what we tasted despite the egg and ham that was also in the sandwich. We did get the chai latte which was nice since it wasn't overly sweet for our taste. Maybe we shouldve got more coffee here? There was a good stream of people ordering coffee rather than food.
This place was so cute! Very cozy and homey. The food was delicious. The dishes were simple and healthy. I'd definitely come back.

Ines is an adorable coffee shop on 74th street with delicious coffee. I love the interior d̩cor, a deep blue color endless throughout the space. The staff is friendly and inviting as is the coffee shop set-up. We did not get anything to eat, but we will next time, as the egg sandwiches looked delicious. I loved my Cortado.
Great coffee, fresh and yummy healthy start bowl. Cute little place with a nice ambience to use your laptop.

Love this place. Maybe the best bacon, egg, and cheese in the neighborhood. Great, cozy space; surprisingly friendly staff including the cook who comes around to patrons just to make sure everyone is enjoying the food. And they have doughnuts from Dough!!!
Awesome music, staff, food and all around vibe ! Its tucked into a quaint corner of the Upper East Side. Coffee sourced from my fav roasters in NY ( Devocion ) !
Nice cafe with a selection of pastries and sandwiches/toasts/bowls. Good amount of seating and very nice staff. Love the decor inside. Good place to spend an hour or two.

Lovely new spot worth checking out in UES. Beautiful decor! Stopped in for a quick cup and ended up staying for a tartine with avocado. Both were excellently prepared and timely served. Will definitely be coming back for the Nutella bowl!
Great place to do work. Perfect food and music. The staff was super nice as well! Will defiantly be back!
I am in love with this new cafe! The food is amazing, the service is spot on and the atmosphere is relaxing and inviting.
What a great find nestled in on the upper east side. Great coffee and the desserts makes for an excellent treat.

I'll admit I was craving Intelligentsia after watching Jerry Seinfeld's episode of Comedians In Cars Getting Coffee with Bill Burr. This location is very swanky and in the lobby of the High Line Hotel, directly in front of you as you enter. The pour-over is very smooth and high-quality, and is one of the best I've had in the city. However, it's so expensive that I wouldn't be able to make this a regular spot! A plain coffee was more than $4, double its counterparts nearby. The cappuccino is also more than $5, and the portion you get is very limited (a bit bigger than a typical espresso).    Seating is limited here. And because of that, when others grab a seat, it'll take forever for them to leave. There are a couple couches and four or so stools by the counter, so once you grab space, snatch it up. Otherwise, you'll be waiting endlessly!  One day, I'll splurge on one of those monstrous, perfect croissants...

I came here with a friend on a weekday morning, and we found a seat on the couch. This isn't really a cafe, and it reminded me a bit of a hotel lobby. It's dark though and has an interesting ambience. I got a matcha latte, and the matcha flavor was quite average. Price-wise, it was extremely expensive for a regular-sized cup.

The coffee is always a hit, but the baristas are sometimes amiss. For the past few years, if I'm not brewing coffee at home nearby, I'm grabbing an Intelligentsia honey latte at the Highline Hotel. A honey latte is your typical latte with honey drizzled at the bottom before the latte is prepared. It's a perfect, natural sweetener and complement to Intelligentsia's coffee, and I would grab one enough that I knew the welcoming barista's names and they knew my order a couple of years ago.  However, in my second to last recent visit, I grabbed coffee and pastries with a friend, and the small blonde barista was not friendly, flat out ignored any "good morning", "thank you", and despite being spoken to and smiled at, did not engage.  In my last visit, a different barista taking my order claimed that they do not make honey lattes and pointed to the honey on their counter, instructing that I could pour in honey myself if I wanted. I am by no means needy or so much of a diva that I can't pour my own honey, but for the past 4-5 years, other baristas had no problem pouring the honey beforehand.  Perhaps both times I arrived, I received the brunt of a post-morning rush, but the friendly faces that I once encountered while treating myself to a sweet coffee are no longer there and I now leave with a bitter taste.

OVERALL MEH: The architectural designs here make it an unique experience but the coffee or hot chocolate were disappointing. Overall I don't recommend.  ENVIRONMENT: the cafe is located on the first floor of the High Line Hotel. On the outside, this hotel looks like an ancient architecture. The brick wall interior exudes a medieval feel. The inside space is a little crowded with hotel guests and visitors. As a result, it can be difficult to find a seat on the couch. Not having many tables or individual seats - so only come if you are looking for a casual setting.  COFFEE: We ordered a hot chocolate and a latte and waited for over 10mins. There's a long line of customers as mentioned earlier. The latte doesn't taste like coffee because they added a lot of milk, but if that's what you like then it's good. DO NOT order the hot chocolate - it's sour for some reason.

Overpriced incipid coffee time and again. Also...Rude! Rude! Rude! Avoid this place if you are like decent coffee. Avoid if you dont like RUDE... Example...On a recent visit I merely lifted the  murky lid of the cake keeper on the counter to see what was there.  I touched nothing.  As I stifled an OMG at the grim specter of DEAD baked goods, the barista snatched the cake keeper away.  She towered over me as she sneered "We just cant have people going through the pastries!" going through?... I lifted the lid!  Fine.  I left.  I crossed 10th Ave for a fresh, delicious piece of poppy seed cake at Underline Coffee where the coffee is good and the service is welcoming.

Locate inside the high line hotel lobby so seating can be limited since hotel guests are also hanging around to check out of the hotel and what not  cute lobby decor, esp the typewriter at the coffee table we were sitting at --cold brew coffee: MMm glad i gave intelligentsia a second chance! the first time i tried it in LA i remember thinking it was too bitter but MAN has my palette changed since 6 years ago!  the hot coffee to stay is served in a little mug PLUS more in a carafe on a wooden tray, cute presentation!

My favorite coffee spot EVER! Their espresso based drinks are just amazing - especially the cappuccino and iced latte. Also inside of a hotel with a nice outdoor seating area. Wish I can have a cup of intelligentsia everyday

This high-end coffee chain has a nice look as its embedded inside the lobby of The High Line hotel. This is a nice spot to catch up with a friend over espresso. There is seating outside in the courtyard area as well as inside the lobby. I LOVE their cups! They have really neat art on their cups that makes the pricy cup of joe worth it!  I wouldn't trek across the city for this cup of joe but if passing through Chelsea, it's a nice pick-me-up. They have a couple pastries and other milk beverages available. Coffee shops like this are nice because it's a more personal experience with the person making your beverage. It's the art of coffee and the baristas that take pride in their job.

Long morning walk along the Hudson from the Upper West placed me on 23rd St.  Quick yelp search for nearby espresso directed me to two places: a small shop on 22nd/10th that I won't name and - a block further down 10th - Intelligentsia's truck inside the High Line Hotel's front courtyard.  Even though I just did a 3 mile trek, I'm still a lazy bastard deep in my soul.   So i went to the place 1 block away instead of Intelligentsia 2 blocks away.    Ordered a Macchiato and it was terrible.  Couldn't drink it.  Threw the $3.50 brew into the garbage can on the street corner and decided to walk a block further to Intelligentsia.  Shoulda gone there first.  Their Macchiato was fuggin fantastic.  Staff was really nice too.  Also picked up a bag of their limited Brazilian release 'Agua Preta.'

this is my friend's favorite place, hence I went with her once. I can see why people like it, definitely knowledgable baristas, good and full menu and nice interior.  just way too small inside and the dessert don't live up to the expectation. maybe in the summer it would be nicer, sitting outside.

This elegant little spot hidden in the High Line Hotel boasts some of the best coffee in the area. While not my favorite of all time, the very solid pastries (brownies!!) and beautiful interior make this spot worth the trip.  Intelligentsia can be found in one of NYC's coffee epicenters. With Blue Bottle, 9th Street, the Ace Hotel Stumptown, and Joe's all in walking distance it is difficult to make the case that the espresso here beats them all hands down. However, those cafes do not possess the smoky, super-chill ambiance of the High Line Hotel. I really like the feel of this coffee shop as well as the music, design, and docile mood.  Combine that with super nice baristas and great baked goods and you have one must-stop location for all coffee lovers walking the High Line.

Nice coffee joint with a lot of nice young people hanging out there. I liked the atmosphere a lot. The espresso was good but a bit burned. Not such a great selection of coffee mates (pastries or cookies). Great location!

Walking in, there is a doorman for the hotel, even though you're going in for coffee. After some lobby chairs is Intelligentsia. The coffee is obviously incredible. However the space for the cafe itself is extremely small and probably only fits 3 or so people comfortably.  They also sell many different beans to go.
Amazing cold brew coffee. Probably best I've ever had. Don't even need to add any milk or sugar.
One of the best lattes I have ever had. I got a quiche and didn't really care for it, but my latte was amazing. So creamy and the perfect blend of coffee and mocha.

After having Intelligentsia in LA, I was dying to recreate my experience.  I walked 46 blocks to satisfy my craving, that's dedication. The location is kind of inconvenient, in the High Line Hotel all the way on 10th Avenue. But it's absolutely worth it.  My latte was exactly the same as it was in California, probably even more special since it was in New York. The barista was really friendly when I told her about my new found obsession and recommended that I try their new location in Herald Square.  There are tons of comfy looking chairs and sofas scattered around the lobby of the hotel, where the cafe is situated. It would be a really nice to hang out if I were a guest at the hotel.  It's certainly not the cheapest cup of coffee, but it is the most excellent.

This should be your go to destination for coffee in West Chelsea.  Even if you find yourself in the upper 20's,  Intelligentsia is worth the walk. The hand crafted coffee and espresso is consistently fantastic, and the baristas are skilled and efficient.  As an additional perk, Intelligentsia is located in the lobby of the High Line hotel which provides a pet friendly place to start the day.
Best chai latte I've ever had! And the environment is inviting and cozy. Definitely recommend.
Beautiful setting with the a parody-level imported Brooklyn hipster attitude and set of all the crazy customer-unfriendly procedures they could muster, all delivered with a condescending smile.
A+ hot chocolate, plus the most quaint garden in back of the hotel to enjoy.  The front porch area is lovely and spacious as well.  Great place to hangout for a chat over coffee.

You go here for the coffee truck and the lovely backyard, Manhattan feels miles away and it's so quiet you can finally get lost in that book a bumpy subway ride always seems to get in the way of.  Intelligentsia roasts great coffees, unfortunately their pour over doesn't pour to match, but their milk espresso's are soft and creamy - just the way i like them. They make a perfect cappuccino.  Be sure to derail from the High Line and stop for a coffee break in this lovely spot.
Great coffee with a great outdoor sitting area. Great place to catch up with friends and enjoy a morning coffee.

The ambiance is quite lovely and old world retro. Little seating inside but ample space out front and back, both areas serene; fountain out front and courtyard feel in the back. Would be best if they had some explanations of the flavors or "notes" of the beans they're brewing. I accidentally ordered a bean that was far too citrus-y and bright for my tastes (karyendi burundi). If only I had known. It was a fun experience learning that coffee could even taste that way though.

Wow, I wish I found this place years ago!! Intelligentsia Coffee is my new favorite place to hang out during the day and get some work done.  Tucked into the High Line Hotel, this place is an absolute gem for so many reasons.    First off, the name is super cool.  Intelligentsia? Yes...love it!  Second, the indoor space is tiny but also has comfy couches and cool decor that makes it cozy and a great place to sip on a coffee (or green tea, which is my preference; whatever floats your boat) while you're banging away on the keys of your laptop.  Third, the WiFi actually works very well, which doesn't sound like a big deal, but I've experienced crappy WiFi at different coffee shops around the city numerous times and when you can't get any work done as a result and have to change venues, it becomes a very big deal! Ok, that was a long sentence.  Let's move on.    Fourth, and best of all, there are two outdoor patios that you can choose from.  At the front of the hotel, there is a lovely patio complete with very comfortable seating, patio umbrellas to shade you from the sun if you so please, and lots of trees that makes it feel like an oasis away from the hustle and bustle of the city.  The patio actually belongs to the Alta Linea restaurant (serving Italian cuisine starting at 5pm), but there's an Intelligentsia Coffee truck parked in the patio where you can get your caffeine fix (or you can just walk inside to the actual coffee shop).  At the back of the hotel is another large patio surrounded by two large red brick buildings reminiscent of those you see at college campuses.  The "backyard" patio also does a good job of whisking you away from the concrete jungle because there is lots of greenery and it is insulated from the street, so it feels warm and welcoming.  Fifth, the folks that come to Intelligentsia seem interesting and diverse.  Let's not kid ourselves...people watching is fun.  And Intelligentsia has cool people coming through to chat, work, read, or just relax, which makes the atmosphere all that much more entertaining.  Intelligentsia is the place to be.  It's where I'll be.

It was a cold, cold walk along the Highline that drove us to Intelligentsia. We took the opportunity for a warm drink, snack, bathrooms, and phone charging. I had the spiced cider chai, which was totally new to me and now a favorite. My only regret is that we weren't staying at the hotel.

This is a unique and very creative concept for a restaurant/lounge. The downstairs is a Cafe and the upstairs is the bar and full restaurant. I was really impressed with the decor- very modern and trendy. It is a higher end restaurant.  We sat at the restaurant bar counter. A unique thing is that it's a tip-less restaurant. Therefore, the prices are significantly higher. Each main dishes cost about $40 each. Service was great but the food was normal.  Nothing crazy about the food to rave about but do love the concept of this restaurant- innovation and food.

Somewhat torn.  The meal was by almost all measures fantastic - and our second visit in 3 weeks as well.  The leek appetizer was well done and delivered as described . The pork entree was likewise - perfectly cooked and the presentation let me control the spice via the Harissa.  The taglitelle with lamb was fantastic - really well balanced amongst the rich lamb, herbs and the preserved lemon.    Then came the desert course - which after waiting at least a generous 20 minutes was not what we ordered.  Tremendous let down for a strong evening.  Didn't really want to wait for a replacement after waiting that long the first time.  Also - can't adjust the tip for a non-tipping restaurant....so go to yelp we did....

This is an interesting review to write, since in three weeks the chef will have changed and that, at the end of the day, is the foundation of any restaurant experience. Our meal was off the charts superb, across the board. Knowing Danny Meyer, this will likely be the standard, but if you can, run here before the end of March and revel in Gregory Marchand's super rich and delicious cuisine. The space is gorgeous - and mercifully QUIET - the staff is lovely, the overall experience top quality. Checking out each new chef is definitely going to be on my list.
We walked in just for coffee and desserts, but desserts didn't come for more than half an hour. So disappointed cuz reviews are very good.

Came here for a quick bite and cup of coffee after seeing our original brunch spot was too crowded.  Not too many options, but everything looks very healthy and organic, and the prices were pretty high because of it.  I ordered the avocado toast, my friends had the yogurt with berries and granola, breakfast burrito, coffee, latte, and cappuccino. They had forgotten to give us the cappuccino so they gave us a free item card, which my friend used to get an iced coffee.  For the price (~$9), my avocado toast was average--i've had better for cheaper. I've even made better for cheaper. The toast itself was really thick and there was too little avocado for the size of the toast (and the price). I liked the feta and pickled onions, not a fan of the seeds though. It tasted good and healthy, but I don't think I'd ever get it again.  My friend really enjoyed the breakfast burrito.  I really liked the vibe/interior of the place though. Very hipster-modern. Employees were kind, too.

Came here bc it was right next door to our hotel.  It did the job for quick pastry breakfast and to get our caffeine fix.  Ordered a cortado and something was off about it,  I ended up having to use excessive amounts of sugar in order to drink it.

dropped by here for coffee in the morning since it was close to the hotel I was staying at...  I got iced americano and avocado toast, which were okay... The avocado toast did not have a ton of flavors, tasted just the creamy avocado and a bit of mustard. The coffee was just normal, nothing special. I don't think I will go back unless I have to.
Warm coffee unfriendly manager/supervisor.  Not coming back. Burrito was ok.  Went there for convinience

I feel bad giving this a 3 but it's mostly because of the toast I got. The ambiance is nice. It's a good spot for an intimate chat with friends and the apple cider was delicious.  The service was not bad. They gave me a number after I ordered and brought my food to me. The literal only thing is that the toast killed me man. I might just not be sophisticated for a milk&honey smoked toast. It tasted really Smokey, like it was burnt but the after taste of it and the "in season" fruit were so hard. I guess I shouldn't try to eat fruit in the winter, but it was torture to finish it. The hot apple cider made it easier for sure.
Really good coffee! Breakfast burrito was smaller but good. Can't wait to try the coffee again when I return to nyc, I always stay at San Carlos across the street.

The breakfast is off the charts. I had the breakfast burrito but I asked for a side of farm sauce and then put siracha in it and it was amazing. My husband had the shakshuka sandwich and it was also redonkulously good. Yeah me using that word was lame but too lazy to delete it.  The pour over was kind of weird so they gave me a new drink and they were really really nice about it. Usually the pour overs are great but sometimes they don't come out right. But I do recommend their pour overs as well.  The staff is really nice. This goes a long way when your being rained on and your day was crap. They were slammed but still pleasant and asked me how I was and made brief polite conversation.

Ridiculously high prices - $4 for coffee, not exceptional in any way.  Go to Starbucks less than half a block away between Lex and Park, where the servers act more normal, or the NY Luncheonette in the same building on 50th Street if you want real cooked food.  Irving Farm opened on their backs because that diner is so popular, there's often a line out front.

Omg! I am shocked and dismayed by the unpredictability of this place! I have tried 5 times now to grab some food and every single time their kitchen is closed like 2-3 hours before closing time, or it's raining and they closed early, or the latest example today.. their kitchen is closed for renovations. I am blown away.... how is it impossible to get food from here after 5pm? I truly hope management takes note of the unpredictability and does something about it! I live in the neighborhood and eat things like avocado toast several times a week and would absolutely frequent this place if it wasn't for the lack of predictability of the closure times of their kitchen; I am tired of playing the game of will their kitchen be open as it's 5pm and they close at 8pm! I am outraged by this shocking lack of commitment to advertised hours of operations. The definition of unprofessional.

Sometimes you might want to just sit down and relax in a coffee shop, as opposed to simply grab-n-go. Irving Farm is definitely belonging to this camp. I'm so glad that it opened a new location in midtown east, just block away from my office.  Unlike many other coffee shops in midtown, Irving Farm is pretty spacious and carried a somewhat chilled vibe. Really enjoyed my heartily prepared cappuccino!

Needed a peaceful no-wifi break from a tough day, so darted in here for 30 minutes of toast and calm. So glad I did -- the space is calm and well-organized for either quiet or friendly conversation, and both my Americano and my Milk & Burnt Honey & Toast (guest-starring some nice persimmon) were precisely the civilized little break I needed before recommencing to slaying Midtown's corporate dragons. My next visit will involve their good-looking avocado toast; looking forward to it!
Irving Farm was right next door to my hotel. I walked over and bought an Americano and an espresso and brought it back tonight room. The espresso and Americano was fair at best.

Fantastic coffee.  I dropped by every morning when I was staying in midtown last week.  Excellent cappuccino, no need for any sugar added.  They are accommodating & can make 2% milk by mixing whole & skim and welcome personal cups.    One day I had the breakfast burrito & it was delicious.  Loaded with eggs & avocado.    The line moves quickly and coffee & food are served promptly.

I ordered the oat milk iced chai latte with an oat and currant scone. The latte was just how I like my chai, spicy with just enough sweet. The scone was also good, dry but the good type of dry you would expect in a fresh scone. I look forward to stopping in and trying some of their other creations before my trip is over.

Coffee was fine however their service is abysmal.  I copped attitude because my drink order was not to their liking.  Then waited 40 mins for scrambled eggs, had to leave and asked for a refund as I never received my food.   Snarky server informed me of their "no refunds" policy.   Total BS!

This place is wonderful! I'm only disappointed that I didn't discover it until my last day in the city. I had a chai with pumpkin seed milk, and it could not have been more delicious and comforting! They have a good amount of seating here and offer actual food in addition to your usual coffee shop pastry selection. They have a refrigerated section with yogurts and I think some bottled waters (I didn't take too much note to this section). Additionally, the baristas were really friendly! I would definitely return here upon my next visit to the city!

This is for the JFK location, since I can't find it separately. The coffee, food, and service was simply awful. The cappuccinos tasted like weak tea that had been left in a cupboard for years. The bagels took forever and we're finally served barely warm (see next point). The service was like something out of a "what not to do" training video, as the three young ladies working the counter devoted their primary effort to quarreling with one another, right in front of the ever-increasing backup of frustrated customers. They even made snide comments to a delivery guy who rushed the cream cheese over (he quickly left the scene). When everything is this bad, it's a management problem. This is the worst customer service and coffee quality I've experienced in years.
A lot of small flies were gathered in cookies and muffins. It was very uncomfortable. And I ordered hot chocolate but mocha came out....

Delicious coffee, very unique sandwiches - they clearly have a great product and a cool atmosphere. Love the pour over options, and pretty much the entire menu. But why do specialty coffee shops have to be so pretentious and patronizing? What is it about hipster baristas that makes them think they are better than everyone else? Why must they act annoyed if you ask them for anything? And the sign that implies that you hate the planet if you don't use Oat Milk in the cappuccino? Sheesh? Please the let the customer service meet the quality of the product
Excellent!! Great friendly service and relaxing environment. The lavender coffee was perfectly balanced for my taste.
Latte was excellent!  Quick service for breakfast to go and the pastries all looked great!
Good to ok food. Priced higher than any competitors which is saying something in this neighborhood.

Meh.  Tried the eggs with avocado on sweet potato (one of only a couple of gluten-free options except for granola/oatmeal).  The poached eggs were undercooked and cold, which was off-putting.  I love both sweet potatoes and avocados but the dish just didn't work for me.  My husband had the wrap, which he said was "fine" but no raving review.  The coffee (he had drip, I had a latte) was also fine but not exceptional.

Ordered the iced green tea. Which was solid  This space is cozy and the tables are small but comfortable. They have an exterior door outside their primary door, so in the winter there usually isn't that chill breeze that sweeps in whenever someone comes in.  It's fairly small with only 8 tables crowded in, which is pretty good for a non starbucks cafe in Manhattan.  I sat here for about an hour and a half while waiting for someone's afterschool ballet class to end. I'd say I was pretty lucky to get a table, and I saw some other ballet students waiting here as well (the studio is just around the corner)  I would come again for the place to sit, but would leave for another cafe if they didn't have a seat.

Visited very briefly on Saturday, Dec. 15, 2018. I only stopped in to check out bags of whole beans. The place was pretty crowded; there'd have been no place to sit if I'd wanted to do so.  I did end up leaving with a bag of Ethiopian Konga Cooperative Yirgacheffe beans, which are outstanding. Pricey at $20 but you gotta live sometimes. They were at least very fresh, roasted earlier the same week. They make a dang good V60 pourover, that much I can tell you. Might be the most tremendous pourover the world has ever seen before.
The coffee is good and the sitting area(outside) is awesome. The bakery items are not great, I would recommend coffee only.9

Way over priced for what you get. I got an almond milk latte and it was only filled up 75% and the milk didn't taste very fresh. I probably won't come back to this location, although the people who work here are literally the sweetest and friendliest folks!

Their coffee is great! Barista's make every coffee great. It's a good coffee shop to come in, grab your coffee and leave because it's tiny and it's always packed with people. There is always a line when ordering. I gave it 3 stars for 2 good reasons: 1. No bathroom 2. No wifi  I like working on my computer at coffee shops. Despite me having wireless wifi with Spectrum (which they are terrible!), I still prefer using the coffee shops wifi because it's not so spotty. WiFi is super important to me. Even if I don't bring in my computer, I like to be on my phone and do work from it.  So, it's  coffee shop to grab coffee on the go. Def not for strollers either! Too small.
Just okay.  Staff is friendly and prices are average. Bf had a macchiato and I had a drip coffee. Neither one of us really enjoyed our drinks. They had an unfortunate burnt flavor to them.

The man working the front was extremely rude and condescending. I've never been treated so horribly before. Definitely do not come here. I sat for one second and he literally yelled over the counter asking if I was going to buy anything and if not that I had to leave. I had *JUST* sat down and there were plenty seats available. Can't help think this was racial profiling because he was mugging me the moment I walked in.

I work at an office a block away from Joe Coffee and my coworkers and I were looking for a place to get coffee since Starbucks closed and the nearest Starbucks is on 72nd street, so we gave Joe a try. Since none of us drink coffee we stuck to the chai latte and we fell in love. Well, that day we went was the last time we were able to get chai. It's been 2 weeks and they have no chai at the location. You'd think that since they only have a few options other than coffee, they'd keep those in stock but nope. Now we have to take the long walk to Starbucks. It's unfortunate because we have lots of meetings and love our chai and with about 40 staff members.... that's a lot of chai. Too bad.

Nothing beats my baby Bold Bean in Riverside, Jax, FL but this was an easy pick for a quick Latte on a Tuesday morning.  This place is very tiny, maybe four small tables total inside. Luckily, there was no line when I arrived so I was in and out quick. They have espresso, Coffee, lattes, etc available.  I went with a Caramel Latte ($4.25). It had that authentic coffee taste where it tastes more like coffee than a sugary dessert, Mmm. Also, the barista makes the beautiful design on top (see picture below).  They use the Square system here so when you run your card if you've used Square before your receipt will automatically be emailed to you. You have the option of a print out too but I prefer to save a tree.  I would definitely come here again. :)

I really like the coffee here. It's way better than Starbucks and the staff is just lovely.  This particular location is, however, too small.  In the morning the line goes out the door wth only 5 or 6 people in cue. It's great on a warm day however, as you can sit outside.  I would most likely not use this as a meet-up spot.  it's just a really great place to get coffee to go. Today I had an iced latte with skim milk and it was fabulous. I couldn't finish it but it woke me up and filled me up so that I was able to nail it at the gym right after!
They do a great latte! Coming from Melbourne, Australia (we are known for our coffee snobbery) we were very happy to find somewhere to get a good cup. Only negative is it's expensive.

I am not an expert on coffee, and can only review this joint based on my experience drinking coffee across America. The coffee is lightly roasted and the espresso is undercooked. The sourness of their coffee can be tasted even when litigiously hot--a bad sign.  The coffee is mediocre at best, but the staff I experienced there on this one particular morning was fun.  There was a blue-haired barrister, overweight--clothing non-designer. She had a septum piercing and some tattoos. Her conversation with her co-workers were about the maleness of the indie rock scene, and how POC (people of color) are underrepresented in the scene. As a black man from Michigan, this made me feel uncomfortable. Let me shelve my race card and instead play the snowflake badge. I need a safe space. This hurt my feelings. It's no wonder my espresso came out sour... a bitter, sour-grapes chewing, Vagina Monologue reciting third-wave feminist milked it from the machine. An espresso machine designed and created by the patriarchy, based on the principles of science, which we all know is a sham propagated by male hegemony.  G'day!

I just don't think the coffee taste that good. I go with the house drip, traditional iced coffee, and cold brew. I go at least once a week because it beats going to Starbucks down the block but I just dont think the coffee taste good.  Service is good for the most part. A few times its been really slow and other times you feel rushed. The set up isn't all that great to wait in line, for your coffee and to get milk but it works.
Great coffee. I love their house blends. Much stronger than my office coffee - perfect in the mornings. Quick efficient ladies behind the counter.

It might be fighting words to say this is the best coffee in NYC, but I'm willing to go out on a limb for Joe. This is easily the best coffee I've had in NYC. The only espresso that comes close to it is Blue Bottle in San Francisco, and the espresso made from beans my sweetheart roasts at home. Yes, the space is tiny. Yes, the baristas aren't the fastest (though they are among the friendliest and certainly the most competent). But you're looking for great coffee, right? If yes, Joe Coffee is for you.

Slow service and coffee is just okay. There's always a long wait to get coffee, probably because there is only one espresso machine. I only come when I'm in the area and need coffee. Starbucks with their long lines are faster than here.

Coffee is great but the service could be better. I ordered an iced-coffee and asked for less ice. The barista simply poured out the existing ice and handed me a half-cup of iced coffee. I was a bit surprised to be honest. The service was also a bit slow and there were a ton of flies/mosquitoes flying around which was surprising since it was chilly and it was October already. Will hope that other locations aren't as poor.
Stopped here for a caffe latte on my way to Central Park. The barista was super friendly, and there is great outdoor seating. Definitely will stop here again!
Hi, can I have a latte with a shot of pretentiousness please? $6 for a pint size yogurt parfait that one can finish in 3 bites? This is what's gone wrong w NYC. Good luck Danny Meyer
Coffee is good but it takes forever. Are you still waiting? Probably because it takes so long. Hellooooooo.

Awesome coffee place. While the line can sometimes be long, that's just because the coffee is so good!  The staff is really friendly and all the coffees they make are incredible. I especially like their single origin coffee, it's always fantastic. There is also a nice little patio to sit outside on a nice day to enjoy the coffee and take in the laid back upper west side vibe. Overall my go-to coffee joint!
Love their Coffee und relaxed ambience:). Once you try it you are not going to settle for Starbucks anymore

I enjoy their coffee a lot, so much that their lack of interior study space is forgivable. I wish they had a bit more room to spare to give customers more space to read and talk, but again, their coffee makes up for it.

Came to this location this morning since I was on the Upper West Side and thought I would see if I liked the vibe here.  It's quite cute, though the line basically went almost out of the door, but other than that I like the place and the customer service I received.  Very polite and friendly.  I had a free drink card from the Joe Coffee location at Grand Central that I received after some guy basically cut the line and took my drink and another customer's drink, forcing me to have to wait for yet another one to be made, which was quite the wait, as the baristas seem to believe in taking great care to ensure that the drinks they make come out great.  The waits can be a bit long, but the quality makes up for it.  I have actually stopped frequenting one of my organic coffee spots (at least for coffee anyway for now) as I've been very happy with Joe Coffee and the pastries that they sell... Addictive!!
It is a coffee place like all the other coffee places that pop out everywhere. However, for a reason I am not able to articulate I like this one way better than Starbucks.

Came here with my mom. Ordered two soy lattes ($12 for some reason). Watched them make it and was pretty sure they used regular milk, but figured they knew what they were doing and didn't want to be a bother. The guy gave me my two lattes and told me they were soy. I am lactose intolerant, so soy milk is essential for me (and cost an extra 50 per latte). I immediately thought that it didn't taste right, but didn't want to argue after he told me that they were soy. About an hour later, I was sick. Experiencing everything I normally do after consuming lactose. Now I can't be sure, of course, but all signs seem to suggest that my latte was not soy. This alone is not good, but when you consider that I paid an extra $1 for soy (though I was really just paying to get sick), it's especially unfair and wrong.
I ordered a cafe late and it was pretty good!!!! The cream was decorated nicely and cozy atmosphere!!! The best place to take a rest and drop by alone!!!!

If you're in need of a quick breakfast, Kahve is a good option. It's a coffee shop/breakfast spot with wifi, seating, and a printer (yeah, weird, but it's their thing. You can print anything you need while you're there).  I ordered the BLT with avocado and an over easy egg and it was tasty. It came on two slices of white bread filling me up and the price was reasonable.  I recommend Kahve if you want a quick place to eat in the morning!

Dropped by Kahve for a miel latte to sooth my soul, and that it did. The service was lame; the guy seemed annoyed to be helping me, but no matter. I ordered the miel latte with almond milk, and it was delicious, especially with some added cinnamon, but I don't think a latte with some added honey should be over $6. It's a bit outrageous, if you ask me.  Kahve itself is an adorable little cafe, with coziness level to the max. Everyone is sitting around working on their laptops, so if you're looking for a quiet place to work in or read, this is perfect. It may be too quiet for a date or meeting of some sort, as everyone around would be able to hear you, and for me, that'd get awkward. The music is low, but the prices are high, so I wouldn't make it a regular trip, but a fun splurge every now and then when I'm in the mood for a unique latte the hipsters would like.  If you do want to come regularly, get their card. After ten drinks, you get a small one for freezies.

This new coffee joint takes the place of the old Bis Co Latte shop. Been to their 9th avenue location before (also 3 stars) so was hoping for something better here.  Early morning on a Wednesday - got the Cuban coffee ($4) and the Artichoke/Goat Cheese Croissant ($5.50). Coffee was good, particularly sweet as a cafe cubano should be, but not too hot that it burnt my tongue. Disappointed in the croissant though - felt the flavors didn't blend well and maybe could have used more filling.  I do like the fact that this shop opens early. The competition in the area for coffee shops is intense, so hoping the best for Kahve.
Decent wine, mediocre service. The bartender/barista rushed us out as it was nearing closing time so we had to down our wine. Not the best experience.
Sweet little coffee shop close to the corner of W 47th St & 10th Ave. Decent coffee, but expensive upcharge for almond milk. Do we really still need to do that? Come on.

The coffee is probably not the best. But the place is so lovely and this location also offers drinks/cocktails. It has those fancy coffee, with white chocolate/raspberry. The Cuba drink comes with three espresso shots! A lot of caffeine. I just get usual latte and the barista does the latte art even mine is to go. Plus, it's just Starbucks price.

Totally got the hype here! As a girl enjoys all kinds of exotic type food (and drinks), I would strongly recommend this place given its extensive list of signature coffee drinks.  I got the lavender vanilla latte (and substituted for skim milk, as you all know me...), it carries a slight flora scent, on top of the vanilla smell and I thought those made a perfect combination. Aside of that, I saw many Yelp pictures on zebra mocha and it looks delicious to me - would love to come back for a casual sip.  My server was very attentive and smiled to me all the time. I guess I completely fell in love with this place!

If you want the most chemically infused, cancer-inducing coffee, with the worst service imaginable, look no further.  I bought a cup of their house drip to try it out, and after a few sips, tasted not only the acidity of their "coffee", but what can only be described as a mild dose of Ajax mixed in, just for flavor.  Sure, bad coffee I can deal with, but after a few minutes, I began to feel the burn all the way down to my stomach and decided to approach the barista (asshole) to get a new cup. When I did, I was told the coffee "was made the way we were shown", turned around, and refused to even offer a different drink in exchange.  Won't come back, don't come here. I can deal with bad coffee if the service is decent, but I'd prefer to not drink your cleaning product because your staff is too busy checking themselves in the mirror to make sure the customers are happy (actual interaction.)

I try to avoid leaving bad reviews, but sometimes it's just necessary. This place makes one want to move to L.A., if only for the classiness of even their scrappiest coffee houses (and I write as a LONG-time New Yorker). Even if you choose to ignore the horrid "view" outside this joint (not necessarily their fault, though one need only call the city to request trees be planted), and take into consideration that the coffee, and basically all offerings here, are fine (hence the extra star), what you can't ignore, and what is far from fine, even a teensy bit fine, is the staff. They seem to think one need be sour just because one happens to work in New York City.  Eff that. Hell's Kitchen has plenty of alternatives for your coffee fix.

Khave was the only coffee shop in the area that stood out from our preliminary yelp search. The ambiance is extremely fun with pink neon accents and a mirror running the length of one wall making the tiny space feel a bit larger. The selection is pretty standard but the coffee is very tasty; making it apparent they use quality beans. You can also get alcohol here with certain times offering a happy hour. There is a loyalty card which is nice if you live here. Definitely recommend!

Looking for a good place to sit, have coffee and enjoy some good morning grub.  This was a fabulous find!  Coffee is amazing.  My girlfriend and I each had one of their 'toasts' for breakfast.  I had the bacon, tomato, goat cheese and arugula.  She had the traditional avocado toast.  Both had truffle oil drizzled over the arugula.  They were amazing!  Add to it the nice chill jazz music in the background and it was the perfect Saturday morning.  Love.

We wandered in off the street for a quick coffee to warm up. The bright lights and music caught our eye, that and the promise off coffee and wine. Though I stuck to the house brew coffee, it was the avocado toast that made this place stick out. It was incredibly tasty! One plate was enough for 2 to share, and it offered great value at $11 including the addition of some bacon. Definitely recommend

This review is for 4.5 stars.  Nice little coffee bar off to the side of a dirty street. About 6 tables line the tiny restaurant. They have the typical brews as well as some interesting like matcha and black sesame lattes. We went with a black sesame and a pomegranate iced tea. Together they were under $9 which is quite reasonable. Really fast service and tasted great. I would come back to try a classic coffee for sure.
Wonderful little cafe with excellent coffees. I usually stop by to get either the lavender matcha latte, which is perfectly sweetened, or the draft latte, which is very creamy and foamy.

Cute little coffee shop tucked away from the main drag in Chinatown. Pop in for a breather as you battle the afternoon heat and sweaty Chinatown crowds, or stay a little while because the drinks are good and the atmosphere is super chill. I ordered a rose and lychee tea latte on a recent visit here. It was delicious and not a drink you see at other coffee shops. They serve other types of tea lattes as well as well as more traditional coffee drinks. The space is small but it doesn't seem like many people know about this place yet because seating isn't a problem.

Stopped by for a liquid lunch and was not disappointed. The baristas were friendly, the shop has tons of sunlight - during the day obviously ha - and half a dozen tables. There's free WiFi and outlets. Besides the standard fare of drink offerings, they've got a decent selection of teas as well as La Colombe's draft latte and cold brew on tap. They use La Colombe beans as well. The tea I believe is TeaPigs.  I ordered a macchiato and it was delicious. A little more milk than I'm used to, I think it was technically a cortado - but it was great nonetheless. The milk texture was on point, and the espresso was strong, tasted like caramel and vanilla. Highly recommend if you're in the area.
Black sesame latte to die for!! Not a ton of seating space but a good place to get some work done - big windows, light and bright, good background music.

Stumbled upon this place when I was walking towards soho around 2pm. Place looks really neat. You can see a display of two massive Kyoto Drip towers and can't help but to appreciate the beauty of it. There's also a signature coffee they have on the menu named "Kyoto Rose coffee" which caught my attention but they ran out. Totally fine I get that, coffee shops sometimes just sell out on certain items.  What also caught my eye is their pour over station. Since on the menu it said pour over is available from 12pm - 6pm I thought I would be able to order this no problem since there was no one in line and the place was fairly empty at the time as well. The barista said "we're not doing any pour over drinks at this time." I asked "why not?" And I never got a response.. weird. I was shocked to say the least. Definitely not a good impression of this place with the horrible service since it's my first time here. So I ended up getting a drip coffee instead. The coffee is good but terrible service. Don't advertise your pour over being available at a certain time and say you can't make it.

So happy this place opened up. It's pricey coffee but that's how it goes in the area nowadays. However, top notch service. Lots of variety, featured brews. The drip coffee is amazing, so smooth. They recently switched to la Colombe so it's even better now.  The guys/staff are great. Super friendly and genuinely nice guys. I work in the area and see them around all the time.  The space is clean and modern. They have a bathroom on site and baked goods.

Tea good. The service friendly. It some of the patron that lounged there for free wifi in limited space and taking up seating for their purse and is too rude to move their purse when asked and her friends just as rude. If such a great place but they to place a restriction on wifi allowance to no more than 2 hours and a rude sign to remind those when busy to take up only a seat. The place is adorable but their seating arrangements of community table was a bad idea too close for comfort.

A cool little cafe with heaps of tables , would be a nice place to hang out with your friends over some drinks.  I got a iced coffee/ latte to go. Staff was friendly and service was quick. But the coffee was disappointing. Maybe there was too much milk or something.  But i will be back if I need a place to chill or hang out !

I tend to look for coffee shops to study in. In terms of that, this cafe checks off all the things I look for in a coffee shop: -wifi -good drinks: esp. the latte and the blood orange hibiscus tea -bathroom -low noise level -plugs -spacious

I love not only their coffee but their Sandwiches. I tried cortado and Avocado sandwich and i really love them. I didnt know this coffee shop was in my neighborhood but I just found it today.  Their latte art is so so so adorable and sweet as well. Thank you for being close to my house

Very cute space that's tucked away in the middle of busy Manhattan. The area is very clean and wifi is free and speedy. There are no individual tables (only 2 large tables for 6 people and a counter area). They play great classical music in the background and the overall noise inside is minimal. They serve pastries as well!!
If you get there on a day where they have the spinach artichoke pastry, get it! It's my favorite mix of salty creamy flakey goodness to go with their smooth, slightly smokey latte.

I stumbled on this caf̩ between Macy's and Nordstrom Rack.  It is unlike any other "coffee shop" in the city - more of an oasis, like a discovered secret garden. The ambience is very zen and calming. The design is architecturally chill - tall ceilings, lots of wood, obviously every detail was well-thought-out. And that goes for the menu as well. A small coffee is huge - and delicious, a combo sourced from Joe. There were also a variety of interesting teas and delicious-looking pastries. The owners (a couple) were warm and welcoming. I hope it is discovered, but keeps its chill atmosphere.

Came to Knave to meet some friends from out of town. Very nice decor.  I learned that it was not actually a church but built to look like one.  Nice job!  Be aware that seating near the exit has a lot of harsh lighting coming from outside which I didn't like.  Totally took away from the ambiance.  I asked to be moved and they accommodated us with a different table very quickly.    Very good service and nice cocktails.

This place is absolutely beautiful and relaxing. It's like an upscale lounge. Service is fine. The menu is very small and simple, which is nice. Although the ambiance is amazing, it is very expensive. A small cappuccino will run you $8.  Expensive or not, going here is a treat.

Cocktails are between $23-27 so be ready to drop some change. Beer is also expensive but that's the price to pay for the atmosphere that the bar provides.  It's not so much as bar as it is a narrow path between two halls/entrances, strategically designed to give it a much more spacious impression.  Hues of dark red, with specks of warm chandelier lighting make it perfect for dates, not so family friendly haha  To be honest I thought it would be a larger venue but I liked their couches anyhow. Probably will not return, mostly bc the drinks are exorbitantly priced...even for midtown.

The place looks amazing which is why it gets three stars. Nice to relax in here but that's about it. Three stars is for the vibe alone. The service is non-existent. You have to ask for someone to come. You have to ask them to take your bill. They will not come back after the brought your drinks. The coffee actually isn't that good which is the order part. You want a place like this to have amazing coffee and it just doesn't. They also have parfaits and other collections of stale fruit. You walk in wanting this place to be amazing but nothing here is. Also overpriced. Two iced coffee with tip will run you 20 bucks..

Located inside the hotel, Knave admittedly has an incredibly unique interior.  Entering its nook is like setting foot inside some Gothic cathedral.  But I'm uneasy about overly quiet spaces, and this one was practically as silent as a tomb.  For such high prices, the coffee options were extremely limited.  And the barista certainly turned his nose up at me when I asked for vanilla in my latte.  It's definitely the "we don't wish to serve artificial sweeteners of any kind - how dare you" kind of vibe.    If the caffeine choices are slim, then call the food items severely slim.  I got stuck with a dry, possibly day-old (?) chocolate croissant, but ended up stealing bites of my mom's blueberry muffin: moist, with an unexpectedly pleasant tang.    Maybe it'd be different if Knave was the place around for miles, but NYC is practically a breeding ground for coffee spots.  Overall, probably not worth your time and $$.

Not only is it a business operating in a public space that discriminates against people with a normal income, but they charge you $20+ for mediocre cocktails made with muddled rotten fruit. Also you are paying astronomical prices for sub par products in an environment that is not only infested with vermin like roaches and mice but a mismanaged team of people who only care about themselves than about the guests experience. They don't clean the glassware, the $22 glasses of wine always have lip stains- gross! Personally I only like to pay for quality. I was a former employee as Steven P. Has pointed out, but I am not guilty of low quality because I have and always will have high standards which were not appreciated what so ever during my employment which is a whole another review on Glassdoor isn't it?!  The bad service I am referring to occurs mainly amounts your lazy over compensated entitled night staff PIPES. I'm just telling the truth NYC I'm an honest person so whether you like it or not I'll always tell the truth.
The drinks were delicious, the nut mix with fried olives was yummy and the service was great!

This place is so over priced and the service is awful, the management kept moving our parties seating arrangement. Plus the actually informed my party that they were not allowed to bring their burgers from the place across the hall. Never ever go to this lounge it's awful!!!!

This place is a little pricey, but for the location and the atmosphere, it's not *too* pricey.  Plus, the drinks are extremely well made and STRONG (exactly how my friends and I like 'em).  The cheese plate we shared was tasty and the nuts and olives were pretty ridiculous.  Overall, a great spot to sit and feel "fancy" and enjoy a drink or two.

A great place to sit, read and grab a cappuccino. Makes for great people watching and lounging. It can get busy and crowded which makes navigating its narrow hallway location challenging, but overall a nice stop along the journey.

Tried to get in to the secret burger joint in Le Parker Meridian but at 1 pm on a Friday afternoon the line was out to the lobby. Alternate choice was the Knave. Good choice. Nice seating, great people watching, very good service and a limited but very interesting menu. i had the smoked salmon with blue cheese sandwich on a baguette. Really good. Great coffee and desserts also.

After a beautiful performance of Handel's Messiah at Carnegie Hall, I thought a warm drink will be the best way to cap the night.  We hied off to Le Meridien and much as a part of me wanted to go to Burger Joint, the inviting atmosphere at Knave seemed to know me by name.  I was craving mulled wine, that is red wine heated with cinnamon and cloves.  Unfortunately, Knave didn't have it that night so I settled for the comfort of hot chocolate.    The hot chocolate was Valrhona, melted in a mug, and served with a side of steaming milk.  We also ordered hot cider, which was as perfect as can be.  The music was muted and the service was very efficient and attentive.  I actually enjoyed those fried olives,which were served along with mixed nuts as snacks.  Knave occupies part of the lobby of the Meridien, so it is a narrow room, with high ceilings and mirrored walls.  I though it was a very efficient use of space and a lovely place to have a night cap. :)

Knave is a classy, fancy coffee shop. I really enjoyed my time here. They serve a wide array of drinks - alcohol, coffee, tea. Free internet is available which is always a plus.  Drinks are expensive, but if you're looking for a place that's unique, laid back, beautiful, not extremely busy then this is a wonderful place. Noise level was not loud at all. Great jazz music playing in the background.  I spent about 3 hours here drinking some tea and getting work done on my computer. I can certainly see myself coming back here :)

Food: Drinks.  Fried olives and nuts.  Service: Quick and Friendly.  Pricing: Typical midtown NYC pricing for hotel bar (moderately expensive).  Atmosphere: Interesting Gothic style.  Avoid sitting in front (57th street).  Verdict: Good place to meet someone for a quick chat.  Not a place to have fun and relax.  Top bar selection is average.

very elegant and different, but best for grabbing a starter drink or a nightcap.  the name actually looks like "nave", which would have been a suitable name since the much of the building and contents looks like the inside of a church (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Na?).  not sure if you can enter from the north side, but if you enter through the south, you first encounter some lower couches, seats, and coffee table.  frustratingly, in the setup is a two-person couch, a chair, than a circular footrest that likely serves as a seat for the fourth person.  this combo is than repeated until the end of the bar.  there is a 10-15 foot area where the actual bar stands.  the actual bar is beautiful, carved wood, stained glass, with no bar stools.  again, as if stolen from a church and converted.  lower lighting and mostly hotel guests drinking or having a quick cup of coffee/cappuccino.  drinks are expensive, but the pours are very strong (actually bring the club soda or tonic is a small carafe on the side).

Probably my favorite location in the city. I happened to stumble upon this La Colombe completely by chance while making my way to the Auto Show, and was delighted to find it. The location is HUGE! Tons of seating, nice marble counters, a lovely view of Lamborghinis in the windows of Manhattan Motorcars across the street. The espresso is just as good as the other locations, but I totally love this space. Came on a Sunday and it was empty, which is a pleasant surprise compared to the bustling ones downtown. The staff is friendly and chill. It is definitely out of the way for me, but when in the area, I now know where to go for my caffeine fix.

This is the first time I'm trying teas at La Colombe, as every single time I order coffee here (and get impressed repetitively). Their tea selection was quite extensive, and for Oolong, they have got Thailand, Taiwan and mainland China. While it took a little bit long to brew, their tea was definitely among the best I have sipped among different coffee shops. Perfect temperature, perfect taste, and perfect combination with milk - flawless. Can choose milk to be steamed or as it is, so considerate!

I love La Colombe.  I think it's some of the best coffee in NYC.  Oddly enough, I discovered them not in NYC but in Venice, CA at a great spot which only serves their grounds and sells bags of their beans as well.  I was so impressed, it became my morning stop for the necessary Americano with steamed milk on the side.  Perfection.  Only thing I might change is that I prefer to have an Americano in more of a cafe coffee cup and saucer with the milk on the side as too often the barista will add too much milk.  When they put it in a regular coffee mug- it's not appetizing.
Yes it's here and it's good!  Clean and spacious and its la colombe.  Opened 2 weeks ago Thursday.

No wi fi. No chai. Hot chocolate not good/chocolates almost at all. But good brewed latte. One of the girls behind counter was on her phone, then eating consistently and then left for a smoke break. She was not attentive to myself or other customers.

Eh, wasn't impressed. There's almost no seating in here, first of all, so you're likely to lose out unless you get lucky or come super early. My friend and I did get lucky, but it's not really a comfy place to hang.  As for the product - the drip coffee I had was good but not anything too special. The egg sandwich had an odd spice to it that was just overbearing. I wasn't a fan but I was starving so I wolfed it down anyhow. Finally, I asked for some tap water and was directed to the bottled water for sale in the cooler.  Next!

Had the Serrano sandwich. The bread was a little stale and the eggs were a little more cooked than I was expecting from the pictures. That being said my sandwich was still super flavorful and was the perfect brunch to get my day off going.

one of the best egg sandwiches I have ever had!! (got the one with cheese and bacon) though -1 star for the price/portion...I had to add an egg to the sandwich, and my fiance had to order 2 sandwiches for breakfast when we picked these up and ate them at home!

Great local spot! Super nice guys behind the counter serving great coffee/espresso and delicious homemade pastries. Perfect example of what this place is all about - they don't allow pets (as is the law), but they will actually take your order outside and bring it out to you to accommodate!  Lena+Panineria make a mean side-by-side combination on 8th street.

Hits all the right notes. Great coffee, great snacks, friendly service, and seats by the window for people watching. The cappuccinos and cortados are both great; the chocolate croissants and the butter scones are wonderful accompaniments. This place's draw, though, is the macaroons that have been the family specialty for nearly four hundred years. Yes, four hundred--since the 1600s back in Basque country. The macaroons are not the pastel-colored treats you normally see. Theirs come in one style: chewy almond-flavored bites of perfection. The shopkeeper's rich french accent completes the picture. Cannot recommend this place highly enough on a cold fall/winter day.

Disclaimer: This is a review based off their matcha latte and tumeric latte drinks.  I am not a coffee drinker, so I'm always looking for great tea/alternative options. I went several weeks ago and got their tumeric latte. I thought it was very mediocre, it was quite gritty and not incorporated well. Flash forward to last week. I figured let's give them another try, tumeric lattes are hard, so I tried their matcha latte. It was the same story.  I love their mission statement and their space is beautiful, but their coffee alternatives is not something I'd seek out.  I have heard only great things about their Flat White.

I dont get the hype for this place.. the coffee is nice and yummy but is it really worth the wait!? Initially we went up to the original location couple blocks up and I didnt want to wait for it so we said screw it.. the. We were by the district for lunch and ran in to this location which is way calmer on a weekend and gave it a shot.. I feel like there are other local coffee shops with just as good cappuccinos so dont be upset if the line is too long and you need to grab a coffee elsewhere. Also the honey lavender latte had no lavender flavor to it kinda tasted like a regular latte so It was below expectations but the cappuccino was good with very tasty foam.

Excellent coffee. Love the Irish cream mocha. Wish they had more gluten free muffins/offerings. Hope they keep the double doors open to accommodate strollers. 2 stars off for inconsistent gluten free offerings and the crap shoot of getting in with a stroller as the door is sometimes locked.

Cool staff. Ran out of chocolate for Expresso Blender drink, only other option of caramel is still delish. Great scenic area, seating avail inside + Battery benches outside. On my Schwarzenegger, I'll be back...

Love their teas and coffee. Backed by hugh Jackman, who doesn't like this place. It has character and strong caffeine which is a must for all who work in world financial centers at 2pm  Plus! Their donuts are HUGE and amazing. What more can you ask for?  I work near here and would definitely come back on a frequent basis for coffee breaks.  I like..only caveat is that it is a bit hard to find. Tucked away in a maze like building. Worth a find tho!

It was a gorgeous and warm Mother's Day where everyone seemed to be out and about. We popped in to grab a beverage and find a place for my young son to go to the bathroom...  Warning- there are no bathrooms here. The coffee, however, was truly excellent. My iced latte was one of the better ones I've ever had.

Nice little shop with a variety of drink options. I got the honey lavender latte and it had just the right amount of sweetness. To be honest the lavender flavor was pretty subtle but still yum. It was $5.50 after tax, kinda pricey but still reasonable for the area I guess. Would definitely go again and try the other drinks

Since all the the construction/revamping of World Financial Center has shut down all the shops and food options around my office, I am SO GRATEFUL for a decent coffee joint within walking distance. Laughing Man is a great little spot to hit up for that 3PM coffee break. On my first day discovering this place, I actually had two separate coffee chats scheduled, both of whom I dragged to Laughing Man. It's hidden enough that the WFC crowd doesn't swarm this joint like they do with Starbucks and Financier (the only two other coffee options).  Oh, and get the flat white for sure!!!

We walked in at a busy time.  This is a really tight place without any seating (except for two chairs out front). The coffee and espresso ordered were fantastic.  We will definitely drop in again.  Flavor is worth the wait.  Its also nice to support a good cause with an interesting background story.

I have been here about 5-7 times. Great espresso stand with a limited selection of pastries but its nice that its focused on the coffee. Best place to get coffee if you are near the WFC or coming from the ferry.
This coffee is so good. I ordered I regular coffee and went back an hour later for their speciality, the light white. It was that good. I'll definitely be back and send my friends.

Good coffee, nice location considering.  Went to try the one in TriBeca but when I walked by and saw how teeny tiny it was I kept on walking so it's nice to have one open close to my work and that isn't claustrophobic.

My coffee tasted burnt. That's because the lady steamed the milk and espresso together. They almost seemed annoyed that I was ordering something so I didn't bother asking for them to please remake it. My cake was delicious. Will not be visiting again for coffee.

If you are wandering around the Italian Disneyland that is Eataly the Lavazza Cafe located by the front entrance is a decent stop for coffee or cappuccino. Along with the delicious pastries and baked goods they offer here this can be a dangerous place for your waist line.  Always seems crowded with all the hustle and bustle here. We had to do "the hover" and wait for a few people to leave before jumping into their seats at one of the tables. The staff are a bit slow in clearing the dirty stuff off the tables so I did it myself. Cappuccino's were tasty with thick foam. The desserts we chose were of good quality, but be warned your surely pay for it. In fact, it seems most things here are a bit higher priced, but I guess it comes with the territory.  It's a nice stop for a change of pace, but nothing to make a habit of. So many other coffee and dessert places to hit up in the area or within a few minutes away.

Awesome awesome awesome coffee here. The real deal. Everytime I'm in the area and want  a well crafted delicious coffee I come here. I hate having to deal with every European tourist coffee snob that comes here. But swallow your pride it's worth it. Staff is friendly and it's always busy. I'd skip the pastries.

Minus half star for allowing people who don't buy food or drinks to take up seating with outside food, especially when all the seats are taken.  The coffee beverages are really good. Some of the pastries are good, depends on your preferences. Love the tiramusu.

Ordered a bicerin. Hot chocolate was cold with cream poured in, instead of on top, making the whole drink room temperature. Espresso component was also incredibly gritty. Let the counter know the hot chocolate must have been cold and that the drink had espresso grits in it, and they told me the drink is always served like that...so don't order a bicerin here! I figured that since it's Lavazza in Eataly, there would be a bit more authenticity and care. Not the case, and undrinkable!

Coffee is quite good actually! Four-star. The big drawback is that it's so perpetually filled with european tourists that it's nearly impossible to get a seat. That being said it's still very entertaining people watching. The proximity to the park not only provides it with a nice view, it also makes Lavazza the perfect post-Shake Shack coffee palate-cleanser :-)

MealPal here today, picked up mere 30mins ago, I can already review it because I finished the tiny little Pastrami Break (a.k.a. bagel with two, too-thin slices of pastrami) in the few minutes it took to walk back to the office. No way shall I ever try this bad value again. The ingredients were alright in freshness though pastrami's not hard to keep "fresh" and the bagel quality was alright compared to my favorite bagel place in Midwood. The horseradish is so inexpensive a way they can gussy up what is a too-small item. Pastrami itself was normal, nothing to write home about, it actually worsens the pastrami craving which sent me here at all because the portion size is totally insufficient. It's the worst fear of MealPal: paltry item with chronically under-whelming portion size. I'll note this in the daily MealPal last-meal survey.  The store space is heavily air conditioned with bright cute decorations through the tiny space, must be just 80 ft2 of standing room in there, the bulk of it is for their kitchen and storage space behind the scenes.  I shant be back, it's a reminder of the bad values of midtown eats near college areas with affluent college kids (i.e. NYU, CU).

I'm on a lavender latte kick and I'm slowly seeing the drink pop up in various Caf̩s across NYC.  I walk in (And I do mean walk in, its very tiny) and see a full arsenal of Dough Donuts proudly on display. As a matter of fact, there is a good looking selection of baked goods at Le Caf̩ Coffee.  I order my lavender latte and a very small biscotti. The lavender latte didn't have enough lavender and the biscotti could have broken all of my teeth on this thing.  The coffee itself tasted good if it were a plain latte. I wanted more lavender. Come to find out, this place is a chain? I walked around the corner and saw another Le Caf̩ Coffee?? Maybe they make a better lavender latte.  3 stars from me today

Le Cafe Coffee NY Manhattan Union Square 2pm Sunday 31st January 2016 Three Stars  I just stopped for a cup of joe. The shop was small but cozy. The coffee was a bit burnt and bitter but it did the trick.
Perfect little space to get out of the morning commute for a quick cup of coffee. Friendly baristas, and line moves extremely fast. Great morning pick me up!
Great tasting everything bagel!  Mocha latte was velvety smooth with cool art on top.  Definitely coming back.

Good stuff here, but nothing groundbreaking. I tried the lavender latte - a first for me - but was underwhelmed. The latte tasted good, but nothing like lavender. That is, until I got to the bottom, where there was a sickly sweet amount of lavender syrup or whatever. Pass.  The almond croissant was from Dough, I think, and it was decent but doesn't make my list of the city's best (and I do have a list).  Friendly service and great selection of Dough donuts (but with Dough up the block, there's not really a reason to get them here). All in all, I probably wouldn't return, because there are more interesting options in the area.

Coffee house and restaurant hopping with a friend on a Saturday afternoon on a stifling hot summer's afternoon into a cool air conditioned environment called for stillness.  Quaint small coffee shop set to a French name but nothing resembles French with the exception of Marcon cookies.  I was given the WRONG sales receipt for items that I did not ordered.  One Marcoon cookie $3.75- not worth the hefty price as it was average quality and extremely overpriced One ice tea $2.50 One coffee $3.00- average  No restroom facility and esteem stool ledge seating is very minimal.  Service is robotic from stolid servers.

I work nearby and go here all the time for my flat white fix. Always impeccably prepared and always with a huge smile. The most consistently excellent baristas I've ever encountered. You can not go wrong with any coffee drink from this place.

This very unassuming, soon to be closed coffee shop, surprised the shit out of me.  First off, they have customers? In a half block radius, it's dominated by coffee giants such as Starbucks, Caffe Bene, & previously aesthetically appealing Bourbon Coffee. It's tiny and from the brief conversation I had with the baristas, it's boring... but I like it. Because it's so small, it kept my on-the-go flow going, especially since I like to take my coffee to my gym to stare at all the swimmers. I sound like such a creep.  What really piqued my interest was the Rose Latte. I've been spending time with this girl who's obsessed with rose flavor everything & having seen their promotion, I was caught in their marketing ploy. This is a conspiracy I tell ya'! The Rose Latte was actually a refreshing change of pace from my usual black coffee. It had a subtle bitterness and a light sweetness to it. Definitely something I can see myself drinking in the winter or taking that girl to, assuming of course she gets me something pretty when she comes back from Hawaii.  If not, she'll never know the joys of a Rose Latte.  This is the part where Kiss From a Rose starts playing.
It's a little shop with lmt seating.  I got the rose coffee? Pretty yummy. Staff are nice too!  Tip: they have pouch card if you decide to stop by often!

I was very tempted after hearing about the lavender latte but was utterly unimpressed by it. The lavender was very subtle, so to me, it could have passed as any other regular latte. The guy making it was great with the latte art, but I had expected more lavender taste to it.

When I went to this coffee place, I was amazed when I tried there Latte Lavender Coffee and there capresse. The capresse is a sandwich on whole grain white bread I think? But any way, it had sweet vinegar, olive oil, tomatoes, Basil and mozzerella cheese. I defiantly recommend this coffee shop if you are going to see a movie around here, but you are hungry. This is defiantly the place to go!

This cute cafe just made my day. The first time I visit this place I realize I don't have my wallet when I was about to pay. I Was so embarrassing tell them to cancel the order before they make the rich smooth latte for me and I thought the cashier would be mad at me for my carelessness. Guess what, they told me to bring the money back to them tmr and they gave me the latte and donuts. Not mention about their yummy passion fruits donuts, It's feel awesome to have trust from a totally stranger and this place just officially became my new favorite coffee spot.

Quick, friendly service. Tall counter seats line two walls. Full glass storefront is perfect for people watching. Conveniently located on 14th street, between Union Square and 5th Avenue, across from New School's new building. Great addition to this block!

This is my morning coffee & sandwich place. Everyday when I'm on my way to work, I try not to buy things but I end up in there. Their coffee is the best. The sandwiches are made fresh upon order & are made with love by both of the guys that work there. They're too sweet. Side Note: it's a little overpriced.

While this chic little coffee shop had delicious product, it still has a few bugs to work out. The lid to my hot coffee wouldn't snap shut, and I was burnt twice from the coffee spilling out due to the lid.  While the burns were annoying, and a little painful, the manager was super helpful and offered me a new cup (which still didn't fit any of their lids). Also, their blueberry muffin was delicious. I'd go back if I'm in a rush or don't want to travel far for an inexpensive breakfast.

Since I came here because of yelp I figured it would be only fair to review this place. I have walked by this place many times since my life has brought me to this neighborhood more. Extremely modern and relaxing even though it is right next to union square. I usually get black coffee and because of the unique aesthetic of this place and the heat. I decided to get a chai tea, usually I destroy the flavor of things by putting in espresso. A double shot and it did not over power it at all. I think I found a regular summer drink. Can't wait to bring the misses here, PRICE WAS AWESOME TOO!!!
