You must try the lavender latte ... its just the most perfect subtle hint of lavender mixed with smooth and expertly made coffee.  A must in the neighborhood... it doesn't look like much from the outside and it's in a not-so-pretty looking area but the coffee was surprisingly and perfectly delicious!

Great sandwiches, salads, pastries, and drinks! Really friendly baristas and a cool mix of french-esque and 90s music. Also I have to say, ever since my trip to Paris, I've been looking all over the U.S. for the same Parisian style/quality macarons, and here I have finally found them! Just as perfect! I wish there were more locations! I took one star off because with such a welcoming atmosphere, I think patrons deserve more than ~6 bar seats.
In my first visit the drinks were good and environment was friendly. Service was a little slow, but not terrible. It's hard to find a good latte on 14th st, so this is the place to go.
Almond milk cappuccino is simply the best! The coffee is authentic and high quality -- what more could you ask for? I highly recommend this place and will definitely come back soon.

The fast and friendly service beats Starbucks any day! I highly recommend their pastry and authentic coffee. i work near by so I always grab breakfast on the go here. Pricing is very reasonable for the quality.

I just discovered this new coffee shop and absolutely love it. It's small and clean inside with a great vibe. Their coffee is EXCELLENT and fairly priced.  I tried a sandwich today and it was phenomenal and super fresh.  Reminded me of a bocadillo from a street cafe in spain ;).

Le Cafe has it all: a coffee shop with a warm yet urban style, offering outstanding products and a great location right at the heart of Union Sq. The cafe shelters all kind of coffee devotees; one can met interesting locals, diverse tourists, and random house guests, all of whom contribute to the unique atmosphere in the shop. Coffee lovers can enjoy a cup of La Colombe coffees along with freshly baked goods and in-house made sandwiches. All coffee drinks are amazing, but I absolutely love the Lavender Latte. The staff is helpful and provides friendly service and consistent products. They offer a coffee loyalty card called for 10 + 1 Free drink. I wish they had cards for the sandwiches, too. Smoked Turkey Dijonaise sandwich is my favorite. I live around the corner and feel totally hooked on the products and convenience that this venue offers. If you prefer a cozy little coffee shop with great products that is not commercialized, La Cafe is your spot.

Seeing as this place has one dollar sign yet such high reviews, is close to my family's Airbnb, and is a walk's away from Central Park, it seemed like the perfect place to take my family!  We walked in on Tuesday around 9AM, and luckily there were enough seats for us! I appreciated how each little table had its own glass water bottle for us to pour. We looked at all the pastries and the menu, and I was deciding between a Nutella croissant and a grilled cheese sandwich. Because I was having trouble deciding what I wanted, some people behind us ended up getting 2 Nutella croissants. I had decided I wanted the Nutella croissants, but the employee said they ran out. How does a bakery run out of Nutella croissants at 9AM? Le Reveil Coffee needs to know to make more than just 2 croissants so they don't run out at 9AM. So with this in mind, I ended up ordering the grilled cheese sandwich.  Ready to get my hands and mouth all up in some American and/or Mozzarella cheese, I was disappointed in when I noticed my sandwich had some sad and somewhat unmelted brie cheese in it. It tasted like a sad yet healthy substitute for a grilled cheese sandwich. Not what I wanted at 9AM. They also gave me some salad, which is nice of them, but salad in the morning is not my cup of tea. I got to eat this depressingly healthy meal for "only" $10.  If someone comes to Lereveil Coffee, I would suggest coming here for the pastries. My parents ended up eating the almond pastry, and although it was small, they said it was very delicious. I advise everyone to stay away from their non-pastry items.

Cute spot conveniently located near the 72nd st station. Service was subpar the cashier was pretty frazzled despite there being only 3 customers in line at the time. Food & drink took what seemed a lifetime, about 20 mins, and the order was completely wrong. Didn't bother to take it back knowing it take forever especially since a longer line had formed at that time. A 2nd worker appeared after the line died back down lol. Food was good though.

I came across this coffee shop just today. The interior design fascinated me. It is designed like more than just a coffee shop. Their Coffee? Just incredible taste. They're using my favorite brand Intelligensia. If you check my picture you'll undertand why I liked the place so much because you can get all of that all at once. The Salmon toast ROCKS! Warm and friendly Barista's. The owner guy looks like a young & successful business man very good looking I'd have to add  and he was also very helpful with my questions. Next time I come I will try their signature Turkish Coffee. I think for now I'm going to open my laptop here and work a little bit and enjoy my freshly made pourover
Went here with my kids on a random Wednesday for lunch. Loved this place, great Turkish coffee, yummy healthy salad with salmon, and sandwiches for the kids. Pastries galore!! The service was A+++!

I'll wake up to this alarm any day. Just happened to be passing by and I liked the look of it. No wait on a humid Saturday early evening and I walked away with an amazinnngggg cortado. Walkable from my apt. Yay!
Awesome and very friendly staff. Delicious pastries. Thank you for the best experience. Keep up the good work! Can't wait to be back.
Eastern European "owner" guy is rude. Takes a lot away from the experience of a cafe.  Food is good and staff is polite. Management needs to do a better job training them.

Today I had the best sandwich and coffee to start my day! I got off the subway at 70 st. I have found my coffee house in New York! I recommend this to anybody that wants to have a great sandwich and coffee. The service was first class too. I met the owner and it's a very warm feel! Mike Hartman

I'm excited that Le Reveil opened and at such a convenient location, right at the Q station entrance/exit. It's beautifully decorated and has a few seats available to sit and enjoy your coffee. The coffee is great and includes Intelligentsia cold brew. The real thing I have to rave about is the pastries and baked goods. They are incredible! They are freshly baked. I will even wake up early to get a simple plain croissant.

Absolutely the best-tasting coffee. I live on the first ave and this coffee shop is my favorite place. The chefs are all day ready in the kitchen for your order fresh food and perfect coffee. I think they started to order from seamless

The coffee here is good but its not great.  Kind of on the expensive side, particularly if you order soy, almond or oat milk.  Thankfully I can deal with dairy.  The espresso drinks are pretty good.  Nice space, plenty of seats throughout.  Thought there was nothing wrong with the service.  To me, it was like any other place I've been to in the city.  Like i said, espresso drinks are good - i'd go back for that, but no way would I pay $7 for a caffe mocha or something "fancy" like that.

If your in the LES, come grab a coffee here. The prices were decent, plenty of seating and I loved their simple latte with almond milk. It was sooo silky and creamy! I wonder what brand of almond milk they use cuz I want to buy it! Skip the avocado toast unless you need breakfast. It's yummy but pricey.

Ludlow Coffee Supply is an awesome coffee shop located in the LES! It's pretty small and seemed like it can get busy during peak morning hours. It's also part barber shop, which is kinda cool!  The space is well-lit and the interior design is cute & minimal. We were lucky enough to grab the small table by the window and stayed there to grab a bite to eat and get some work done. The food here is simple but delicious. We ordered the avocado toast w/ alfafa sprouts and the marinara baked eggs. A tad pricey but expected from NYC. The service was super friendly and the coffee, great!
Sitting here is like hanging out in some livingroom! Cozy, pleasant... good coffee and music. Love to chill out here.

I would give five stars for the avocado toast and the interior of this place but the blatant rude baristas (on several separate occasions) casts a shadow on the great things that Ludlow has going for it. This was not just one bad day for one barista - this seems like an epidemic that's spread through every shift. I was given the wrong order three times over our week long stay at Ludlow. When I politely asked for the correct order, I was met with glaring retort, "You didn't say that" or "That's not what you ordered" and then they'd snicker to each other as they remade the coffee. I ORDER THE SAME DRINK EVERY DAY- I KNOW WHAT I SAID. They show complete disinterest in the needs of their customers and honestly, their arrogance is too grand for the mediocre coffee they serve. THE COFFEE JUST ISN'T THAT GREAT. There are so many more shops around NYC to patron, leave this one behind.
Very hip coffee shop in the heart of the LES. Delicious  coffee and good vibes all around.  Personally love the cold brew.
Legit spot for coffee. A bit hipster and stylish. There decent communal stool seating and a handful of smaller 2 person tables.
A bit underwhelming, with subtle signage, but solid pastries. grubstreet.com/2016/03/l?

Coffee and oatmeal before work. It was simple, just nothing memorable.  I didn't even remember I went here until I noticed I checked in. There's a lot of other options in the area so I'd hit up those instead for the future since nothing stood out for me here.
The waiter take the wrong order. We ordered matcha latte, but she make it chai latter.

This gem located in midtown is one of my new favorite spots! I love that it's just a few blocks from Penn station (my station into Manhattan) so it's very convenient in my daily routine!  I had the large Hibiscus iced tea and the Mushroom Grilled Cheese sandwich, the total was $10 and change. The tea wasn't bitter nor was it too sweet, so I didn't need to add any sugar to it (thank goodness) - the Mushroom grilled cheese was INCREDIBLE! I was starving so my expectations on anything edible was at an all time low, but after one bite the sandwich satisfied my taste buds to a whole new level! The bread was toasted/pressed EXACTLY the way I like it and the grease from the cheese was mouth watering! The smell of the mushrooms were overpowering but in regards to taste, blended perfectly well with the bread and cheese!  I love that there's additional seating in the back! It's super cozy and chill! There's plants, a large painting and even a motorcycle!!!  The staff was lovely and I hope they'll get used to seeing me multiple times a week!!

Coffee with coffee cubes gets me every time.  My second trip to this coffee shop for a coffee and never disappoint. I will definitely come back for more coffee and maybe some delicious looking pastries

I start by saying my four stars is purely based on the fact that we only had iced coffee, chai latte, and a slice of lemon bread.  I don't the coffee was very good and the lemon bread was excellent.  Cool little spot to grab some joe and a pastry.

Very warm atmosphere and they made my iced almond latte very fast. I loved it here. they have a full cappuccino and other coffee making machines ready for you. the service was quick and I enjoyed it very much.
Coffee is delicious! Great atmosphere too. I ordered the ham breakfast sandwich and was enough but not fantastic. Would definitely recommend the coffee

Fair coffee, but far from great...kinda' weak...given the ratings, you must need to get crafted beverage, as the brewed earns no 4 stars. Breakfast sandwich was horrible. Yes, horrible.  Find another option; it's a big city.

Edit: Store reached out to me and asked for my recommendation in terms of how they can improve their service. I went there and they offered to provide me a new drink / dessert to help create a better experience! They definitely have potential to grow and become better. I appreciate the attitude to learn and develop the cafe further!  I saw this cafe everywhere on Instagram and decided to try it. I've never felt so strongly about anything, but I have to say this cafe is absolutely HORRIBLE.  The environment is cute, pastel themed, but it wasn't anything super special. We got 2 desserts, the staff supposedly tells me it's panna cotta for one and coconut chocolate with lemon filling. Both are just DISGUSTING. It tasted so gross, hard, and almost like plastic.  I got a dirty bubbles with the mai tea. It was nasty, the bubbles tasted hard and cold, the tea was just bad. Everything is pre-made and literally I asked for less sugar in my tea and they couldn't even do it. The staff has no clue what's going on and I was so sad that I took my friend here. We both love bubble tea and for the first time ever, we threw out everything after 1 bite.  I would never come back again, this cafe needs A LOT of work

Oh Luxamor. This place is the fantasy of a certain demographic (points at my picture) on steroids: everything done up in cotton candy pastels, and pretty drinks and desserts. They have some seating in the front area where you order and also a bigger back room with more tables - I had somehow lucked into an hour when the back room was very empty but within a few minutes it filled up. I will say it's a nice place to study and read, especially since (presuming you buy something) you're free to stay for as long as you like. No one from the front counter really comes to the back except to bring in orders.  My nit is that some of the drinks were pretty expensive especially the specialty drinks that run around $7 each, especially since they don't already come with bubbles. I ordered a grapefruit fusion, expecting to be blown away, but it seemed to be just sugary iced tea with slices of grapefruit cut up inside. If you're not into very sweet drinks, I would also ask if maybe they can cut the pumps of syrup or sugar. Bubbles were okay - a little hard to chew. And I agree with another reviewer that it's A LOT of plastic being thrown away; I think they could invest in some good glassware or mugs for the people who take their drinks to stay.  Didn't try any of the desserts or savory food. The "cheese foam" item on the menu sounded interesting.
#NAME?

Super cute place, the ambiance is great. Has a few tables in the front and a larger area in the back, super cute tables and benches! Perfect place to get some work done. However, their drink isn't so great in my opinion, I heard lots of good things about their maitai tea but it was way to sweet and the bubble was hard... they literally put old boba in my drink, terrible. My boyfriend got the mango punch and it was also way too sweet, it was overpriced for a mango slush ($7). This pace is a bit overpriced, got two drink and a tart for $21.

After several months of a long search for the perfect study/work spot, I have finally found The One. One would think that such a search would be easy in the abundance of cafes and coffee shops in NYC. Let me tell you, dear reader, it was not!  This place has it ALL. Outlets at nearly every table. WiFi. No distracting, obnoxiously loud music playing as if we're in da club, but in fact (tasteful!) k-pop and hip hop music played at a reasonable volume. Interior design that is pleasing to the eye. Comfortable seats. And lastly...a restroom. *kisses fingers like chef*    (Disclaimer for tall people: The tables and seats in the back are low and perfect for shorties like me [I am 5'3], but may be uncomfortable for you. Luckily, there are a few tall tables with tall stools at the front, also with outlets!)  The drinks are tasty. I tried the signature milk tea and maitai milk. They're a bit pricier than what I would normally pay for a milk tea, but I consider it the price of admission to take advantage of the beautiful workspace.

I absolutely loved Luxamor! It was refreshing to see a boba spot with a nice seating area, as it is rare to find one where you can sit, work, or hang out with friends while sipping on delicious boba tea along with trying out their unique desserts. The egg and avocado waffle was probably my favorite, and it would be great to see more savory waffle options on the menu in the future! -@nyconthetable
The boba milk tea here is solid. I think the service is so so but the quality of milk tea is really smooth and not too sweet.
It's a cute shop with very aesthetic interior it would be a nice place to with with friends and enjoy an afternoon with tea and deserts I would definitely come back to this place again

Ok so I stopped by this place to grab a cup of coffee, so disclaimer, this is just based mostly on a quick stop for a Chai Latte.  So I was in NY for business and on the way to my office I decided to stop by and grab a cup of coffee. Normally I am a latte guy but decided to go with a Chai Latte. Unfortunately it did not taste good at all, the spice was overwhelming to the point I could almost not even taste the coffee in it.  The staff were really nice and to be fair I would definitely come back again. They had plenty of seating and really nice decor inside as well.

I go all over the place with this chain. As everyone mentions, the decor and ambiance are adorable and welcoming. It's like having a tea party with your chic french grandma.  The ordering system is a little awkward if you're eating in. You seat yourself, I forget if me and my friend got menus or were given them. You get up to order your coffee or whatever at the barista station in front, and you get up to order your food from the counter in the back. The food is brought to you, the drinks you get yourself. It's a casual whimsical place, and it wasn't busy so this worked but it feels odd.  Maman, any of them, make one of the best chai lattes I've ever had, ditto for their almond croissants. The chai is heavily spiced, very aromatic, sweet without being a Starbucks syrup bomb. The croissants are generously packed with what I always think of as almond paste, covered with almond slivers, and sprinkled with confectioners sugar. I adore it.  This was my first time sitting down for a meal. My friend ordered the Waffle-iron hashbrowns* with smoked salmon, avocado, cucumber, balsamic mixed greens, lemon, dill & a soft boiled egg. The * indicates the dish is gluten free, which is fine because none of those should have gluten, and everything was delicious, except the hash browns. They were a soggy mess, not crispy, not seasoned, and tasted like they tried to use a healthier potato replacement instead of real potatoes. I don't know what was going on. The other ingredients were great, but with no hash it's a smoked salmon salad.  I ordered their namesake breakfast sandwich: bourbon bacon jam, avocado, roasted tomatoes, topped with a fried egg on a cornmeal focaccia bun. It was good, and I think some people would even say really good, but the jam was too sweet for me. There wasn't really something meaty or savory enough to cut through it, even with the bacon incorporated into it. The avocado, the runny egg, it was just a lot of ooey-gooey textures and sweetness.  I think I like Maman more for their pastries and ambiance than their most substantial fare.

I was walking to Eataly and passed my a sign that said "Lavender Honey Latte". Just by reading this sign I turned around to walk into Maman just to try it. I guess those chalkboard signs really work, huh?  The place itself is so beautiful! If I worked or went to school in the area this would be a great place to sit down with a computer or even to relax or catch up with a friend. There's a lot of seating room and also the wallpaper is so cute!  They have a bunch of regular espresso drinks you would find at a coffee shop with a few fun flavors. The line to order is right by the door which can get really cramped with people walking in and out. There were also people just hovering over that section so it was a little annoying to order because you weren't sure if the hoverers were ordering or not.  When I ordered my drink I go around the corner of their table to wait for my drink. It came out so beautiful with a little heart and cute little lavenders as decor. The lavender looks esthetically pleasing but drinking I was a hassle because it felt like you kept getting attacked by little petals. I liked my drink but I always compare my lavender lattes to the one from Laughing Man which was the best I've ever had but it's also in Tribeca and I don't like traveling that downtown. I'd probably order their regular coffee/espresso drinks to get a better feel of their drinks though next time.

Super cute coffee shop. They had cookies to sample up front. Damn girl, they were bomb. They're bowls are filling but that's mostly bc they had a lot of carb fillers. I wish they had a little more proteins in their nourish bowls . Flavors are there. Can't complain about that. As for the lavender croissant... the layer of sugar was super sweet. I couldn't eat most of it but the croissant itself was soft and flaky. Cold brew was bomb. I was trying to do some work here but it's a bumpin' place so it was a Little bit loud. Otherwise, plenty of seats and is super cute

Maman's cookies didn't really need Oprah's endorsement; everyone was already aware of their greatness before they earned a spot on her "favorite things" list. If anything, her praise just made their baked goods even fresher, since the increase in demand ultimately led to a larger quantity of cookies leaving their ovens. Of course, the downside to this is that the bakery often sells out well before closing time.  It makes sense, though. The nutty chocolate chip cookie is delicious. In my opinion, its flavor can be attributed to two characteristics: a crispy exterior (particularly the edges) and the inclusion of macadamia nuts. The macadamias are soft and creamy, forming a contrast with the crunchy outside layer. Almonds and walnuts can also be found among the composition, but are rather forgettable when the macadamias are taken into account.  As a whole, the cookie is buttery and slightly salty, due to the combination of the nuts and a little added sea salt. It tastes even better warmed up, when the chocolate chips are partially melted - you know, like in one of those slow-motion cookie breaking Instagram posts.  Stop by any of Maman's six New York locations early in the day and grab yourself a nutty chocolate chip cookie. It might just make your own personal list of favorite things!

This place is the best. Their almond croissants are the best I've had and I lived in Paris for years. I've had the sandwiches and the brunch specials. Everything is delicious. The decor and ambience is impeccable. Thank God someone decided to open this place. We're all lucky to have it.

Maman is a very cute cafe. I went here for brunch on a Saturday morning. Although it seemed packed, we were able to get a seat without much waiting (there were two of us). I had the tahini cardamom waffles and they were okay, but it wasn't as good as what I had expected. I liked how they were creative with the ingredients of the waffle, but IMO Jackson's Eatery in LIC did a much better job.  The pound cake slices looked very good so I bought it on another day, but that was another disappointment. The presentation is awesome, but I really wish they could vamp up the food quality by a lot.

My new favorite neighborhood coffeehouse of hot chocolate fame in the past. I had tried to go to the soho location on New Years Day for that lavender hot chocolate (closed) but now i suppose i can come here! they have the standard pastries and cafe as well as some bites.  The space used to be a vegan restaurant which most definitely failed in this particular neck of the woods. I have more confidence in this being successful here.  I came back and had an amazing avocado tartine (basically avocado toast) with an egg and the lavender hot chocolate. The drinks are up front but the food is in the back so there is a bit of a disconnect when you sit in. I got a lounge-y area by the back which was nice and cozy. It's very warm in here.  And yes timeout. This lavender hot chocolate is great!

We stopped in on a whim for a breakfast brunch. First off, it's adorable. Can't get over the adorable French simplistic vibe. You just want to sit there and soak it up. They had gluten free options too - a gluten free granola in their parfait, a gluten free hash brown waffle, and a few salads that can be made gluten free. Only bummer is they didn't have a GF bread option for all their yummy sandwiches. Oh and also had some vegan and vegetarian options. Had an oat milk pumpkin spice latte that kicked Starbucks out of the water! Staff was sweet and attentive. Definitely will be back.

If I were rating on ambiance alone, I would be giving MarieBelle 5 stars. It's a chocolate shop and tea house that makes you want to squeal in girly delight. Pastels, gold gilding, generous free chocolate samples, adorable dainty china.  Me and a friend were participating in this years hot chocolate festival. For a week or two, different businesses in the city offer a specially promoted hot chocolate, and you can go around and try them out. That's what brought us here, but their hot chocolate menu was so extensive that we  just ordered whatever sounded good. The small cups are like something a large doll might drink out of - seemingly minuscule, while the large is served in a normal decorative tea cup.  We tried a classic hot chocolate with nutmeg and cinnamon, a cardamom spiced number, and an chile spiced chocolate. Unfortunately we weren't able to finish any of them. Each one was overwhelmingly rich. When we stirred them, chocolate "goop" clung to our spoons, and would stick to the edged of the cups. It tasted and felt like they just served straight up melted chocolate without much to flavor it and it clung to the inside of our mouths, literally hard to swallow. I think sticking to the smaller tea cups will be fine for most, sipping and even sharing with a partner. Really, it was that rich.  Service was beyond sweet and attentive, our server seemed really happy to work there and to take care of us, all smiles!  It's a nice place to come for the experience, and if I find that happening I would just try different menu items.

Honestly, I'm torn about this place. I felt partway in a preserved French patisserie and partway in a haunted girl's dream house. There is a small cafe tucked away behind the storefront which lacked the open, dreamy ambiance you would want with French sweets.  Came in on a chilly Autumn day looking for a warming cup of hot chocolate. I got literally...in the form of a $6 mini Dixie-cup sized shooter of basically a semi-solid chocolate bar. It was tasty but not exactly sipping chocolate. Not exactly what I expected and was not wholly satisfied with that expensive "cup" of chocolate to fulfill my craving.
High tea set is overrated and overpriced.  The service isn't good as well. The place itself is beautiful, but I will just have their a la cart dessert next time.

Unimpressed by the cafe- pricey uninspired food. Minimal service. Quaint french inspired  little chocolate shop in the front with tiny cozy chic bistro tea room in the back. Ordered a cold chocolate drink and Croque Monsieur. Drink was like a thick smoothie. A meal on its own but I didn't think the chocolate was unique or amazing. A bit chalky. Croque was dry as a bone. Very little b̩chamel which is the whole point. nothing exciting about  bread ham and cheese used either Perhaps might come back and sample chocolate or ice cream available also in front but save your hard earned $ and skip the cafe.

This is a fun place with friends. Always best to go before 4 PM, before it may get busy. The staff person took really good care of us and there was so much patience when we were deciding on chocolates and teas. It is good to know there is a mutual love for chocolate in tea, with tea, and separate. Both can be mutually inclusive and exclusive. I had a great time here!

Just want to post that we had the best customer service experience at Mariebelle cafe today. A nice male waiter waited on us. My young daughter ordered hot chocolate and he literally made several samples with different thicknesses and different levels of sweetness until we found the perfect one. He never rushed us. He was SO patient. The cafe was full and he was the only one working. He did an excellent job executing all the orders and paying personal attention to every table.  I hope MariBelle understands how lucky they are to have this man working there. MariBelle's chocolate is outstanding but it's all about the customer service!

Great desserts, very nice service. We were offered spicy chocolate ice drink samplers and lots of water. Opera cake with rose gelato was very rich but not too sweet. Very nice atmosphere with great classical music, cacao bar, fancy chandeliers :)

I've been going to Marie Belle for over a decade - it's the best chocolate shop in the city. My absolute favorite there are the Cocoa Dusted Dark Chocolate truffles - they're incredible. Today, I had a very special surprise when I was picking up some chocolate - Maribel Lieberman (Marie Belle) was there! She's terrific, just like her chocolates!
Way too rich for my liking, but a beautiful shop with cafe and seating. The hot chocolate tasted like dark chocolate to me. Helpful staff. Totally instagram-able!

A cute boutique store. Includes a variety of homemade chocolates. In different shapes and flavors and all in the display. There is also a free tasting of few. Prices are average. In addition, there is a cafe - restaurant inside with home products

Came here today for the first time, loved the decor, displays of chocolates and the back room where you can sit and eat a light lunch or dessert and hot chocolates.  I ordered regular coffee and a lemon meringue pastry and the waiter brought me my coffee that was made with espresso and explained that they don't make regular coffee there and here comes the best part, he heated my tart and brought over to me expecting me to eat it hot.  I asked him, why would you heat my dessert, he explained, all customer want their dessert warm and because they are way too cold we have to heat them.  I asked,  do you heat the moose desserts as well, he stated YES.  We heat all deserts.  I was in shock and asked to take it back and bring me my check.  I also forgot to mention, when he took the dessert back, he was shouting in the back with another co-worker in spanish assuming I didn't understand what he was saying about me.  Bad customer service, really turned me off, left and went straight to Laduree for better service, taste and no heating for any desserts.  Last I checked, you eat dessert cold unless you ask to warm it up!  Management, if I am wrong and there is a reason to why you warm all your desserts, please reply back with a good reason, otherwise, retrain your employees and no badmouthing the customer where they can hear you!
So whimsical and the Aztec hot chocolate was so decadent without being too rich. The store has a great selection of all things chocolate.

On the way to Ground Zero we spotted this chocolate shop and I wanted to stop!  Cute place, but pricey!! Very beautifully laid out and pretty.  We especially enjoyed the little cafe in the back part of the store. The gentleman back there was very friendly and customer service oriented. We liked him immediately! We shared an Aztec hot cocoa and a dessert. Both were quite yummy!! Love the ambiance of this place.  Nice place to get a little treat for someone or get a little gift for someone.
Great place to enjoy chocolates & gelato.  Will gladly go back again!   Next time I might bring a friend.
What a beautiful store! Poopface chocolate is amazing; it's a work of art. They also offer a great variety of dairy free options. I love this place!

Once upon a time.. a boy and girl who were craving hot chocolate. They decided to go to Mariebelle after a friend's recommendation. Unfortunately they walked into the caf̩ 10 minutes before they were about to close the shop on a rainy/snowy cold evening, plus it was a very slow day for the employees there. Despite all that, John the waiter was very welcoming, humble and very knowledgeable about his Chocolates (Very professional). The girl tried Banana Hot chocolate and the boy dark bitter chocolate and they were very yippy happy!!! Great atmosphere, delicious chocolates, d̩cor and etc.  You walk in and you walk right into the heart of Paris! A must try. Banana Chocolate is highly recommended. The boy and girl held hands and kept walking into nowhere in Manhattan mist.  -Accounting Major

This beautiful little shop has so much to choose from it can be a little overwhelming, but Inbar, the wonderful sales rep kindly walked my friend and I through nearly the entire selection. We wanted to buy a few gifts and she asked us all the right questions to help narrow down the options.  Her suggestions were extremely helpful and appreciated.

This is my new favorite shop for deserts. The generous offerings of samples were a dream. The Bitter Dark Hot Chocolate, White Hot Chocolate and Pistachio cookie were unforgettable. Our server was very pleasant and as sweet as their menu.
Cute chocolate shop, I like the graphics it has been designed and printed. A perfect birthday present.
My most favorite place to visit in NYC! Cacao bar is decorated like Marie Antoinette's Versailles. Everything is delicious! I don't mind paying high dollor for their products:)

I had their dark chocolate mocha drink,  Le Moelleux au Chocolate and their Signature Dessert $11...chocolate heaven! the waitress warned me, do NOT get a large drink the reason so it is SOO rich you won't want more than a single.  I got a medium and I couldn't even finish it.  Great for a date or a girlfriend! Such a cutesy place!  Don't mind the weird guy who works in the front at the express station for the chocolate bar--he just stares at the wall or in space for a LONGGGG time where it's freaky =X  i notice they don't have a link to their cacao bar but here it is: mariebelle.com/s.nl/it.I?

If you want to feel like you were transported to some plush European chocolate shop for the day, stop by.  The decor is absolutely incredible and makes you feel as if you're about to have tea with the Queen.  There is chocolate everywhere, so how can you not like a place like this?  I tried their hot chocolate (which was basically like drinking melted chocolate) and had some of their chocolate bark.  Adorable place to go with a friend to catch up and get an awesome dessert!

My review is focused on the Cafe in the rear, but I'll start by saying the shop is quite cute and methinks it an excellent place to pick up gifts for the chocolate lover (the packaging is impressive and will surely be loved by the recipient):  -  Surprising menu with lots of savory items (including savory crepes and sandwiches) - Lots of teas, premium coffees and such - Amazing (well at least the description on the menu) specialty desserts - I wouldn't know how they tasted because they're only available Wed through Sunday (we were there Monday, dammit!) - Cute, a bit cramped, very Paris feeling - Several kinds of hot chocolate to choose from in three sizes....this stuff isn't playing around...a small will fill you up for a day and it's something you really have to eat with a spoon - Chocolate chip cookie -- ummm, yes please - Sweet crepes -- delish

What an amazing chocolate tasting experience!  Had the pleasure of drinking a handmade hot chocolate American style with milk!  Not only is the hot chocolate outstanding, the tasting room makes you feel like you are transformed back in time in a French cafe.  The antique cases and decor are stunning.  The variety and the knowledge you acquire while visiting this shop is a great experience!

We had the white hot chocolate and maya dark one, with a decadence cake. It was all so chocolaty, seriously, the cake was just like a dense block of delicious chocolate. It's the kind of dessert that would make your heart beat fast. At the end of the treat I felt like my stomach and my heart couldn't take any more chocolate!
The best hot chocolate in town, however the food is not good. Just come in for the chocolate and leave the food for another place around.

I have been coming to this place for over six years - it is a wonderful gem that is an homage to wonders of chocolate.  There have been some changes over the years - there is a take out spot in the front, a shop in the middle and the cafe remains tucked in the back.  I miss the old style of the cafe with old movies projected on to the wall but the renovations are welcome and the spot remains warm and luxuriantly welcoming.  This place is a must for real chocolate lovers.

Mariebelle isn't one of the cheapest chocolate places around town, but it's one of my faves. Everything here is good - I've loved every piece I've ever bought from here and the hot chocolate is delicious as well. I usually come here to pick up a gift or a treat for myself, but they also have a small cafe if you want to hang out for a bit and enjoy some of their amazing treats!  The space is small and it's easy to miss, it's a bit of a "hidden" gem in the city.

I love the shop.  I been there because the shop select me... Let me explain. I make a research about chocolates in NYC to visit on my vacations there and I do not select Maribelle to visit, but I just be walking on the street and saw the store then I enter and OMG I was on heaven.  The staff was so nice and helpful, offer me samples and introduce me to new flavors.  Never liked before spicy or fruit chocolates, but their passionfruit chocolate was soooo good. For me be there was a life changing experience that hope to repeat next summer.

The flavored chocolates were kind of cool in the beginning, but I'm a fan of Plain Old Good Dark Chocolate. Luckily, you can get this in two forms.  1) hot chocolate mixes - I prefer to buy the refill packages and make them at home. If you can drink a mug of this stuff at full strength, you're not from this planet. Use espresso cups instead. You can tell when the hot chocolate is ready because the color will suddenly deepen and the texture will noticeably thicken.  2) Single origin bars. Sinful in the mouth. I've uploaded a photo.

Stopped by this place today in the middle of the snowstorm and it was just what I needed.  It was warm, smelled delicious, and the hot chocolate was exactly what I was craving in this weather.  I had the Dark - Spicy Hot Chocolate (Large) and even though the cup doesn't look big, the chocolate is very rich and heavy and I couldn't even finish it all.  Absolutely will be returning here.

Mariebelle's hot chocolate is RIDICULOUS.  I had no idea that you could have a truly delicious cup of hot chocolate.  I absolutely love Swiss chocolate (Minor, Lindt, Callier), and was in for a treat.  I tried the Dark Mocha and the Milk Chocolate/Hazelnut, and both were amazing.  One sip of the Mocha and my mouth was filled with strong dark chocolate flavor with hints of mocha.  The Chocolate Hazelnut was like liquid Nutella- chocolatey, warm and comforting.  The wonderful texture, flavor, and temperature made this the perfect cup of hot chocolate.  Thank you Mariebelle, you have forever ruined me from drinking 'regular' hot chocolate.

Found this little gem right next door from a spa. The decor is lovely. I had the chicken avacado sandwich, it was simply delicious!  So fresh, so yummy! Service was very friendly and quick. I look forward to my next visit.

Had a Groupon which was expired. I was told by the sales people at the store that I had to call their marketing/event manager to get the ok to use it at the base rate. I left this person multiple messages over several months. Not a single message was returned. I then spoke to Groupon who spoke to the store and I was told by Groupon that I would get a call from the store within a few business days giving me the ok to use the Groupon. Weeks have gone by and the store has still not outreached to me. I hope the owner/manager is reading this. To you, what an awful way to treat a potential customer. The likelihood of me spending a lot more in your store then the Groupon was high. You not only lost this business, but your lost any potential return business from me and any chance of me recommending your business to friends.

Supremely delicious chocolate shop in Soho. I stop in probably more often than I should and treat myself to a beautifully styled, two-piece box of artful chocolates or a tiny box of succulent loose tea.  The shop itself feels like something straight out of Amelie; tiffany blue trim, old timey-glass cases filled with delicate chocolates and other tasty confections.  There's also an adorable tea shop in the back that serves the most delicious hot chocolate and light crepes.  Definitely a place to take your sister or mom whose visiting from out of town for a ladylike cuppa and a sweet treat at a reasonable price!

i got a small spicy hot chocolate and a couple pieces of chocolate covered orange peels.  When i say 'small' - i mean ...a little more than a double-shot glass's worth...so yeah, v. small.  but the hot chocolate here is so so RICH and decadent, that 'small' is all you really need.  that being said, the total was $10.00 - and that's a lot for such a small amount of stuff.  for a once in a while treat, def worth it - very decadent hot cocoa, and nice interior to sit in if the mood strikes.

This Spring rainy weather has me craving warm hot chocolate, so I finally opened up my 2 tins from Marie Belle that I received for Xmas 08. I had to take a scissor to cut the paper seal and open up the metal lid. There was a weird web thing attached to the lid... threw that out and opened up the next tin... same thing... but this time there were DEAD INSECTS in the tin... threw it out ...thought the tins were pretty and thought I'd reuse them... then had 2nd thoughts and recycled them! I'll forever have the image of dead insects in my Marie Belle hot chocolate. My apartment is clean too, no insects and plus the tins were stored in a closed glass cabinet. Did this happen to anyone else? I have teas from Marie Belle and now I'm paranoid that maybe I should throw those out? Do insects like tea? ILLLLLLLLLLLLLLL!!!!!!!!!!!!!DISGUSTING!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

$9 for hot chocolate is a bit much, but...  This store looks beautiful. I swear I thought I was in a fragrance, beauty soap, and jewelry store if I don't look closely and see that they are really chocolates. The chocolates are so beautifully design, it almost makes you feel terrible for eating it.  My gf recommended the hot chocolate cuz she had their hot chocolate when MarieBelle had a booth in Bryant Park. It was good, not as strong as Jacque Torres, but I guess I prefer the hot chocolates from wich'craft instead. It was also kinda hard to walk and drink a hot chocolate (we were going to our last chocolate stop) as you need to sip it not pour it in your mouth and burn your tongue (which I did a bit). Overall, $9 is bit much for a hot chocolate, but they have a really decently price brunch menu that I want to come back and try.

Fancy, beautiful, expensive chocolates for the fancy, beautiful and expensive at heart. Seriously, everything is so beautiful in this store... not to mention delicious. There's also an adorable little cafe in the back with various sweet and savory goods and different varieties of hot chocolate.

We came here for afternoon tea in the Cacao Bar/Tea Salon. This is a perfect resting spot after a long day of shopping in Soho. The double shot of mochachino was the perfect boost. The apple tart was delish! It was made with fresh green apple slices. I'm giving four stars for the cozy and snug setting. The cafe is setup with antique tables and decorated with colorful wall paper and chandelier. But I'm taking a star away for the service, which seemed disorganized and overwhelmingly understaffed to serve a full house. But overall I enjoyed my experience here.

my go-to place for the best hot chocolate ever.  Jacques Torre, Max Brenner etc etc don't even come close. it's like drinking a high quality melted dark chocolate bar. Yes, it is expensive, so get a tin and make your own at home.

Beautiful chocolates and other tasty products such as tea and pin-up girl chocolate bars.  I love this cozy chocolate and tea cafe but steep prices hence 4 stars.  2 pieces of chocolate in a their cute "shopping bag" mini-box cost $10 a pop.
This location is closed. New location at Broome and Wooster. Learned this hard way and was way late to meet my friend's parents :(  Otherwise, a fantastic chocoheaven with surprisingly good food.

You would never guess what's going on in the back on this little shop. You might not even stop by. But my god you would miss smthg !!!  When you enter in the shop you are first surrounded by boxes of chocolates.  They look pretty old fashioned... nothing special. I have been able to taste a praline chocolate that was delicious but I went there for smthg else:  So if you continue deeper in the shop you'll see this cute room, the cocoa bar, with nice seats where you can have a hot chocolate, a tea, some sweets ...  Poeple were very nice and I was able to taste one the their basic hot chocolate which was AMAZING!!! To tell you the truth it goes down so slowly in your throat, it is so intense in chocolate that the tasting size portion would be enough. But you haven't gone all the way there to stop at this stage. So I ask for a small (believe me its enough for 2 people) a spicy aztek black chocolate. It is divine but very spicy !!  If I ever go back, (which I will certainly do someday soon) I would get a small milk aztec hot chocolate.  Go and enjoyyyyyyyyy
A really special place for a delicious treat but the atmosphere is so stiff, which takes a lot away from the experience. Otherwise the $4.50 kick-ass drinking chocolate would be well worth it.

We started here and progressed to 5 other hot chocolate spots. To see the map visit fullfrontalfridge.wordpr?. Our trek was Marie Belle, Vosges, Starbucks, Ceci Cela, Devalicious, Cocoa Bar. Marie Belle got the most coco cups for decor and atmosphere. The product is very much like a dessert and just terrific on flavor, aroma, texture, total chocolate experience. Vosges was very modern, with an interesting white hot chocolate drink. The sit down is not as cozy at MB but very nice. Starbucks, you can skip. Ceci Cela has a nice smooth hot chocolate, it is uncomplicated and has a nice flavor. Devalicious was closed and Cocoa Bar was fun. They have a drink called funky monkey was has a banana flavor. But truly it was the spicy hot chocolate that we liked the most through out the walk. It was a great New York activity to do with the children, we made them walk which was good as we were consuming lots of sugar etc. Enjoy.

Ok so I would normally give 5 stars because the drinks here are great  but they lose 1 star for no bathroom and 1 star for finding any way to charge you extra.  I've been here 5 times and normally the weekend baristas are very friendly. Today though, everyone had an attitude. My friend asked which milks they offer - normally there is a list at the register but it wasn't there so the cashier had to list them but he acted like it was an inconvenience. We weren't told that certain milks are extra and that is not written anywhere....but I knew.  My friend asked for half macadamia milk and half oat. We were charged for both milks - $.70 and $.50 each. We then asked why and they guy said "that's just the way it rings up". Ridiculous! My friend then asked for a cup of milk since she paid for it, so finally the guy acquiesced.  Down from 4 to 3 stars because there is no bathroom and no alternative. The guy told us we can use the deli next door - so after spending $27 for 3 drinks we tried the deli and they denied us because we hadn't purchased anything.

Walking the High Line last weekend, we scouted out this Matcha bar and was excited for a speciality drink!  I ordered the Reishi Matcha Coconut Latte with macadamia milk and the hubs a Spiced Matcha Chai with almond milk.  They were both just meh. Mine was better than the chai but we were kinda disappointed.  There's a cafe in Atlanta that makes the best Coconut Matcha Latte and I was hoping this place would at least be on that level but perhaps it was an off day.  My hubs is a chai fan but it wasn't his favorite.  Next visit we'll try another spot.

This location is tucked away in a neighborhood near Chelsea Market. Originally we ran out of time for MatchaBar on our itinerary, but on our way to Chelsea Market that day we stumbled upon this location and decided to get a hot morning drink :D  I got with a hot matcha latte, which I could tell was authentic with the bitter taste, but this drink was slightly expensive. It's $4.50 on the menu, so after tax it's well over $5 for a cup.  They also offer other kinds of matcha drinks with different flavors fused into them, so if you're looking to spice up your normal matcha order then you have this opportunity.  Nothing much stood out to me particularly. Still glad I tried this, though!
The environment is okay. It's a nice place to enjoy some quiet time and read a book. The taste of matcha is too bitter.
There's something to be said for a coffee shop that not only lets owners bring their puppies in, but knows them by name. Great matcha also. 10/10 highly recommend.

I excitedly visited here about a month ago, hoping to enjoy their specialty matcha drinks. I was greatly underwhelmed. Honestly, I can get a tastier, cheaper matcha latte from Starbucks at a fraction of the cost of a latte here. The peaches and cream latte was unusual and a nice concept, but would've been much better if it wasn't so watered down. Save yourself some time and get a green tea latte from Starbucks.

Found this place driving to get a matcha latte at Beard PaPa's.  The green tea latte from most cafes are made with syrup and is too sweet.   The one at Beard papa has more matcha taste and not syrupy sweet.  So when I saw the awning of Matchabar, I immediately checked on Yelp and decided to get my latte here.  What a serendipitous discovery!  Now, I'm hooked.  Wonderful, smooth matcha flavor and no syrup, so you add sugar to adjust for sweetness.   It has a clean finish and no lingering aftertaste.  I also loved the small, quiet interior.  I only wish the latte was a bit hotter.

I visited with my best friend and my sister. We each tried a different latte and I ended up liking all three of them a lot! They were really distinct, but still had that recognizable matcha flavor and appearance. We stayed there for hours coloring in one of their books. It was so relaxing and the seating was just so cute! The place was small, but in a cozy way. It didn't feel cramped at all. Make sure you sweeten your drink if you're a fan of sugary drinks -- they're completely unsweetened, which is better because it fully accommodates people with different tastes. I highly recommend it!
Biscotti is so yummy! I also got the Matchiatta with honey. I like it, but I definitely want to try a few other drinks too. Great service.

My coconut chai matcha latte tasted like water with a tiny bit of coconut milk in it. I couldn't taste any matcha or chai at all. There was also no frothiness like a usual drink with foamed milk even though the latte was made with whole milk (can't imagine how flat the non-dairy milks are). Sure, it wasn't overly sweetened like most matcha latte's, but that's pretty easy when there's no flavor at all. Adding insult to injury: I waited about 10 minutes for my drink and it cost $5.50. Skip this place and get a matcha drink almost anywhere else. 1 star is for the nice wallpaper.
Soon to become a neighborhood staple. The matcha served is perfect. Not too sweet or too earthy. $5 for matcha latte with almond milk! Will definitely be back.

My favorite matchabar drink : iced jasmine matcha. Want it everyday. The frothy matcha layer on top and brewed jasmine tea is such a compliment together. Tastes great!  Not sure abt their other drinks though...

I love this place!!!!! I'm so excited they opened another location near The New School so I can drop by between classes. I looooove the Earl Grey Latte and the sparkling cucumber drink. They play good music and the vibe is really welcoming. Also try the matcha coconut cacao bar it's so good....

I came on a Friday afternoon and nearly everything was gone! I decided to get the vegan donut. I'm pretty sure it's $2 each but the guy was kind enough to give me 2. But they turned out to be extremely dry, crumbly and old tasting.  It was way too sweet for me I couldn't finish one. I did see a vegan almond butter cookie that also looked good.  Don't get the vegan donut! I will try other items next time.

Very good latte.  The barista was a little slow, but really friendly.  I also had the chocolate chip cookie, which someone recommended to me.  It's really big, but not so great.  Not really worth the calories, sorry!  But I'd come back for the coffee!

I heard so much about this place from my coworkers so I finally checked it out. Its a cute little coffee/baked goods shop with no seating. Their baked and refrigerated goods looked fresh but I only ordered a small coffee. While some of my coworkers like the coffee here, I did not like it at all. It was bland and it did not taste like it was freshly brewed. The Starbucks freshly brewed coffee tastes stronger and has more flavor than the one served here (and that says a lot).

Great cafe with good quality foods and coffees. Every item is very affordable and I believe every item is same price of $2. The variety is fantastic with something for every day of the work week, and the staff is great as well.
EVERYTHING IS JUST $2!! Great coffee for just $2. Amazing breakfast and lunch selection for just $2. Only thing that's free is the fabulous customer service!
This place is quick and everything is $2. The egg sandwich is good and they even have a smoked salmon bagel.

I swooped in quickly to pick up breakfast for some friends on the Wednesday before Thanksgiving. I was drawn to the big "everything is $2! [for now]" sign outside the cafe. I'm not sure how often they do this type of flash sale, but the marketing works!  I was not particularly wild about the drip coffee, but the pumpkin loaf was standard and solid. I wish the babka had had a little more flavor.  Lots of sweet and savory snack options.

I'm not entirely sure I get Matto. I don't mean I don't understand what they do. They're a wannabe Starbucks, attempting to be a hipster kind of New York cool coffee shop (like you might see on "Friends"), with so-so overpriced cakes and muffins (and sandwiches?!?!), and a less than chill ambience.  We were meeting someone looking to work on a project with us. We got there a bit early. 6 pm on a Wednesday. It was busy, but they had one person behind the counter. He seemed frazzled. Tables were dirty. Place was dirty. It felt very chaotic, unnecessarily.  But there was a table in the back. But it felt less than serene or comfortable. It felt like someone thought let's open a coffee place in Chelsea, but not make it a happy or enjoyable place. It wasn't conducive to a casual cup of coffee with my husband, much less a friend that we were meeting in person for the first time.  I don't see going back.  I'd love an option to Starbucks. But this just isn't it.

cute little spot. kinda dirty though and small. grab a seat as soon as you find one. it's a nice little cafe though. the staff isn't the kindest. but everything is $2! and the food and coffee is delicious.

While their $2 promo is tempting, many of their drinks are waterdowned to accommodate the deal. Also just because you were the first person at the counter doesn't mean you'll be the first to be helped instead they will glance over you and assist someone else. Now that's service I was dying to recieve after work! I will try their other location but the workers here aren't too attentive . Unless of course you're a certain value .

I order a veggie burger and an ice tea , less than $5 total. The organic veggie burger is very tasty as the girl grill it also.  It is a neat cafe with lots of Jewish bakery and related items like beet salad etc

Espresso Matto is a good spot to hang out for those long talks with a friend or two. For me, Espresso Matto is simply an easy place to wind down with my friend after our saturday spin classes. There's nothing great about this place aside from the fact that all their items are $2. Their pastries are average, but I must admit I am a fan of their spinach burekas and feta cheese sandwiches - and it's a steal at $2 a piece.  The coffee though? Luckily I am an iced coffee kinda girl as long as I don't have to brave the cold outdoors. Lattes and cold brews are my jam and espresso matto doesn't do a bad job when it comes to their iced drinks. Their hot drinks though? They consistently burn the coffee, burn the milk, and that drink WILL burn your tongue. My weird girlfriend knows this and still orders the hot drinks, and I've witnessed her scorch her tongue before way more than once. I also stupidly scorched mine last week when I decided to try her cappucino. These barristas are clearly not experienced.

I was walking to meet a friend after work but needed a place to stop and do some writing just before - stumbled upon Espresso Matto, where I saw the sign for $2 everything. Done. It's a clean and aesthetically pleasant cafe with a decent amount of seating, ok music, chargers near every table, and cold brew. If I had to spend a lot of time in Chelsea, I'd study or write here for sure.

What is wrong with me? I stupidly had a Dunkin Donuts $4 coffee in the morning and another coffee with brunch. Then, walking around, my friend and I stumbled upon Espresso Matto and it's offer of everything for $2. They wouldn't sell me a 5 pound bag of coffee beans for $2, so it's really false advertising. But my friend got a decent double cappuccino for $2, so everything else is really cheap. I would totally come back here and get a flavored latte. $2? Seriously? How?!

If you're looking for a quiet place to work/study then look no further. This location has sweet treats and yummy hot beverages. Staff is very friendly and accommodating. I devoured a chocolate chip the size of my face! Lol

I swooped in quickly to pick up breakfast for some friends on the Wednesday before Thanksgiving. I was drawn to the big "everything is $2! [for now]" sign outside the cafe. I'm not sure how often they do this type of flash sale, but the marketing works!  I was not particularly wild about the drip coffee, but the pumpkin loaf was standard and solid. I wish the babka had had a little more flavor.  Lots of sweet and savory snack options.

They're a wannabe Starbucks, attempting to be a hipster kind of New York cool coffee shop (like you might see on "Friends"), with so-so overpriced cakes and muffins (and sandwiches?!?!), and a less than chill ambience. Tables were dirty. Place was dirty. It felt very chaotic, unnecessarily.  But there was a table in the back. But it felt less than serene or comfortable. It felt like someone thought let's open a coffee place in Chelsea, but not make it a happy or enjoyable place. It wasn't conducive to a casual cup of coffee with my husband, much less a friend that we were meeting in person for the first time.  I don't see going back.  I'd love an option to Starbucks. But this just isn't it.

cute little spot. kinda dirty though and small. grab a seat as soon as you find one. it's a nice little cafe though. the staff isn't the kindest. but everything is $2! and the food and coffee is delicious.

While their $2 promo is tempting, many of their drinks are waterdowned to accommodate the deal. Also just because you were the first person at the counter doesn't mean you'll be the first to be helped instead they will glance over you and assist someone else. Now that's service I was dying to recieve after work! I will try their other location but the workers here aren't too attentive . Unless of course you're a certain value .

I order a veggie burger and an ice tea , less than $5 total. The organic veggie burger is very tasty as the girl grill it also.  It is a neat cafe with lots of Jewish bakery and related items like beet salad etc

Their hot drinks though? They consistently burn the coffee, burn the milk, and that drink WILL burn your tongue. It's a clean and aesthetically pleasant cafe with a decent amount of seating, ok music, chargers near every table, and cold brew. If I had to spend a lot of time in Chelsea, I'd study or write here for sure.

Then, walking around, my friend and I stumbled upon Espresso Matto and it's offer of everything for $2. They wouldn't sell me a 5 pound bag of coffee beans for $2, so it's really false advertising. But my friend got a decent double cappuccino for $2, so everything else is really cheap. I would totally come back here and get a flavored latte. $2? Seriously? How?!

If you're looking for a quiet place to work/study then look no further. This location has sweet treats and yummy hot beverages. Staff is very friendly and accommodating. I devoured a chocolate chip the size of my face! Lol

I was getting done with business nearby, and I was in need of coffee and a snack. I found this place using my Yelp app, so I made my way here. I walked in to this moderately sized coffee shop. It was fairly busy, but the line was not long. I ordered an inced latte, and went with a banana tahini toast. The latte was as expected, although the caffeine content was not as great as I'd like it to be. The toast was delicious, although a bit too sweet for my tastes. The staff here was friendly, as were the other patrons. The place had fans in side the place, as well as an A/C unit. I'm assuming their central A/C was not working, or they were in the middle of installing a new unit. They had one restroom, which was clean, just like the rest of the place. Next time, I'll stick with a black coffee, as it is less likely to be short on the caffeine content. And I'm forgoing any such toast henceforth.

It does the job, but that's about it. I've been here several times now since I work nearby. Overall, love their iced coffee, matcha tea and earl gray tea, but their iced chai is just okay. I've been here twice for a coffee chat. The space is very small and intimate. The first time I had a meeting here, it was perfect. The second time was very.....off-putting. Whoever was doing the dishes that day wanted to make it very clear he was doing the dishes. There was a lot of banging and crashing, I'm surprised nothing broke. My friend and I ended up having to talk over the noise to hear each other. It was pretty ridiculous. I don't think I'll come back for sit-down visits, maybe just a quick coffee take out here and there.

My feelings of this place are mixed. Things I love: the matcha latte (so much yum), atmosphere, and decor. Things I don't love: the employees seem rather judgmental no matter how friendly I was and a breakfast I had with egg, tomato, ciabatta made my stomach feel instantly queasy.

New spot that's fairly popular with the morning crowd. Your regular coffee shop doling out specialty coffee and some baked goods in an inviting atmosphere.  First time I came here I realized they don't sell large coffees (needed a bigger fix that day). This time I was okay with settling for a regular drip and a bran muffin ($6.50 total). The muffin is fantastic - flaky interior and just the right amount of raisins to counter the hearty bran. As for the coffee, was pretty disappointed. Got a big sour taste from the drink that wasn't helped by the milk or sugar at all. If it wasn't for the fact I needed something to wash down the muffin, I probably wouldn't have finished most of it.  Service here is friendly and they keep the busy line moving. Maybe just a bad day, so will re-rate when coming back.

Brunch cafes live and die by their eggs. If you keep serving "poached eggs" as hardboiled...I worry about your future...especially when your team doesn't care when feedback is given. Apart from that, the quality and texture of the coffee was great.

This coffee shop just opened up around the corner from my apartment and it is pretty amazing. First, and most importantly, the coffee is perfect and on point every time. They clearly pride themselves on making the perfect latte / capp / cold breh / matcha (whatever your drink is) and it shows. I have only tried a couple of things from their food menu and both times, they have been great. Would definitely recommend the avocado and poached egg on toast! The shop itself is so cool, chilled and hip, you kind of just want to hang out there all day, drink coffees and people watch.  I'm so happy to have such awesome coffee spot in my neighborhood and to be honest, I was a little hesitant to write this review - because even though it's only been open a week or two, every time I go in, this place seems to be busy and selfishly I kind of want it to stay under the radar! But seriously if you're ever in the 'hood, do yourself a favor and check this place out, it is so so good.

Great space to chill out while it's quiet! I got here bright and early in the morning and was the only one who dined in - rest of the customers got their coffee to go. Started my morning with a skinny flat white ($4) and the ricotta, poached pears and honey toast ($7.50). The breakfast menu is fairly simple - a variety of toasts (bread is from Balthazar Bakery - yum), ham & cheese croissant, a morning sandwich yogurt & granola, or pastries at the counter. My toast, while not extraordinary, felt like a healthy start to the day and did not leave me feeling sluggish. I did think it was a bit pricey though, considering the portion size... I enjoyed my flat white, and noticed that the coffee art did not bubble up despite me taking some time to photograph it (heh) - thumbs up!

Kind of an expensive Aussie themed cafe. The coffee is small but 4$, they even serve a minimal 1 slice Avacado Toast for like 10$. That being said - the staff is friendly and it's somewhat trendy although small.

Great addition to the West Village! We really liked the relaxing vibe we got at the shop. I ordered an iced coffee and avocado toast. The avocado toast topped with the poached egg was so good that I'm already thinking about the next time I can go in and get one! My wife ordered a latte and loved it as well. This is definitely going to be on my regular rotation. For my fellow PATH commuters, this is minutes away from the Christopher St station. Must try!

Great new spot in the West Village on Hudson Street. Australian owner with an Australian take on coffee! They also have a good food menu; we had the avocado toast with poached egg and a ham+cheese croissant. Good spot to grab a coffee in the morning, people watch Hudson, or grab a bite to eat. Worth a stop as you explore all the great places on Hudson Street and the surrounding area.

Cute coffee shop. I got the Thai Salad. While it was a really large portion the taste was blah. It needed salt and some kind of fat like sesame oil to make it pop. Also I'd roast and crush the peanuts on top because they just sink to the bottom.

Delicious. Great coffee, great decor, great food, and great service. Was having a crappy day trying to get a package from the FedEx place around the corner... I stopped by this place just to get out of the cold for a sec and it really exceeded my expectations. I had some sort of Vietnamese bahn mi-esque sand which and a cappuccino. Both were a bit pricy (but what isn't in New York.) Would 100% recommend.

The overall vibe is relaxed, friendly and cool  - everything you would expect from a coffeeshop named after a beautiful Australian beach. I also love their spicy tahini eggplant sandwich. It may be the best in the city.  But above all, the Americano I had there was just exquisite.

This was a cool little cafe, seemed staff were having an off day with no greeting of us or explaining what we needed to do. We went and found our selves a seat, after about 5 mins we went up to staff member to ask for a menu. We were told it's up on the board so we went and had a look, we selected the oatmeal and asked if we can get pears with it, we were told that's what it comes with (says on menu seasonal fruit, currently berries) I had the sandwich which was great and coffee was good. Would come back again and now know how it works but would suggest the staff are a little friendlier if owners were looking at feedback.
So happy this place opened around the corner from my work. It has a great atmosphere, simple and beautiful design, and both the food (sandwiches and salads) as well as the coffee are spot on.

Great coffee with good service and a convenient location, but it's annoying that the only to-go size is a 12 oz cup. I'm not looking for a Big Gulp full of coffee, but at least offer a 16 oz. cup for those of us who like to drink more than a few sips!

4.5 stars for the coffee but almost nothing to serve with it. It would be nice if they cleaned the filthy windows that line one wall of the store and the bird crap covered doorway. 56th between Park and Lexington is not Alphabet City. I'll go to Little Collins around the corner when in the area. They have good coffee too and seem to appreciate their customers enough to clean the place.

Ninth Street Espresso is situated right next door to the Lombardy and is a walkable distance from the Lexington Ave / 59th St station. It is also connected to the hotel from the lobby if you go past the steakhouse and the salon.  I had the pleasure to visit during a weekend trip to the city and my stay at the hotel gave out complimentary breakfast vouchers for coffee and a pastry. The shop offers a limited selection, which works in their favor of specializing in select pastries. The case held croissants, mufffins, and danishes. Hot and iced coffees/teas with self help to the milk, creamers, sugar, and a few other things.  Having tried the iced coffee, raspberry muffin, and plain croissant, the clear winner in the mix was the muffin! It was moist and minimally sweet, with the flavor of tart raspberries. The croissant was not as flaky to my liking and no offer was made to toast it or warm it up a bit. As for the coffee, as I usually like mine iced and black, I did not favor the taste of it here and had to add milk in it. Not sure why it didn't have a stronger coffee taste but the milk made it better.  Not many people were there on a Sunday morning around 930am but it is kind of in a quiet area with less foot traffic.
Cramped upscale coffee and danish shop furnished with stools and high tops rather than comfort seating.

It's been over a year since my last review and during that time I've been to most the local cafes in the area: Birch Ground Terminal (La Colombe) Bustlier Brooklyn Diamond Coffee (La Colombe) Capital One 360 (Peets) Juan Valdez Cafe Bluestone Lane (Sightline) Gregorys Coffee Demarco Fika Pomme Palais (Illy) As a fan of 3rd wave coffee, this cafe ranks among the top (with Little Collins, Blue Bottle, Cafe Grumpy, and Pennylane) in Midtown East.  The high quality of their dip solid and consistent with the nutty, citrus notes of their Alphabet City Brazilian beans brings me there every work day.  While they don't change their bean (except for a Nicaraguan bean they sell retail), what they sell is top notch. It's unfortunate that ppl claim the above listed cafes have "great coffee" when most are programmed with the dark burnt taste from Starbucks. I'm thankful for a great cafe like this.
Coffee was acidic. Not sure why this place gets rave reviews. I prefer Starbucks clover brewed coffee.

The Ninth Street Espresso is considered the first quality-driven, specialty coffee bar in the city.  They are located between the Harlow and the Lombardy Hotel, and have a very small, but honest menu - since this is a coffee place, they offer what they are known for: coffee!  Brewed coffee, iced coffee, espresso, and espresso with milk (they also have tea, too). Underneath the cash register, there is a little case of pastries from Balthazar's: plain and almond croissants, danishes, and muffins.  I had the espresso with milk and an almond croissant.  The espresso came with a cute heart art on top - very strong, but very tasty, and probably one of the best espressos I've had!  The almond croissant was also nice, as it was pretty large, had a nice caramelized/crunchy crust with slivers of almond, and it was perfect with the cup of espresso.  The baristas here are friendly, professional, and really take care in making a perfect cup (you can see that in how they prepare the beverage for you!).  Definitely a cute place to stop by to get some caffeine :D  +delicious espresso with milk +Balthazar pastries (almond croissant)
Cool space underneath a hotel.  Great coffee and pastries.  Probably my favorite coffee place in ny!

Best latte I've ever had. They also brew their Mexican blend from 9-10 every morning. Wasn't able to try it but the description (spicy, cinnamon) sounded very intriguing.  FYI If you buy coffee beans you get a free drip coffee with it. They didn't tell me that until after I had already ordered (and they started making) another drink. The store doesn't have much seating and could be a little cleaner.

I really like cappuccino, it's so smooth and lovely. The decorations of the place is cute and classic, service was good. Too little of variations in bakery but it's  ok, all I want is a croissant. And their croissant is decent. I had cappuccino and croissant, perfect combo for a cold breakfast. Dislike for only take cash, have to walk all the way to ATM for cash, not very convenient on a cold day. Guy was cute haha.

I've been coming here since the first week it opened back in June 2013. I work a few doors down. This spot is easily the best part of working in the neighborhood, and Ninth Street's coffee is easily one of my favorites by a wide margin. Their strong coffee has powered me through a lot of tough times at work, and they have a fond place in my heart.  Great, friendly staff who get to know you. Great atmosphere. Even the shop is kind of recessed and hidden in plain sight, and is a great place to disappear into right in the middle of Manhattan, whenever you need to hide and get good coffee. (It's very easy to walk right by the shop without noticing it.)  Couple notes: - They are cash only. - The sizes of espresso-based drinks do not impact the price. - There's a triple-shot of espresso in any espresso drink of any size- so the larger you go, the more there is a ratio of milk-to-espresso (or water-to-espresso for Americanos). - They are coffee purists for real- don't come looking for pumpkin spice here- just really, really well made espresso/lattes/cappuccinos, drip, and cold brew.  They invest very little in advertising, and rely strongly on word of mouth. It works. Every person I know who goes here raves about it and gets other people to go. Now I'm doing it. So go try them!

The espresso is v. good  Pretentious vibes resound.. Kind of like Kaffe 1660 but w. out the nice lighting and seating. - 1 start for the 'tude  This would not bother me so much if they took credit card ( cash only #no) Contrast this with my go to spot Uptown Roasters that brews an equally good espresso, accepts credit card, and doesn't make you feel like the uncool kid tryin to fit in

simple. straightforward. cash only.  drip coffee is $2.  Espresso shots start at $3 and are offered at 3, 6, 9, 12 oz. capping @ $4.25 for the 12oz with mlik (soy on request)  I'm pretty sure you go here for the espresso. It really is amazing. Rich and smooth, and enough to get you started on having a semi productive day on a Saturday that you slept through the entire morning because of your questionable decisions the night before.  Friendly and unpretentious service  Connected to the Lombardy hotel so yes, they have bathrooms . And they are super nice. Because some people just need to use the restroom after drinking coffee, I'm looking at you coffee shops with no public bathrooms...you inhumane teases.  Peace.  P.S. I forgot to mention, their cinnamon roll is amazing. moist. chewy. rich but not over the top sweet. just a great, unique texture. and delicious.

I am hopelessly addicted to this place.  It's a rare week that I don't make two or three afternoon trips from the office.  The espresso drinks are the best in the area--better even than Little Collins, although my Australian coworkers would berate me for saying so.  (LC has the edge on drip coffee, but $3.25 is a bit steep versus the $2 here.)  But the macchiato at Ninth Street is a delicious miracle in a three-ounce cup.  The atmosphere is nice and mellow.  Not much seating, but it turns over quickly.  The storefront is long, so there's plenty of window to gaze out and watch the world go by.  Friendly staff who seem to enjoy what they do.
Finally!!!!   Great coffee.  Who would think in NYC it would be so hard to find a good cup of coffee....I am a bit of a coffee snob but really.  This place has fantastic coffee!!!!!
Fantastic coffee and pastries from Balthazar. The cheddar biscuit is outstanding and the cookies are to die for.
Excellent coffee, quick service. The cashier or barrista don't have the most welcoming face but they get things done quickly and amazingly ;)

Okay, you know how you get crumbs EVERYWHERE when you eat a Nature Valley Granola bar? Imagine that, but on steroids. I dropped so many crumbs that I became a Disney Princess and somehow summoned a flock of birds to eat my sloppy seconds. I wish I was kidding. I was surrounded by birds.  Noglu and I started off on rocky ground because I had no idea they stopped having table service at 2pm. After that, you can still buy treats from their glass cases or refrigerated selection, but that's it. No menu to order off of. I was thankfully able to snag myself a chicken, arugula, grilled onion and mustard sandwich on GF bread. I say thankfully because my second issue (which is no fault of Noglu) is the stuck-up, entitled customers you have to elbow your way through at this bakery. As I perused my options, someone literally slid their way between me and the case and started CLEANING HOUSE on the sandwiches. Just grabbing stacks of them. As if that wasn't obnoxious enough, another customer tries cutting me in line when I just want to buy my one stinkin' $11 sandwich. I understand that GF food can be hard to come by, but I was about to go Hunger Games on these ladies.  The food was definitely good. Not something I would go out of my way to get again, but not something I regretted buying. I wish I was joking about the crumbs but the bread seriously disintegrates with every bite. As if the birds weren't enough, several dogs also came to investigate. Eat these things at your own risk. I recommend the great outdoors.
