Very (very) expensive but makes sense given the location. We got a chocolate cream puff (which is a regular-sized cream puff topped with a smaller chocolate cream filled puff) for $9. Taste was ok. Madeline's were very dry. Next time, will have to make it there early to try their caneles since there aren't a lot of places in the area that have this.  Inside, shop was quaint and cute. Bench outside for nice days.

I developed a severe wheat allergy about two years ago. It causes my throat to close and I can't breathe. Very serious. And about a month ago, my daughter was diagnosed with Celiac disease. Again, very serious. So finding good gluten-free options is extremely important to me. I was thrilled to discover NoGlu bakery and decided to use them for an Easter order. They are pretty pricey, but due to the severity of our gluten issues, price takes a backseat to safe and delicious food options that allow us to eat like "normal" people.  I ordered a large lemon meringue tart for dessert and croissants to enjoy after church on Easter morning. I hadn't eaten a croissant for more than two years and looked forward to it for a full two weeks after placing my order.  Imagine - I'd found gluten-free croissants!!!  On Good Friday, I called to confirm my order and delivery. I asked to add some gluten-free macaroons to my order.  The woman who answered said, "I'm not sure - we're pretty busy." Mind you, I'd paid a small fortune for my tart and croissants, not to mention the delivery fee - surely since they regularly serve macaroons, they would comply with this small request from a new, happy-to-have-found-them customer.  After checking, presumably with the baker, she returned to the phone and said, "Sorry, no!"  I was disappointed, but didn't complain because I was so looking forward to those gluten-free croissants and didn't want to jeopardize their delivery by making a snarky comment.  My order arrived Saturday, as planned. Easter morning too, finally arrived. I ate nothing before church because I knew I had the croissants to look forward to upon my return home. Alas, the NoGlu croissants were NoGood! Stale doesn't begin to describe them. They looked like croissants, though smaller and flatter than the puffy French ones we're used to. These were heavy and hard. Think week old Challah, but not nearly as airy or tasty.  When I opened the tart, I was disappointed to see it had shifted in the box and was way off center on the display disc. There would be no "oohs and ahhs" coming from my dinner guests. In fairness, the lemon tart, though nothing much to look at, was delicious.  I'd like to give NoGlu 2 stars for service, 1 for the croissants and disappointing tart presentation. But the lemon tart was damn good, so they're getting a 3 star review.  If you know of really great gluten-free bakeries in NYC, please share. It's not an easy lifestyle - we need to help each other out.  Meanwhile, I wish you safe and delicious gluten-free delicacies, served by pleasant peeps!

Came here on a random afternoon to study, and the location is perfect! They have an upstairs seating area that is quiet and has enough space, along with WiFi. It's next to a window so it's also pleasantly well-lit. The upstairs does close at 5pm, so that would be something to keep in mind. The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the coffee- which tasted weirdly peppery to me. They do have a rewards card that they'll punch for you each visit!

I couldn't believe it when I stumbled upon an all GF bakery!  Spent $8 on a GF/DF brownie.  It was good but a little dry, which happens with GF baked goods sometimes.  Staff weren't especially helpful.  I would have ordered a coffee to go with it, but they were more concerned about helping two women who came in after me who were more assertive.  It was unclear if I was supposed to help myself from the case in the window and bag my own item or have shop person do it for me.

The prices here are astronomical. I get that gluten free items are more hard to come by but it is a bit ridiculous the price point for the size of the items at this place. Tiny muffins are $4? Make it make sense.

If it was up to me then world would be better with Gluten- my wife seems to feel different so off she drags me to another gluten free bakery on her birthday no less. I was pleasantly surprised no less to find the food as delicious. The sandwiches were great and the bakery selections also good.  Also great coffee and plenty of room for us to bring our kids

Dear Chef Kim - you are heaven sent!!!!! The croque madame, the baguette, the pecan tart, the chocolate cake, the mousse - we ate so many delicious and decadent treats that we haven't had in years!!! You made us so, SO happy! What an incredible experience and we loved the upstairs dining. It was like eating ourside! Thank you to the whole team for making it such an incredible experience and a literal answer to prayer for two celiacs in the city - THANK YOU!!!

This is the #1 place in Manhattan if you want a gluten-free... anything. I personally do not have celiac but my girlfriend does and whenever we go to an all gluten free place I am sort of weary but this place blew me away. We got the cheese burger and a piece of cheesecake. The burger was no joke probably the best burger I have had anywhere, with the bun tasting as good if not better than a gluten one. And the cheesecake was even better than that. We will definitely be going back many times!

Oh. My. God. I just tried their brioche bun and it was by FAR the best gluten free bread I've ever had. Typically gf bread is crumbly and dry but this was so moist and fluffy. Seriously can't get over it! The bun was a little over $4 which is a bit on the pricey side but you can't beat the quality. Tempted to go back tomorrow and buy a full loaf!
I've been Gf for over 5 years and have tied this place several time... overall? very mediocre GF products and also ridiculously overpriced. Not worth it

Omg good.... I have not found anything they bake not be be delicious and fresh! I wanna eat the entire store! I have tried the apple bread muffins, the pumpkin, Banana and chocolate,  the chocolate brioche muffins .... Everything was awesome! I travel and this is one of the best! This is my go to bakery in NYC

DELICIOUS.  You are going to pay a lot more for something a lot smaller than maybe you expected but it's worth it.  Being able to eat a cream puff that actually tastes like a well-made cream puff without all the fun aftereffects later,  HEAVEN. I went late in the day so a lot of stuff was already sold out but my cream puff craving was satisfied.

As someone who's gluten-free 95% of the time (I do cheat...) I was excited about Noglu. I Went for the croissant, and decided to also get the Apple Bread Pudding. The croissant I could've definitely done without. It was dry... and not very croissant like. The bread pudding made the visit to the bakery totally worthwhile. It's moist, with just the right sweetness. I would say best bread pudding I've had considering it's gluten free. Looking forward to trying their other pastries

I walked in to Noglu today to grab a quick to go bite and on my way out discovered the chocolate muffin  - - oh my god! What is this piece heaven! I kind of don't want anyone else to know so that they will always (always) have this double chocolate muffin!

CELIAC heaven!!! It is worth every penny. I had so much trouble deciding what to get, but ended up with the lemon tart, cream puff, and vanilla swirl eclair. The lemon tart had perfectly decadent meringue on top and a strong lemon flavor. Cream puff wasn't too sweet and had the perfect crunch/softness of bread and amount of whipped cream. The eclair was chewy and decadent. I also got the ham and cheese croissant; love, love, love this place! I wish WI had an all gf bakery as special as this one! Thanks for making this Celiac so happy (FIRST TIME for all those goodies!).

I love finding hidden gems, and this one almost made it. The coffee and ambience is top notch,  it the food and price were below average. This place should be a 3.5 but we're limited by the whole star system.  Coffee: 5/5 - had the drip coffee and espresso here, both were great. Not over roasted and had subtle chocolate and plum notes.  Food:  3/5 - I checked the refrigerated display and noticed the sandwiches (with bread and croissants) were pre-made and looked less than fresh. I chose the tuna avocado melt and that was a major disappointment. It wasn't toasty or melty, and the tiny amount of avocado was barely detectable. And it cost $10!  Ambience/service: 4/5 - this place is very rustic and cozy in the best way. It's tucked under some scaffolding and hard to spot, and is calm for a place near Hudson yards. Ideal for a quiet convo. The barista was friendly and fast but a little overwhelmed with 10 customers in there.  Price: 2/5 -   $3 for a 12 oz coffee and $10 for a terrible toasted sandwich? It's Manhattan but its not gourmet! This was the worst part of the experience, I felt like they fooled me on price. The food items were not listed with prices, so it came as a surprise when I paid.  Overall, a good spot that could be great if it was cheaper for the food.

It was quick stop to grub a cup of cocoa. The small cafe was pretty packed. I was at the javits center but not much around there so ended up there. (The Starbucks in javits was sold all the coffee they had!) They had different kinds of cocoa but I just got a regular one. It was ok. I also got white chocolate and macadamia coockies those are also just ok. The cafe is small but cute and cozy. I will try their coffee next time.

Based on my experience this probably should be a lesser star rating, but the place has such charm that I know in my heart if my order was different I could have been much more satisfied. I hope.  I saw this pop up in my yelp search for coffee spots near the north end of the High Line. Even the name sounds adorable. The inside is truly "Old Country" as opposed to most modern looking coffee shops popping up all over. 3 reviewers claim the cold brew is awesome. They are either liars or something has drastically changed in the recipe since their reviews. Or they like bean water. I took a sip, it filled my soul and my stomach with sorrow, I took another sip to be sure, and as I approached the nearest trash can, took a third and final sip to be POSITIVE that this was as disappointing as I knew in my head it was...and tossed a 90% full cup of iced coffee right in the garbage. It was flavorless and sad.  Service was flat as well. I can handle that, though.  Like I said...something about the place is leaving me with a hint of hope. I will re-review when I'm back on caffeinated beverages w/ anything that contains sugar. But for now, very eh.

Very nice baristas. They get 4 stars. The low stars are my estimation of the coffee, which is, after all the primary reason to go.  The house blend drip taste as just okay--which in NYC means go somewhere else if you want great coffee, and it's too week. Should have brought my headphones: can't stand the music.  It is, however an pleasant workplace because of the plethora of outlets.

Came here around 1pm on a Saturday with my boyfriend. Cute colorful decor as you walk in. Small cozy place, like most cafes. We ordered the Nutella hot chocolate (WOW!), chai latte (a nice light and toasty chai), an everything bagel with cheese and ham, and then the same bagel but with turkey. They were out of croissants which was a bummer, so we had to take the bagel route. The bagels were toasted and tasty at least. I deducted a point from being skimpy on the bagel fillings. There was like one tiny slice of ham / turkey. I also deducted a point for lack of seating. I ended up sitting near the bathroom. Not too comfortable unless you happen to get one of the leather chairs. Otherwise you're stuck with a tiny wooden chair. Better off getting your stuff to go. If I was only rating the drinks, it would get 5 stars because that Nutella hot chocolate was something else! :)

My friend and I had a little bit of time to kill before we had to leave for our bus. Old Country Coffee is conveniently located, just 2 minutes away from the bus stop.  I think the barista was maybe the owner? Not sure, but he was SO friendly and nice! It's such a cozy little coffee shop, perfect for a rainy day. The coffee was delicious and smooth. I just wish I had more time to enjoy the coffee shop. Will definitely return!

My saving grace this morning. Catching the bus by Javits. Before I never knew there was such a lovely, inexpensive, tasty place that's open early enough! Friendly staff & a coffee happy hour!!!! My mornings off to a better start.  Oh and really good music.
Oh man. This is a hidden gem that I've never spotted because of construction scaffolding. Cozy spot with wifi. Great service. Good coffee.

I stumbled upon Old Country Coffee and it's a cute spot that you wouldn't expect to find hidden this far west on 34th street.  The staff is very friendly and accommodating. They have baked goods like chocolate cake and lemon tarts, that all look delicious. They offer a couple of savory options like sandwiches. I originally stumbled in looking for breakfast food (eggs, not to be found). It was so cute inside and inviting that I had to go back to check out their offering.  So far I've only had drinks, and while they are a bit pricey I dig what they put out. First drink was a hot island joy. Their take on dark hot chocolate (YES they have hot chocolate) with almond and coconut flavor. Good and tasty but I would try something else after one try.  Next I went for their Iced Mocha and they use 85% dark chocolate. It was damn good and made with almond milk on request. They also have soy, coconut, and cows milk (moooo).  The atmosphere and laid back energy are a big draw especially if you want to chill and read or get some work done.  The interior is decorated with antique items like an old cash register, water pump, studio lights.  Check them out if you're in the area for a caffeinated drink and chill.

Friendly and prompt counter staff, who moves people through the line quickly.  Be prepared for the stroller crowd descending on the place and monopolizing the single rest room.  It's just part of the neighborhood fabric, which is ok, because that's part of what gives this place a nice local flavor and decent breakfast or lunch options.  Very nice and fluffy almond croissant a coke and a coffee only set me back about $8.  Looks like some nice wraps and dessert options too.  A nice respite if you're heading to the Megabus stop over between 11th and 12th Avenues.
What a great place. Comfie to hang out and get some work done. Really nice staff, good food and great coffee. Highly recommended.

This place is adorable, classy, with reasonable and respectable selection of high-quality drinks and bakery items. Not crowded and clearly a favorite among wide range of locals, young and older, who pop in and out. Unfortunately, the waft of cigarette fumes from just outside the entrance is nauseating, constant, and will keep me away.

I love this place! The coffee is great, the ambiance is relaxing, and the service is good. It's a much needed addition to the area and I hope they stay put for a long long time. It's worth the walk over here to get a delicious cappuccino. Go get a donut a Doughnut Plant then head east for a great cup of coffee.

Disappointed.  Was initially excited to check out this schmanzy coffee place with wifi. It was clearly was popular/crowded.  After placing my belongings down, I approached the barista to order a small coffee and matcha. I asked what was in the ham sandwich and (he begrudgingly answered as if I was asking unecesarry questions) there were two kinds: ham and veggie. So I asked again and another barista stepped in and the bill came out to $15 something, and gave a tip after he complimented my nails.  I waited for 10-15 min and wondered where my drinks were so asked about it until I learned that the sandwich was the only thing they placed the order for. It was a medium sized sandwich for $15. I was annoyed and asked them to cancel my order. But the sanwich came out so I said forget it. And one of the baristas said they would comp my matcha. But a third barista ended up double charging me for a coffee and a matcha. Someone had to refund me and then instead of comping the matcha. They comped me for the coffee.  Annoyed I asked to just give me everything and walked away. 30 minutes later, one of the baristas came up to me to give me the receipts reminding me of my (still) wrong charge and a comp card which seemed useless because at this point I didnt plan on returning.    I think what was most disappointing was their initial snark attitude of the 2/3 baristas until they epically messed up my order.  The food and drinks were very good, but was it worth a $15 dining sandwhich experience? Absolutely not. And the service was immature and unrefined relative to the cost and interior.  It was disappointing.

The ambiance and decor is nice. It's in a hotel lobby area, there's only seating around the coffee shop or you can go into the lobby. We ordered a cortado and pour over coffee. They only have one pour over stand so they told us it would take 10mins to make.

Beautiful space and their nitro coffee is very smooth. I only stopped in to grab a coffee to go but I spotted the lobby bar in the back and I predict I'll be back sitting in front of their large glass windows soaking in the sun with a drink in hand...

In search of a cozy coffee shop in midtown that wasn't Starbucks, I stumbled across Paper the other day. Their coffee shop is nestled in the lobby of the MADE Hotel in Chelsea. They offer a buy ten, get one free deal so I'll definitely be back!

This is a hidden gem - I'm almost worried to post but I can't not. Met my brother here since it's close to penn station and was impressed by the cool vibe,  fabulous food and amazing staff. It's a lobby of a hotel, but feels so much more cozy and welcoming. *Michelle* immediately greets you with a smile and was the one to recommend the sweet potato pancakes. WOW! She was not kidding when she said they were amazing. The free refills on coffee and outdoor space round this out to be my favorite coffee spot that I continue to visit. Stop in for brunch, a meeting, or to do some work and you won't be disappointed!

I had a pretty good cup of coffee here. There wasn't much seating in the place but their Brazil pour over was pretty solid for those who, like me, love dark and bitter black coffee. It wasn't as strong as it could have been but it was enough to give me my caffeine fix while tasting decent.  The atmosphere of Toby's is very quiet. There isn't much seating but it wasn't very crowded when I got there, so it was a perfect place to get some work done or have a subdued conversation with friends. The location is incredibly convenient.  I didn't try the food but they had some interesting options that I might try in the future if I were in the area. They were out of acai bowls though, so make note if you are coming for that, you might want to check in advance if they have them that day.

Really want to give them five stars, the fifth one is because of the wifi... I am glad that they offer wifi in this spot but I have to say the signal sucks. It's a good place for chilling with friends, studying, working, or just for coffee. Nice location in west village, highly recommend! Tips: you can hardly find the plug to charge your laptop or phone. I found one under the sofa, it's kinda deep inside. Hope this would be useful for people in need lol

Look no further than Toby's.  This place has been on my coffee shop hit-list for a while and I finally got a chance to stop by. What a beautiful place! The atmosphere is a nice synthesis of industrial, contemporary, and cozy. The dark wood counters, potted plants, NY Times, and perfect lighting make for instagram heaven (guilty as charged).  I ordered a flat white with high expectations, and wasn't disappointed. Really nice quality coffee and well crafted by people that know what they're doing. Came back for a cortado which was also great. The food is also quite nice. Love how they carry Doughnut Plant doughnuts :D  If you find yourself in this part of the village, be sure to stop by.

I love their vibe here. The ambience is super chill, but everyone comes here for the coffee and the aesthetics. I enjoy coming here because it's close to my campus, and there's plenty of seating here as well. Definitely make a stop by here if you're around for some good coffee! Don't be shy to take pictures too because the aesthetics are just so on point.

Wow, what an awesome coffee shop. I've never been to their other locations but the new West Village location is great. Delicious coffee, beautiful exterior and interior, and very VERY friendly staff. I should've gotten the baristas names this morning when I was ordering my coffee because they were the nicest baristas ever. As a Stumptown lover, I am so happy that they serve Stumptown coffee here. I went with the drip and it was delicious. If you haven't visited yet you really should, it may very well become your neighborhood coffee spot real quick! I will certainly be visiting their Williamsburg location the next time I am in Brooklyn.

If you want a good coffee and I am talking a REAL coffee, Toby's Estate is where it's at! Popped by this morning for coffee and a light breakfast after many recommendations from friends back in Australia and safe to say I was not disappointed. My latte was creamy and well-made with some nice coffee art on the top - definitely up to Australian quality! I was also pleasantly surprised to find Vegemite Toast on the menu - this is not everyone's cup of tea but if you are an ex-pat Aussie you will LOVE this! My partner ordered the granola and said it was nice. One thing I would note is that this particular Toby's Estate is not the place to go if you are starving and looking for a big breakfast/lunch to keep you fuelled for the day - the menu is small and the serving sizes of the food we ordered were also pretty tiny, so more of a snack as opposed to a breakfast. If you want a 5 star coffee, this is the place to go in the West Village!

I came in last minute for the Cappy hour ($2 cappuccino at 10:30am - noon). I believe the barista should be more attentive - she charged me regular price for the cappuccino at first, since she was not aware of the discount hours.  I was looking forward to choosing from pastries by pain d'avignon, but it seemed like the cafe didn't have any today. Blueberry muffin was pretty good, but otherwise there were sad looking pale pastries.

I recently visited Patent coffee at the suggestion of my girl. I tried the CBD Arnold Palmer and had a Yelp check-in offer for a free cookie. That cookie was delicious! I tried the chocolate chip.  I'm not usually big on chocolate chip, but it was really good. I wanted to try the CBD coffee, but the only non dairy alternative is oat milk which is strange as a solitary choice and I'm just not into it. So I settled for the Arnold Palmer which was ok. I was looking for the herbaceous flavor that usually comes with CBD products and I missed it. I also didn't feel any if the effects of the CBD after drinking it. I would try the coffee next time if I'm in the area, and definitely grab a cookie.
CAPPY HOUR! Y'all this cafe has $2 cappuccinos from like 10:30-12:30 PM, and they're sooo good! Make sure to get their chocolate chip cookies while you're at it. Heaven is that.
Amazing super cute cafe, with great customer service! I got the oat milk latte and it was lovely. They also serve CBD Cold Brew which I've never seen in a coffee shop! Definitely worth checking out.

Service is subpar almost like you are doing them a favor by being there and I was there during a slow time.  The 1 sandwich choice was good and the coffee was nice and hot. Not much else out in this area so it works out.

I love this little coffeeshop! They are a very no-frills type of place which I love! Highly frequented by the UN crowd but I can almost always get a seat even when they are busy. They make delicious coffee and they sell doughnut plant doughnuts on the weekends - which are to die for! The staff is super nice and I love that they have a stamp card for a free coffee after 10 visits - it's awesome especially since me and my husband come here almost everyday!

Minimalist aesthetic, zen-like experience, rich, velvety latte, delicious drip coffee from Stumptown, incredible gourmet donuts. Would go out on a limb and say best latte I've had in the past 5 years. Maybe ever.

Hip and hipster - coffee shop tucked away in a quiet street, but you can hear chatty noises as you close in to the shop. In the spring and summer, they open the door and AC escapes so it's not exactly cooling in the cafe.    A glass bottle of cold brewed Stumptown iced coffee from the shelf is $4.75. Small coffee concoctions i.e. latte cost similar. Let's just say - it ain't cheap. For something this expensive, the quality was definitely underwhelming.  Iced (house) coffee tasted a bit diluted and almost too sour for my taste. Iced mocha had a thick layer of undissolved coco power at the bottom. Americano was just average.

Cool, hidden spot, but you can't be this expensive and not nail iced coffee.  Other items were fine.  Food - Ice coffee was way way bitter.  Did not finish it.  Soy latte was fine, according to gf. Service - Nothing wrong here - quick counter service, etc. Atmosphere - Very cool, best part of the experience.  The place is hidden and has a super minimalist theme.  Very much liked that part. Price - $10 for large iced coffee and soy latte.  Pricey, but not crazy for NYC coffee shops.

I don't want to be a "hater" so I give 2 stars rather than only one, but to be honest I stopped going to this place after a few visits.  The lines are long, and you have to wait many minutes if you try to order anything other than just a drip coffee (which is served warm, not hot, and costs $2.50 for a small).   The place is always crowded with UN diplomats and there is never a place to sit.    Other things which make me give 2 stars: the wifi is slow, and maybe it's just me but I get a kind of judgmental attitude from the employees there.  Would it kill them to smile and not act like they're doing me a favor by taking my order?  Another thing which irritates me is that there is a chalkboard outside the place which always has annoying slogans or messages written on it in pretentious handwriting.  At least one of the people working there seems to use the chalkboard as an artistic outlet to express contempt for the people they serve.  I have started brewing my own coffee at home and am happy to no longer give this establishment my money.

So happy to live near a place that serves Stumptown.  Very good coffee.  The baristas know what they're doing.  The pour-over is exceptional and worth the extra cash.  Very trendy yet simple decor.    The place could obviously use more space - don't bother coming during the day to work or sit down.

They are serving may be the best coffee in the area. I love the espresso so much. I was impressed that this place is very clean they are just looking after the tables very frequently.  Nice and smile - just two words to describe the staff. And minus One star because of the prices. Comfortable place at all.
Great coffee, ridiculous pricing. I bought half a sammie and a large ice coffee for 15 bucks. So, once in a blue moon, it's not bad, but that is pretty steep.
Close to the UN, try the matcha cake!! I Excellent coffee, nice staff! A little pricy though.. I really like the Scandinavian decor

Cute little spot near the UN but like other yelpers have mentioned, I would have easily missed it had I not kept an eye out. They serve Stumptown coffee, which is one of my favorites, and the baristas were very nice. I wasn't sure what other types of drinks they served though as I didn't see a menu anywhere. Maybe I missed it if there was one? Definitely would've ordered specialty coffee drink had I seen one.

Quaint little place. I live right around the corner so I finally was able to check it out! My friend and I both got the seasonal lattes-- cinnamon brown sugar. In theory, it sounded good but the syrup at the bottom was too thick! It refused to dissolve & every sip was phlegm-like. It was undrinkable, $6 to waste! I was able to transfer my drink to another cup without the syrup on the bottom. I think this drinks works better as a hot drink solely, so the heat can help dissolve the syrup. I will not be ordering that drink again but I will give the coffee another shot! We were at closing time and left with a few free donuts! Made our experience better. Overall I paid $15 for two lattes and a chocolate croissant. Be aware that the fresh pastries might cost more than you would expect....

This is a cozy little coffee shop but they ran out of a lot of the pastries and couldn't heat up pastries that I did get. Sold out of pastries could be a good thing because it is fresh but it is bad when there isn't enough to go around :(  I bought a donut, almond croissant, latte, and expresso with soy milk coffee. It came out to about 17 and some change. There are also no flavors in the latte.   The upside... there was wifi and the croissant was good. The passion fruit donut was weird but the coffee was good.  Cozy spot but i personally like more in coffee shops I lounge in so though coffee (important for coffee shops...) was good, I'd have to give it three stars for not having more variety. It's mainly being bare bones for a coffee shop with manhattan prices.
Today I've had the best latte ever. It wasn't only delicious but beautiful as well. Thank you Perk Kafe!

I love cute cafes as much as the next person, even more now that my building has decided to start hammering and drilling at the lovely hour of 8 each day. Perk Kafe opens its doors at 7 am (!!), but even on an early Wednesday morning, almost all of the tables were already taken. There's one long communal table to your left when you walk in, two smaller tables to your right, and some stools running along the windows, so not as much space as I had originally thought based on the pictures, but if you come on the early side and you don't mind sitting next to and across from strangers, there's usually a seat.  Perk Kafe boasts the best cold brew but I was feeling boring, so opted for a decaffeinated berry hibiscus tea instead. The coffee menu isn't too extensive and I didn't see any food options other than the standard baked goods, but I'd love to come back and try those pillowy Dough donuts that were the size of my hand.  The guy working the cashier was very nice and warmly greeted everyone who walked in, not just the regulars. This is a dependable neighborhood spot to grab some joe and get some work done or read a book (not sure about chatting here with friends, everyone looked serious about maintaining the quiet), I'd definitely come back.  NEXT TIME: the donuts, the rice crispy treats hanging out by the side
This is probably the best coffee shop for studying/working in the area. Outlets are available, and the wifi is consistent, and the coffee is good. The only negative is that there is limited seating.

It's not after every heat wave, I find myself craving a hot chai latte and a chocolate chip scone. Today, I stumbled upon Perk Kafe after riding the Q train from Brooklyn in wet clothing. I was in need of something warm, and comforting. I settled for a chai latte and it was delicious. The chai to milk ratio was spot on, and definitely packed a fragrant punch from the chai spices. The chocolate scone was delicious as well. It was laced with orange zest, which is always a wonderful compliment to chocolate. The scone was also flaky, and definitely worth another purchase. I'll definitely get another latte here.
Great coffee the quality of their roast is pretty good

Absolutely love this place. The staff is so sweet and it's the perfect spot to do homework or read a book. I'm in love with the Chai Tea Latte and their latte game is on point. They're starting out in the area, but hopefully a buzz starts going around. Best coffee in the area!

I love this place! It's one of Yorktown's hidden gems. The coffee is great (Stumptown), they have doughnuts from Dough, and there is enough sitting area to comfortably work. Plus, they are constantly playing amazing music.

What? A nice quiet coffee shop with good coffee this far uptown? I'm so impressed - They serve Stumptown. They have wifi and aren't snobby about its usage. They have a great space for studying or reading. GREAT addition to the neighborhood.

I had heard great things about this place and other reviewers really seem to like it, so may have to come back and try my luck with a sandwich. Came here this morning and got an avocado toast on gluten free bread, and I received the saddest, littlest piece of toast I've ever seen. It was TINY. They did put plenty of avocado on it, which I respected, but the flavors were bland and could have used some salt/pepper/lemon. Also wasn't that big of a fan of the liberal application of pumpkin seeds. My experiments with ordering gluten free bread in NYC have been wildly inconsistent, and sad to report that the GF bread here is dry and tasteless. Also got a large orange juice, which was good -- nice and pulpy, just the way I like it.

3.5 stars - first time here and I'd like to return before giving it a higher star review.  So the expectation is there but I'd like to have a second taste.  Passed by on a whim - exploring my work hood and wanting to find something different, this caught my eye.  Oddly it shares a building with a local College but the space works.  Limited seating so I took my order to go.  Grabbed an avocado grilled cheese sandwich today.  In it had sliced tomatoes, chunky avocado, jack cheese and grilled on multigrain bread.  By the appearance, I think they grilled my bread too much for my liking (see photo).  So while not as pretty, it tasted great.  Liked that the avocado was a bit chunky and not like a spread, it adds substance.  The tomato was semi thick sliced so again, making it more hearty.  The jack cheese combined with all that, tied it together.  Yum.    I watched the sandwich crafters at work and am thinking a second visit to try the burger and the other grilled cheese that caught my eye - it's a bacon with caramelized onions, two cheeses on sourdough.  Hint of garlic mayo too it says.  You had me at the bacon.    One note about the sandwich, it did get a bit messy to eat so I'm glad I had mine to go.  So I scarfed it down in the privacy of my office with a ton of napkins on hand.  Note:  there's a line but it moved quickly.  There was also a pickle bar where you can grab a few but I couldn't get close enough to take a pic.  Too many people!  :-)  Will let you know how it is when I return.

Came here at around lunch time on a Sunday and it was relatively quiet. Luckily they serve breakfast all day as that was what I was craving for.  Tried their breakfast BLT and a latte. The sandwich was pretty good, just a little stingy on the bacon :(  Coffee was a disappointment....doesnt have much a strong coffee taste (probably too much milk) and it also had a sour aftertaste to it, which i didnt like  Price was reasonable though.

Man, the pictures looked better than the taste.  I work close by and came here for lunch. The positive is that my sandwich was made in literally 45 seconds, the negative is that it was dripping in vinegar. I got the spicy Mediterranean wrap and it was just average - way too much onion and swimming in vinegar  The pickles were bomb AF though! That was the upside.  I might come back to try the grilled cheese sandwiches, those actually look delicious!

We came because of excellent reviews and left with a "so so" feeling after lunch. Coffee was great. Goat cheese arugula salad had the bare minimum cheese. Sandwiches were acceptable. One grilled cheese sandwich was undercooked inside (not melted) and burnt on the outside (pictures of food on yelp show how variable the grilling of sandwiches is).

Usually, lunch spots in midtown east are nothing to write home about, but occasionally, you come across one worth giving five stars. The Pickler is awesome. every. single. time. The quality of every thing they serve here is amazing. I love the salads because eating the mixed greens tastes like eating straight from an organic garden, the bacon is crisp afffff, they provide plentiful portions, and even all the dressings taste homemade. Be sure to get a sandwich on the pressed sourdough bread- it's so good you'll never want to eat a sandwich from anywhere else ever again. I've paid the same midtown prices for subpar quality lunch and it makes me sad, but the Pickler never disappoints! :)

Solid Ruben (swapped slaw for kraut). Great pickles. Fast, friendly service. Not a lot of seating as others have mentioned, but it's there if you're willing to work for it. I will definitely be back to try other sandwiches.

Very much enjoyed a trip to this cute little spot during a recent visit to NY. It's a few blocks from Grand Central and a nice break from that hustle and bustle and packed food court.  I went for breakfast and got the egg sandwich BLT. The crispy bacon was so good that I kept eating all of the little crumbles of it that fell off when I bit into the sandwich. I got mine without mayo, so that probably created a more crumbly sandwich than it would've been normally. But still very tasty. Also got a cranberry almond muffin, which was delicious. Not overly sweet, but yummy almond extract flavor in the batter with slivered almonds in top. The cranberries were whole and plump--these weren't diced up craisins, but real juicy berries. Also got a latte and had a tasty breakfast that kept me full until late afternoon.  The staff was also very nice. Pickler is on the same street as the Amish Market and some other garden/market type places, so you may enjoy a few other stops along the way.

If you work near Grand Central and are Gluten Free you should definitely check this place out. They have three GF options - bread, bun or wrap. I would say definitely get the bread as the wrap kindof falls apart (as almost all GF wraps do,) and the bread is the best GF bread I've ever had!  Even if you are not GF this place has a lot of sandwhich options and great service!

Working in the Grand Central area, I've investigated some lunch spots. Pickler & Co is a cute little place on the east side of 45th street  between 2nd and 1st Avenues. They're claim to fame are the pickles, of course, that you can have with an order (one per customer) along with a sample size of they're homemade slaws.  They have a variety of sandwiches with quirky names like The Burn, Hammer, Marilyn and Rachel (ie Turkey Pastrami, Swiss, 1000 Island, Kraut on Rye). They also have a coffee bar and some breakfast items/sandwiches. Coffee is good, not too bitter, I think its from Counter Culture (?) and the bread is always fresh. Decent prices for the quality of food but the hours open are a little limiting. Def check out if you're hungry at lunchtime in the area!
Best sandwiches in Midtown and possibly NYC. I regularly get a Turkey Club but everything is great including the free pickles. Breakfast is also a huge winner and one of my favorites BECs
Love the people here. Customer service is always top notch. It's a nice way to start the day!

I wanted to be adventurous today - so I went on yelp, typed in my zip-code and "Lunch" and this was the first place to pop up! The reviews looked great, so I wanted to see for myself what this was.  When you walk in, you will see a coffee shop to your right and the lunch place to your left. I went at around 11:20 and there were maybe 1 or 2 people besides me. So there was no wait! I already had my mind made up with what I wanted to get - the Turkey Club for $9.25 (smoked turkey, pork bacon, pepper jack cheese, avocado mayo, tomato and romaine on sourdough). The sandwich looked smaller than I had anticipated (perhaps because I was so hungry), but later found that it would do the trick to fill me up. The sandwich was really great - but I guess everything that has bacon is defaulted to be great.  I would assume this places could get pretty crowded as you approach noon, so be prepared!  The place had 1 or 2 tables to sit, but it is obviously not a place you would want to come to eat in.
Very good food and customer service...highly recommended....All the staff very friendly..thank you for good food and your incredible service

Frankly, Dave and the team at Pickler just know how to make a killer sandwich. Went with a group of four friends, and everyone agreed that the place was a must-visit.  Had a couple vegetarians in the group who raved about the broccoli sandwich, but the deli staples were top notch as well.  Can't wait to go back.

This is my favorite place to get a lunch sandwich in midtown east. Here's the reasons why: - Tons of pre-set sandwiches. You can make your own or tweak them as well - Very quick and efficient ordering and line - Everything is delicious. My go-to is a chicken club in a wheat wrap - Well priced. Most things are $9-$12 - You can pick from different types of pickles and coleslaws to go with your sandwich - Friendly, attentive staff

I'll sound a slightly discordant note on this highly rated spot.  Tried the roast beef on a pretzel roll, a bag of chips and a bottle of iced tea. The tab came to $19.05 with tax. I left a buck in the tip jar, so I broke $20 for a sandwich lunch.  The sammich was pleasant enough, but for $12.40, I'd expect a bit more food. Yes, this is midtown, but we're not reviewing a place with waiter service and outside seating. We're talking takeout. The pickle at the bar was quite good, the admonition to take but one a little annoying. I took the spicy slaw, served in one of those tiny Solo cups meant for dressing. It was only half full, so I received about a teaspoon of slaw. Up to my elbows in slaw I was not.  Next time I'll plump for turkey instead, I think the turkey sandwiches were in the $8 range.

I am happy I tried this deli. I read Yelp reviews and it seems they were true. This place is set up as a deli so there isn't much seating. Luckily I went a little earlier so my friend and I were able to get seats at the high top table.  I chose to make my own salad which include romaine lettuce, cucumbers, onions, dried cranberries and chicken. It was very good and the portion size was pretty decent. It came out to about $9 and change.  My friend got a chicken Caesar wrap and she said it was delicious and here was only $7.  For everyone who is excited about the free pickle and coleslaw taster if your meal is over $7... it is self serve where you pick up your food. I unfortunately did not know and missed out, but next time I go I will be sure to get it!!!

I had their Pastrami Sandwich with Hot pickle & Coleslaw.  This place is a nice, smaller shop with the building it is in undergoing repairs.  The sandwich was really quite good! It was a little smaller than I hoped for, but such is life.  Definately choose here over the Lenny's not too far away.

Favorite NY sandwich shop in midtown east in an area that is saturated with lunch options.  I go here 2-3 times a week.  Best sandwiches for me are the Reuben and an egg salad sandwich (I add bacon).  BLT is good here too, but the bacon is rarely strips but crumbled.

Happened to be up in midtown for an appointment this past weekend and decided to give Pickler & Co a shot. I think I saw it featured on one of those NYC sandwich lists so I was pretty excited. Got in there and it's a little bit confusing when you walk in, there's a counter both to the right and the left. The left side looked more like a restaurant so i went there only to be told I must order on the other side, no worries that's not a big deal, just a bit confusing.  Ordered the reuben, as that's one of my favorite sandwiches to order no matter where I go.  First bite tasted good, had good flavors, everything in good portions. A few bites in, noticed that the sandwich went from hot to warm to cold in the middle. This makes me sad but I finished it anyways. Other than that, all was good though.  Wouldn't go out of my way to go here but maybe your experience will be better!

Absolutely LOVE this place. Love the quality organic meats used and craft sandwich menu. Complimentary pickle bar is a nice touch as well - the horseradish is to die for! Staff is friendly and helpful, wait time is minimal. Favorite sandwiches include: the reuben, the blt. SO GOOD. They make a great custom salad as well (but don't chop it).  If i have to cite a negative ..I wish they had better hours - they don't open until 730 in the morning which is too late for me to stop in for breakfast or i would, limited hours on wknd
Food is pretty good, which is why it receives any stars; but the staff is beyond not caring and look at orders as an imposition. Ritual App didn't help at all.
Stopped by for breakfast - the breakfast Rachel was amazing. Great flavors, not bland like breakfast sandwiches often tend to be (for me at least). Would recommend!  4 stars because

I've ordered here several times during work lunch and am impressed with the quality and taste. Top notch NY style sandwiches, burgers, and wraps with quality ingredients. They use Applegate meats for their deli slices and, true to their namesake, their pickles are great-- flavorful and crunchy!  I love the spicy ones.  The service has been competent and polite. I've made a few last minute rush lunch orders for my team meetings (10-15 people) and they've been able to accommodate in half an hour though I had to pick the order up myself. I emailed the order after giving them a call. If you're in the mood for a tasty, authentic, and high quality sandwich in Midtown, I have not found a better place. My work mates love every time I order from this place!!! I highly recommend.

Great food I would absolutely recommend stopping by. Also they have kombucha on tap, the New Yorker and la croix for sale what more do I have to say. The pickles are excellent and I love pairing the spicy and sour with the Carm sandwich.

A roasted broccoli sandwich?? Oh yes-it is awesome!! A coworker brought me her and I will be thankful forever.  In a neighborhood with many sandwich places this by far is the most delicious and efficient.  After coming here only once, I downloaded the ritual app and now can order and pick up in no time.  This is a winner!
I haven't written a Yelp review in years...but Pickler is just that good. An oasis in the desert. Pro-tip, you can order and then wait outside and get your food through the pickup window.

A review I've been meaning to write for a year, but always gets pushed out of my mind the second the sandwich euphoria sets in and takes over all brain function. The Pickler is truly THE lunch spot in Midtown East - a desperately needed haven you can rely on for consistently delicious, affordable, and speedy bites. I say bites because whenever the sandwich is finished, devoured much too quickly, I conclude it must just be the result of its size being too small rather than my appetite for melted cheese, Sriracha mayo, and avocado being too voracious. The bonus free pickle and slaw is a lovely touch as well. All in all, a welcome, independent, sustainable lunch option that I'll probably see you at every day for the rest of my life, once you get the taste. My only caveat is I've never been impressed by their lattes but you're not there for the coffee.

Sustainable comfort food=guilt-free guilty pleasure. What's not to like? From the Reuben to the patty melt to the house-made pickles to the espresso; I've never had a bad experience here. I hope they stay a long time--my lunches would be much the  sadder without them.
Just arrived in NYC and this was the perfect sandwich place after my long bus ride! The avocado: avocado, hummus, romaine, and sprouts in multigrain. Delicious!

Was here a while back and it was stellar. This time around not so much. Seems like the quality has gone downhill. And I don't like the fact that when you build your own sandwich, you're charged for every little thing. My sandwich didn't taste that great, and I don't think I'll be returning anytime soon. And you have to pay extra for mayo which is ridiculous.

Great food and coffee!  All their more expensive sandwiches come with a free pickle and cole slaw taster! Standout is the buffalo chicken grilled cheese. It's amazing, with hot sauce-doused chicken tenders and mozzarella on a ciabatta roll, grilled like a panini.  Coffee bar serves local Counter-Culture coffee and also sells beans to take home.  I would highly recommend trying any of their sandwiches and a coffee, just remember to get your pickle and cole slaw while you're waiting!

For quite some time I had been craving a sandwich that is prepared and served the old-fashioned way, and not the standard cookie-cutter variety you find in Korean-owned delis on just about every street corner in the city. So, after walking by this nondescript sandwich shop for too long, curiosity got the better of me yesterday and I decided to pop in and give it a try.  My smoked turkey on rye did not disappoint. It came with a sour pickle and coleslaw, and was wrapped in the wax paper I remember from way back, just as I like it.  I'm looking forward to my next visit to Pickler & Co.

This place is great. I've ordered from here a few times and was so impressed with how good everything I tried was via delivery that I went to the actual storefront... Which obviously didn't disappoint. Clean. Comfortable. Pleasant staff. What more could you ask for? Oh, good food.... The Rachel was delightful as was the smoked turkey sandwich. And basically anything you put on a pretzel bun. My only complaint is that I don't know exactly how I'm going to get around to trying all their delicious sauce options. So happy to have this little gem as an addition to the neighborhood.

The sandwiches here are excellent! So far I've tried the Reuben and the Nicoise Kaiser and both were quite good.  It can get crowded, but don't lose hope, the line moves super fast. Also nice that your order comes with your choice of pickle (half sour, spicy, horseradish, etc.) and coleslaw (mayo - the BEST, vinegar, or spicy)
My favorite sandwich place in Midtown and my go-to lunch spot.  I love their broccoli sandwich subbed with avocados. They have decent coffee as well. Lots of sandwich options to choose from.

Excellent food! Good service. The best turkey club wrap I have ever had--dare I say, I'm addicted to this sandwich now. Good pickles too! Reasonably priced. I couldn't ask more from a local lunch place.

(As a college student of the school adjoined to Pickler & Co. by a window (MUCH better than the last cafe that was there) Since day 1 of opening they've had it all -AMAZING customer service -ALWAYS great food and drinks -NEVER a disappointment  I am so thankful they came to be, and now I always have somewhere to get the most delicious CHEDDAR SCALLION SCONE and iced black and blueberry tea.  Seriously, if you have time for lunch you need to go. And with a "make your own sandwich" station thats so not basic compared to everywhere else in the area, how could you not.  PITTSBURGH PRIDE (Pickler & Co. Pittsburgh company)

Great new addition to Grand Central lunch area.  The Pickler is fresher, tastier and more competitively priced than neighboring sandwich spots. They have pretzel buns which is very important (I recommend a make-your-own pretzel panini), great soups, gluten free chicken fingers and pickles with every order! I've probably come every week since they opened. There is just so much try and I haven't been disappointed yet.  I do recommend that they consider chopping their salads. Is it just me or it easier to eat a chopped salad? Anyway,  highly recommend!

Just tried Pickler & Co for the first time and had a great experience. Crafted my own sandwich - grilled chicken, avocado and Parmesan on ciabatta. It was delicious and under $10 which is great for the area. Definitely recommend to anyone looking for breakfast or lunch.

Went here for a quick breakfast because it was near my hotel. Service was quick and food was great. Got the breakfast ham, which was excellent -- ham, fried egg, cheese and siracha mayo on a pretzel roll. Would definitely order again.

Great local place that uses high-quality ingredients.  Staff is very attentive and the service is quick for the AM rush. Owner(?) is almost always in the back helping out, which is vital to maintaining the high standards. Great job.

The coffee here is the best in the area. It's a tiny place that you can easily walk by without noticing - but that would be a shame. They have nitro brew coffee and their espresso drinks are stellar. This is my go-to spot for coffee without a doubt.  They are in the process of opening a food section for lunch and I am excited to try it when service starts.

I have been here a couple times because they are signed up with MealPal. I really enjoyed the sandwiches I got (cubano and grilled cheese avocado). Both delicious and the perfect size. I have never spent more than a minute inside because I just pick up my sandwich and leave but the space seems cute, definitely a grab and go type of place. I would highly recommend!

Great, cheaper breakfast option. Good coffee and breakfast sandwiches for less than $10.  I recommend the breakfast BLT (BLT with a fried egg on sourdough).  Fast, friendly service. Emphasis on local ingredients.
Great little shop for lunch or a coffee! Efficient service, great cappuccino and wonderful sandwiches. I work in the building right next to it and it is my favorite spot for lunch!

Extremely overrated and overpriced. This place seems hyped up when the food is mediocre at best. The energy of the place is a little cold and sterile. The menu is overflowing with options but extremely disorganized and hard to read. I watched them put together my "craft your own" tuna sandwich and it was so sloppy and careless, the guy clearly didn't give a damn. I immediately regretted paying 11 bucks for what looked like a five year olds first attempt at sandwich assembly. With such plain, simple ingredients, it tasted way too salty. The iced coffee was gross and watery. Can't believe how high the rating is - what a disappointment! The only saving grace would be the fresh food ingredients and ethical business practices they advertise.

A local gem! Maintaining a strict gluten free diet, I'm spoiled with gluten free bread, wraps, rolls AND chicken fingers at Pickler! Love their avocado toast, bacon egg cheese avocado wrap, chicken tender wrap, or turkey brie fig chutney wrap... but I have a feeling you can't go wrong. Portions are not huge but the food is high quality and you get the satisfaction of supporting a relatively new local business. Now my only challenge is to go to work late enough or get out early enough, as Pickler is unfortunately closed on weekends.  PS my non gluten free friends have enjoyed it as well, including the cold brew coffee!

This place is a rare gem!  I've been a few times with a big group from my office and even though they are crowded, they usually get us in & out with great efficiency. There are daily specials to lure you in, but once inside-you can see chalkboards FULL of great options.  My favorites are the Croque Monseiur and the Tuna Melt. (Although I'm very happy to be wokring my way through the whole menu).  Everyone else in my group has also raved about the sandwiches, never a dud in the bunch. They also have a variety of pickles and sauerkraut which they offer on the honor system to go with your order.
Fast, affordable and yummy. What more can you ask for in NYC?!!! Max's Wrap minus the beets was awesome and Rachel was good too. Not many seats to eat inside but great for carry out.

Just tried this place for lunch, one could not ask for more when it comes to quality, service, and price. Ordered a make my own sandwich which comes with a small side of coleslaw & a pickle - nice touch! All for under 8 bucks which is so rare in Midtown.  I definitely will be back to try different things, the breakfast menu looked awesome as well.
4 stars for the food. 2.5 stars for the decoration. The food is great. However, the internal decoration is outdated and needs quick improvement.
I've tried a few sandwiches here and have yet to be disappointed. Great value, great service, great bread, great pickles! It's my new go-to lunch spot.

Stopped here for the first time with friends when visiting NYC. We came on a Saturday afternoon (an hour before closing), which we were told is one of their slower days. I love the idea that you can build your own sandwiches, especially due to the fact that they have so many options. Unfortunately they were out of grilled chicken at the time, so I went with their roast beef. I'm not a huge fan of roast beef, but it was very delicious. I would definitely recommend coming here whether it be for lunch or for a quick bite to eat. Ordering can be confusing due to their menu board, so be sure to plan out what you want prior to your visit if your in a rush.

So rare to find a great sandwich spot with REALLY good coffee in midtown. On top of that they offer a great gluten free selection at a very reasonable price. I think I might have found my new favorite spot :)

I have so many great things to say about this place, but I will start by saying that they make the best lattes ever. I think I singlehandedly drank half of their cold brew over the summer (which they always had enough of, unlike a certain coffee corporation), and the second it got colder I switched to lattes and I couldn't believe how delicious they were. They brew Counter Culture coffee which I love to no end, and everything is always fresh and clean and everyone is always friendly.

I'll update this if necessary.  My one experience was terrific, and it was with something as simple as a tuna sandwich.  It was very easy on the mayo (which I like), the bread was unusually tasty (especially given the sandwich competition in midtown -- endless bland delis), the wide range of choices for pickles and slaw on the side were most welcome.  Clearly this place it aiming to be a notch better than most of the local competition -- much more interesting menu, much better tasting ingredients, though accordingly a bit more expensive.  I'll definitely be going back to try lots of other items.  [Update.  Continued success.  Had a delicious vegetarian sandwich with avocado, hummos, tomato, probably one or two other things. YUM!]

I am so happy I came across Pickler & Co. It's now a part of my morning routine. I haven't tried much of the items on the menu and I say that I will, but I can't get enough of my usual - breakfast sandwich - ciabatta bread, egg white, provolone and prosciutto. It's just so good. The prices are great for the area, the food is fresh, the staff is kind and it's clean. There aren't too many places in the area where you can build your own sandwiches (with a pretzel roll as a bread option!) for reasonable prices and get quality food. It's easy to miss when walking by but you're in store for a pleasant surprise if you stop in.
They are an open cafe but also linked with my school! They have great chai tea lattes. Also the prices are affordable for being in the city. The service is nice there as well!!

This place has the best salad on the upper east side with the absolute worst service. My God the waiters are so terrible you are usually the only person in the restaurant at any given time and they still find a way to forget about you.  This place with good service and better coffee would be a gold mine.

Don't let the frosted/shady windows fool you! This place is a gem! It is a desperately needed lovely cafe in Sutton Place-- finally an alternative to the tiny/crowded Starbucks down the block.  What I love: - Super friendly service. I am always greeted with smiles, water, and table service. - Eclectic vibe - Delicious food...freshly made to order (the pizzas and spaghetti is amazing) - In house roasted coffee - Wide tea selection - Great place to study, work on the weekends, catch up with friends  My only reservation is that the wifi is weak and goes on and off, which makes the study/work a bit tricky.

My daughter and I checked out this new coffee bar and restaurant in our neighborhood.  We actually usually go to the local diner every Saturday. I am glad we decided to try out this place. I really liked it alot.  Interesting menu.  Great coffee and food! Nice vibe to hang out!  They are still working out the quirks with their service.  But I forgive them for that. I wish them luck as the neighborhood could use a place like this.  Can't wait to go back and try other items on the menu!  BTW I have no relation to the owners, I just really want this place to make it!  Give it a try!!

A truly versatile community cafe and bistro. I've gladly come here for everything from a quick (well-made) coffee, to weekend brunch, to dinner and wine on weeknights. For latter, I highly recommend the fig and basturma pizza.
I tried the Greek salad, it was a fancy Greek salad and delicious! Service was excellent. Def coming here again.

There is a lot of cool and yum coffee shops in the city, but this one is definitely one of a kind! They roast coffee beans in house, so the coffee is as fresh as it gets. They also have pizza, sandwiches, and pasta.  The pizza is freshly made to order with variety of different toppings like pulled beef and lamb.  Try it, you won't regret it!

Excellent!! I tried the chicken wings, the meat balls and the backwood bolognese more than once and absolutely LOVED it! So full of extra flavors! I hope they'll have delivery soon. I've been ordering pick up so far. I wish they would open their doors/ windows to feel more of an outdoor seating, it would have been nice to dine in if they did. Especially since the windows are not clear, so you can't see the outside. Ordering from them again this evening! :)

Been to Prodigy Coffee in the Greenwich Village twice now, once in the summer and now in the impending winter season. It's a nice little cafe with seating with tables and chairs for about 7 parties and a bench outside. The prices are comparable to those most non-commercial coffee shops.  Located near the West 4th Street B,D,A,C station which is convenient. The ventilation is a bit of a crap shoot, issues with AC in the summer. And the actual coffee isn't the greatest. The drip coffee leaves your mouth with a bit of a sour taste which these days is really off putting for me. They do play decent tunes which is a plus.  Place to go in a pinch but nothing special.

Went here to get an iced chai and was a little underwhelmed. Some places really have a rich chai flavor, but this one was much more watered down than I have had from other places around the city. That being said, the staff was friendly and knocked out my drink in record time.
Prices are reasonable ($3 for my small Cafe Au Lait). The place would otherwise be the perfect place to study/work, but it loses a star for no WiFi and another for no bathroom.

Cute little coffee shop with basic options any coffee lover would like: pour over, lattes, baked snacks, etc. They have limited seating and no bathroom so I don't recommend getting too comfortable. Staff is helpful and pleasant.

The smell of coffee drew me into the store but my eyes went straight to the little display they had of sweets from local bakeries. Knowing well I had dinner plans later, I restrained myself and glanced over their drink menu. It was a bit chilly out so I went with an Almond Chai.     My Indian roots couldn't help but get something that was chai with a small hint of almond. It was something hot with a nice fragrant, spicy hint in the milk tea.  I wish they had a few more items on their drinks menu. They make up for it with their revolving specials menu so there's always something new to try. If you're lucky, you might be able to get street parking however the subway might be the way to go. Confused about the Cafe Au Lait or the macchiato? Ask the employee behind the counter! They're a fellow coffee lover and super friendly. After a few hours of doing some work and sipping on hot chai, I made my way to a local bookstore they had around the corner. I can't wait to come back to try their baked goods next time...ideally they'll have donuts by then!

The employees are very nice. I've never had an issue with anyone working there. They always smile and greet you. It's very clean too. The pastries are good too.  I am giving it 3 stars only because I ordered a large black coffee. No milk or sugar. Just plain. Why is the world is that $4.08??? Did you all pick the coffee beans yourself?  I find that to be insanely over priced for a large black coffee.  I probably won't go back for a black coffee but I can go back for a muffin or pastry.

Stopped in pretty quickly for a shot of espresso ($3.25). I was surprisingly sweet and easy to drink during this quick pit stop.  Generally, the space is small, and the tables were filled mostly of friends catching up (vs. people working). During my brief time here, though, I witnessed more people taking something to go, perhaps influenced by the lack of seating in the space.
I was looking for something quick and casual for after lunch kick. Ran into prodify cafe. low key coffee stop with awesome quality cappacino.

Cute place in a great location. Decent amount of seating and good lighting by the window.  Nice selection of pastries-- cookies, loaf bread, muffins, scones. Cappuccino was well done, and had latte art.
Nice place. Good hot chocolate. I'm giving it a low rating because it has no WiFi and no (or limited) outlets where I could plug in my laptop...IN NEW YORK, for goodness' sake!
Amazing Coffee!  We tried their cinnamon babka, pumpkin bread & banana bread - all were excellent! Also their cappuccino & iced tea are both great! Will return!!!
Hands down, the best coffee in The Village. Excellent service and great neighborhood - also love the fact that this is not a chain store

The BEST coffee in all of NYC! Locally roasted by Gotham Coffee and they really know what they're doing. The iced coffee was awesome! You can buy beans to go too. Small space but surprisingly roomy. I love this place!!

Cute little coffee shop. Got a large iced coffee for $3.75 and it was actually large, not a medium disguised as a large.  There's a few tables to hang.  It's a bit more well-lit than most coffee shops.  I like it.
"Sorry, we can't serve you this coffee because it's too fresh."  lol... they get two stars because at least they're in a good location, and they're not-as-fresh coffee was alright.

Coffee and dessert taste good. I would have given 4-5 stars. The service was actually negative 3 stars. This is what happened. My friend order an iced coffee, my cappuccino, and a piece of dessert bread. Everything came out nicely.  Then I sprinkle sugar on my cappuccino and at my first stir, I find a fine, shorter, blond-ish hair (I am asian, not my hair at all) being pulled out of my cappuccino. My friend brought it immediately to the counter. This Asian guy gave an attitude about it. No apology, but an attitude instead!! His exact word was "I'll make you another one" and he seemed annoyed.  We wait. Instead of making my cappuccino so I can drink and eat with my friend together, they keep on making drinks for other customers.  I finally got up and waited right at the coffee pick up area. The same asian guy asks after 3 minutes "can I help you?" I said "I'm just waiting for my cappuccino" he doesn't say anything. And then starts making my drink. He took out the cup and saucer out of the dishwasher-looking thing. I didn't think much of it. The. He hands me my cappuccino. I almost dropped it because the saucer was burning hot. I had to drop it on the counter, grab a piece of napkin and finally brought the cappuccino to my table. He saw all this happening. Didn't say a word. A word of warning was supposed to be there, but there wasn't.  I wanted an apology, and a warning of burning hot cup & saucer, but in return all my friend and I received was the TUDES!  Do NOT appreciate it at all.

Cute little coffee shop with a great cappuccino. Service was fast and the girls were friendly. There was good amount of seating, for being a small place. It was the perfect stop on our rainy day in the city. I love little coffee shops like this!

You get a strong blast of coffee right when you walk in the door. It's a coffee purist kind of place, coffee drinks and just coffee drinks, no seasonings or anything. That's fine, even good, but also good to know. A latte comes in a small cup, so it's not milked down. The cortado came in the same sized cup, with half as much milk, which I suppose is very literally correct, but that seemed a bit too milky. It's small, so not a sitting cafe, more a place to grab a coffee before or after brunch or wandering around the neighborhood.

Always serving up delicious coffee beverages by the coolest and hippest staff. Smiles abound here on weekends, maybe due to the coffee, but, maybe due to the staff!   They actually serve coffee here at a perfect temperature, unlike most places that burn the coffee. I always enjoy coming here, as I have apparently joined the club of fans of Prodigy Coffee.
Incredible babka! Beware though -- this stuff disappears REALLY early in the morning. Don't try the speciality drinks as they are truly sub-par.

Small coffee place, there were available chairs, and tables to sit at and have a nice chat. I didn't have any coffee so I can't speak for that. I'm just glad for the A/C and slight reprieve from the summer heat!  This place was relatively quiet.
Service was quick and easy Customer service means a lot to me and the staff were fabulous ! Not to mention they all looked very young (college students maybe) but I'll be returning
We love Prodigy coffee! The staff is super friendly and the space is homey and cute. Their very generous  and their coffee is the best on carmine. 1,000 stars to you guys!

Best coffee, freshly roasted, never old. Taste notes are really clean. Lovely decor, cozy friendly place. My greatest memories I hold in this place :) This is the small coffee place to make you feel like in the movies!

This is my new coffee spot. Incredibly well made, delicious high quality coffee. I dig the nonsense menu and minimalist style. I usually go for an iced black or a hot pour over - both some of the best in the city. They have a small pastry selection, and I've had the banana bread which is large, moist and tasty. Prices aren't crazy and they take credit and even paypal. The baristas are extremely quick and  friendly as well. Ill never go to sbux again.

I'm losing count of the number of artisan or third wave espresso places opening up in the city.  It's almost de rigueur now.  That's a nice trend as made to order coffee is following a similar trend as wine in it's long history, and craft beers in the last decade also.    Meandering around Soho after my thoroughly relaxing spa treatment, we made our way northward.  Yelp helped steer us towards this spot, as it's rare I get over to Carmine Street.  They pulled a very fine shot for me on my birthday, and we sat and enjoyed the people watching.  Gorgeous day brought people out of the woodwork.

I was very happy to find this place once I finished TAing for an NYU course. I wanted to try something new and definitely didn't want to go to one of the many starbucks near by.  There is actually a decent amount of room in this coffee shop - which can be difficult to come by in NY. So, technically you can bring work, a book, or just hang around with a friend. It looks clean and modern, which is also a plus. The one little complaint I had was that the barista seemed angry with me. I don't think I did anything particularly obnoxious or "dumb." I mostly just asked about their snake bite beverage. To be fair, that was my first and so far only time there, so it's not a good representation of the baristas are.  As hinted at above, I tried their snake bite. This is an espresso with dark chocolate, no milk. I was really excited to find a place that finally served something like this. I generally don't like much milk with my espresso anymore but I will always love dark chocolate. I really enjoyed it and as I said, I was thrilled they served such a drink.  I will definitely be coming here again on days that I TA for NYU. I have to also thank YELP for helping me find this place.

The first thing you'll notice is the smell of the coffee brewing as soon as you walk-in.  Heavenly, isn't it?  After a short wait in line, I ordered a simple iced coffee with skim milk. The service is great and they accept credit card. I know this sounds silly, but for someone who never carries cash, it's a plus.  The coffee tastes as good as it smells, and snag a loyalty card - you know you'll come back again!

Awwwww some coffeee!  The barristo Pat was super nice and it's great to see someone who makes great coffee who has a good attitude.    Try the cortado and sit by the window, and you'll have a good day.

No pics here! The staff was blaming me that they are not welcome competitors and would treat the customers who don't ask for permission of photographing first as the spies. This is my very first time to be blamed by taking pics. And the first staff has asked me what my purpose is. Obviously, the second one didn't hear that and "questioned" my purpose again. Even after telling her I was trying to upload pics onto yelp and personal FB, she started to "teach" me what I should do first with serious face, not chatted with me nicely!!  WOW! It's a store truly fears being involved in competition. What secret will my pics leak ..., someone please "teach" me! I thought I was promoting this shop with my photos. My bad, I'm sorry! I didn't know they wanna be prepared...  This is why a potential customer needs yelp. If a reviewer ask for photographing permission first and tell about his purpose, then every store would know he's going to write a review. The store staff would be consciously prepared when they are aware of this. Accordingly, would other yelpers see the reality of a store when every reviewer does so?  I just wanna ask again, "What would a competitor STEAL from PICTURES of a coffee shop?!" Pictures would leak the taste secret or any receipt?? Come on..., even so, pictures get help more than hurt! The staff is well-trained and thinks she is doing right things. But in fact, she really isn't! She actually hurts the store most...
Had an excellent espresso experience there. Will be returning to try their other drinks..   Yay for @prodigy_coffee Stop in...it will make you happy too :)   #WINNING
Cute little Brooklyn-ish cafe in the West Village. Nice presentation of their coffee drinks and enough seating for a few peeps. Would like to come back to sit down and sip on a drink.

I used to work in the west village and this was my go to coffee spot. I might even go as far to say this is my favorite coffee establishment in NYC. As an avid iced coffee drinker, nothing offends me more than a warm coffee in a plastic cup with like 2 melted ice cubes floating around. That was never a problem here; cubes were always above satisfactory. Also, they are literally ALWAYS quick, which is a big thing for me, and never rude or impolite. The coffee tastes great and so far it has been the only brew I've come across to seemingly contain more caffeine than a Starbucks iced, which is awesome for my addiction. Standing ovation for Prodigy Coffee, I'm just sad I switched jobs and now only have access to midtown coffee chains :-(

I really like this place.. I mean, I've only ever had their coffee and cafe au lait but the service is quick (especially for morning rush), and usually with smiles/not intimidating. The space is small, but I see all kinds of people in there, which is nice. Only 4 stars because I haven't stayed long enough to know what service is really like beyond 5 minutes. Also they take card.  For us Coffee Junkies: Don't expect a bucket of joe for the large. It's probably like 15oz tops (reasonable) but it's pretty strong without a bitter taste... or the need for an extra cup later on. A little bit on the pricier end.. but worth it.

Unfortunately I didn't find this coffee shop as great as reviewers found it. My order was pretty simple, an Americano with a shot of steamed almond milk in it, to go. I had to explain it three times because it wasn't getting through to the person taking my order, and when I eventually got my drink it just tasted like watered down coffee. The location and inside were cool but that's about it.

Yelp lead me right on this one. Every time I visit NYC from California, I spend too much time trying to find coffee places that have great coffee, choices of milk, and no attitude that I like my latte hot (seriously, I've ordered about 2000 lattes by now, so I am not too concerned if it may "burn the sugars" thus I can't have it that way). Prodigy was worth the 35 minute walk from where I was staying, and Allie the owner was accommodating, friendly, and open to talking about coffee and the culture/attitude it can generate. Will definitely go back - good choices, value and tables inside too.
Cute and quaint interior. Quiet, could do some good work here. Nice almond cappuccino!

The Dish: I got the iced coffee here. And like everyone else reviewed, best iced coffee I have had in awhile.  Truthfully, I came here because of my pledge class name - matches the name of this place. But, it's a quick, quaint cafe that I will certainly come back to if given the chance to come back to New York.

Don't remember why exactly I stopped in at this brand-new store, just another small Greenwich Village coffee place. Kind of odd, since it's right next door to the just-closed Grey Dog, which was a big coffee deal in its day.  But it was nice, big open window on the sidewalk, 6 or 7 solid caf̩ tables, really friendly service--and SPECTACULAR cappuccino! You can almost taste the beans still roasting away in the cup.  So sweet and heavenly and substantial. RIch taste. The best ever! And I've tried most in the neighborhood.  Damn you, Prodigy, I can't _stand_ Starbucks anymore. You've ruined me for anything less.

Stopped by for a caffeine fix and something chocolatey.  Had a coffee au lait with 2% milk and hubby had an Americano along with a slice of some chocolately bundt cake-like treat.  Coffee good, not great; cake was pretty good.  Small place with limited seating.

Note: This is only a review of the atmosphere and the tea selection.  I saw this new coffee shop near my office earlier this week and went in hoping to finally find some chai in a coffee shop that I want to sit in, read, relax. They do not have chai and their tea selection is minimal. Understandably, they just opened so this may change but as of right now, I'm completely underwhelmed.  The atmosphere is relaxing but it seems too raw for me, it doesn't feel comfortable. I would compare it to the Vincent van Gogh painting of the chair. There was no music playing.  Something about this place just rubbed me the wrong way. However, apparently the other reviewers like the coffee, I just can't speak to that.
