Pretty good, more expensive for an espresso then Joes or Gimme at 2.75, and I didn't see a frequent buyer card, but it's still a good little coffee shop here in the West Village ! ;-)
I really like this coffee shop. The only problem is it is small in both space and in sizes. I love that they have non-dairy creamer options. If only they had more seating...
I got a green tea here.  This place closes a bit early, but it's a cute coffee shop that's nice and clean.  My boo got their coffee.  Not much else to say, but they were friendly!

On our way out of the city to go to a wedding in Jersey, we needed a BFFship of espresso and milk in our mouths, so we pulled over and this place happened to be the nearest spot. not too salty of a decision! we both got a cappuccino and enjoyed every smooth sip. my friend's heart is still feeling the emptiness of her cup days later. the space is small and narrow, but atmosphere is still nice.

My favorite coffee spot in the West Village. Such good coffee, friendly service, a warm atmostphere and tasty treats. Their specialty drinks-the Undertow and Snake Bite-are fantastic too and you'll only find them here.
Probably the best coffee in the West Village area. Service is a bit ambivalent, but I'm happy to have an option other than Starbucks.
Great coffee. Try the prodigy espresso and the snakebite. The babka is delicious and the owner charming and interesting.

What a lovely little coffee shop. Nice waitstaff, unpretentious, cute, a few tables with perfect people watching placement. The coffee and lattes are both great, full of flavor and delicious. I only wish it were in my neighborhood so I could come more frequently.
Excellent coffe and decor. Service is friendly. Just beware that they lack a restroom for customers and there is no WiFi.

Got a large regular coffee here and wasn't too impressed. With hipster baristas (there is even an Asian hipster guy working here too lol) The coffee had an acid taste and wasn't really strong at all. At $3, I thought it was pretty expensive for being a regular drip coffee and not even an Americano I can get at Third Rail for $2.75. They have a few small tables at the store. Nothing really stood out, kinda boring for a coffee shop with not much going on or to even look at
Super cozy place, good coffee, excellent and more importantly home-y and friendly service. This is a place I would come back to just to be "a regular".
Wonderful addition the hood. Excellent coffee and treats. And the owner and staff have created a welcoming vibe. I became become a regular and a fan in just a view days.

A damn fine cup of coffee, and definitely try the babka: it's incredible. So sweet and buttery while magically not being too heavy. The space if pretty sparse, and their offerings are limited to pretty much just coffee, but the lack of non-coffee distractions helps them brew a great cup and makes you really appreciate it. The service is also incredibly friendly.

I tried it today for the first time. The coffee was excellent! Great addition to the neighborhood. Its a bright, cheery ambiance. The music playing was pleasant and the service was great. I will definitely be back for another iced latte!
Great coffee. Their latte is one of the best I've ever had!

Love this place, great addition to the neighborhood! Great coffee and super friendly baristas. Narrow selection of pastries but they seem well selected. Bright space, unpretentious, very clean, good vibe.

I finally got a chance to stop into Ramini since I've been on a hunt to try chai tea lattes all over the city. The place is small. The crowd when I went around 7:30 wasn't bad.  Customer service wasn't that friendly seemed more focus on getting people in and out. I get that. The drink I tried however I didn't like. The chai was not good to me and I think priced a little higher than other coffee spots in the area.  It was interesting to try but I won't be back...

I liked this cafe, but had a really odd experience. I wanted tea but as one knows, the office is freezing in the summer and didn't want to have ice in it. The man behind the counter was nice, but said if he filled the cup all the way it would be an extra $2. I understand how ice does take up volume in a cup, but $2 ?!? It was almost as expensive as the tea itself.  I tried the almond flour vegan (I think ?) matcha cookie as well and enjoyed it. It was crumbly, yet still moist and not too sweet. I would think about coming back if I were in the area, but would probably go to other places with more reasonable conditions first.

Came in here on the run to a meeting. The coffee was pretty good and the service was nice. I was terribly impressed with the coffee and the latte was sorely lacking the good creme on top. I did not taste the food, but did see some people sitting with some food. There isn't a lot of space but it does seem like a convenient place to sit.

Nice coffee shop. It's pretty small, and when I got there around 10 am it was already packed. So don't plan on sitting in. I got their mocha latte, definitely tastes like a hot chocolate coffee. Good place to grab coffee and go

8th avenue in city can be a bit of a culinary wasteland so when Ramini opened my fingers were crossed. There is OK coffee in the neighborhood with Starbucks and Guy and Gallard but nothing that hits the high bar. Ramini hits that high bar, it is delicious, professional and nice. And to top it off the baked goods are excellent: cookies and sea salt brownies were amazing. if you're in the area, definitely worth the visit over those corporate coffee shops.
Best flat white in New York City. Great Matcha as well and nice nite size treats. A gem of a coffee shop in the garment district.

Stopped by here walking around the area after looking for a good coffee shop. Had their Iced Coffee and was very impressed, perfect amount of creaminess and not too bitter. Really wanted to try the Kyoto but they were sold out. Will definitely be back to try that one

This place is a godsend since it's the only respectable coffee joint in the area. It's a coffee desert in Midtown West, man.  Anyway, the space is small (only two or three tables), but that's to make room for all the equipment and food (just some light stuff).  Good cappucino, but I've also tried their Japanese style cold brew and wasn't too impressed.  If you're into coffee, definitely check them out!
Perfectly made shot of espresso. Served with still water. Small pastry selection but homemade chia pudding.

Did not disappoint!  What a wonderful spot!  Ramini Espresso Bar & Cafe is a hidden coffee gem in Midtown West.  The coffee, price, and the service here is simply OUTSTANDING. I heard the hype about the place...  Low-key, comfortable atmosphere, dazzling yet not overwhelming in decor. I was pleased by the people and the taste of coffee here. The prices are super moderate as well. I had the best cappuccino here, it was super delish, it was fragrant and very well brewed. The macarons are awesome too.  Great staff - everyone was so nice & helpful.  Go try it!

(3.5 stars) Few seats but great layout for getting work done. Drip coffee is crazy hot but good once it cools, and I believe they use stumptown beans. There is no bathroom though so just be prepared if you plan on getting situated for a while.
Americano was one of the best I've ever had. Good music, easy place to sit and sip and kill a few hours.

2 weekends ago, I traveled to New York for fun w/ friends. We were walking around 8th avenue and exploring West Village. We wanted to get a quick snack or drink. One of the girls wanted coffee bc we have been up since 7am exploring this city. We came across Rebel Coffee and checked on YELP to see if it was good. Since it had many good reviews, we decided to try it!  After entering, this  coffee shop reminded me of Starbucks, but more relaxing and home-y.  It is definitely more quiet compared to Starbucks! So, if you need a new place study... this could be the place to do so. The decor of the place is very modern too. The workers were really friendly and nice; good customer service.  I ordered a Macchiato and that was good!!! I am not a big expert when it comes to coffee, but it tasted good to me. My friends also ordered latte, hot chocolate, and mocha. They all said that their drinks were good too! All the drinks were under $5, so the pricing is really reasonable too.  I would def. come back here if I'm  in the area again!

Over summer, I was at NY for a couple days before flying out to Europe, so I did a bit of exploring. My friends decided to show me around and raved about this coffee shop. When they took me there, I could see why: the atmosphere  of this place, aroma of the coffee, and decor of the shop. I had a really good time sitting there hanging out with my friends. Compared to most LA shops, which are loud and hectic, this place was the complete opposite. I would definitely recommend checking out this location!

Love this new coffee shop in the west village. I'm a serious espresso drinker and their lattes are incredibly smooth, creamy, and perfectly finished with some latte art. Amazing enough, they also serve underwest donuts!! I've been meaning to make the trip all the way up there, but it's in such an inconvenient location for me - and now I don't have to! They're super delicious and definitely worth getting one. The environment is pretty hipster with seating so it's great place to relax while enjoying some really great coffee and doughnuts. Going to be my new go-to coffee spot in this charming little neighborhood.

My wife and I dropped into this new coffee shop by chance, en route to breakfast at Cafe Clancy.  We are serious coffee drinkers.  We both had an almond milk latte.  The coffee was absolutely superb.  The charming barista, Vivian, told us it was roasted in Maine.    The shop is laid back and very comfortable.  A great place to have a quiet conversation.  But it is the quality of the coffee (and the service) that made it so special.  We will definitely be back.

Launched in late-2017 and recently making noise by way of a pending collaboration with Michael Laiskonis it was on Christmas Eve that R̩colte was visited, the Upper West Side space not yet busy having unlocked doors just minutes prior but shelves and racks nonetheless packed with Pastries both familiar and unique.  Owned by Allen Wang of Kung Fu Tea, and designed by Pastry Chef Peng-Chieh Wang, R̩colte offers items built on classic French technique with nod to the East, the use of Japanese Flour one part of the formula but items featuring Yuzu, Matcha and Mandarin also rotating through the lineup based on season.  French for "harvest," a bounty of Breads featuring various types of Grain dominating the right half of 300 Amsterdam Avenue while Desserts reside left, it was progressing down the line that six items were selected to the tally of $20, first bites of an item labeled "Maple Lover" finding the Viennoiserie well laminated but not particularly sweet and a bit soft on the exterior while an Almond Croissant was more crisp thanks to baked Frangipane on the surface that was thankfully absent within.  Onward next to Kouign Amann, Wang's version leavened longer than most and thus tall but light with crisp layers throughout, it was on the recommendation of a staff member that "Caramel Sweetie" followed, the texture akin to Bread Pudding baked like a Drop Biscuit while Canele were hit and miss, the Dark Chocolate version surprisingly perfect in terms of structure despite a lot of Cocoa while a more traditional version had seen Custard set oddly to create a dense and gummy center.

I admit that I was expecting more from this place given some reviews I've seen. It's not bad but my items weren't as good as I hoped they would be.  Points for having some interesting drink options in their cold case, free wifi, some outlets, and decent amount of seating.  The cashier skipped over me even though I had clearly been standing in the line less than 3 feet from her. And she was out of it and not listening because I had to keep saying I wanted some items to go and needed a bag.  As for the food: Elderflower Lemon Tart - looked pretty enough but didn't really taste elderflower. It was just a lemon tart and the lemon curd was good. The tart shell was hard though and I thought the plastic fork was going to break. Metal utensils would be better or a softer tart shell.  Croissant - There was a sign posted about their croissant being rated as "the best" or something like that, but I don't remember who gave them that designation. The croissant was just ok. I would have liked more airiness like croissants at other bakeries that I prefer.  Matcha Brioche - I was hoping there was some kind of matcha filling inside but there wasn't. There was a little matcha mixed the brioche bun, but mostly the matcha was the cookie coating (their description) on the top. The brioche was ok but boring, and the matcha coating on top was the best part.

Came here for those pretty pastries and baguettes the store is popular for. Coffee shop is big spacious and clean with plenty of room for seatings to work or just chill. Ordered at the front counter asked the clerk what's the most popular cakes that customers ordered and he recommended the Chocolate hazelnut Yazhu cake. For some reason I didn't take that recommendation and decided on the Pistacho with orange zest Yazhu cake instead. The pastry cake didn't taste as fresh and creamy as I would've hoped, it just felt flat in my mouth. On the flip side my Mocha Latte tasted really good.

We stopped in for breakfast. And I am so happy we did. I love the idea that you get a tray, waxed paper, and tongs and then pick what you want. That is where it gets difficult. Everything looked and sounded amazing. The puff pastry/croissant choices were rich and flaky and decadent. The breads were so pretty and unique. My favorite might have been the ham and onion pinwheel with sesame seeds. Wow. Th coffees and tea was tasty as well. I had to get a few treats to fly home.

Thankfully this is about a fifteen-minute walk and out of my way - otherwise I'd be here every day!  Savory or sweet - it's ALL delicious.  The four stars, versus five, however, are for the coffee (it's "hit or miss" depending on the barista), and for the customer service (some of the cashiers are quite nice, others fall a little short).

Best pastries on the upper west side. Lighter and fluffier than Orwashers and less sweet too. The chocolate croissants are to die for.  I prefer them to Paris Baguette, although Recolte is also Asian-owned. Levain across the street only has cookies. Orwashers is less refined. The french bakeries are too sweet. This seems to hit the sweet spot.  Downsides? They aren't free.

I've lived in the neighborhood for a while now and have given this place numerous chances but finally after today I had to write a review. CUSTOMER SERVICE is LACKING! Either I along with other customers I have witnessed are ignored or treated RUDELY as if we are inconveniencing those that work there, particularly the register. I have witnessed twice staff even be rude and disregarding of elderly. Today as I waited by the register, when the girl finally turned around she gave a face of disgust/ totally bothered to have to deal with me and customers. Ontop of that they charge $4.50 for hot water and one tea bag and don't have honey for the tea!  The positive is that they have a yummy La Fermiere honey yogurt and good croissants and really delicious apple turnovers! Unfortunately the service keeps me from stopping in as much as I'd like and others on yelp have had very similar things to say and Recolte service doesn't improve regardless.:/

Nice bakery with lots of seats, comfy chairs. I tried honey walnut bread(I'm not supposed to have carbs, obviously I couldn't control myself, anyway) , which is made of Japanese flour, super soft and flavorful. Coffee was great as well.

You can no longer buy a single small maple croissant!!!  They bag them now... what if I only want one, not 4 or 5 or how ever many they put in the bag!  I was so annoyed I walked out and told them they just lost business.  Not everyone has a family or friends they work with that want to share.  Make it available the way it was and I may come back, but to do that is greedy AF and totally unnecessary.  They are obviously good, but that kind of thing is petty business crap and that is why I won't go back.  I can do without the bread in the morning anyway. Annoyed.

WARNING : I saw a RAT in there about an hour ago. Going exactly behing the counter in the area where they sell food. DISGUSTING !!!!   Only one waitress seemed to care about it and the others just rolled their eyes.

We first visited here just after they opened in September 2017 and fell in love with the Croissants and coffee. We have returned to NYC a year later & so happy to see how successful they are winning best croissants in NYC for 2018.  They use Imported French flour and Japanese flour to creat marvelous breads & Bakery items.   The coffee is excellent as well.  Kira, the lovely young lady who waited on us was excellent and makes fantastic lattes.    Wish we lived closer than SF so will have to encourage them to open a branch in the East Bay.

The breads and pastries are wonderful but pricey. What sets Recolte apart from places like Breads Bakery, however, is the TOTAL lack of attention to customers. From the time you walk in to the time you leave no one greets you or thanks you. Even when there is no line to check out, you are left standing there forlornly while staff clean counters, chat or do anything other than actually acknowledging your presence. What's really annoying is that management does this, so it's not surprising that the untrained staff follow their example. Interesting that this Asian-run business seems so clueless. I'm Asian and have never seen this lack of customer service in Seoul, Tokyo, Beijing.

While visiting NY I stopped in this cafe to warm up and have some coffee. The selection of pastries and bread is great and looked like it would be delicious but was just so-so. The coffee was fine. But the servers were very unfriendly and rude. I asked if they had soy milk and the cashier said yes, which was nice. But then after my turn the woman who ordered before me (who had an accent) came up and said she had asked for soy also and they told her no. When she asked if they could change hers the woman making the drinks very aggressively said no I'm not making that again. And got angry with this woman for not saying anything sooner, when clearly it was not her fault at all. Then after I finished I was unsure whether I was supposed to clean up my tray or leave it since I didn't see anywhere to put the tray. As they were busy I decided to leave, and one of the workers angrily came up to me and and shoved the tray in my face and very angrily told me to throw it away and where to leave the tray as if it were totally obvious. I can understand that to workers who do this everyday its obvious and annoying. But try to understand that I didn't know, and I felt attacked for making a mistake. Attacked and uncomfortable is is how this cafe made me feel.

I heard that they soft opened this morning. Pain au chocholate and caramel covered bread, kouign comnn are super amazing and they offer a wide variety of french bread. Most of all, all bread are made of french flour. Latte was so nice as well. I think that the coffee machine that they have is the newest one ;)

As I've found with many places especially on the Upper West Side this is over rated and over priced.  Wanted to like but my whole family just didn't feel the desserts were worth the price.  They tasted fine.  Refrigerated desserts run $4.50-$7 but they're TINY sizes!  Had cheesecake, profiterole cup, chocolate paradise, and tiramisu cup.  Boxed in plain unmarked brown boxes with no label sticker.  Better value and comparable choices available near by.

SOMEONE NEEDS TO SAY IT! So, why not me. As much as I love coming here and getting there lavender or rose latte ..just realized that the barista on occasion becomes the cashier. When that happens she will touch that screen full of bacteria and then swipe your card. Then proceed to make your order which is fine up to this point BUT once she goes to put her hand inside the glass jugs to put lavender or rose petals it's a health hazard AND flat out *disgusting. - That glass jug overtime gets added bacteria each time she places her hand inside. She's basically sprinkling partial bacteria on your drink. - I also noticed that if you order to stay those mugs or cups are being washed with a rag...that's very likely full of bacteria. I ordered once to stay and avoided it going forward. If you have a business of food or serving beverages *invest in a industrial dishwasher. It will save you washing time etc. - Lastly, those baked goods look unappetizing and stale. I once got a croissant and it was hard/ chew definitely not fresh. So, I never got anything baked item again.

Doubling as a cafe and florist, Remi is a fresh change from all the dingy and minimalist coffee shops around NYC.  But I find that it's somewhat a case of the platypus: multiple functions, none of which it's quite an expert at. I've come here to do work, which was short-lived without any outlets; I've come here to buy flowers, which was cumbersome with sitting customers to maneuver around and a staff member who didn't know much about the products and repeatedly had to go back and forth asking a coworker for quotes.  On the other hand, the lattes and the art atop them were just lovely. I'd also be willing to rank this place in the 95th percentile in terms of variety of milk alternatives (who knew macadamias had nipples?!?)  The end result at Remi is notably good -- but I'll probably be back for a coffee date rather than a study session or bouquet hunt.

I came here because my friend who knows I love Instagram, coffee, and flowers recommended this establishment. I'm so glad I came because I was not disappointed!  Remi's Flower and Coffee is a smaller coffee shop that has more flowers than it does tables to sit at. But, the coffee is delicious and so creatively made.  I'm not a very big fan of lavender so I ordered the rose latte with almond milk. The owner/my server was very nice and fast with my order. The rose latte was gorgeous and a decent size cup for coffee!  If you want to duck away from the concrete jungle for a few minutes and sip coffee with friends or just on your own- Remi's Flower & Coffee is the place for you.

Our favorite coffee shop during our visit. It doubles as a cute flower shop and their lattes were delish. There's just something about being surrounded by flowers and drinking a hot cup of caffeine on a rainy day.
BEWARE: not a lot of seating so try to come during an off time. Very cute cafe with insta-worthy drinks. The drinks do cost a bit more though! ($5 - $6)

This place is gorgeous. I went to grab a bouquet for my girlfriend's graduation. The florist helped me to pick when i knew nothing about  flowers. She did a great job explaining and wrapping the flowers . After getting the bouquet, I decided to get coffee since I saw a barista do good latte arts. Like my expectations, coffee was as perfect as the bouquet.  Thanks guys, my girl likes it a lot. She said she felt so special bc it was not like from Deli     It was the most beautiful bouquet in her graduation.

What a gem in Midtown! I was attending a conference nearby and came here for an afternoon matcha break. The matcha was excellent but even more of a delight was the lovely floral arrangements inside the caf̩. So very pretty!

Stopped by here as I've been in search of some special succulents, but found myself pleasantly surprised by everything else as well. The shop has an immediate cozy feeling, and had many other plants and flowers which caught my eye as well. I also ended up trying the Yuzu iced tea which was a perfect amount of sweet to still allow the Yuzu juice to shine through, and ultimately made for an extremely refreshing drink on such a warm day.  Overall, would highly recommend this place whether you're looking for some new decor for your house, or if you're looking for a cool place to hang out and grab a quick drink

One of the most beautiful cafes I have ever gone to! It has 2 of my most favorite things combined, coffee and flowers! Fresh and lively atmosphere, the staff and baristas are super friendly and the florist knows what she's doing! The coffee is exquisite! Had 2 of the specialty ones, Rose and Lavender Lattes with oat mylk! Amazing! It can get crowded and not a lot of seating is available but thats the case with all of the best cafes! I enjoyed my experience here very much! Also the lighting here for pics is awesome! Very instagrammable!

Unfortunately, I had what might be an unusual experience here, considering the positive reviews.  But this was my experience:  My macchiato was made with an overly sweetened oat milk that made it unpleasant; my wife's whole milk macchiato had a grainy texture; the characterless bro rock soundtrack played at an ample volume; and when I asked how the "House Special" flavored ciders were made, I was told, "from a pre-mix."    I'd actually been really excited to try this place, knowing of its connection to The Little Marionette.  But it was a letdown.

I took a very specific long walk to visit Saltwater. I mean....How many overall 5 star reviews do you see of a place with over 100 reviews?  I LOVE coffee. Not "sweet coffee type" drinks. Just strong black coffee (no sugar please). I admit I am a Starbucks bold guy (and any coffee in Italy or Palio Cafe at the Bellagio in Vegas).  I walked into Saltwater and was a bit surprised by how small it was. I mean smaller than my apartment small.  In fact, when I walked up to the counter to order, it looked like an apartment kitchen. That being said, the staff was welcoming and pleasant. There were a couple of people in line in front of me who were ordering the real crazy, creative "coffee type" drinks. Since I didn't want a maple, mocha, Chai, cold brew, Matcha, purple, latte with foam on top, I was kind of embarrassed ;) I asked how bold their drip coffee was and they let me sample it, which I appreciate. That's all I had - a small black coffee. It was very good. Not the best ever but very good.  Bottom line: I wouldn't go out of my way, and take another long walk to Saltwater just to get a cup of coffee, but if I'm in the area, I'd probably stop by. If you are into the very crazy "coffee type" drinks (coffee and tea), I would stop by Saltwater at least once. That seems to be their specialty. Just remember -  you're not in your apartment, you're in theirs!!

We love this spot in the East Village. It's full of light and has the perfect amount of seating for both working (there are outlets!) and enjoying coffee with friends.  The latte was delicious and presented in a tall glass on a beautiful ceramic plate. We definitely recommend this spot!

I love this coffee shop! The atmosphere is very relaxing and well-lit, and the service is lovely. The chai masala latte I got was delicious and didn't taste too sweet, which is usually a problem for most chai lattes I've had (not to mention the beautiful colors of their drinks!). I would definitely come again to sit and do work, and try the matcha or turmeric lattes.

Cozy, hip aussie coffee place with small tables and wifi. Generally good espresso drinks (personal fav was the oat milk latte) and sometimes offers specialty drinks too. One big downside is a lack of bathrooms anywhere near by.

Definitely get their flat white.  It's bold and has a great flavor profile such that it's not too bitter and not too milky.  For what it's worth, I usually drink my coffee black with no sugar or milk.
This place is amazing. Guys who work there are always very friendly and want to make sure you enjoy your coffee.

Really cool coffee shop near the grounds of East Village. Had a coffee which was good! Aussies really do know how to make a good one. Overall vibe of the place was nice and cosy. Friendly staff aswell. Would recommend.

cafe_name: Sant Ambroeus Coffee Bar at Loews Regency Hotel
review: Service wasn't too good, unfriendly. Alittle bit rude to tourist. Coffee is $5+ , but is good coffee.

cafe_name: Sant Ambroeus Coffee Bar at Loews Regency Hotel
review: This is one of our favourite places for breakfast.  They have outdoor seating, no seats inside but there are tables to stand at.  The coffee is very good, they have several good choices for breakfast; fruit, yoghurt with fruit and crunchy stuff and croissants with salmon. They also have plain croissants and different kinds of pastry.  My favourites are the yoghurt and the croissants with salmon. Fresh and delicious.  We also tried some of their sandwiches for lunch, they are really good too. My favourite was the panini with ham and cheese.  I also saw that they sold ice cream in the afternoon, unfortunately I didn't taste it. So much food, so little time :-)  The staff is very friendly and the service is fast. Perfect for a quick breakfast or just a cup of coffee.

cafe_name: Sant Ambroeus Coffee Bar at Loews Regency Hotel
review: Quick, Helpful, DELISH! A little pricey for pastries, but a nice treat indeed :)

Since I was already nearby, I decided to stop by to grab some treats.  I got the funfetti and maple bacon cookie. The cookies were good but nothing impressive. I wouldn't suggest going out of the way for this bakery but it's a nice snack option if you're already in the area.

Begun as an online business in 2011 and moved to a 45h Street Brick and Mortar location by 2015 it is from Nebraska-born Zachary Schmahl that Schmackary's came to New York, the idea to bake Cookies just down the street from Levain intrepid but still paying off over three years later even as other places such have Chip have recently entered the market.  Eponymous for Schmahl's nickname and homey from day one, a small seating area with newspapers just left of the counter lined in Cookies, Muffins, Scones and more, it is immediately on entry that guests are welcomed by tantalizing smells and pleasant service while prices trend lower than average for The Big Apple.  Offering a rotating selection of flavors beginning at 8am daily, the Christmas Holiday yielding two seasonal specials, it was after some debate that six of thirteen Cookies were selected in addition to one Coffee Cake, all of them still warm to touch and the latter moist yet dainty in the form of a Muffin with ribbons of Cinnamon-Sugar and caramelized Pecans adding crunch.  Cozy and surprisingly busy just thirty minutes after opening, many grabbing items to go but some choosing to linger over Coffee, it was progressing left to right from a box that Cookies kicked off with Red Velvet, the crispy edge and soft center textbook while White Chocolate Chips and rustic Cream Cheese Frosting helped balance the Cocoa.  Moving next to Bacon Chocolate Chip and then Mexican Hot Chocolate, both texturally similar from edge-to-center and the former quite salty, it was by way of "Dirty Peppermint" that Cayenne was countered before moving on to a glazed Ginngersnap, the use of Black Pepper to magnify Cloves and Ginger frankly brilliant while the Super "C" selected by an 11-year-old punched also punched above its weight-class thanks to granules of Sea Salt on top.
The go to place in the area when I need to satisfy my "extreme" sweet tooth. Cookies are bit pricey but their size makes up for that.

Although Levain and Chip cookies will always reign supreme in my book, I've decided I should be a little open-minded to other cookies. You never know when a dark horse enters the race. I think if I preferred slightly crispier cookies over softer, denser ones, I'd be going to Schmackary's every weekend to carbo-load on the cookie deals they have.  On our first visit, they had a basket of slightly stale cookies in a basket. I think it was 2 cookies for $5 and the variety was pretty impressive. The guy behind the counter was incredibly jovial - he insisted on a fist bump from me and my fianc̩, and said something friendly to every customer. I suppose being in such close proximity to cookies all day will do that to you.  Here are the cookies I've tried: Graceland - PB, banana, and bacon. I thought this was a tad too sugary and the combo of pretty strong ingredients made it really rich to eat in one go.  Classic chocolate chip with sea salt - Delicious. Appreciated they went a little stronger with the salt than most places, as it provided a good balance to the chocolate.  Oatmeal cranberry raisin with some kind of icing - By far the best of the three. I'm usually not a fan of oatmeal raisin as the lesser brother to good old chocolate chip but this version was actually better.  They also have coffee and tea to go with the cookies. Not too much space inside but if you take your cookie to go and munch on it down the street, I guarantee you'll have more than one person enviously eying that cookie.

Schmackary's is easily one of my top 3 cookie spots in NYC. The service is always friendly, but the line can get insanely long. There's also limited seating, so I'd take these over to gotham market or city kitchen to enjoy these cookies.  The cookies here are pretty close to what you would consider your stereotypical cookies. Chewy but not doughy cookies in the shape of a tradition cookie flavor. My favorite thing about this place is the creative cookie flavors that actually work most 80% of the time. While some of these may be seasonal, my favorites include:  classic chocolate chip, choconut chip, anything pumpkin flavored, and red velvet.  My only complaint here is the line, and especially the way the line system works, which is a fucking nightmare. You have to try to squeeze into this tiny door with people constantly coming in and out and yelling excuse me, and there isn't a well-defined way to stand either once you're inside, so all these tourists look confused and lost most of the time.

Great and friendly staff!  Love the location and the environment!  The cookies are great!  I couldn't choose between two and after I chose two the guy through in the other for free!  Great service especially because the one I chose wasn't nearly as good as the one he gave me for free!  I chose the cookies and creme and he gave the chocolate monster which was so soft and amazing!  Highly recommend!  Also a bottle of milk to be cliche.  My wife got the cinnamon one.  She gave it 4 stars and it was just so much cookie for her she couldn't finish the cinnamon swirls were a bit much to her.    The apple cider was sooooo good!  Had a nice creamy taste to it!  Nicely done!

If I lived anywhere near Schmackary's, I would weigh 500 pounds. That is just how good this place is.  A near-perfect trifecta of tasty treats, fantastic coffee, and incredibly friendly staff combine to make this a destination on the west side, near west side, or anywhere in the general area, really.  The cookie options change frequently so there's often something new to try, as well. This is one for my Must Visit list on future trips to New York!
Probably one of the best cookies I've ever had. I got the hummingbird which was hands down my favorite and I also got the cookies and cream. Cute spot!

Schmackary's is a cookie and coffee joint. I came here while walking by here with my gf. Their cookies are fantastic! They have a several dozen or so flavors that rotate per day, combining various cookie base types, toppings, and frostings. Prices are slightly expensive, around 2.75$/cookie. These are the best cookies I've had in a while, and I would definitely go out of my way to come here.  The venue is pretty small, maybe sitting 7-8 people. There was a substantial queue when I got my cookies. Service is fast and pleasant.  Ordered: Birthday party - vanilla sugar cookie base, sprinkles, oreo bits, cream cheese Funfetti - sugar confetti cookie base, cream cheese frosting + sprinkles Smores - graham cracker cookie base, chocolate, marshmello frosting Apple crisps - oatmeal base, apple crisps, salted caramel and cinnamon mixed in

The best cookies in town, since you know there is always a line. I have been a few times over the last month and love trying a new flavor each time.  The store front is so cute and there are a few counters to sit at. Grab a cookie and walk on or grab a seat on the bench outside. The staff are super friendly and always know which to recommend first!  The frosting makes each cookie special, yummy, and the perfect mid day treat!

The corn cookie is a great balance between sweet and savory, definitely not cloying. Nice little nubbins of corn in the mix  The black and tan was better balanced than I expected. The cookie has some real nice cocoa depth which is complimented by the sweetness of the icing. The icing does have some Guinness flavor but is quite sweet.

I came here on a weekday afternoon and it was a quick and easy in and out. I got the 2 cookies for $5 deal which included tax.  // Red Velvet I'm a big fan of red velvet and was pretty disappointed with their red velvet cookie. It tastes like double chocolate, a chocolate cookie with chocolate chips. Don't get me wrong, it was delicious, but it didn't taste like red velvet. The icing wasn't cream-cheesy either.  // Oatmeal Scotch This cookie was amazing! I would happily order more of these! I love oatmeal cookies and oatmeal with butterscotch is a great combo and they executed beautifully.  Both cookies were impressively soft. I ate half of each cookie when I got them and the next morning, the other halves hadn't dried out and were just as delicious. I look forward to trying other cookies when I get the craving. The pistachio and maple bacon ones caught my eye, so hopefully they'll be around to get next.

Long time since my last Schmackary's visit, so I went a little overboard and purchased a four cookies.  Today's Schmackary's menu included two cookies which caught my attention in the Almond Roca and Candied Yam. In addition, right along the display case, is a small bin containing day-old cookies from which I picked a pair of day-old Pumpkin Spice cookies.  Almond Roca (4/5): This cookie lived up to it's namesake as it really tasted like an Almond Roca. Especially reminiscent were the crunch of the Almonds and the buttery sweetness from the Toffee. The laced chocolate drizzle on top just completed the cookie's spot on translation.  Candied Yam: (1/5): This cookie's list of ingredients was so interesting and sounded like a winning combination, but upon my first bite I knew this wasn't to my liking. There was an immediate chewy texture akin to a preserved apricot, which I think were the yams. For me this ruined the rest of the cookie which was pretty pedestrian in flavor with very nondescript cinnamon and brown sugar flavors. Toasted Marshmallow topping was okay, but just made it a bit messy to eat. I ate about 1/4 of the cookie, and the remainder went into the trash.  Pumpkin Spice (3/5): One of this cookie's ingredients is mysteriously labeled "Autumnal Spices", and even through the clear plastic wrapping, the smell of this cookie was so strong. This smell translated to its taste which had just a good amount of Pumpkin flavor and a nice amount of cinnamon chips which continued the seasonal flavors of this cookie. The Maple cream cheese frosting laced on top was ok too. Pretty good cookie.

Very good cookies, with real frosting! And the staff is awesome and super helpful/friendly. Shoutout to the dude with the Vietnam shirt, he was great.  We tried the holiday funfetti, cookies and cream (fudgy, almost like a brownie! And the frosting tastes just like Oreo cream), sweet corn, and the peanut butter flavors. All great, but the Cookies and Cream was my favorite.  Definitely give it a try!

I wanted a dessert one night so I ventured here. They were out of several items, like the rice krispies, but I was able to order 4 cookies. The cookies are big and I liked three of the four.  The maple bacon cookie was not what I was expecting and this flavor combination works much better in a donut. It had either too much baking powder or soda, which gave it a slightly salty flavor. It also had a strange aftertaste.  The cookies and cream tasted like a brownie, in a good way. The caramel apple crisp was really good. The cereal killer was weird but good.  I would definitely revisit, but I'd personally much rather eat a slice of strawberry cheesecake.

Decadent delicious post dinner dessert! We had the S'more cookie which was soft and melts right in your mouth. The cookies and cream was also a major success. Too bad did not come with more people to justify getting more cookies, but would love to try other flavors next time I visit!
Really great cookies and worth a visit to try some great treats!  They also have proper coffee/espresso available as well.
had my hubs stop here on the way home from work and soooooooooo good. I'll be sending him for cookies more often :) and I'll have to come here once I'm in the city to try a shake mmmm.

My coworker brought a box of these cookies to the office and offered me one.  I am usually the one person who never accepts pastries because I'm not a sweets guy......  Yea, well these cookies are easily the most delicious cookies I have ever had.  I got the confetti cookie and one bite was all it took.  I had to look around afterwards to make sure no one was looking at my face because I probably looked very confused.    I feel bad for anyone who brings a box in our office because I can guarantee I will chase them down.

Worth the wait! We waited about 20 minutes outside before it was our turn to order. The cookies are expensive but a decent size that makes it worth the price. They were constantly refreshing the plates with more cookies that were covered in delicious new icing. Great variety and warm! Greasy though so make sure you get plenty of napkins!

Freshly made cookies every day! They have some interesting flavors. I got 12 cookies for $24, but was it worth it? Not really.  Some of their flavors were overly sweet and salty.  Their cookies are quite large.  About the size of a complete cookie. Their chocolate chip flavor is different in which they add salt.  Great customer service, very fast paced so make sure you know what you want to order.

Nom Nom Nom. Me want cookies. Me want all the cookies!! At $2.75 a pop, the variety of cookies they offer sure is worth a try. I've had their red velvet cookie and the cookie dough cookie. Both were delicious. Soft with a slight chew to the bite and the flavors were packed with deliciousness, with a hint of salt on it which complemented the sweetness perfectly. This place offers a variety of both common and unique flavors so it makes the decision of which to choose hard but the ability to eat very easy.

I absolutely love this place! Every day they have new cookies! You come in thinking you're just only going to get one and you end up walking out with a dozen! The staff is very nice and patient while you pick so there's no pressure. When a flavor runs out, they're already bringing in a fresh batch. Just be ready for the line that is usually out the door but totally worth it!

I was greeted at Schmackary's with a very large (older???) crowd this past Saturday night around 11pm.  Interesting, old people want cookies and ice cream sandwiches at 11pm.  We got the confetti cookie and oatmeal (with butterscotch chips) and made it into an ice cream sandwich.  It was super, super sweet.  I loved the oatmeal cookie (wish I got both sides as that).  The confetti cookie was just basically a sugar cookie - nothing special and it has frosting on it, adding to the sugar levels.  Loved the vanilla BEAN (!) ice cream in the middle - though it was a little hard to eat as the ice cream kept oozing out on the sides.  Definitely needs more ice cream in the middle.  Overall, it was a decent after-dinner dessert, but I don't think I would crave it.

My exhausted, sweaty body needed a sugar kick after spending the day walking around time square so I decided to walk over to Schmackary's since it's just a quick jaunt away from my hotel. Yelpers seem to think this place is the cat's pyjamas so I figured it was worth a shot. I enjoy a good cookie but rarely go out of my way to get them.  First of all, the shop is small but nice and clean. It's decorated with a homey hipster vibe and the staff were all young and surprisingly friendly, especially after I spent most of the day discovering how New Yorkers get their reputation. The kid who helped me was kind and cheery.  I decided to grab 6 cookies so I could take a few home to my family (if they make it that far). So far I've only tried the cookies and cream flavor but it was quite tasty. Moist and sweet. Just what I needed as a pick-me-up! I'm not sure it would be worth a long trip out of your way but it is definitely worth a stop in if you're around the area.

Worth the walk.  I love cookies and this place didn't disappoint.  Unique selection of cookies in a welcoming, unique setting.  A nice change from Broadway's mass produced, mass quantity,  mass...  you get it.  Or do you?

Stumbled on this spot while looking for dessert in Hell's Kitchen. Agree with other Yelpers, actually a decent price for a cookie in New York.  Not a huge cookie selection, but there are several different options. The salt they add definitely is a very nice touch. You can also ask for your cookie to be warmed up, which I think is almost a must if you are going to be eating it then.  Great chocolate chip cookies at a reasonable price... right next tons of restaurants.... What more could one ask for...

I was very excited to go to Schmackary's - I've heard a lot of good things about their cookies, even that they are "the best in NYC". I came by on a Friday afternoon. The selection did not sound very appealing for my taste, and so I only picked up two flavors, Chocolate Duet and Caramel Apple Crisp. While I expected to bite into a warm, soft cookie that would melt in my mouth, I bit into a somewhat dry, crunchy (the center was only slightly softer) disappointment.  The flavors were meh as well - the chocolate cookie was too sweet, and apple pieces in oatmeal cookie had no taste at all (where's the delicious tartness of Granny Smith apples?!). Maybe I picked the wrong flavors? Who knows. But I will not be back for a second visit.

You can choose 1/$2.75, 2/$5, 6/$14, or 12/$24. Chose 6 cookie option. Funfetti, Carrot Cake, Choco Chip, Maple Bacon, Cookies n Creme, & Peanut Butter Dark Choco. Best was Funfetti even tho i dont like frosting or sprinkles on my cookies but the cookie itself was so delicious. Very flavorful!  Sprinkles baked into the dough not only sprinkled on top. Preferred to try strawberries n creme but didnt hav it. Also, u can order an ice cream sandwich made with any two cookies for $6.25

Only in NYC would there be this type of cookie store that's open most nights until midnight.  If your in the area and feel like something sweet? Fro-you isn't gonna do it. You need a schmack!  I walk into an empty store and tell the girl, well smack me down! (She doesn't smile at my jesting)  I order two cookies for my son and I, The Maple Bacon as well as the Sweet Corn cookie. Now most people would say, really? The most boring flavor in the shop, corn doesn't = dessert and shouldn't be in a cookie!  Hush your mouth!  Corn is something that the American indians have used waaay before we traded them a few blankets for the Island of Manhattan. Are you gonna hate on history?? Besides it sounded different, its made with corn flour / cornmeal, sweet corn and pecans. Sounds like a party to me!  I order a coffee and take a bite of the Maple Bacon cookie. Friggin awesome! Salty, savory and sweet. Makes for a fine and dandy cookie.  The two cookies for $5 bucks is a great deal. Also, don't pass on the coffee. they have a good blend that's roasted locally.  Need a Cookie and Milk fix at 11:37pm? Here's your store. Only in NYC.. 4 Stars to the kid from Lincoln Nebraska

Chocolate duet. I followed fellow Yelpers to this place. A long line didn't deter me...  Twenty minutes later, I had to have a bite. A mouthful of cocoa, chocolate, and butter was overwhelmingly fresh and my taste buds were gleaming with smiles. The melting chocolate, the sugar, the butter along with the crunchiness of the dough...!  I forgot about eating healthy for a moment, but I did walk for about an hour afterwards. Totally worth it.

We came here two times while on vacation and tried different flavors, but the funfetti was definitely my favorite!! We noticed most of the flavors had an interesting salty flavor (as well as the normal sweet cookie taste), which was very interesting and delicious!!

Good for cookies but not for milkshakes. I paid $7 for a small milkshake with a chocolate chip cookie infusion that was more like having cookie chunks with milk (Btw the cookie chuncks were stuck at the bottom and were bigger than the straw) would've bought the cookie for $2.75 and had it with a cup of milk at home.
A good post theater treat! There's always a line, and the cookies are good, not great. Prices are decent for NYC. It is pretty small as well.

I strolled in here 10 minutes before they closed and they had a BOGO promotion. I got the matcha which I didn't like that much. It had a grainy texture to it and Although matcha has a strong taste, that didn't come through in the cookie so it definitely fell below my expectations. I got the dark chocolate walnut cookie for free and I liked it but didn't love it. This too had a graininess to it that was unpleasant but less so than the matcha and it was overall ok.

Don't come after 9:30pm (they close at 11). The employees were in a rush to get home, and weren't ready or willing to serve us anything. The cookies were gone, so we settled for $6 milkshakes...that is, until they told us they weren't willing to serve us, since they were closing in 45 minutes. Complete waist of 20 minutes waiting on line.

Such yummy cookies!!! We were visiting from CA and my daughter had heard of it so we went to give it a try. They had a variety of cookies, traditional flavors and some unique ones. They were delicious! We went back our last morning there and got a dozen to take home.

We went to a Broadway show and needed a sweet treat after we were done. Schmackery's was close and even though it was late we still had a decent variety of cookies to choose from. Really good cookies and worth the stop to satisfy your sweet tooth. I tried the special (marshmallow with lucky charm topping) and it was excellent! Fun options outside of the usual flavors. Looking forward to going back.

YES YES YES YES YES YES YES! Now THIS is a good cookie. I love when bakers put a little extra love into their recipes. It's obvious that Schmackary's is passionate about their cookies. My little sister and I stopped by on a late night run and snagged a half dozen of some pretty eclectic baked goods. Our personal favorite was the seasonal eggnog (there was only one left), but I was pretty blown away by all of the variety of flavors they had to offer. Only downside to all the good? They sell out pretty quickly, and they have a rotating menu. I went back 2 days later to grab an eggnog cookie to take back to my fam in Miami -- and it wasn't on the menu that day. I guess it's procedure...
Went late at night, they had buy one get one!! The cookies were the perfect blend of soft and crunch. The oatmeal cookie was like Nicholas cage, "gone in 60 seconds". Wish they had these down south!!

Prior to my two most recent visits I would have given Schmackary's at least a 4-star review.  On the minus side the lines tend to be long and the store not large enough to accommodate most of the crowd.  However, their Classic (chocolate chip w/ sea salt), Sch'mores, Red Velvet, and Funfetti usually made it worth the wait and crowding.  Sadly, during my two last trips to Schmackary's I left empty-handed after waiting in the line only to find an excess of cookies no one seemed to want (e.g., Maple Bacon, Butterscotch Schmackaroons, and Sweetcorn, etc).  It's nice that they have a large variety of cookies (something Insomnia Cookies has always lacked), but it would be nice if Zachary or the baker would pay attention to what actually sells and bake accordingly.

I followed Yelp's suggestion to come to Schmackary, as part of my mission of finding the best oatmeal raisin cookie in the city. I came here a few times in the morning before going to work, want to try different cookies, I love how they have special flavours on daily basis and if you go in the morning, you can also buy the leftover cookies from the day before at cheaper price.  Customer service is great here and they also do good coffee!
I love Schmackary's.  What else can I say?  Big.  Yummy.  Cookie.  Different Flavors.  Good.
Smores and green tea cookies! Flavors rotate, so check out their website to see what they'll have for the day. I liked the green tea better than the smores, but it didn't blow me away.

Schmackary's is the reason why I had to do extra time on the treadmill this morning!  We found this cookie shop while on the way to eat dinner after taking in Rock of Ages last night. As it is almost brand spanking new I felt it my duty as a Yelper to check it out as our dessert option. I stuck my head in and asked when they closed and was told midnight. Wow - stays open late and it also gave me a reason to cheat on my diet a bit!  They offer a nice little selection of cookie varieties in a few different sizes. From their modern classics, to seasonal sensations, to other baked treats, and even milkshakes this place is a sweet tooth's delight. Coffee, tea, and espresso is also served here. We were drawn to two cookies that we bought and took home to enjoy with some coffee.  Maple Bacon - which is made with candied bacon, maple syrup, toffee bits, and sea salt.  White Chocolate Cherry Chunker - which is made with white chocolate, Montmorency tart cherries, oats, and cinnamon.  Both were the old-fashioned standard size. I have to say that each cookie stood out on it's own with distinct flavors. The Maple Bacon had a smokey taste to it with a tinge of sweetness and saltiness that helped even out the flavor. The first few bites are odd tasting but as it melts in your mouth the bacon flavor comes through in a subtle way. The Cherry Chunker was just filled with big chunks of ingredients. The cherries they use are delicious and juicy, while the white chocolate helped level out the tartness. Both cookies were moist in the middle with a nice harder crust on the edges - just as I like them - and each were totally devour worthy!  Friendly guys working the counter that answered any questions we had. Only a few high tables to sit at so it's really a grab and go spot. Not the cheapest cookies but worth a try as a once in a while treat. Even a gluten free cookie choice on hand.  Good thing this place is well across town from where I live on the east side, as my inner fattie is trying hard to come back out and temptation like this would be hard to deny!
Yummy yummy yummy. I live in Florida and I'm still dreaming about these cookies! Such a cute little hole in the wall place that's so cozy! I cant wait to go back and get more cookies!

Small store with unique cookies. Not the best place to hang out. Can get crowded easily. All of the cookies were soft, yum!  I got 2 cookies for $5  Maple bacon - as you first bite in it has this sweet chocolate chip cookie flavor. Then as you chew more you begin to taste the bacon and feel the bacon bits. Super delicious if you like the sweet salty combo and bacon!  Red velvet - not ridiculously sweet. Perfect combination. Must try if you like red velvet

Found this place online and made a detour during my trip to stop by for some cookies. It's a small place but super cute and the staff was very friendly! I grabbed a cold brew to go and a box of four cookies (lemon poppyseed, cookies & cream, funfetti and chocolate pretzel I believe it was called. I sat on the little bench out front and did some solid people watching while enjoying my snack. The funfetti cookie with icing was definitely my favourite but the consistency of all the cookies was literally perfect; chewy yet firm. I'll be day dreaming about these cookies until my next trip back to NYC for sure!
Very mediocre cookies and over priced. I think you're paying for the location more than anything. If you have the time, head up to 74th street to Levain Bakery. Best cookies ever.

I find myself in this area too often and always drawn to Schmackary's because they have piping hot and fresh cookies with some really great flavors that you just can't find anywhere else.  My friend and I first came awhile back for their "happy hour" which gave us two cookies and a glass of milk - nothing beats that.    I also really like their rotations of cookies, between my friends and myself, we've tried the maple bacon, sch'mores, red velvet, oatmeal scotchie, pumpkin spice... and I can't wait to try more.  The cookies are always fresh since there's a never-ending line to this place that does filter through fairly quickly.  With that being said, sometimes they don't have certain cookies ready when you're there because they're sold out and/or still baking.  That's okay, it's fresh and worth the wait ^.^  I'm still waiting for the day I happen upon the green tea cookie, I always come the wrong days!
I did not like that the cookies were dry and hard to chew. The funfetti cookie and the pistachio one were too sweet.

Hands down, the second best bakery I've ever been to. And lemme just say, that is no small feat! Each time I walk into their quaint shop, I am filled with giddiness. The employees are always super groovy & personable. No matter what, if I'm in Manhattan and I'm close by, I'll make a stop at Schmackary's... even if I'm not hungry. I LIVE for their Butter Scotchies, but every one of their treats are all deliciously varied and unique.
Back again! Love it!!! Favorite spot! Always welcoming!!! Can get pricey but it's not just about the cookies but the experience for sure
Love these cookies!  Great place for a bite before or after a show. Haven't tried a bad flavor, and we've tried many. Very little seating.

Mom and I went to Schmackary's before heading to JFK to head back home to sunny South Florida. We decided to bring some cookies home to my dad and brother.  We tried several (red velvet, chocolate chip, something with peanut butter, etc). The employees were super sweet and they had Red Jacket cold pressed apple juice. This is where the stars have been awarded....  The cookies. Um...they just weren't very good. I really wanted to like them because our experience in the store was great, but the first cookie I ate, I took two bites and threw the rest of it out. Half the cookies we got tasted like "healthy" cookies a.k.a. cardboard. The other half were so ridiculously sweet that they were almost inedible.  They have interesting types of cookies, the staff is sweet, and that Red Jacket juice is money. So, it might be worth a try, but there are too many places with awesome sweets for me to return next time I'm in the city.
Big selection of cookies, I'm gluten-free and the cookies I had were delicious and huge!  Definitely coming back for more. An awesome dessert spot, as they also have milkshakes.

This place is divine.  I was over in the area today and I just had to check it out for myself.  Every cookie I tried was awesome.  My favorite was the Maple Bacon which was the perfect mix of chewy, grainy, salty, and sweet.  I also devoured the Carrot Cake cookie which again was a good mix of salty and sweet.  The icing on top was also very good.  In addition, I tried the Kitchen Sink, Oreo, and Peanut Butter Cup.  I was not disappointed.    I'm so glad this place exists now.  The only bad thing is that it is extremely close to my yoga studio so I will undo all the good from my workout but I don't really care.  These cookies are worth it.

Certainly had some pretty damn good cookies here I just found this place two weeks ago and I have to walk on the other side of the street so I am not tempted to go in Great cookies!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! My nieces will be here with their sweet tooth next summer and we will be making this a regular visit mouth watering delicious
Choose 2 different cookies to make your ice cream sandwich.     So many flavor combinations to work with! deeelicious.
Great cookies and be sure to check in on Yelp!
The cookies are amazing.  Only got one and ate it there.  When I was done, I had to buy another one.  Love it.  Also: I constantly run into celebrities from Broadway shows in here.

Currently enjoying the chocolate duet and an iced latte. My favorite spot to kill time before catching a Broadway show. Always perfect. Last week my gluten intolerant significant other was surprised by how sweet and satisfying their sweet corn cookie is! And so was I, I was jealous in fact. Just great, five stars.

These cookies are amazing, especially the frosted ones. By the time I went around 9:30 at night, they only had about half their flavors left (cookies and cream, the chocolate cookie with white frosting, was still there, so I was happy.) Best to come early to this place to get your cookies and milk fix.

I had my first one today - COOKIES and CREAM.  I intend to go back once a week and work my way through the entire list.  Then keep coming back and going through the list again, until I leave NYC.    Travel in Safety.  Jane
Delicious cookies.  Sometimes too sweet and too buttery, but if thats what you are going for---go for it.  Good to share one cookie 4 ways, then its not so over-indulgent!

Awesome chocolate chip cookie! And bacon cookies?!?! Yes, I thought it was crazy until I tried the ice cream cookie sandwich with two of these babies on the outside. You can't really taste the bacon, but you can really taste the maple. Pretty good :D
They say their tea is loose leaf, but of course it's in a bag. Beyond that, however, everything is delicious. It's also very cozy.

I wanted to love this place. I heard so much about Schmackarys and since I live nearby I decided to stop in. I got a peanut butter cookie and a original chocolate chip. First tasted peanut butter, tasted salty and lacked the traditional peanut butter cookie peanut butter taste. Next the chocolate chip cookie.... I ate half because it was so salty. Way saltier than the peanut butter. So salty in fact that after eating bites I had salt crystals in my gums for a bit. I them goggled Schmackarys taste salty and saw tons of others share my experience.  The Maple Bacon which they claim is a favorite, I found to be so bad I threw it out after two bites. For a while I loved the Red Velvet cookies but they don't seem to taste the same twice, they always taste different.  I last had a Funfetti which I have had several times before but the last time I had it it was salty and oily, so oily it upset my stomach.  Glazed Pistachio & Candied Yam lacks flavor.  I like Fluffer Nutter and Caramel Apple Crisp.  I think much of this stores success is 75% tourists and non locals and 25% locals and mostly hype.  If it were in a subarb or any other area other than the theater district, I do not think it would be as successful.  I used to come to this store several times a month, now I have only been there 2 times in 4 months and do not plan to go back anytime soon.  They also do not tell you all the ingredients r calories in the cookies which I think is wrong especially in this day and age f food allergies.  The cookies are also pricey but they are large.
cookies and milkshake- all flavors delish

Lots of hype about this place. Decided to finally check it out.  -Espresso: Solid. Beans are dialed in well, very mellow and balanced. Zero acidity (which I don't personally like) but they definitely know what they're doing.  -Coffee: This is where they lose stars. Just FYI, It's not a pour-over because they have a machine hooked up to a Kalita Wave that does everything. I got the Geisha and felt completely ripped off. On initial glance, I could already tell that the coffee was underextracted (very light brown color, almost like a tea). Took a sip and it confirmed my findings. Almost tasted like Folgers instant coffee. I could barely discern any flavors notes because of how watered down the coffee was. Waste of money and waste of good beans. Perhaps my experience was an anomaly, but after drinking this, I can honestly say I will not come here again.  TLDR: Espresso is good, coffee is bad here.

The coffee was good not amazing. However the place was very nice calm environment but the cashier had a nasty attitude after I asked a few questions because it was my first time ,which dimmed the good environment I initially thought was here .

No t-shirts, tote bags or other lifestyle sh!t. They don't even let you tip. Only good coffee, along with sparkling water, and cool yet attentive service.  Hands down the top three coffee shop I've visited in NYC over the past six years. I live in the uptown but am more than happy to traveling 30-min+ to Morgan Ave.  Hope Sey will thrive but won't be dominated by shallow Instagrammers.
such a cool coffee shop in the area .  their coffee is the best . Beautiful minimalistic design, friendly stuff, close to subway , tasty pastries . i love their oat milk

Get: croissant! Nice and flaky  Cute, underground coffee shop near port authority. Came in here before a meeting to kill some time with a croissant and a coffee.  The cappuccino was okay..I did really like that they had a variety of milk options. I got mine with almond milk. Other than that though this was a bit forgettable.  Croissant was pretty good, nicely sized and light and flaky.  It's a smaller shop with about seating for 14+. Modern minimalist design.  It was quiet when I came in with more people grabbing their coffee to go. Price was about what you would expect for a cafe near Times Square.

Underground, hidden, poorly lit cafe with a good amount of seating (about 15 people). Prices are average ($4 for latte, $2.25 for tea). Worried about being let down by midtown coffee not living up to Australian standards, I went with a tea, which they have many flavors of. Jasmine tea was strong and refreshing, enough flavor for two cups. They also have pastries and bars. Music is pretty loud, but there are people working on their laptops here. Service is cool.  Because it's underground, there's not much ventilation, so it gets stuffy down there.

This is a small but nice cafe tucked away downstairs of an apartment building on a residential side street. I came here for a coffee and time to sit and read by myself while waiting for a friend. Fair warning, this place doesn't have many seats, and also doesn't have any bathrooms. The staff was nice enough to tell me where I could get a free (and nice bathroom) at a nearby hotel, and I told them to go ahead and make my latte, I would be right back. They had my coffee ready for me by the time I got back, and I had also ordered a doughnut, and that was plated for me to grab, as well. The staff is very friendly, and patient, as I took my time asking about which doughnut I might order. The music is quiet in the background, and the tables are clean, but small. If I wanted a coffee before seeing a show, I would stop by here again.

Hidden gem near time square on 44th street, down one flight of stairs.  Great tasting espresso drinks, they use birch beans.  It is a bit small but you maybe able to grab a seat still. Friendly wait staff, I say that because the barista remade my drink after she realized she put too much milk in my cortado.  Would definitely stop by here if I'm in the area again!
The espresso was very smooth and flavorful, I love that they have good milk alternatives also(oatmilk is the beeneez).
It is a cute little cafe. I had a Yerba Mate tea and that was good. It is a good place to work as they have outlets and wifi. However, they don't have a restroom.
Cute little cafe with good coffee. Nice slice of comfort just on the edge of times sq.

I have to knock a few stars off this review.  We came back to the Stone Street Coffee Company today and don't get me wrong, the coffee was still great, but the service - meh. The women behind the counter was rude. Also, they now charge $.75 for the vanilla infused simple syrup. Seriously? $.75? How petty are you that you charge several dollars for a cup of coffee then you feel that you need to charge extra for simple syrup with a vanilla twig in it? The counter person kept chanting it too, taking the bottle out of my hand until I paid for it.  I may have felt better about the $.75 if it came without the attitude but clearly the counterperson was giving that away for free.

Hello dear humans and coffehumans. Today I'm going to write a review that well it is hard to write. My dear girlfriend and I were walking towards ninth street espresso at Chelsea market when we stumbled upon a place we haven't seen before... This one!! Very small very interesting and also nice because they use their own coffee and let me tell you, it is very good. Now, they reason why I'm sad is because when I ordered my espresso and iced coffee the barista place my espresso in a to go cup, espresso shouldn't be placed in a to go cup... But that was my mutate for not specifying such a terrible act. Now, the barista grabbed a plastic cup and poured straight from the machine, the espresso shot... WHY!!!!!! No one should do that ever... Ever... Not even f it is convenient. Pouring hot contents into plastic is a terrible thing.... Please never do this, that's why I had to give three stars! God never do that for anything!!!!

Pretty good coffee with a window to service the outside? Very cool. Small fact about Stone Street Coffee Company, it;s a father and son operation. And they're Greek! (I'm half Greek) Friggin Opa to you!  They busted out a plant in Brooklyn, started roasting coffee beans and sell the blend to some high end restaurants in NYC. Nice goin' guys, keepin' it real in my NYC!  Anyhoo, swung by today for a Caff̬ macchiato and a chocolate croissant. Pretty good place to grab a coffee and go. I now have four of my favorite places to go in this area!  I love coffee and if you love it as much as me? Swing by and support this place. Trust me.. Opa!

The 5 stars are for the coffee being delicious and the service polite. This isn't as much a place to go with other people or while it is busy. It is suuuuper tiny. However, I came here and sat for a while and was surprised, as they had free wifi and were very accomodating. The guy behind the counter, who I believe may also be the manager was really warm and friendly, not only to me but others I saw enter. There were some homeless people that came in and he was really gracious and gave them some water and let them sit for a second before they were on their way.  They also have a "walk through" window which is pretty convenient as well!
Coffee is solid, chocolate chip cookies are aggressively mediocre.

think a bunch of these reviews are for the adjacent bar not the coffeeshop.  I was excited to find this place this morning, had great service and a good cup of french press, and really like the window concept - fast and convenient on the way to work.  so off to a good start for me at least.
Very good coffee on the west side. I enjoy their americano a lot.  They also use Belly card for their stamp card, which is a very cool company and a very cool take on the idea.

Ok-- this place has a lot of positive reviews on yelp so I am unsure if I came on a bad day but the music in here is so loud! I had to yell at the barista to place my order  I am unsure how anyone could have a conversation or do work in here.  I got a chai tea latte which was good but a bit over priced.

If you are expecting like a starbucks peach ice tea flavor or any other peach ice tea flavor  and ordered peach ice tea? Dont expect to be so good. It doesn't really taste like peach ice tea at all. Instead, lemonade mix with lots of water.

Love this place. I get coffee here all the time. Eat here occasionally. Recommend it to anyone.  Pros: Great coffee, and good food, lovely staff and whilst you have to wait sometimes, it has great service.  Cons: Price

Delightful breakfast spot.  Loved my coffee, loved my breakfast "sanga".  I took it apart and ate half the roll with jam, which I requested.  The jam was an incredibly delicious homemade blackberry jam.  This place is just a wow on all levels.
Great coffee! Damien is super helpful & a pleasure to chat with

Come here during the afternoon and there's always a lively almost clubby vibe with the music that they play. All the baristas are great and you have a nice choice of different coffees. I usually go with the self-serve coffee with three different choices. They do the trendy thing with avocado toast and other similar pastries / dishes but have yet to try any of it.  While they have very solid coffee, the one downside is that their cup sizes are relatively small compared to other places.

Walked past and decided to buy juice and coffee for two friends. Ordered grapefruit juice for $6 that was 3/4 full in a small cup. Since I was buying it for a friend, I asked for ice to fill up the cup so it doesn't look like it was drank by someone. The guy poured out some of the 3/4 juice and added one ice and it looks even more sad. Will spend my $10 elsewhere.

I had my first taste of their dessert from a colleague who treated us to a brownie yum. There carrot cake is a hit or miss. Once it was so good nutty and not to sweet but another time it was so sweet I throw out 1/2 of it (granted it is not cool to waste food but even with unsweeten black coffee it was too sweet). Their coffee is pretty smooth.

So glad Taylor St opened in NYC. I first tried their coffee in London and absolutely loved it. It seems to have an extended menu compared to the shop I visited in London, including the classic, wild and decaf choices. I got a classic flat white, which was rich in flavor, delicately textured and had a very pleasant aftertaste. I'm excited to try the "wild" next time. The staff was also very friendly and had an Aussie accent. I later found out that even though the brand was founded in London, the owners were from Sydney! Having lived in London and Sydney, I was pleasantly surprised.

I stopped by to get coffee / get some studying done while waiting for a train at Grand Central. This is a very upbeat/somewhat loud cafe. The vibe is great for grabbing coffee or a meal with a friend of stopping by on your way to work. Got a drip coffee (which comes in three varieties) and it's great. There are two floors - a to go spot downstairs and a table service area with lots of seating upstairs. Plenty of seating, but I wouldn't recommend coming here if your primary goal is to get work done, as it's just a bit too loud.

Good single origin coffee and friendly staff, but wow was that pour over painfully overpriced at ~$7.  Take the extra few minutes to walk over to Birch Coffee down the street or find another good coffee shop elsewhere.

Came in here on a random Saturday afternoon for a coffee break. I noticed this crushed ice with espresso, vanilla ice cream, and half/half drink on the menu outside and was super interested. It's called a Crushed Ice Flat White or something similar.  It's basically an espresso vanilla milk shake? I thought for the price point, it wasn't really worth it - and it was with the Yelp check-in discount too!  Barista was kind of disinterested and wasn't very friendly when we walked in or during our entire visit.  If you're in the area and need a coffee fix - sure, why not? But I wouldn't recommend making a special trip.

I was dog sitting in the area and wanted a treat on a rainy morning. I found this hidden gem while walking the pup and instantly fell in love. I ordered an iced rose oat milk latte and my mind was blown. First, rose syrup in coffee? Would it taste perfumey? Nope, the taste was subtle and sweet. Props to this place for carrying Oatly Oat Milk and providing great customer service!
I can't believe I just paid that much for a coffee but it was the best coffee I ever had and the cashier is always really nice :) Will replace my evening beer with morning coffee?

Hearing of the Bien Cuit*-sourced baked goods, I dropped by the new space to be half-greeted by a staffer who'd give half her attention throughout the exchange (she was far more concerned with the regulars there before me, as her male colleague disparaged someone eating some Sour Patch Kids as a the fast track to diabetes -- an odd contrast when uttered behind a pastry display). Asked twice (clearly each time) about what a couple of the pastries were (since they're labeled with neither name nor price) and chose the maple yam danish ("Danishs (Yam) $4.00"), which was a dense, bland letdown until I reached the yam center, which barely had a hint of maple.  FYI Square loyalty program: Congrats, you earned your first star! Earn 9 more stars and get: Free Coffee  *Which I wasn't surprised didn't past long in the West Village.
Got amazing service from Chris here, really good coffee, nice ambiance. Great location, and they have wifi too.

Checked out Terremoto Coffee yesterday, which did not disappoint! Tucked away in Meatpacking, this coffee shop is a true gem. I suggest stepping away from your usual flat white to try one of their specialty drinks; the Lavish Latte was especially delicious! They offer many tasty experiential flavors like toffee and lavender, so definitely give one a shot. Peter was our barista, who made the coffee just to our liking and provided quality customer service. Overall, the space itself is clean and warm, and the uniquely wallpapered entrance offers a great backdrop for your next foodie Instagram post. Go check this place out!
Amazing almond milk coffee! The best I've ever had. Cute intimate spot and very nice staff. First visit -- defiantly coming back

Service was nice. The large is super big which is appreciated lol. The dark chocolate mocha was pretty good. They serve dough doughnuts, various muffins, pastries and little snacks. Good amount of seating.

Quaint space with friendly staff and some bar seating.  Lattes lacking in amount of steamed milk. It was a bit too coffee strong for my liking.  There's an area off to the side with not just sugar but also honey to sweeten your drinks to taste.  Some pastries are available for sale as well as bottled drinks and hot chocolate.  Overall, an ok place for two friends to catch up, but there are better places to go.

Not a big fan of this coffee shop. I got the almond croissant and the iced chai latte and I've definitely had better elsewhere. The croissant tasted a little stale on the outer edges but was moist near the center because there's custard filling in the middle. I saw some reviews that said that there's chocolate in the croissant but mine didn't have...For the chai latte they put A LOT of milk. It ended up tasting like cinnamon spiced milk as opposed to a latte. Ended up paying $8+ for both items. I got the same two items at Madman Espresso and only paid ~$6 AND the almond croissant tasted way better there. Small place with a few chairs and tables if you're dining in. Staff members are friendly. Drinks and pastries are very mediocre and kinda overpriced but hey you're in the UES.
