I didn't feel rushed at all throughout my stay, and the service was exceptional. The main floor is for orders to go, with bench seating for waits.  I really enjoy the set up because this separation prevents disruption of your activity from people walking in and out. It's also very spacious (rare in the city) with tables well spaced throughout the room. The ambience, lighting, music selection and volume were just right. I'm definitely a big fan of this establishment.  Please continually order something as you work, I don't want this place to fold. Thank you!!

Such a cute, sunny, welcoming coffee shop owned and operated by Australians. Food and pastries always look fresh and taste good. Coffee is great. I actually haven't had the chance to check out what the upstairs seating looks like, but the layout of the main floor is spacious and not chaotic. Sugar/straws/stirrers area always well-stocked. The only thing is that prices are steep, but they do provide loyalty stamp cards (buy 4 coffees, get the 5th free! Whaaat).  Love the vibe here.
Why is this place $? The price is pretty steep if you get it to go.  An 8-oz latte is $4.25 NOT including tax. Please!! I miss La Colombe.

This is a cozy hidden cafe,  it's a serious gem for those who loves coffee. Coffee is rich and balanced. Baristas are super friendly. Ask for their punch card, with which you buy four and get one free!

I found Taylor St. Baristas on the way to Bryant Park from Grand Central Terminal. I exchanged some banter with the sweet blonde Aussie cashier over booming rap music (can you see why I love this place already?!) & five minutes later, my iced mocha was up. Bitter and sweet, and had a good ratio of almond milk to espresso. My vanilla lavender donut's pastel stripes and generous glaze was so pretty, I wanted to photograph it so that future generations of yelpers could admire its aesthetic! Step into this modern space & get yourself my exact order if you have a sweet tooth, or a flat white -- I've heard they're amazing here.

Cute little spot that we slipped into.  Not too much variety, but love a spot that does a little and does it well.  Drinks were a little pricey (and really beautiful) but the food was reasonably priced.  We had the buttermilk scones which were the perfect amount of crunch on the outside and flaky on the inside.  The jam tasted homemade and was fresh and delicious.  The brekkie sanga was a real treat.  Crispy toasted bread with thick cut bacon, a rich cheese sauce and two eggs.  Kept me going through a full day in the city.

It's a very trendy place - go upstairs if you want to get a table (table service though) and free wifi. It's cool looking - people dressed nicely and vibe is nice. Portion of latte is small (but it's still perfect for me) and they had only one waitress serving everyone so she couldn't quite keep up - served my pastry with no napkins or eating utensil....but it all tasted good. I'll come again if I'm in the Bryant Park area with some visiting friends or when I feel like getting a really tasty espresso drink.
Healthy food, helpful staff, free wifi and a great upstairs to sneak in come screen time....great place.
Totally fine cafe with an odd site & app. It's not on the Ave./has no Madison frontage.

Comprehensively Fantastic! The people that work here are very friendly and informative, the coffee is top notch, and while I did not try the food items, they looked very very good.  They serve a very high quality coffee (Counter Culture) and there techniques for extracting excellent body and flavor are spot on. It's not "discount" coffee, nor is it massed produced chain, but it's well worth the extra change!

I was looking for a bit to eat, and came across this place on Yelp. I was expecting the usual coffee and pastries coffee shop, but to my surprise they have a full service restaurant, which they opened today (July 8, 2016). I ordered The Tower with an iced coffee (see photo). The guacamole lacked salt, but the chives and the cilantro relish that topped the open-faced sandwich balanced out the lack of salt. The poached egg was perfect- the whites were cooked through, but the yolk was still runny. The egg was well salted. The coffee is strong and bold, and for the price, you get a large glass. This is a great place to sit and work, sit and chat, or just grab and go. I recommend this place to everyone, and the energetic, free-spirit of the staff makes this place an enjoyable place to be.
Great coffee. Love this adorable little place. Baristas are also super nice! Definitely over priced, but it's great quality.

When I first walked in there's a really nice display of pastries and other foods they offered. Different selection than other coffee shops here. I really like the upstairs dine in seating area, they also play great music!
Just the perfect spot. I had my lunch, coffee, and did some work. What more can you ask for? Awesome chilled vibe and delicious food and coffee. Looking forward to my next visit
Great coffee. Even better vibe.  Bonus - best loyalty program out there. Buy 4 and the 5th is free!
Ordered the miso brekkie bowl and the avocado roast. Amazing, best avocado toast I have had in the city

So excited this great coffee shop opened in the neighborhood. I've been really pleased with my lattes the past two days. I tried the original espresso the first day and it was so smooth and delicious. Today I'm having my latte with the "wild" espresso and it has a wonderful deep flavor with a hint of blueberry which is a welcome addition. The staff is very friendly and the baristas seem to be a cut above. Also, right now they're having wonderful opening week prices so my drink was only $2.50. Looking forward to many more visits here, especially once the upstairs sit down cafe opens up.

Just got 2 coffees here and a hot chocolate, service was  very slow, even though place was not super busy, I ordered a Non fat Cap and two other drinks- all large. I watched the barista make it with whole milk. I asked her if it was skim when she gave it to me? she said we dont have skim milk, I said then why did the cashier take my order for  non fat cap then? She didnt like my question and gave me a major tude. All three large beverages  that i paid for were served as smalls. I just left and they kept my money. I  Will not be back. There is a coffee shop every100 feet in NYC. Need to treat people better. Good Luck....

taylor st baristas has everything you'd expect from a great coffee shop, and more. you can tell that a huge part of their culture includes learning customers' names, which is highly appreciated.  oh, and the coffee is great. i'm constantly in the lookout for good coffee in NYC (not super easy to find) and this place serves my fave, so far.  plus if you buy 4 of any hot drink, you get the 5th for free. shows they really care about customer fidelity. that's why i stop by every day on my way to work.  if you're in the area, go check them out.

Was very excited to hear that Taylor St was coming to New York. Always loved their coffee in London and the NYC location sticks to the same concept with uber-friendly staff, great coffee and this amazing avocado toast. Definitely a fixture on my schedule whenever I make it to NYC.

Dropped in here this afternoon for a quick coffee. Really cool vibe, great music and staff. They have their drip coffee with little tasters so you can get a sense for what you're going to drink. Prices are about average for a boutique coffee shop. I got a nonfat latte for $4.25 and it was really solid. Their food menu looked good but didn't try anything this time around. Will definitely be back.

Cute tiny coffee shop near the High Line! It fits only about a couple of tables, which makes Terremoto even a little romantic.  You should try their yummy specialty drinks (they are written on the board on the right of the counter). The lavender latte was subtle, but you could taste the flavor just enough.

You must pop in. This coffee shop is what makes our city unique.  I had a cortado that tastes like heaven. I don't know if it's the amazing barista or the beans or... Truly an uncompilable treat.  The atmosphere design the tone of the shop is I belong here, and the walls are begging to tell a story.

Amazing coffee shop! I had a cold brew and shared a ham and cheese croissant and raspberry twist pastry with my boyfriend. Also had a sip of his drip coffee. The coffee is phenomenal, as are the baked goods (I believe the croissants are from Ceci-Cela). Iced Terremoto Latte was also great - it was like a caramel chai tea latte.  Also, you get 20% off coffee purchases with Yelp.

i've tried a handful of their lattes that are made with their house special syrups. i absolutely loved the dulce de leche, as it's the perfect balance of carmel sweetness and espresso! you seriously won't regret trying any of their coffees.  can't wait to come back here on my next nyc trip.

One reviewer said that this was his smoothest espresso pour in NYC. I have to agree that it is up there! We had two cappuccinos and they were spectacular. They also have Ceci Cela pastries, which we happen to love. Definitely worth a stop if you need a pick-me-up in the area.
Small coffee shop with great coffee. The rose flavored latte is delicious. They even use paper straws!
Found this spot randomly while looking for a coffee spot to wait (Had another event to go  to later that evening).  Good mocha and chill vibes. Would visit again if I'm in the area.

Terremoto is located on a side-street close to Chelsea Market and pulls the best espresso I have had (thus far) in New York City.  AMBIANCE (4/5) The feel of this coffee shop is super cozy and "showy". The espresso machine is wrapped in gold accenting giving the whole place a very regal feel. The only qualm some people may have (this is why I loved this place) is how small the inside is. There is not much seating and the whole place can maybe house 3 customers at a time.  COFFEE (5/5) These guys know their stuff. The coffee here is very tasty. My personal favorite drink option at Terremoto is the Long Black which is pretty much an Americano with less water so the espresso flavor comes out a lot stronger. They also have many unique lattes that incorporate cool flavors such as lavender, etc.  Terremoto is worth it. Just grab a coffee from here before exploring Chelsea market and you'll be set.

So happy I happened to walk past this jewel and took the time to stop in.  Got a pour over from Kenya and enjoyed the complex flavors. Only three tables inside so I counted myself lucky when one opened up. I sat for a few minutes in their cozy space--exposed brick and cool music--and listened as the knowledgeable barista gave passionate and friendly advice to others. A great find.
My new favorite. The macchiato is excellent. Highly recommend the double chocolate chip with sea Salk cookie as well.

Always great coffee and lattes!  Had a Vanilla Chai Latte from here twice. Very delicious! I believe they started making their own Chai recently and I must say it's really great.  Crossiants are also good. Crispy yet softy. Buttery and flaky! Recommend getting the Ham and Swiss Crossiant and some Cold Brew also.  Barista is so friendly and cute too lol.

Play that sade (that's sha-day for you babies who don't know the 90s R&B wonder) because this is some smooth silky latte experience I'm undergoing! Of course the whole milk helps. Maybe not my lack of lactose dissolving enzymes but I have a few working models.  The store itself is celebrating 1 year open since January 2016. The cups are black with gold encouragement and thanks. The specialty lattes are fun and have floral or sweet motives. The barista was a nice guy even though the four people in the coffeehouse were blasting their voices over his explanations of everything. There's a little self explanatory sign for espresso drink newbs on things like "what's a latte?". And they have matcha but I wasn't gonna get it this time.  I got the space oddity which has rose petal flavoring, I guess just in time for my special valentine.  Definitely come here. If you can snag a table, nice! Otherwise some obnoxious people were sitting here when I walked in and I'd rather not hear their full blast lame-o conversation. To go is just as good. Mmmmm smooooooth.

Really solid espresso. But the Bien Cuit croissants are over priced - $3 for plain and $4 for chocolate, fruit, etc.  Went at 8:45am on a weekday, wasn't much selection either.  But I'm biaised, I'm a big fan of Ceci Cela.  I like a buttery, light, crispy & flaky croissant.  This one was thick and too heavy and not crispy enough.  Plus the fruit/chocolate/etc. croissants were really small.    But they have CUPS!  Lucky I could look up prices on the app, because they don't list coffee prices anywhere in this place.  New CUPS customers download the app & get $10!!! Use this code: lzx7t  Oh, definitely use the check-in offer from Yelp, you get 20% off - which makes the croissants a lot lot cheaper! ;-)

Terremoto has various specifically lattes (lavender, rose, or honey) that are lightly flavored (more like essenced), giving a nice addition to the flavor profile without all that added sweetness. If you appreciate a latte but don't want it drowning in sweetness, then you've found your ideal coffee spot.

I have never been to a coffee shop like this! The manager was one of the nicest guys and the service we experienced was beyond amazing. He talked to us about the coffee and the process on making the latte, because he saw how interested we were.  The coffee tasted delicious, and the atmosphere was so unique and cool. The gold, brick and wallpaper gave it a great vibe. Also, the cups were really neat. Definitely make this a  stop if you're visiting NY!

Single shot of espresso: thin, no crema, and bitter. Even if it had been a bad pull, the barristo should have noticed. When your business is coffee, you have to aim for excellence in that every time. When your pull is worse than one from a bodega, then you have q.c. problems. $3.25 for swill. One star.
Great coffee! Really nice baristas! I really like their flavored lattes including the lavender and caramel lattes. And their cups always make me smile.

Nice small independent coffee shop. Service was ok, not particularly friendly, not unfriendly either. We thought the coffee was very bitter, couldn't finish it, had to throw it out even after putting in 5 packets of sugar, but that could be due to our personal tastes, although we usually never have to use sugar.

I stopped in here for a quick espresso on the way to a show. This a nice little coffee shop with good service. The espresso I got was one they were experimenting with. I wasn't the biggest fan of it, but it got the job done and I do like that they serve sparkling water with it.  They have some baked goods available which is pretty much a coffee shop standard. They don't have a lot of room for seating, basically one table, but I wouldn't hesitate returning here if in the area.

We were drawn to this venue because of its excellent Yelp reviews. This place, even if small, serves great coffee and is very cozy. I'm fascinated by coffee and it was nice to be able to talk to the manager about the equipment they use and all sorts of other stuff. He was very easygoing and friendly. He even let me have a quick look at the espresso scale they use (Acaia Lunar) when I told him I plan on buying one sometime soon. The coffee was extra fresh, the milk was textured to perfection. I couldn't ask for more. We planned on going again during our short trip, but unfortunately didn't manage to. It's definitely on my 'To do list' the next time I'm visiting. Thank you for the great experience!

Damn these people know their coffee.  I went in some early AM to buy a bag of beans and was subsequently asked a series of intense coffee interrogation - what methods do you use to make coffee? Aeropress? Pourover? Do you have a burr grinder? Do you hand grind or have a machine?  It was impressive their depth of knowledge. I think I must have passed because I did wind up getting a bag of coffee. It actually wound up becoming one of my favorite brand of beans (Onix)! I also learned  a lot of the baristas are part of a roasting union of sorts? Unrelated but cool.  The coffee itself here is great - you'll definitely appreciate it if you're into just great pourovers or espresso. Maybe leave your friend behind who only likes starbucks - they will not find a caramel macchiato on the menu here ;)
Great ambiance, the Baristas and coffee . I have had a wonderful time seating and sipping coffee. The staff were very helpful.

The coffee here was so delicious that we came back twice in one day! The "space oddity" with oatly milk was unbelievably delicious. Both baristas were friendly, knowledgeable, and engaging. Fantastic find!

Detail can easily win or kill a business in the culinary industry and in this case, Terremoto completely caught my heart from all aspects.  Cute decoration with color of black and gold (one of my favorite combinations), coffee cup lid with a close button, cool names like "the purple rain latte" (by the way can you even guess what that is?), nice barista (she was nice enough to tell me the answer), and most importantly, one of the best flat whites in the city! Aside from regular espresso items, they also serve seasonal specialties and even Kyoto brew! If you happened to be hungry, make sure to also grab from their great pastry selections, including the giant macaron which simply made my mouth watery.  I'm loving it!
Great Colombian coffee at a cute spot in Chelsea !! Couldn't ask for more during my coffee break

People are nice here and there are varieties of coffee/latte available. But what I don't like are: 1. No price on the menu, only the size available on the menu. So you'll only know when you are paying. 2. Half cup is ice for my iced latte. Starbucks is not the only place using this kinda of tricks.

The west village has many options when it comes to coffee shops. I've been to a few and I haven't loved any in particular, they were okay.  This morning I decided to give the elk a try, and I'm so glad I did! As I waited on line I noticed the pastries, they had gluten free options! Which is always a huge plus! I ended up getting the Cardamon loaf cake and an ice coffee with oat milk. The service is awesome, they were nice and quick ! The price wasn't too bad. I will definitely return when I'm in the area.
One of my favorite coffee places in the city, I've been coming here for years. Great coffee and excellent service. Never had a bad experience here.

Was happen to be on the Christopher street pier on a weekday and had the crave for a good cappuccino, as oppose to the regular American coffee which is usually served here on this side of the world. Walked by this cute place, ordered a large cup of cappuccino and ended up staying to read a book. Did not had the pleasure to taste any of the food offered on the menu, but everything seemed tasty. The price was 4.5 usd for a large cappuccino which I guess is an average price for this kind of beverage here in the city

Seriously my favorite coffee shop in the West Village.  Sat here probably for 3 hours. It is fairly small but I love how cozy and intimate it is. I wouldn't come here with a group of people because the place is small, but its great if you come with a friend or by yourself.  Loved the coffee here! I got a cappuccino, a latte and a matcha latte and all were so good!! The food is very good - everything from backed good, to avocado toast, to eggs, to sandwiches, to soup - you name it. Simple and delicious food, though a bit overpriced, portions are generous.  The staff is really nice and friendly.  Would definitely recommend

Absolutely loved this coffee shop. Cute and quaint. Has excellent coffee. They gave me a 10% off on yelp which I thought was very sweet as many places don't do that. This place not only has great coffee and atmosphere but also great customer service. Can't wait to go back tomorrow

I've only gotten their latte and sat to read a book. What a pretty cafe! It was a bit crowded but I eventually got a table. Love the natural light here, and the cobble stone streets nearby, definitely one of those coffee places that put you in a good mood!  They also sell some small knick-knacks on the side wall.

I love this spot in the west village !! My friend introduced me to it and I will be coming back many times in the future !  What I got : The matcha latte, green smoothie with no honey, and the scrambled egg plate.  The scrambled eggs were perfectly cooked and came with sweet potatoes and tomato ( which I opted not to get). The matcha latte was really good (although I should have gotten it cold on such a warm day. The smoothie was really good ! It had cucumber and kale and mint which had a refreshing taste.  My friends got sandwiches and they looked so good ! I definitely want to try one next time !

Ran across this gem of a coffee house! It's not only a coffee spot but a cafe as well. My double shot cappuccino was absolutely perfect! Super strong and the perfect temperature! Which is hard to nail! While waiting for my order I noticed a cute wall with an assortment of products... tried the rose quartz body oil and am loving it. Will definitely be back!

I've been here a few times and it's such a cute coffee shop. There are a few tables but it can get crowded. The space itself lets in a lot of sunlight and the staff is very friendly. I would definitely recommend checking it out!

Good things do come in  small packages. Always crowded, and for good reason. The coffee and teas rival any other NYC establishment. Along with a cappuccino, I purchased a gluten-free peanut butter cookie (btw, love gluten) and one bite and my mouth leaped for joy. It was just a tad sweet but that didn't stop me from taking down another! Along with coffee and tea and munchables, there's an assortment home goods (think candles and such) which are all organic and stuff...a gift to yourself and to your home for sure.

My friend first introduced me to this place a couple months ago, when i moved into the neighborhood, and this cafe has constantly been on my mind since then. Their food is healthy yet filling and extremely flavorful. I've had the breakfast burrito, avocado banh mi, and spicy chicken sandwich - all of which are amazing!! My goal is to try everything before my lease is up!

A well-designed, intimate space if you're looking to catch up with a friend and chat. They have several tables designed specifically for laptop-free use (so, maybe not the best go-to option if you're looking to do an hours-long marathon of work, especially since it was pretty crowded on a Saturday afternoon).  They do have a small counter area outside the storefront for you to place your coffee on, if you'd like to read and just have somewhere to put your drink. A particularly innovative design considering how limited seating is on the inside.
Great place and ambience. Good coffee, good music, perfect spot to get some work done .

Beautiful (but small) coffee space with very friendly staff! There is only 2-3 tables and some bar area to set up camp at.  I ordered a mocha with skim milk. It was delicious, perfect temperature, and decently priced. The coffee art was beautiful.  Definitely swing by here for coffee on the go or a quick cup of joe with your boo.

Yelp check-in discount :)  Cozy and intimate neighborhood coffee shop with pastries stocked from Balthazar. Very friendly staff.  I ordered an almond chai latte which was delicious so I can't speak to the coffee.  Ambiance is great for meeting a friend, reading a book, getting work done on a small laptop at the window bar. Not good for groups.  Would go back solo to try the avo toast or baked egg toast. :)

The matcha lattes are great here, and they are very generous with their servings of matcha. They also have a good selection of food to choose from, but I've yet to try them. Out of the sweets, my girlfriend has enjoyed a few of them so I'd definitely recommend checking this spot out. On weekends, the crowd can make the space tight, and lining up discoordinated, but otherwise, this is a great spot to grab something quick.

Whoever answers the phone is a 100% complete moron I got a false purchase at their location and this dimwit took the phone off the hook and proceeded to talk shit while I listened I can't wait til her daddy stops paying her rent and she's forced back to Ohio ....food might be good idk but the people aren't worth dog shit

Fantastic coffee with a great atmosphere. I'm not sure what roaster they use or if they roast they're own but either way it's really good. It's a perfect place to chill, enjoy your coffee, and grab a bite to eat.

Lovely place on a charming West Village street to get a delicious cup of coffee.   The paragon of a village coffee house. As a bonus you get this lovely view of a carriage house Across the street, which was built in the 19 century and has been restored to a beautiful home

the food, the coffee  i always order the avocado toast w/an egg & oat milk mocha (seriously both incredibly delicious - like crack!!! - leagues above any other in my book)  the fact that the food comes out of a mysterious cabinet/rope pulley system made my day.  this place keeps me coming back every time.  i work from home/coffee shops, so i always like a place where i can set up camp for hours at a time! bums me out that the tables would be laptop free, but i understand why & still stay and work at the tiny bar because, well, its just THAT good.
Very cozy cafe in a very cozy location. But coffee and food was just ok. Disappointed in the avocado toast. A bit overpriced.

Really bright and bustling spot to grab a drink and study! I came here around noon on a Saturday looking for a spot to read for an hour or two, and this was perfect--bustling but not too loud. Its table seating fills up quickly, but when I came counter seating against the side wall was empty. You might not get one of the few coveted window seats, but the entire cafe is doused with plentiful light from outside and there's generally a seat or two open. Bonus: they have outlets!!  As for drinks, I got an iced latte with whole milk ($5) and I enjoyed it. I wouldn't say I'm a coffee expert but I appreciated how creamy it was. I didn't try any of the food but it all looked really good and portions seemed generous. Their stuff is pricey--if you check in on Yelp, you get 10% off, so definitely take advantage of that. Overall though a great place to grab a drink and study.

Open early on a weekday morning like any good coffee shop. Got in before the morning rush so I can get my food quickly. Friendly staff and nice ambiance to enjoy a meal with lots of light coming in through the windows.  After viewing the pictures, decided on the Avocado Toast w/Fried Egg ($10), Pumpkin Olive Oil Cake ($4ish), and an Iced Coffee ($4ish). First: the iced coffee is damn good. Added a bit of cream and some simple syrup for a well balanced summer drink. Second: the cake is just the right amount of moist as per most olive oil caked, with a hint of pumpkin that makes it unique; delicious. Third: huge spread of avocado on the bread. A little tough to eat with all the ingredients, but it all works well together. Could have used more chili flakes.  The price point is high, just like much of the area. However, the coffee is made right and the atmosphere is perfect. Many other things to try here.

We stumbled upon The Elk the other evening when it was freezing cold out and had one of the best matcha lattes (with almond milk) I've ever had. The dude behind the counter was really nice and we dug the comfortable vibe.
Beautiful coffee shop. They have a couple of tables and even though you can't use your laptop here it's a great place to sit, drink coffee and maybe read a book

Cute little space in a great area, just not a lot of seating. Got the avocado toast with fried egg and watermelon juice, which were both terrific. Really appreciated the different textures in the dish - the perfect blend of creamy avocado mixed with pine nuts for crunch, chewy toast, and the fried egg topping adding a delicious extra layer of protein/saltiness (runny yolk is my ideal condiment). Will definitely be back to try their other menu items.

I walked in here expecting to be charmed because of how cute the cafe appeared on the outside. Immediately upon walking in I just felt like the space was jumbled and confusing. Not only do they sell food and coffee, but bath soap and cleaning spray...?  Also, half the space is for laptop usage and the other is for tabletop usage. It just made the space feel disjointed.  Lastly, I felt like the food was overpriced and was definitely not worth it. After I left here I wandered down the street and ended up at Toby's. I would definitely recommend Toby's over The Elk.

Stopped in here while walking around the Village on our way to Washington Sq. Park. I got a iced chai tea and my husband got a latte. I was worried I wouldn't like my chai tea, I tend to be picky with my caffeinated beverages, but it was delicious. My husband really enjoyed his latte as well. My chai was $4 which is, I think, priced exactly right for a delicous chai in a good coffee shop in New York.  The aesthetics were adorable in this little cafe. Very hipster/neighborhood coffee shop and it fit the feel of the area. So glad we could stop into this cute little gem. The food looked good so next time we'll have to grab something to eat!

This place!!!!! Such a beautiful and carefully thought out space. The details are everything here. If I lived in the neighborhood I would definitely be here all the time but alas I live in Midtown East.  Seating is a bit limited so try to go at an off-hour or very early in the morning.

The elk is super cute and trendy with expertly made espresso drinks and surprisingly tasty food. Went here on a Saturday morning with my girlfriend and the place was bustling. The only negative we both agreed on was the seating situation: there were a lot of people working on their laptops and all of the indoor seats were full. Their food is available for take out, but most of it is not easily eaten on the go so you kinda need somewhere to sit regardless.  Baked egg toast: well crafted, on the small side (though at $7 it's what you can expect), served with side salad and a great spicy green sauce Omelette: good but nothing special, eggs were cooked well

Enjoyed the cage-free egg with ham for breakfast! A touch on the pricier side here, but a good solid cup of coffee in a nice ambiance. The servers were chirpy and I would say its a fine stop-over before heading to Hudson river park or a weekend west village jaunt.

Coffee was okay. Got the avocado toast, which wasn't bad but wasn't great either.  Although I did come there when they were closing for NYE. That must've contributed to the half-ass services and food. Will come back soon on a regular day to try again.

My favorite weekend coffee spot. The lattes are perfect to take on the go and sip at the pier. Or feel free to stay and enjoy CEREAL, raw bliss balls, the smell the fresh roasted coffee and relaxing atmosphere.

Do not order their iced matcha latte. Got mine with almond milk and I barely tasted any matcha; the color of the drink was a really light green color. Very watered down and not worth the $6+.  The cafe itself has a nice relaxed feel to it. If I ever come back, I'll make sure to order something else.

5 dollar for 8oz of grapefruit juice?! i was like, what the fuck right now. eggs, juice and fitness classes are probably the three most overpriced things in the city (booze is in its on pantheon, of course).  but i really digged the spot. its a young mix of writers, artists and business/finance types. the brunch looked really good too...i want to come back at some point for the food. its a great corner spot, no pretense, for a quick cup or an intimate meal. the tables are really cute, they even say things like "no laptop zone"....which is smart, because people it keeps from camping out at this tiny spot.  ill come back, and ill order some eggs benny on kale. i was eyefucking it for a minute.

Looking at the some of the reviews here and the people probably just had an off day. I've seen the staff treated poorly by terrible customers and they way they handle themselves and the situation is very commendable. Anyway, I really like the good vibes of the baristas and the coffee is good too. Plus, the playlist is probably the most dope in the city. It's fun to sit nearby the window and see all of the cute pups that wait outside for their owners. (They have doggie treats inside!) :)
Good avocado toast. Bad kale caesar salad. Food takes a while to come out and there's not enough seating for the volume of people coming through at all hours.

A hidden gem tucked away on a gorgeous little street in the West Village. It's my go to spot whenever I'm in the area. Ambience is beautifully modern but also homey and cozy, the staff is always friendly, the coffee is rock solid, and their food is wonderful! (Be sure to stay for breakfast or lunch) Try the avocado toast with a poached egg on top or the market bowl. Such a unique and wonderful place that I would highly recommend to anyone in search of a perfect little nook. My absolute go-to coffee shop.

Love to find neighborhood hidden gems in all areas, and this is one in West Village.  The coffee selections are good, and strong.  And the food ... yum yum yum ... my recent favorite is the egg sandwich. Love the setup where a lot of light comes in even on raining day. There are always very adorable small flower arrangements on the tables. A quiet and comfortable spot to sit in, any weather, weekday morning.

I used to come here a lot until Merriweather on Hudson opened. I came back today since Merriweather didn't have any tables available, as I needed to grab a quick bite and send a few e-mails while eating.  I was told by a tall girl with dyed streaks in her hair that I couldn't sit there since the tables are not "laptop-friendly". I questioned this logic, as I would have sat at the table anyways, even if I didn't have my laptop with me since I ordered food. Mind you, I was there for less than an hour; nevertheless, she told me to move. I'm not one to cause a scene, so I moved. A few moments later, a girl with several books sat down to presumably study and get a coffee. She was not told to move. Meanwhile, I sat in the corner, pining for more room to work and eat. I award The Elk 1 star for poor service and extremely flawed logic.  Next time, I'll wait for a table at Merriweather to open up, and I won't bother coming back again out of principle. The staff there is waaaaaaaaaaay more hospitable. Bye bye!

Delicious tea, great selection of coffees, teas, pastries and small bites. But the service is what really stands out.  The currant rosemary scone is a great pick (worth the $4 if you're looking for something savory-esque and tart).  LImited seating (like every other cafe in Manhattan) -- there are about six barstools and a few smaller tables -- but it's not crowded (yet), so it's not a stressful cafe experience, the way some over-popular ones can be.  Added bonus, great music selection (a la Alt+J plus soul).  Definitely worth a stop in.

Love this coffee shop and the idea of it, until I went back in on my second visit and realized the staff have completely turned me off on ever going back. I never really care about things like staff but when they are literally so demeaning and terribly rude, it makes you never ever want to go back in there. Can't believe I gave any more money to this place.

Really cute coffee shop that also serves light lunch. They don't have much seats and the small tables are laptop free, only high chair area can use laptop. They have bench outside the coffee shop, can enjoy sunshine there!

Another hidden gem in the West Village!  The Elk is perfect for both meeting some friends over a cup of coffee / good food AND working independently.  The way they do it is that they keep the tables 'laptop-free' (don't know how hard they reinforce that rule but the sign's there!) and there's some counter seats near the window where people with laptops do work.  Avocado toast with fried egg on top was amazing, and the chili flakes add a nice kick to it!

This is my go to fave coffee shop--but it so much more. They have a full kitchen in the basement and the food comes up on a dumb waiter! Delicious soups, salads and the best grilled cheese sandwich On the planet. All of this in a cozy, warm shop surrounded by my Village neighbors! Home.....

Definitely a hidden gem in the West Village for some intimate coffee and laptop space. Great place to bring a friend or two but very limited seating. They accept credit cards and have a laptop only space by the window. I believe there are food options but I had a small cookie and coffee which were great. Very cute interior as well.
Small stuffy place, definitely get the coffee to go. We tried the vanilla latte it was everything I hoped for it to be. Very great tasting coffee!

There's a lot to put up with. The space is tiny. On the weekends, getting a table here is like the Hunger Games. The staff's attitude is...shall we say, "Parisian". Questions are met with barely or unsuccessfully suppressed eye-rolls. There are "lifestyle" items for sale in the "general store" section of the cafe.  And I put up with all of it and still come back. The coffee is great (it's a tossup between this or La Colombe on Vandam) and their kale caesar with jalapeno pulled chicken is to die for.

Atmosphere is pretty good, coffee is excellent. One star off for pastries - they are just so-so and overpriced. I will definitely try a bowl next time and amend the review if it stands up to the amazing cortado.
One of the best coffee-shops in Manhattan!!! Must have their almond latte (although any kind of coffee you'll get is amazing) and avocado toast with scrambled eggs!!

Love love love this place. Great spot to meet a friend or do some work (although laptops are only allowed at the front and sides of the cafe). So cute. Come here for a casual breakfast and get the avocado toast with an egg on top. You won't regret it.

This was a great spot for a mid morning coffee and a bite to eat. Tables are reserved for non-laptop carrying patrons so it was nice to not worry about a spot to sit and enjoy a basic (but perfect) Americano and a delicious avo-toast.
No space. Just lots of ppl working. Guess it's a free co-working space. No room for customers who actually buy stuff

They know how to steam almond milk. And they use good almond milk!! The coffee and food here is delicious, I recommend the avocado toast (on good gluten free bread, thank you!) and the lentil soup. I come here every morning when I'm in town .

My first experience at Elk surpassed my expectations. I enjoyed Mojo (coffee spot in its place previously), but Mojo's service was sub par and staff was not friendly.  Elk had not only great food (the egg wrap is a new favorite), but they had welcoming and friendly staff. We ordered oatmeal and an egg wrap, planning to split the two. When two oatmeals came out by mistake, they quickly corrected and whipped up an egg wrap in no time. A few minutes later the woman who rang us up brought over a muffin on the house (delicious carrot raisin that I'll order next time). Nice to know that there are places that make customer service a priority.  Highly recommend The Elk for a casual breakfast/brunch or even lunch spot.
Found a small clear piece of plastic in my spicy chicken sandwich and had to stop eating. Choking hazard, very dangerous!  Please ensure the safety of the food you serve in the future!

I probably eat their food at least 3x a week because it's really, really tasty (and convenient). I love the Market Rice Bowl because it's seasonal veggies that are always delish- with pickles and picked onions and this sauce that is so good I could drink it. Their soft scramble is ideal too. The baristas are always very pleasant and always willing to deal with substitutions and bill splitting complications. Ive tried their soup once () and their sandwiches. I've been wanting to try the egg salad sandwich they keep pre made up front because even that looks insanely tasty.
I got a drip coffee. There were no sleeves. Hot hands. Coffee was decent.

The aesthetic is chill as heck and the barista is too. The chocolate chip cookies are deliciously chewy but a bit on the pricier side. A small, air-conditioned nook in the West Village that I'd love to come by again.

Would it hurt the girls behind the counter to smile,  say hello and greet customers???   It seemed as though they were miserable and hated being there!  I get that some people have bad days but this has occurred a few times and with all the coffee houses in the West Village to choose from, I would rather grab a cup where there is a better vibe.  Matter of fact, I ran into a friend and he had same experience at Elk that we both thought it was worth writing about!

It was my first time at the Elk and my first time in NYC I simply came in here for a cup of coffee but ended up leaving with so much more. I was help by an African American gentleman who pretty much planned the 48 hours I had in New York and did a wonderful job at that. He was so friendly and went out of his way to make my time memorable. I have already told several people about this place and can't wait until I can return.

Space is nice, coffee is fine but after you tell them you have no cash on you and pay for your drip coffee with a card, they'll tell you it's $0.25 for soy. Which is fine for a soy latte where they're using a whole cup of the stuff but for a splash in your regular coffee, it seems ridiculous and creates an awkward situation when all you have in your wallet is three pennies. You want me to put a quarter on my card to pay for a teaspoon of soy milk? Places that lack common sense don't deserve more stars.

Another NYC treasure ruined. Mojo's (one of the cosiest and least pretentious spots in the West Village) is now a garishly lit window for posers, with lousy coffee, no bagels, no wifi, and arrogant, lethargic staff.

I hate to give this place a bad review, because it is very charming and the food/coffee is delicious.  I come here every Saturday, and it is generally very good.  But today I went to get my coffee and they forgot my order and another woman's order.  We were both waiting for around 15 minutes each and we were very patient.  When they finally gave us our orders, they gave the woman a voucher for a complimentary drink, but they did not give me one.  It was  rude and incredibly insulting.  Very dissapointed.

A perfect neighborhood coffee shop. Excellent coffee and breakfast sandwiches albeit a bit pricey even for the West Village. A great place to relax, read the paper, and enjoy the laid back atmosphere. When I'd rather pick up a quick bite rather than cook or need a quick caffeine fix, this will be my go-to spot.

Great little coffee shop on Charles Street. Makes excellent selection of coffees, my favourite the latte or flat white. If you are Kiwi or Aussie in town craving a Southern Hemisphere coffee this is the place to get it. There are benches outside to sit on and people watch as you sip or there is inside seating. The menu is concise and the Food is simple, fresh, classic and tasty. Highly recommend.
Like a delicious cookie with a chewy center? Get the gluten free peanut butter cookie.
Beyond obsessed with this place. Fast wifi, amazing coffee, and really great organic healthy food that tastes amazing. New fav work spot.

The Elk is a great little coffee shop, probably my favorite in the West Village.  Now they have some interesting breakfast and lunch items too, so it is a nice place for breakfast or lunch dine-in if you can snag seating.   In the warmer months it is great to take out eat by the Hudson.    I had a delicious baked egg and grain toast with zucchini and parmesan $7.  You can order a large chemex for $7.50, Brooklyn Parlor Coffee.  Drip coffee is also great.  Staff is friendly and sharp.  Hard to find a seat sometimes, but they have some "no laptop" designated tables.   They also have a cool little selection of boutique gifts and cards for sale.

Awesome spot... the coffee shop that everyone wants to have "around the corner".  Sightglass coffee, delicious food offering, inviting, warm and relaxed atmosphere. Can't ask for much more.  I'll be a regular. Thanks, Claire.
Great coffee made to order. Never too busy and always friendly - this is my go to coffee spot when I'm in the village.

The cafe is great, but the portions are small.  I think it's a bit pretentious to serve food in such small portions with the high price point.  Not sure if they're trying to be cost effective to save money on the serving size - their sandwiches are delicious, but SMALL!  It's kind of anti-climactic when you see it.  Sweet people, delicious coffee and yummy food and baked goods.  Need to upgrade their portions and cup sizes to compete with the ubiquitous caf̩s in the neighborhood.

Missing Mojo Coffee, but The Elk seems to be a revitalization of what's important in a coffee shop/cafe. The new ownership did a phenomenal renovation and the coffee is outstanding. I'm looking forward to becoming a regular here. I hear the food is going to be amazing!!! I can't wait till they start cooking.

I'm a coffee snob, but this is the best cappuccino I can remember having. The Elk has truly excellent coffee, delicious baked goods (the gluten free peanut butter cookie is especially good), and the baristas are all friendly and capable. Love the atmosphere and location too!

This establishment is truly a rare gem in the garment district. The moment you step inside, it feels like you are entering into an oasis in the form of a bookstore and cafe right in the heart of New York City! The music they play in my experience has ranged from a thoughtful selection of Renaissance music to Shen Yun's wonderful music. It makes for a peaceful ambience and a refined aesthetic.  Their coffee, tea, and bites to eat may be on the pricier side for some, but I can always rest assured knowing that it is good if not great quality. Honestly, their coffee is the best I have come across over the course of the years. Don't be shy if they make any mistakes or an issue comes up with your order--they will actually take the time to make things right if you speak up and explain what happened. They are a kind bunch!  I'll be back soon to buy a book! The books are so interesting! It seems like a good chance to take a bit of peace to go!

I've been passing by this place for quite a while and I finally decided to try it.  It's a very nice and quiet cafe. I love that.  You will notice many Chinese books on the wall, all the way towards the back. Come to find out this is first a bookstore/meditation place and then a coffee shop.  The coffee shop is owned by a non-profit organization. Their main focus is the book store and mediation sessions they have towards the back of the shop.  If you pass by in the mornings you will see a very nice guy by the name of Tony. He is whom I approached and asked him about the cafe. Take the time to talk to him, very down to earth chill guy.  Now about their coffee! It's great thus far. I've tried their tiramisu cafe latte and their pistachio cafe latte which both have been very nice. I've gone with those two options because for the time being they didn't have caramel which is my go to.  They have a great assortment of pastries. I have tried so far only the maple walnut danish. Very Yammy! Now I do want to try their homemade Tiramisu. Apparently it's prepared by their chef who is a young man from France .  Their cups are really nice, no handles. I actually like them a lot.

If you're down to sip on tasty tea with classical music playing in the background all while feeling like you're sticking it to the Chinese government, this is the right spot. Feels like such a peaceful, meditative getaway right in the heart of midtown yuckiness.  Will try the food next time!

You're in Midtown and want a place to rest your toes. Nothing looks decent that doesn't require a $15 deposit on your liver. Where to go?  Stop by here for a respite from the chaos. Tianti is a peaceful cafe with peaceful pastries and peaceful tea served in a peaceful setting. Yes, you might see some books on Falun Gong, but that's just to get you into the meditative mindset that permeates this quiet cafe. You definitely won't break the bank as you browse the reading ware while sipping your tea and croissant.

Had to come to this part of town (gross) to get my laptop fixed and as I was wandering around trying to find the nearest escape, I saw this spa-like cafe and ducked inside. This place really is so unique. It's not kidding when it says it's a meditative experience--there was even a woman (perhaps associated with the cafe) doing tai chi in the back of the cafe in this little section that looked like it was for meditation.  I spent the next couple of hours doing work here. I'm not even kidding about the ambiance though there was a literal fire (more than 8 ambulances) one block away and still I felt completely at peace.

Really nice, spacious, quiet, clean spot.  Impressive on walking in. It's very calming, or at least it is at 2:30 on a Thursday. Plenty of seating. They have a subdued water feature, and it all feels very open.  The cold brew was excellent, stood up to the cream I put in, and still had a ton of flavor. Price was typical for the area, $5. They had a bunch of cute looking pasties that I didn't try, but would when I come back.  Wifi is free for an hour, which is fine, long enough for my lunch break but probably not great if you're trying to stay and work. The barista was friendly and efficient.  Overall, really great spot and I'm glad I stopped in. I'll be going back!

Amidst the hustle bustle of Times Square and chaos of the active construction site next door, tucked away behind a 7-11 you will find yourself in a haven of peace and deliciousness. Tianti is part bookstore part coffeeshop and it does both incredibly well.  The books seem to be focused on spirituality and meditation and an atmosphere of tranquility ensconces the entire place. There is a fountain in the back room and they occasionally hold meditation events.  The coffee quality and taste is impressive for a book store and I loved the cold brew (on tap!). Full flavor, smooth texture, and clean finish. They hit all my cold brew requirements. The tea comes in a special cup and has an adorable green top on the string. There are pastries and some other food items if you're feeling hungry.  The barista is friendly and helpful. He shared some interesting insights on their different cold brew techniques. Coffee, meditation, and quiet space lovers - Tianti is the place for you.

Great place! I have wanted to visit the place for so long but didn't have a chance to. Last Christmas I travelled to NYC and had a chance to drop by. I'd sit here all day to enjoy the tea and books if I have time to.

This is a quiet place when visiting a quite hectic city. They serve delicious teas and hot drinks. There is a second floor but it was close when I went. The service was also great! Everything about the environment just made the trip there, very peaceful.

That is a damn good latte they make. Almond milk available. Not the best or most reasonably priced one I've had, but very smooth and enjoyable. Very serene atmosphere, with a few tables around and soothing music playing. Good place to meet someone or to get some reading done. If you're into Falun Dafa, check out the mini-library in the back. Service wasn't the friendliest or the quickest, so that put a tiny damper on things.
The rose berry's cake is so good! Also the Latte! Must try! The location is close to Broadway shows. Have a rest here would be a good choice!

Good atmosphere- quiet, has a section with books on meditation, really nice wooden high top table in the back, tea presentation very cute. Tea price ($5.50) is on the high side especially for just a cup. The "kitchen sink" cookie was also good but food/drink in general seemed overpriced. If you want peace and quiet in the middle of midtown, come here.

This is an unusual place but scores high marks for one outstanding reason. Before I get to the reason let me say it has a simple layout, decent coffee, friendly service, nice tables. It has all the trimmings of a good place to grab some coffee and chat. And it's in a location that makes it convenient for any rendezvous you might do near Penn Station. Do you know that area? It's kind of wasteland for quiet places to meet. And because so many people come in and out of the station I'm always getting requests for meet ups in the area.  So what's the outstanding reason? It's quiet! And there's always tables. The bookstore is run by Falun Dafa so I think people might be a little put off, but don't be. It's a very nice spot and everybody is lovely and decent meeting spots are as rare as a white rhino that close to Penn Station.

What a great find I stumbled across on my way to a work meeting in Penn Plaza. A very nice, clean, quiet getaway from the madness of the city. I went with the Cortado as well as the Ham & Cheese croissant and both were excellent choices. Give them a shot, you won't be disappointed.

Was around the corner for an event at WeWork.  Wanted a latte to power me through the afternoon but avoid Starbucks because their lattes are just burnt milk.  Super fast and friendly service. Perfect temperature latte.

This place was such a surprise in the middle of Midtown. I came here on a weekday at 2pm and it was pretty empty. It truly feels like walking into a calm Japanese garden. You can hear water flowing in the background and ugh it's perfect for some afternoon werking. It was esspensiveeee, which was a given, but the matcha latte I got was mhmmm, not good at all. It was super watered down and it made me eek. Not into the drinks at all, but the space is super quiet and peaceful that it just makes you wanna work. There are also a lot of rooms and nooks and crannies to work and have space to yourself. I'm in love!

I needed a quiet place to go to before I take my bus from Port Authority. Unlike the super loud and crowded streets right outside, Tianti Books was VERY quiet and peaceful. I think it has like ancient Chinese meditation ritual books and sessions, but it's also a pretty extensive cafe. Though the drinks are quite expensive (over $5 for an iced latte) I'm used to paying that much for my coffee / anything away from the over-crowded street made me happy.  One thing I will complain about though is how cold the store is. I was wearing my very warm winter parka inside the store yet the tip of my nose and fingers were freezing up. This made me have to go get a warm tea, which I also paid close to $5 for, but the Tea Forte tea bags that they sell were SO cute! With their little green leaf sticking out of the cup, I just had to have it. The cold made my tea get colder quicker, but I still enjoyed it while it was warm. The wifi is also only 30 min free, so if you're trying to find a place to get work done for a long period of time, you may have to pay (I think it was around $2-3 for an hour).  I don't feel too negatively about this place, so I may return if I'm in the area!
My favorite place to chill when in midtown and need a small snack or coffee . Very soothing environment. Perfect for working quietly .

This was a nice soothing place to sit and work. Extremely overpriced forte teas -1 cup is like the price of a box - but worth it for the soothing atmosphere and running fountain.  That is until the racist Australian Barista profiled me. Only mentioning so he knows this is about him. Hey!!!  He over-greeted to start- I walked in to look for my normal seat and an outlet - and he said hi like 8x as if he was scared I was going to start knocking tables over or twerking on them or something. The hi was really a 'why are you here.'  Then I saw the nice section in the back with the fountain was closed off and asked 'is the back seating unavailable?, wondering if it was a permanent change - he said "bathrooms are only for customers."  When I just stared at him - another lady behind the counter said - no that's not what she asked - and to me - 'he was confused'. Oh so now I need translators? Mmmkay.  POC reading you know the deal. Anyone else missing these subtleties - Congratulations you don't get profiled in your cutest fall attire - I wonder why ?!

If you're looking for a peaceful and quiet place to have some tea, coffee and/or a small bite to eat, this is an amazing place. You would never guess it's so close to times square. I was looking for a place to grab some tea with a friend and have a conversation without needing to shout. This was perfect. They also sell pots of tea, have a book store, and play classical music. two thumbs up!

I originally came here because of the photos on yelp but they actually didn't have access to some of the sections posted on there. Although I was disappointed by that, the girl working was super friendly and they have a good variety of tea to choose from, a handful of coffee options, as well as a few pastries to go with the coffee. It was a good stop for a rainy day!

Beautiful space. Not a lot of foot traffic which says something. Clean and quiet. Food portions are small. Had quiche Lorraine. The bacon wasn't fully cooked and portion was tiny for $11. Tea was mild not zesty as described.
beautiful ambiance and warm welcome thankyou for a delicious hemp milk cappuccino & a wonderful place to read!

Really nice space- tall ceilings, lots of seats + tables, neat & clean, calm classical music in the background.  Friendly service.  Lots of outlets + 15 min wifi.  Yummy cappuccino that comes with a free mini biscotti (that was also delicious).  Tianti was just what I needed to take a breather from the New York hustle & bustle.

This place is a hidden gem! It's mostly quiet and less crowded than most cafes in the area. They have nice classical music in the background and a water fountain that is very relaxing. It's the perfect spot for studying or working in a less hectic environment.

If you're looking for a truly peaceful place in the city (especially in winter, when Central Parks gets a bit too unbearable for "peace") try this little bookstore. The main books are related to Falun Dafa, but you can also come and get some work done in their coffee shop area with a view on 30th street. The decor is peaceful and it's very quiet. Try their tea for a change, it's very nice.

Adorable place on 8th ave. Stepping in off the crazy busy street into this relaxing zen getaway was a great surprise. The staff were super friendly and helpful building on the calming atmosphere.  The teas are served British style in all the serving-ware and you also get a nice range of NUMI tea. In the back are a few wooden tables and chairs that are so comfortable to sit and work in, with a fountain!  *Unfortunately their wifi is only available for 30 minutes before you have to pay =.= a shame because it is the perfect set up for sitting and working.

I don't know Tianti Books before it moved to this new location on 8th Ave.  I thought it was a new business, so I went to check out this out today because I'm in the area a lot.  I was kind of excited about the place.  I thought...new small business. Hey, let me go support it.  I get there and everything is super expensive, but I said to myself, let me just try it. I got a medium regular coffee. It was smooth, but I didn't think it was worth the price.  I also got a pastry, which was OK, but it was overpriced as well. The bill came out to be $11.32 for a pastry, a medium house coffee, and 15% tip.  I am not a rich guy, but I sucked it up and ended up getting it because I believe in supporting small businesses.    I asked about Internet access.  The internet is "free" for the first 15mins. After that, you have to pay.  At this point, I wanted to leave, but I tried to justify all the prices because hey, it's Manhattan, and the rent here is skyrocketing.  I was there for about 20 minutes, just me working in the corner.  The place was empty.  Then I started to cough uncontrollably (I was just getting over a cold). I couldn't stop coughing no matter how much I tried to control it. I went to the counter to ask for water. They could clearly see me coughing in front of them. I was about to pop my eyes and lungs out on to the counter. Tap water. That's all I wanted. No, not just wanted. I needed that water. I've already spent $11.32 on a coffee and a pastry. And you'd think they'd give it to me after already spending that much. No.  "Actually, that'll be $.35, sir."    ...  To be fair, they came up to me after I stopped coughing and apologized. As much as I wanted to, I couldn't leave right away because I was in the middle of something on my computer.  I drank whatever coffee was left in my cup to stop the coughing, and finished my work.  They offered some water after the fact, and I refused because I was so angry.  As a former server myself, I would've left that water anyway just in case.  But what happened?  They bussed my table, and...took the water away.  All I know is that I will never come back to this place.  I am usually very happy to support small businesses, and I intend to keep supporting small businesses, even though I don't make that much money myself, but this place is making it very hard for me to keep doing so.
I love everything about this place, except that you have to pay for using the internet after one hour.

Really nice place to do some work. The wifi is good, and even though they purport to limit it to 1 hour you can just log on again (though if the owner sees this review, maybe it won't be the case for anymore, haha..)

This caf̩ could easily be lost in the hustle and bustle of 8th Avenue, but my wife and I decided to give it a try: we're glad we did. The owner, Matthew, was incredibly friendly and immediately welcomed us upon entering. The cold brew is on tap and has a smooth taste from start to finish; the house blend drip is very solid (especially for a drip). The large selection of books in various languages is a unique touch that, as a bilingual person, I find to be amazing. The baked goods looked delectable, but I didn't have the room to try any. There's a nice selection if tea offerings as well as a few smoothies. We will definitely return the next time we're in town.

It's like an oasis in Midtown. Quiet spaces with soft music, great coffee and snack options as well. It's a nice meditative spot, with plenty of literature to peruse on the walls (although it's all related to Falun Gong from what I could see).

The most peaceful little spot in midtown!  Beware, it's easy to lose track of time and a sense of where you really are in here (middle of NYC).  I had 2 hours to kill, and by the time it was up, I still wasn't ready to leave.

Going up the stairs felt a little sketchy like entering a pseudo cult society. It smelt like a mixture of incense and mold. But once you are up there, it's a quiet, comfortable space to read your book, study, or have quiet conversation with your friends, the cafe area has good varieties of tea for very good price, and there are plenty of outlets and has wi-fi, too. I'm excited to find this place.  The downside: +It closes around 7:00 pm which is pretty early. +If you are sensitive to smell of incense like me, it takes a few minutes to get used to it.
Great spot for getting work done. Very friendly staff, and they certainly won't proselytize you or anything.

I just don't know if this place should be called a book store? It is really like one of those Chinatown tea and snack places. There is like one shelf if books. And I even asked about them and got a blank look? Just saying, maybe needs reclassification

This place is like a hidden oasis among the chaos of the City. In my own personal opinion their latte's are seriously the best that I have had in the city. When you walk in it is almost as if it is something from a movie or book like Harry Potter or The Lion, the Which and the Wardrobe, it is as if you suddenly entered a different world or dimension. It is so peaceful and quiet and everyone is very nice. It is the best place I have  found to work or read without loud music blaring or hearing the crazy ones from the street.  My only complaint is that they are slightly more expensive than some places and they are not open very late. But really I don't mind paying a bit more for the awesome setting and environment. Great place to have deep philosophical conversations on life and our universe.  I wish they could open a lot more of stores around New York.  If anyone is reading this, go there, you won't regret the decision.

The place was really peaceful and cozy. The entrance is quite hidden. The cafe has pretty good tea. We had the white rose white tea and the oolong passion fruit tea. The rose one was pretty light and the passion fruit tea was quite sweet and tangy. Overall it was a nice experience and we got to enjoy our tea in the seating area which included chairs, tables, and sofas. There was also a view of the street below. Overall it was a pretty nice, serene experience.

UNBELIEVABLE place. I'm in the process of relocating to NYC for work so once I am here I will be here quite a bit.  They offer a peaceful, quiet atmosphere to study, read, or just straight up chill. They also offer free classes for a meditation technique, which I can;t remember right now. But for how chill vibes are here alone it deserves 5 stars.

Super cute store, but the tea room is closed! Very nice and polite people were there and said they are moving to a new location and will open up the coffee/tea shop when they are settled at the new location.
Came here for the first time. Nice peaceful environment with excellent authentic Italian cappuccino using organic sugar. They also have some green tea ice cream if you're in the mood.

Tianti Books is one of the most serene, powerful, wonderful places I've stepped foot in in a long, long, time.  The owner is inspiring, and it really feels like you've stepped out of NYC and into your self.  Not only is the cafe/meditation space quiet and filled with amazing books, the owner is also incredibly accommodating. He spent hours with me talking about the failures of the communist party and the truth behind Chairman Mao.  There's also power outlets everywhere and it's a solid 2 blocks from Penn Station.  I almost thought about not writing this review because I hope this place never loses it's amazing vibe, but it's just too good to keep to myself.

After a stressful arrival to Penn Station where I realized I left my phone charger behind and was running out of power, I stumbled upon Tianti on yelp. New phone charger in hand, I ascended the stairs to the second floor and was greeted halfway up by a lovely woman who welcomed me to the shop and explained they were in the middle of rearranging some things but that I was welcome to come in.  As soon as I reached the top of the stairs, I felt like I had escaped the overwhelming energy of New York and was immediately transported to a peaceful space. Quiet, meditative music, cool air, and an abundance of outlets (close to seating too!) surrounded me. It's perfect. I don't even notice the employees rearranging things toward the back of the shop.  I'm sipping an iced green tea which is very flavorful and refreshing. What a gem.

Great service. We had a large French press (was about 6 cups) and chocolate muffin (pretty big too). Both were pretty good. This seems like a great place to work as it is very quiet (it's a bookstore) and there's tons of outlets (there's even USB ports).
Excellent Tea, interesting books..Good Prices.  Een hear 2 times..Very nice meditation mats..
great spot, but note as of March 2016 they are no longer serving coffee/tea, as they are moving locations!  call them for more info
Perfect cappuccino, elegantly presented, in a calm, spacious, pretty room.  And they greeted me as if I was a long-lost friend.  Lovely!

Wow what a Gem. We stopped by on our way to Times Sq. and we were pleasantly surprised by the wonderful food and coffee. The food was absolutely delicious and both of my daughters finished their meals with smiles.  Freshly squeezed OJ - House made cream cheese -  My only wish - open one up in Northern VA.

This place is a gem in Hell's Kitchen! The cafe has a really clean and calming atmosphere. I've gone both for leisure and to do work. There has been a table for me each time I've visited. There is also fast and stable wifi, as well as clean restrooms (which is definitely a plus at busy NYC cafes) which are both password protected. There's also a really nice and small outdoor area that's open during the warmer months.  The cafe has a wide range of traditional hot and iced teas, but they also have a nice assortment of Korean teas. When this place first opened, the owner introduced herself to me and created a few mixed teas for me during the initial times I visited. She and all of the other staff are always very friendly and helpful. I am also a huge fan of London Fogs (since I don't drink coffee) and they are always more than happy to make it, despite the fact that it's not on the menu. They also have a nice assortment of pastries and typical cafe, breakfast-type fare.  I am a regular here and would definitely recommend trying this place if you're in the Hell's Kitchen area!

This cute cafe/tea shop is the perfect place to relax or get some work done. The interior is clean and nicely decorated. And even though from the outside it seems small, there is plenty of seating and even an outdoor patio in the back!  I got a piece of banana bread and a green tea which both hit the spot. I love that they serve loose leaf teas which is pretty unique and reminds me of the comforts of home. They will even refill your tea with hotwater for free which works because its loose leaf tea, which can be brewed more than once. The banana bread was also not too sweet and the perfect heaviness to hold you over until your next meal.  Another plus is the amazing customer service. The lady who seems like the owner of the shop is very attentive and clearly explained the menu. There is also free wifi which is a plus for anyone who needs to get work done.  If I lived in the neighborhood this would easily become a go to spot.

Cute cafe with baked goods and sandwiches for reasonable pricing. There is a decent amount of decent on the other side of the cafe and a large outside patio. The bathroom code and WiFi password are provided on the purchased receipt. You will have to go pick up your own drink and food at the counter. I love that everything is served on porcelain plates and glass mug, which you will place onto a tray upon your departure. I believe it is a Korean owned establishment and they do play some Korean music on the background, in case if that bothers you. Also try to bring/pay cash as when I visited that they told me they had issue with their credit card machine and WiFi connection. I was there to do some light reading and I happened to have some cash with me at the time, so it didn't bother me.

This is one of those secret places I want to keep to myself but still have to say good things about.  This is hidden in plain sight in Hell's Kitchen.  Staff is always friendly and the coffee always tastes great.  Seats are also always plentiful. (But maybe not after this rave review gets them packed?? Lol)

I came here without plan, just want to have a nice coffee at the 11pm after returning from Singapore. And this place happen to open till 1am. Lady boss is super nice and friendly. I like the patio. And I highly recommend.

This is near my apartment and always seems very busy. Today, I decided to give it a try. I'm so glad I did. I ordered a blueberry scone which was heated up for me. I was soft and fresh--definitely coming back for that again. I also had a late and the coffee was quite good. I was able to find a seat without much difficulty. For other people looking for a seat, staff would help them find seats!  The ambience is very nice. It seems like the owner works behind the counter as well. She thanks everyone who comes in and out. There is a unique friendliness to this place that seems distinctly un-New York in the best way possible.  This would be a good place for a date, to get some work done, or just to read a book. I'll be back soon.

Great little breakfast gem in Hell's Kitchen! I usually pass by here on my to work in Time Square. The morning I went, was not busy at all, I was able to order and less then 6 minutes I got my BEC on a multigrain bagel and a latte. Both items were great and service was friendly! Definitely recommend checking it out if you have the time or want to try something new!
A very nice, warm, cute, and quiet coffee shop. Good croissant, bagel and latte. If I live near by, I can see myself coming here frequently.

Adorable and excellent.  I rushed through here for a quick bite while traveling through NYC and was pleasantly surprised.  The cafe itself is cute and clean, and way bigger than it looks on the outside.  The staff are amazingly pleasant and helpful - they seem genuinely happy to work here.  Both the baked goods and the bagel sandwiches are delicious, and the bubble tea (though a bit different than what you'd normally get from ViVi or Kung Fu) was delicious.  The prices were pretty reasonable given the location and quality of food.

Extremely cute cafe with plenty of space to sit + work on a laptop for a few (or more) hours!  Atmosphere: It is well decorated and a bit dimly lit, so may be off-putting to some, but is how I like to work. I was there pretty late (around 6pm and stayed til just about 10pm) on a weekday and there was plenty of people both working or having a relatively quiet conversation (aka could be drowned out with headphones). The music in the background was also not very loud.  Food/drink: As for the coffee, it was just okay. I ordered a latte and the foam level was more of a cappuccino. It wasn't bad or outstanding. Pretty average. I also had a croissant and it was also just your standard croissant. I also had one of the macaroons, which were high quality (I think they were priced $2.75)  WiFi: Excellent! Pretty fast, not spotty at all.  Service: The owner is one of the biggest reason why I am giving it 5 stars and why I'll likely be back despite not living even remotely close. She is very sweet, kind and very accommodating! Just outstanding service.

I really like this place. I always get the cold mint tea and am able to get some work done here. One star off for the music playing here. It's always mainstream pop music or something of that ilk. So definitely bring your headphones unless that's what you're into.

Ut47 got this new Sumatran coffee dark roast, I love it as an espresso and the dark roast Ethiopian coffee as an americano. It is so difficult to find good coffee as I drink it black, french way and thanks God for their French macarons,  they are the real deal.

UT47 is such a lovely and welcome addition to Hell's Kitchen. The coffee is absolutely divine! Not to mention the ambiance of the space and friendliness of the staff. I've been living in the neighborhood for about 7 years and we needed a space like this! It's perfect for a meeting with colleagues or a cute coffee date. The owner of the space is an absolute TREASURE, she is so sweet and kind and really cares about her customers.

I am now delighted my first choice was not serving breakfast sandwiches after 11. This was a gem of a find (thanks to Yelp)! Friendly, helpful and welcoming service, gracious, skillful and smiling cook, warm, quiet and cozy atmosphere, yummy iced latte and delicious avocado and egg sandwich. GO THERE!!

Loved the experience I had here! Very cute place, lots of seating and great vibe. I really enjoyed the bubble tea here, it took a little while for them to make it, but it was worth the wait! Will definitely be back!

Stumbled upon this spot in my way to find a cookie joint! OMG ginger honey tea with real ginger slices and the soaked in honey for 24 hours?!? AND a gorgeous outdoor patio in the back?!? I felt like I discovered an Unknown spot in NYC! Great service and super friendly owner/cashier?!? Clean bathroom and separate sitting space

A lovely addition to the Hell's Kitchen coffee/cafe scene!  Coffee: Have tried the lattes, cappuccinos and flat whites and all are A+! With the correct frothiness which is not always easy to find.  Food: - Bacon and egg breakfast sandwiches are made fresh to order and excellent. I usually get it on a whole grain crossaint. They also have regular croissant and various bagels. - Donuts are amazing! Kind of in the middle of regular bread donut and cake donut texture (similar to Doughnut Plant), very soft and moist and yummy flavored glazed. Have tried the banana milk, halva (described as nutty flavor which is accurate) and blueberry lemon. My favorite was probably the banana milk but all are really good! - Apricot pastry also very tasty with plenty of fruit and flaky pastry. - There are many other baked goods like muffins and other pastries I have yet to try!  Space: several tables and seating around the corner from the ordering station. Most people are working/studying here so it's a quiet atmosphere. There's also an outdoor patio which will be nice when it's warm out.  I've never had an issue finding a seat.  Staff: great service! The first time I went they accidentally gave me regular instead of whole grain croissant that I ordered on my breakfast sandwich, but apologized and quickly re-made the correct one.

I have passed by this place multiple times but one night I wanted a cup of coffee and stopped in-i have now been there three times. It is a U shaped space-as you walk in you pass the baked goods and coffee area to order and then, when you make a right, you enter a long seating area just parallel to this. There are a number of table and chairs, a long table at the end, a restroom and a nice outdoor area which will be great when the weather gets nicer. The first time I ordered an apricot Danish [difficult to find] the second outing included coffee [in a cup!] and the cherry almond Danish. This morning I went for the bacon egg and cheese on an everything bagel which was great. I was not disappointed in any of these outings. I would recommend and return. A good place to read and study after eating!
This was my girlfriend and I's favorite in NYC.  We traveled from Iowa. The bagels and tea were amazing!   Definitely recommend it! Everything is very organic and natural!

UT47 cafe has an interesting setup. It's two-sided, partition by a wall connected in the back (horseshoe shape). On the left side where you enter, you'll see a semi-long table with chairs. Then you'll find the coffee bar and pastries all setup on the side. On the right side, you'll find two rows of individual tables where you can grab coffee with a friend or work on your own. Additionally, they managed to create a fairly spacious (at least for Manhattan), patio that provides a nice light atmosphere.  I was coffee'ed out and it was hot outside so I ordered an iced Honey Lemon drink, which could've had a bit more honey in it. My partner ordered an iced matcha latte.
